reviews.review: Fun to be in the chaos . I had the opportunity to walk amongst this fabulous chaos 4 times this trip & it was exciting everytime. I took the typical stand in the middle of everything picture & then run to not get left behind. It was a really fun experience and I suggest everyone does it at least once.

Refer to our reviews on Starbucks Coffee and L'occitane Coffee. You get what you expect but it is hard to get a view as you see it in the movies.
We consider L'occitane Coffee has a better view than starbucks
AMAZING. I have never written anything about a road crossing before, you have to see it to believe it, I cannot do it justice in words
Must in Shibuya. Another Shibuya must, the scramble is kind of hypnotic. Recommend the places to have a coffee to see it from a higher point of view

A must-do in Tokyo. If you're in Tokyo you have to check out the Shibuya crossing! It's right next to the station. Head up to Starbucks for a great view and photo op. Then check out the shops or get some chute sushi!

Really cool on Saturdays :). People are free and love consuming! Shibuya is one of the places to go for that! So if you want to see a tonne of people crossing at the same time, that's the best time to go! Plus seeing from the street doesn't feel as impressive than from above. If you need a coffee cause you had a pretty heavy Saturday night go to Starbucks, that's from where you'll have the best view! If you're fighting against big company and refuse to consume a coffee there, you can also go up (no one really cares!)

One of a kind experience. Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble is the world’s busiest crossing with sixteen intersections. It’s fascinating to see all the pedestrian lights go green and people pouring in from all the directions. The crossing is at the Hachiko exit of Shibuya station, which also has the statue of the famous dog Hachiko (remember the Richard Gere starrer tear jerker Hachi: A Dog’s Tale?).

Not As Big Live. Not as big as it looks on TV or in movies but still worth a visit to watch the masses of people cross the street from different locations. Better during peak times in the morning or evening. Tip: Go to the second floor of Starbucks in the CD shop for a good view and an espresso of course.
so many people!. it was fun to see this huge street cross full of umbrellas. it was a rainy day. took a beautiful video :)

Not quite so amazing in real life. In the movies and photos this crossing looks huge and chaotic, and we visited the scramble because of its reputation In reality the crossing isn't huge. It doesn't seem much larger than any four way crossing you'd find in most other cities.In terms of chaos, we weren't there at the end of the working day and therefore probably didn't get the full effect. We were at the crossing around midday and there were still plenty of people crossing at every change of lights. Nothing I would call a scramble though. We were able to cross without too much difficulty.The classic flashing signs surrounding the crossing are kind of cool. Other than that there are some multi storey shops nearby. They are mostly clothing and I didn't find anything that appealed to me. There is also a multi floored Starbucks with a viewing window overlooking the crossing which would be a good place to people watch. Unfortunately every other tourist has the same idea, and you'll have to put up with their loud talking. Not relaxing viewing that's for sure.There are plenty of chaotic crossings in Tokyo. This one just happens to be the most famous.

Famous Crosswalk. After seeing this crosswalk in so many movies, this was a must do in Tokyo. We went both during the day and night. At night, it definitely made for better photos as all the stores were lit up.
Participate in the crosswalk scramble - it's really not big deal!

Fun for about 5 minutes.... If you're in Tokyo, definitely go see the Shibuya Crossing. However, it's not as large as I thought it was going to be, or as crowded as I thought it was going to be. It is interesting to see/watch and participate, but it only takes less than 10 minutes and you've basically seen it all! Then walk around Shibuya and get something to eat!
Amazing place. Too many people, but it is amazing place for see how working crossing for 1 million people per day :) ... Of course, best view is from Starbucks 2F.
Shibuya crossing. Its a must when you visit Shibuya. All the people combined with huge billboards neon signs and loud music really hits you when you visit this place.
Scramble. Got off the shibuya exit subway, met hachiko statue nearby then crossed the scramble!!! Witnessed it too from the Starbucks 2nd floor.

Not To Be Miosse If You Like Crowds. If you like chaos and madness at peak hour try this around nine AM of for that matters most times of the day. It is the crossing from Shibuya Station to the various shopping and business districts in Shibuya. Watch for the green light and the usual music and go and be aware that people cross this intersection in all directions and no one gets out of your way. To get there catch the Yamanote line (Green stripe either way). if you survive the streets of Shibuya are interesting and full of young people at weekends.

Not as impressive as anime makes it out to be. It's not quite on the grand scale anime would have you believe it is, but it's fun to go there and people-watch. There are cafes on higher floors (including a Starbucks) facing the scramble so you can look down on it from above. It's a fun (cheap) thing to do to kill an hour. Plus, the Hachiko statue is nearby.
A great laugh!. Watch the hubbub of several hundred people cross from 5 directions - photo opportunity from the second floor of Starbucks. Just skip the drink cue and go up the escalator.
A tourist attraction. I've done it three times. I even stopped and analyzed the flows. at the end it is just a crossing but with the flows there is no madness.

Fun but overrated. It's iconic and one of the busiest crossings I've ever seen with semi chaos at times but bearable. Pros: A must see when you're in Shibuya, can't be missed since it's right next to the station. Cons: Crossing can be a little bit chaotic given the amount of people and multiple directions of pedestrian traffic.

Madness that must be witnessed. Crazy....best witnessed at busy times or rush hour. Loved the chancers that sprinted across as the green man started flashing.
Close by, outside of Shibuya station is the statue of Hachiko the dog. If you don't know the story then Google it.....

Join the crowd. A very Tokyo and fascinating experience. So many people yet so orderly and polite. Don't miss it if you are in the Shibuya area.
We went there on a weekday around lunch time, was not as crowded as I expected. Or probably just a false impression as nobody was bumping into each other...
organized chaos. even though it was drizzling and people has umbrellas no one bumped into each other. everyone just walked on the left side. amazing :)

Join in the madness. This is definitely a "been there done that" kind of experience. Experience what is supposed to be the busiest street crossing in the world. If you want to see the crowd and get the full experience, try weekends. There are plenty of photos in the web showing the madness, taken from vantage points. The Starbucks @ Tsutaya is out, I think they don't allow you to photograph from there. I suggest you go to the bridge (明日の神話) linking Mark City to the Department Store above the subway or go to the 18th Floor Hotel Lobby of Shibuya Excel Hotel above Mark City. I don't think they will chase you away from the lobby as it is public access.Shopping around Shibuya closes fairly late but only food places will stay open after 10 pm.
Classic photo. Next to the shibuya station you can take photos from the people crossing the street and near the scramble next to the station you can also find the statue of Hachiko.

Fascinating. We went twice, once around midday and again in the evening. It was hectic, but surprisingly no pushing and shoving at all. After getting some photos at street level, we grabbed some hot chocolates at Starbucks and went upstairs. We had to wait ten minutes or so for a seat at the window, but it was well worth it to watch the craziness below. Not for everyone, and perhaps not something you'd expect to enjoy (it is just people crossing the road!) but it's certainly an interesting sight

Fascinating experience. it is an experience, many people many screens and when the light gives green light to pedestrians, all screens start with music that makes a lot of energy flow and the crossing does not become something overwhelming, but in a fascinating experience

Fun view. I've heard about the scramble crossing for many years and it was fun to finally visit the spot and see what it was all about. My partner and I crossed the road for fun a few times and the decided to find a cafe to watch. Best to go early in the morning as all cafes (especially Starbucks) get really busy. Defiantly recommend checking this out!

Mad scramble. Quite a sight to behold. With the amount of people just rushing around, it's amazing that the people aren't "clogging" up the pedestrian crossing. It's really amazing as I don't believe it will go nearly as smoothly in my home country.

Main attraction. You have to be at shibuya crossing just to witness the madness! Lots of people even on weekdays! Crowded but unique crossing. Take a selfie while crossing but be careful when it turned red!

Don't miss it!. Watch seemingly thousands of polite, obidient Japanese line up by the hundreds and patiently await the "Walk" signal before pouring across the intersection like well-disciplined ants let loose. Unlike the USA, not a single person tried to jump the gun or sneak a quick jaywalk if traffic permits. During our visit, a Friday night, the typical Japanese was about 18. The girls were made up for a Friday nite date and were very attractive. It was a great introduction to Japanese Society. No pickpockets, either. Well worth seeing.
A Must See/Do!. Crossing the worlds busiest pedestrian crosswalk is a must when in this bustling city. Check out the Hachiko Statue right at the crossing.

Such a sight to see!. How do thousands of people cross the road in Shibuya? Carefully and orderly! It is amazing to see how many people cross the road here without police guidance or an accident. It is definitely a sight to see! Tip: Best angle for photos at night is on the same corner as Tokyu Food Show.

Crazy. This scramble is an experience, if you go on Saturday night it is soo crowded but in an interesting way. It does not bother you is like a party going on..anyone going to Tokyo should pass by there..
not that big. I used to think its a big crossing. as i had seen it on tv many times although it wasnt as busy neither as big. probably because it was tuesday morning.

Be part of or just watch the rainbow of entertainment!. The place where people crossing is an attraction! It's a photo must in the world of social media... I think it is best to visit at night when the lights come alive and the street performers come out to play. The area is flooded with weird and wonderful shops/department stores/restaurants and cafes and PEOPLE!!!

Fun short stop. Stopped here a bit after heaviest traffic, and enjoyed people watching. A friend recommended we consider sitting down at Startbucks across the street (2nd floor) and watching rather than participating during the busiest hours. Hope it helps others.

Good place for a time-lapse video. Even if you don’t plan to spend any time in Shibuya, you can just take the subway to Shibuya station and come out from the Hichiko exit. When the lights change, pedestrians walk at the same time on five pedestrian walkways to and from different directions. It’s quite a fun experience. Obviously you have to walk it to be part of the scramble. You get a better view going upstairs to the Starbucks across from the train station. Great place to take a time-lapse video. We were there first at 7:30 in the morning, it was almost complete empty. The shops were all closed too. We went there again around 6:30pm, that’s when you get to see the massive organized chaos.

Chaotic but nice place. This place so full and pack all the time. Its good hangout place if you are visiting with your friends. Best view can be taken from Starbucks which is just at very right place to enjoy the view what you need.

Best to cross the street once, then go upstairs into the train station and takes photos of the chaos from above.. I took about a 40 second video of the crossing and it's crossed many alike every other minute, what a site to see. It reminds me of some of the every which way crossings in Auckland too.

Chaos!. While not the most unique or exciting thing happening in Tokyo at any given time scramble crossings in Japan are always amusing to watch! I would suggest you get a vantage point by a window in a restaurant or bar that over looks the street. Have a couple drinks and watch the world go by.. go for rush hour if you can!
Impressive. If u do paa the shibuya station it does worth to stop and look at the amazing scramble pedestrian crossing
Just wow!. Go see what makes Tokyo one of the largest cities in the world.... just go... why are you even reading this? GO DO IT! its free!

Interesting to see. This is a well known place and in several movies. It is interesting to see in live action, and to actually be a part of it. there are so many ppl but it all goes smoothly with no problems. To get a good view I would suggest going to the first floor in one of the buildings, a place where a lot of ppl go for this is the Starbucks

Overrated and Over crowded. If you don't mind shopping with lots of people then you'll be happy to shop around Shibuya. There are a lot of shops to look into but most can also be seen in your local areas. The crossing is interesting, as it shows how organized Japan really is, but again nothing so extra ordinary for me. Unless you are looking to buy something specific which can only be found in this area, I don't see myself going back here in the near future.

Good Experience. Took the train here especially to walk across Shibuya Crossing with the crowds. The crossing is right outside the station. Starbucks will be busy, but there is a department store across the road that serves pancakes and coffee, and has just as good a view of the crossing if you want to sit and watch a while. Make sure you go and see Hatchiko - the statue is on the way!

When in Tokyo... Shopping hell or heaven. Tokyo was very easy to get lost in but the famous crossing point is worth the effort and the shopping although not a favourite pastime was interesting. You can get anything in Tokyo 24 hours a day. A friend challenged me at 3 in the morning on a Wednesday and asked where and what I would like to eat in 20 mins. Pushing the boat out Beef Fajitas with the works. You guessed less than 30 mins later we were sat in a restaurant eating Mexican food. Not a market for kebabs after a long night out here! One of my favourite cities.

Only if you like crowds. The day we were here it was raining so thousands of people with umbrellas - not fun. But make sure you check out the statue of the loyal dog Hatchiko and the food court in the basement of the department store just down the stairs to the left of the statue - delicious!!!

Cool experience . Nice to go around and experience atmosphere. Bunch of people and stuff happening around. Even if you dont plan visiting, you'll probably have to go across it at some point of your visit
Seeing is Believing!. It's easy to get to via JR Yamanote line and it's worth it just to cross the road amongst thousands of people.

Kind of Underwhelmed. We live in a large city with a lot of busy 5 way corners, and have been to Times Square which is vastly larger and more impressive. So honestly I walked away from this wondering what the big deal was. We were with a guide though, who felt it was a "must see" in Tokyo -- so we went. If find yourself at this corner, take a look, but I wouldn't take an extra subway ride to see this.
Busy busy!. Great experience to see the action and endless streams of people coming on through Shibuya. It is recommended to view from the Starbucks across the street.
Interesting place!. Interesting place to see the new modern Tokyo and all the young people gathering together for shopping and fun! Go to the Starbucks at the second floor to enjoy an excellent view!

Was fun to visit at night.. Go at night, the lights from the buildings surrounding illuminate the masses as they cross in all directions. I suggest going to the second level of the starbucks to get the best view. Easy to get to by train and you can tick it off your list in half hour. Cute and a lot of fun

Huge Pedestrian. This pedestrian scramble is a must visit when you are in Tokyo. Outside at the corner also is the statue of Hachiko. The loyal dog, with a sad story when his master passed away. Going back, the shibuya crossing is like an intersection not for cars but for pedestrians!

The famous crossing !. A fantastic intersection to take pictures with plenty of perspective to explore. It is so crowded, yet everyone seems to be crossing without knocking into anybody. Simply has to be there to experience it as no words can better describe the feeling!
Insane!!! . A must in Tokyo! Can't miss the pedestrian cross. visit at night or pick hours, you will enjoy more. Shame after one hour hanging there could not take the perfect picture.
Just a 2 min picture stop. You go there because Manu visitors speak of it. It's worth a visit and go sit in one of the cafe's surrounding this major intersection for a good view.

Overrated. Heard from many of my friends that the Shibuya Crossing is a must-visit if at Tokyo. Was there, it was just like any other street with a diagonal walkway (there's one at Asakusa as well). Nevertheless, Shibuya is a great place for shopping, especially for females.

Crazy Buzy Crossing!. Its so fun to look at soooo much people crossing the intersection everytime its a go! This place has a lot of shopping and restaurants. Don't forget to have the mandatory shot the the crossing! Shibuya is fun - go!

A very busy spot in the middle of Tokyo. This pedestrians street is a never sleep spot. It is very busy all day. We can reach this place by subway to Shibuya Station exit Hachiko. On the left side of the exit gate we can meet the famous Hachiko statue, and also Shibuya crossing. You better take a picture or video on this crossing, very interesting.
Crazy crossing. It's what everyone has said to describe it. A wildly busy street criss-cross street that's like Times Square. Fun.

Just go there and take a picture. This is one of these places where there's nothing to see just a good location if you want to take pictures. Address commend you go in the evening because it looks even better

An experience to do at least once. This place is designed to be an assault on the senses. That sounds worse than it is though. It is fun to experience and something you should experience if you're in the area. Multiple giant screens running commercials with loudspeakers providing sound, not always the same sound either. This all happens while you're walking around an area that is swarming with more people than most people are usually around. It might seem uncomfortable in other cities but Tokyo is friendly, polite, and clean in a way that other cities this size are not; so it is more comfortable of an experience than you might think.

Very busy crossing and a lot of malls and shops. It's fun to see and be a part of the people crossing the very busy intersection.And the place has plenty things to see. Restaurants, shops and malls.Close to omotesando ( 15 minutes walk if you're not distracted by farmers market)

See people look like ants!. We just got back from the Shibuya crossing and it was so crazy! I could not believe how many people were crossing at the same time! If you go to the top floor of the train station and go to the window you can get a great photo of all the madness. We also saw the Hachiko statue. That is one loyal dog! I was disappointed to see a smoking area put right next to the statue though and right where everyone has to walk through. Yuck!

Like in the Movies. Visited the infamous Shibuya crossing in September 2016. Although it was the 'off-season', there were still hundreds of people jammed packed at the crossing. Felt like I was in a scene from a movie. Had an awesome time.

Lots of stores, restaurants and alleyways to explore. You can spend the whole day exploring this area. The crossing is unique but the alleys are where you will find all the interesting places to investigate.

So many people . We caught the train to Shibuya station and stood in the station for a while, just watching the people crossing from different directions simultaneously. Everyone recommends watching from Starbucks, but we came across these great viewing windows at the station. We crossed the crossing too and I was surprised at how orderly everyone was.
The tokyo drift traffic light!. The experience is awesome! Its a norm for people to take photos while crossing the road. It is really a busy street.

sea of people. The way Japanese are organised people, you can see that at Shibuya crossing, the minute the lights turn red for vehicles, there is wave after wave of people crossing the road from every direction. Amazing to see without any chaos......

Order amongst chaos . So many people and yet it seemed so orderly! Worth a quick wander around just to see. It's like Times Square in New York but you have some space with minimal pushing and shoving. This is the place where I really felt like Tokyo is the biggest city in the world. It just felt huge - the buildings were huge and so many people.

Too crowded. Well, I understand that crowded people is one of the centre attraction for this district area. I just don't feel comfortable with too many people for everything.Even the green bus (whatever) tourism centre worker is a bit frustrated with one or two of my simple question.I don't like it.
Take part in this !!. Where do all the people come from? In rush hour 3000 people rush acros the crossings. Join in and then go to Starbucks coffee bar and view from above this amazing sight.

It's an intersection. This is almost one of those places that is a stop along your way to somewhere else, not really a final destination.You can get out at the train station, walk through the intersection a couple of times and then be on your way. Interesting for sure, but you do not need to spend a lot of time here.

Worth seeing . It is after all only an intersection but the sheer amount of people crossing, coupled with all of the TV's and neon signs make it quite the sight. Go up to Starbucks for an elevated view of the action

Makes you dizzy!. As well as actually experiencing the crossing yourself, you can get a good view of all the activity from above in Shibuya Station. The model for London's more modest Oxford Circus crossing, this original Tokyo crossing at Shibuya is major! My Japanese friends thought I was crazy, but this was at the top of my "to do" list in Tokyo and I wouldn't have missed it for the world.After you've crossed, don't miss the Dogenzaka statue - the dog who waited for his master to come home (which now has a very appealing resident cat wearing a US Navy tag on its collar!) and the old tram car housing the tourist information centre.
How do they do it?. Tried crossing over twice. It's amazing how many people cross this place at any one time. Neon lights everywhere. Lots of shops around. The Starbucks probably has the best view.

This is Tokyo. This crossway is probably what I will associate Tokyo with in the future. Stand at the metro/jr station and you have a perfect view even on a rainy day. Don't forget to check out Hachiko!
Just an average crossing mid-day. Not too crowded. Just another street crossing. Easy to find next to the shimbuya station. I could see on weekends or rush hour how this place might be crazy busy.
Mayhem. As expected this part of the city is crazy busy with tourists but no trip to Tokyo would be complete without it. It's just a short walk from the closest metro station.

I would say a must see in Tokyo!. I have been as recommended at Starbucks in the first floor which was a good spot also for pictures. After sunset the place is even more impressive with all the neon lighting. Afterwards I explored the area around for some food and drinks, which was very nice.

Must-Do While In Tokyo. You really can't say you've been to Tokyo if you haven't experienced the craziness at this intersection! Some times are busier than others, but it's a great experience either way. You don't even have to cross to get the whole vibe. You could easily take the train into Shibuya Station, head outside for a little bit to watch the action and go along your merry way. No need to spend a lot of time here if you don't like big crowds.
The crowd. Exactly what you expect and even more while experienced in person. Go up to the first floor of tstutaya to see it from a privileged perspective

Must see and be part of it!. The most famous crossing in he world.Astonishing number of lights, ads, people, music...but above all the atmosphere-only by visiting this place you realise that you're in the future!
So many people!. Trying to get a good view can be tough. Getting swarmed in the press of bodies can be overwhelming. But, if you're in Shibuya, I definitely recommend this!
people, people and more people!. one of the busiest and crowded streets of Japan, but waling through Shibuya Crossing is definitely a must for travelers... you should not forget Hachiko-san too! ^^

Quick, Scramble!. If you are a tourist in Tokyo and are going to Shibuya, you'll likely see (and experience) the pedestrian scramble. It's much smaller than one would imagine based on how it is presented in movies and photos, but it is just as busy. It's fun the first couple times you see it, and taking a quick selfie while crossing the road is something every tourist does.
Not worth it.. It is OK to stop in and see it only if you are in the area. Was there at rush hour and 50% of the crossing people were tourist videotaping themselves.
This is one memory that will always remind you of Tokyo. Joining the hoardes of people crossing this road is just quality ... you just KNOW you are in Japan ..
Five roads meet. Yea, I think its five road melting point, all the pedestrian crossing. I've seen lots of pedestrian crossing at the same time but here is huge.
Must see. This place is a must see. We watched the crossing whilst having coffee at Starbucks. Try not to stop to take whilst crossing especially during rush hours as not to inconvenience others.

A sea of intersecting people. I can honestly say that I have never seen so many people moving in unison crossing a street. It's kind of fun and other worldly to watch. If you've ever seen a National Geographic episode where they film a traveling school of fish, this is pretty much the same thing. It with humans. It's the hive mentality at work. It's a beautiful thing to behold!!! Do yourself a favor: stand on the island for one light cycle and film this event!!! You'll not regret it!!!

Amazing for people watching. Really crazy to see it in real life. If you can grad a Starbucks and find a way to their second floor. The views over the crossing are amazing from above. You can laugh at the idiots trying to take selfies on the crossing when the traffic starts coming back.

It is overrated but yes, you should go. The small Hachiko statue must take photograph with it.The crossing is always a quite challenging place to get a good picture which can capture the moment.You can go there day or night, but make sure it is the peak time for people go out, not early morning though

People watching. I'd seen it on TV but I could have never imagined to see the number of people crossing streets all at one time. Starbucks is a great place to watch all of the action. It's like Times Square on acid.

An interesting view to watch. An interesting view to watch, and its free. Around hundreds or thousands people crossing The street at The same time. Really fun to watch, especially from higher building.

For good views head to Starbucks!. Whilst it is rather underwhelming in the day, this place seems to come alive at night and looks so much more appealing at night when the streets are lit up. Although it is not the most exciting thing to have seen whilst in Japan, it is definitely worth going to see. For those that want to experience Shibuya Pedestrian scramble without being caught in the action, head to Starbucks as it provides good aerial views that you can look at from the comfort of a seat with a coffee in hand!

Where humanity meets. If you've to the crowded streets of Nee York, this crossing will amaze you further. How can so many people go about their business, in organized, quiet fashion. You'll feel you're at th crosswalk of the world.

A must!. Your trip to tokyo will not complete without taking picture in this pedestrian crossing. Taking picture in the middle of the crossing while people walk cross the road is just amazing. To get a great picture, cross the road toward shibuya 102 building and walk back toward the station. Ita also great at night when most of the local people back from their office. Crowded.

Iconic Scramble Crossing. if your in Tokyo, its definitely a right of passage to do three things in Shibuya
1. Take a picture with the statue of Hachiko
2. walk across scramble crossing
3. grab a coffee at the Starbucks over looking scramble crossing and people watch.

A crazy assault on your senses. A must do experience when visiting Tokyo. Just stand for 10mins & people watch. Then explore each corner & the surrounding area. There is a wonderful memorial statue of a dog under the trees of one corner & the story attached is moving...a beautiful story of loyality & friendship set on this crazy crossing. The lights & loudness of Shibuya crossing are an experience!

Yawn - not sure what the fuss is all about. Sure - there are a lot of people, but I've seen crazier, more intense crossings in Hong Kong, NYC and even Auckland. Not worth a visit just to see the crossing, but you'll probably pass through Shibuya anyway if in Tokyo - so the best bet is to have a coffee at the Starbucks on the second floor of the building opposite the Tokyu Department Store and take in the moving masses.

Must walk it. Not sure what to expect as my niece said to experience it - so we did - yes it is very busy people coming in all directions however no one bumping into each other - they just walk around you

What Can You Say, But "WOW!" :-). This is one of those once-in-a-lifetime experiences that you will never, ever forget. Yes, it's personally living the scene that you've seen in a number of films, but it's more than that if you stand and watch for a while; it's an intimate peek into the Japanese people and their culture.There are lots of amazing stores, restaurants, and shops around the Shibuya Station area that you can spend hours exploring, if you like, and there are some great deals on technology in some stores in this area.See it in the daytime, yes, but see it at night if you possibly can.Lifetime memories!

Manage your expectations. After seeing the actual pedestrian scramble, one wonders why it seems much more interesting on TV than in real life. The crossings get real busy when all the lights are green for pedestrians. Of course you should not leave the spot without actually doing it a few times. Best view is from the Starbucks accross the street. If you have a party with you send the them upstairs first to pick up a nice spot by the window and you can wait in the line downstairs for ordering the drinks. The crowd on the street (which is the whole point) is proportionate to the crowd in Starbucks which means you cannot try when it is off hours and the streets are less crowded!
It's a pedestrian crossing!. Maybe just a pedestrian crossing, but the world's busiest? Makes for a few good photos and the area it's in has plenty of neon/LEDs.

Not so Squeezy :0). If in Tokyo its a must do. Not as daunting as it first looks. Visited in the daytime but I imagine night time would be twice as goodThe sounds , the big screens and the sea of people all heading out to enjoy Shibuya.We shopped , had lunch and soaked up the atmosphere , do it , you will love it !!!

Busy, busy, busy.... We traveled to Shibuya so we could see this famous crossing. Have never been to Times Square in NYC, but I imagine it would be similar to this. People everywhere, and once the lights changed they were moving everywhere, too. Enjoyable but I wouldn't necessarily make a special trip just to see it.

What a rush. Your pulse races. The lights turn green. And then you are carried away in the crush of pedestrians crossing the busiest intersection in the world. Millions do this every day. It is just so much fun. Tips: a lot of people pay to go to Starbucks so they can watch the crush from above. But a free view is from Shibuya station on the walkway. Also if travelling with others make a meeting point in case you get separated, especially important with kids. Say the dog statue, or under a particular neon billboard. Also, selfie sticks not a great idea. Just too crowded.

Must see whilst in Tokyo. We had this down on the list to see whilst in Tokyo as it is so well known. It was great to be a part of it trying to cross the Street all at the same time, as well as taking it in and observing everyone cross the road and taking some photos.

Best time to visit is evening/night. It's famous for a reason but nowadays there are lots of equally busy crossings but this one is worth seeing. Best seen from upstairs in Starbucks directly across the road from the crossing. Hold on to small kids tightly!! If there's a group of you as friends pick a point across the road where you'll meet because it can be crazy! Lots of interesting characters hang around outside the station by the frosting worth checking out

Fun to witness!. We arrived in the late afternoon and participated in the scramble from various corners before finding a window seat at L'Occitane Cafe to observe from on high. (A better bird's eye view would be from the Starbucks corner as the flood of people is mainly from the station.) Fun to watch for a while, particularly over time and as the lights of the advertisements began to dominate.
A Must See. Words can not describe the scene specially for the first time you see it. Many people crossing to opposite sides at the same time without hurting each other.

Just a busy intersection. This place is just a busy intersection where there are so many zebra cross around.It is true though that the number of people crossing around is huge, but to me it is quite normal.One thing that is strange for me here is the fact we have zebra cross exist diagonally in the road.
Bright lights big city. A bit overwhelming, but worth it. This place is iconic! Lots of people watching and window shopping to do.

see to believe. It is one of the best spots in tokyo,so unique. though it is simple (crossing with lots of people) this spot is one that you wont forgot. hundreds of persons walking, tourists locals, yound and old, los of colors lots of lights. amazing!!!advice- best spo to catch the crossing is the elevator of excel hotel (made of glass) and also free and you dont have to buy anything.
Must to see!. This place it's always amazing, but better to see it when it's dark... anyhow don't miss it if have even one day stay in Tokyo!
famous Shibuya crossing. besides experiencing the scramble, you can also enjoy shopping at the plenty shops nearby. nearby station is shibuya.

Shibuya crossing . If your in the area shibuya crossing is worth visiting.I prefer at night as get a better atmosphere with the bright lights of tokyo reminds me of times square.If you get a chance visit 2nd level of starbucks and sit opposite the window watch passers by.Famous also as shibuya crossing is in the fast and the furious film tokyo drift.
Wow!. first place to visit to see the eclectic, the eccentric and everything else Japanese. Don't forget to say hello to Hachiko!
Busy. A good experience of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. You wonder how people never bump into each other...
Just enjoy the shibiya rush. It smaller than I thought. Try not to overthink and enjoy the city japanese culture crossing from hachiko square.
An interesting experience. Just a simple pedestrian full of people crossing paths! That's it. But its the experience that makes the difference. Besides, its known worldwide -- why not experience it?

crazy busy place !. lots of people would not be used with such large crowds, the place is indeed a touristic attraction. People dress funny and attempt funny things during the pedestrian crossing the intersection - one was walking on his hands and having pictures taken by friends. Depending on your nature, crowds could create an anxious feel but I would not associate Tokyo with "quiet and tranquil"... more with "busy, vibrant, alert, sleepless city".

Cray cray. Soooo many people!! I could never get use to the amount people crossing at once. Like other tourists, I was crossing it at snail speed trying to take picture of the madness. Everyone walks super fast with a mission in mind. My advise, if you're crossing at snail speed watch out for the olympian like speed walkers. They will trample you without any thoughts. Good luck and be safe!

Insane Pedestrian Crossing!. Sitting in the Starbucks watching the thousands of people crossing people is a must do for anyone visiting Japan! For the price of a coffee this is an unforgettable experience.

One of my fave spots. I love this area. I LOVE this intersection. It is beyond fascinating to experience in person. Walk through it but also try to get a view from higher up....have coffee at Starbucks or the L'Occitance Cafe (both are always busy)

Shibuya- haichiko exit. It's a great place to visit. I guess you have to get there in the right time to experience those "masses" of people crossing the street. The first time we got there I was disappointed with the amount of people. It wasn't that many. I guess weekdays after 5pm gets really busy over there. And weekends. Second time we went there it was a Sunday afternoon and at one point the place looked like a massive ants place! You will have a chance of getting some good photos/videos from the Starbucks on one side or the bridge (behind glass window) that seems to be leading from the station.

Grab a coffee and watch the world go by. If.... You can find a seat!Watching people walk across a road isn't exactly my idea of a great time. However I actually thought it was kinda cool to sit with a coffee and watch hectic Japanese life unfold below me as I sat in the air conditioned comfort of Starbucks!It's a road.... People cross it.... Still cool!

coolest pedestrian lane in the world. i never thought that watching people crossing pedestrian lanes is a fun to watch! Shibuya is known the Pedestrian Scramble and the legendary dog Hatchiko. If you want a better view or good photo to capture, head straight to Starbucks just acrossed Hatchiko subway exit. But better be early because this place can be a bit crowded because of it's popularity among tourists.

Overwhelming . This place is exactly what you would see on TV. Massive amount of people crossing every directions, absolute chaos. I'm not a crowd person so I watched the craziness from one of the windows at the train station. There are lots of shopping & restaurants around but I didn't bother to explore too far because it was way too crowded for my comfort. Worth a visit to experience the madness if you have some time to kill. If not, I don't think you are missing too much.

Shopping People Busy . It was awesome Proving you love business, crowds, shops and don't feel the need to follow a map then this hub is for you. I loved this district. Loads of different types of shops, cafes, lights and excitement. Still see Japanese culture through this city with the teenage pop culture shops, Japanese food and gadgets of all types. What stood out to me is that the Japanese were still so polite and considerate amongst the chaos. LOVED THOS PLACE

Not to be missed!!!. Amazing experience! You can sit at the Starbucks on the top floor and enjoy the many changing views of this street! There are many shops and restaurants in small streets all around as well which make the Japanese Experience very rich!

Nice experience. Shibuya is known because of the pedestrian scramble and also because of Hachiko (try to read the story about this dog, it's amazing. This was the reason why I wanted to visit the statue).There are some volunteers working during the weekend in Shibuya they have a red shirt informing you can ask for help to them. They are really kind and they can also go with you if you need some help to visit a store or a market around Shibuya station. The good thing is that they are there to have this contact with foreigners so they are not asking for money just to have the experience and to talk with you in English. This was the first time I could see such kind of volunteer work, it's really surprising.

As much fun as it looks!. Try and hit this up first. If you leave it too long it doesn't seem that crazy... I mean, the entire town is busy! Get someone else to film you, there is NOTHING more annoying than a tourist trying to selfie film whilst crossing.
Sight to behold! . Visit in the evening for nice view and Shibuya scramble. View from Starbucks 2nd floor is the great.

Best experience ever!. just follow the flow and you will enjoy on how every intersections unite in one huge pedestrian crossings!Oh if you walk just a little bit after the crossings, you can find the Hachiko statue somewhere there. ;)

Good fun . 6 intersections crowd standing at red at the Shibuya crossing with cars whizzing past. The second the pedestrian light turns green, cars stop and then hundreds of people on all 6intersections cross the Shibuya crossing at the same time in perfect synchronization in seconds and then the road clears and the pedestrian light turns red. It's like a robot city and its quite amazing!!!
Must See. Great photo op, and also just has to be done if you are in the area. Do it at peak time to get the full effect.

Definite Scramble. Have heard of this crossing for so long and the place did not dissapoint. Fascinating to see people stopping mid-crossing to take selfies and videos. Great place to people watch as well, from the side walk of course.
must see. When in Tokyo this place is just a must see and to really feel one with the city. Crazy and fun to watch
Busy intersections! . It was nice to see so many young peoples crossing the street in a busy intersections, a sign of life!

Not that busy?!. I was really surprised at how un-busy it was when I visited, which was around 9am, which I would have expected to be within peak hours. I actually had to check I was in the right place! There's lots of fun to be had in Shibuya, but this was a bit underwhelming for me.

Needs to be seen!. This is quite a sight, but anyone who has suffered Oxford St on a busy day will find it tame, even though it's much, much bigger. The whole area is buzzing and full of shops, restaurants and bars. Go off into the back alleys for more authentic Japanese stuff. Well worth an afternoon.

Nite at Shibuya Pedestrian. A lot of people and most tourist visited to Hachiko Statue...take a picture and chit chat at there enjoy the live music. Crowded places but nice view. Taking a picture in the crossimg street is a must 😄😎

A must see when in Tokyo. Yes, as others have said, it is just a crossing, but an iconic one and you have to not only see it , but do it too and take the appropriate photos ! It's been in so many movies and documentaries that you just have to be able to say "been there, done that". There are also many, many shops , some of which you might not have seen before [ I'm thinking of a Scandinavian t-shirt shop which was new to me] which are worth a look. From Shibuya , it's only a short walk to the huge park, where you can take a breath.

The bright lights and chaos of Tokyo . This is a must when in Tokyo. To witness's hundreds of people crossing the road at once. Surrounded by neon-lit skyscrapers and loud music playing. Shibuya is a feast for the senses and is unlike anywhere I have been before. Amazing experience.

Tokyo Drift memory. Best to view from nearby Starbuck and feel the atmosphere by joining the crowd. there is the time when crowds get bumper to bumper. Hachiko monument right on the other side of the road.
Shibuya Scramble.. Wasn't as busy as I expected it to be...must have just been the time of day and only sorry I couldn't go back another time to see it in full swing.

Most interesting intersection. The title doesn't say much, how can an intersection be that interesting. But it is. Especial good for people watchers. But I wouldn't say come for the intersection itself. Come because Shibuya has lots to offer and then you must check out the intersection.

Mad but a must do!. Totally mad but a must even if it is just for the people watching. I braved the thongs of people and made it across the street in an organised chaos kind of way! There is a great food market just inside the station so grab some lunch and watch the crowds cross the road!

The most famous road crossing!. Although it seems a little odd to visit a road crossing it is certainly an experience! You can get a good view from the JR station next to the crossing, or by going in the Starbucks, but really just walking across the road a few times yourself is why you should go! There are some interesting shops around the area too, and of course the Hachiko dog statue right next to it, so you can fill the time around your visit so that you don't feel so silly for just going somewhere to cross a road!

Classical ! But once again a must see !. Always impressive how so many poeple can cross together in what seems to be a ballet. A sample of Japaneese organization and discipline. No japaneese will try to cross on red light... not always the case for gaijin!
interesting. just get lost in the crowd and enjoy the scramble.Lose yourself and love it. Just don't forget your way later because you might not be able to get back to where you came from hahaha

The famous crossings. There's nothing else to see apart from people crossing the junctions. World famous for what it is. Hang around at the 2nd level of starbucks and spend a few minutes doing nothing but people watching.

Wow. When planning our trip to Japan this was one place that popped into my head straight away. As far as crossings go I loved it. I passed through here twice. It was definitely better around the 19.00 period as it was busier and more impressive. You get a fantastic view for videos and photos from the second floor seating area of Starbucks if you want a shot from that angle but this can be busy.
Funny. Probably one of the funniest things to experience in tokyo.. we watch it 2 times before participate. Try to stop for a few seconds right in de middle for a photo.. it's fun.
organized chaos. one of the most famous pedestrian crossings in the world is an organized chaos and it is brilliant! What an experience!

Ridiculous fun. This may be the only place I've ever been when I'm squeezed by crowds and don't mind them. Japanese crowds seem to be non threatening. I cross and recross, just for fun. There are usually plenty of crazy colourful outfits and hair styles to admire amongst the 'ordinary' people going about their business. Also fun to find a vantage point well above the crowds in a neighbouring building, and just wait for the lights to change and the people to cross. Worth coming at sunset and watching till it's dark and the area is illuminated.

Awesome sighting for organized chaos. What a great view. People from all directions walking calmly towards the other way in an organized yet chaotic fashion. The lights help make it look more funky. A must when in Tokyo

One of the attractive locations in Tokyo. It’s recommended that you visit this busy cross load for your Tokyo sightseeing.
This location will attract tourists’ attention in gathering with a lot of pedestrians, who are crossing this intersection regularly.
Anyway, enjoy your trip.
Arac
Simply amazing . Simply amazing. I could spend hours and hours watching people crossing the square. Have a coffee at star bugs: the view is amazing.

Sooo many people going in so many different directions!. This has to be seen to be believed. The amount of people is quite overwhelming. Saw some tourists taking pictures from higher vantage points which is a great idea. I took video from the middle - pure chaos :)

Too many people. This is a nice place to take pictures for foreign tourists.
I recommend taking photos from the Starbucks of near the building.
It was hard to walk smoothly because of too many people.
I saw a lot of foreign tourists who take photos here.

Not as crowded as expected. Maybe I was here at the wrong time (I went both late at night around 11:30 and in morning around 10:30), but I was shocked by how un-crowded it was. It seemed like any other road crossing. I guess I should have seen it during rush hour. Or it could be that I am desensitized to crowds after spending several months in Hong Kong.Nearby restaurants and shopping are more interesting to explore/photograph.

It's a road crossing at the end of the day!. This is touted as one of those 'must do' experiences when in Tokyo as it is said to be one of the biggest, and busiest road crossings in the world. It is Arguably worth visiting to say you have been there and the huge screens and stores are quintessentially Tokyo but the area is to all intents a very busy shopping area and not particularly exciting

Japan in 7 days. Day 6 Part 23. The last stop of our travel in Japan was a short stop to see the Shibuya crossing. The area outside the station was packed with young people. It was a Saturday night and something was brewing in the area.The green traffic light for walking lasts for 30 seconds and the mad scramble to cross the 4-way street is a sight to see. Hachiko’s statue stands on a quiet corner. Many tourists posing beside it even at this time of the day 9pm.
Incredible. Go out form exit 8 if you want to see the Hachiko statue and also the cross. You will not believe the crowd.

Must see!!!. We took the train there just to do the crossing a couple of times. It was so much fun. Quite interesting to see the system. My husband thought it was so efficient. Lol! It's a nice feeling to be a part of such a crowded movement!
its Crazy Amazing!. We sat in Starbucks across it, and honestly it's quite crazy where people are coming from, definitely organized chaos...I can sit there and just people/traffic watch...
Biggest Crossing . Iconic image of Tokyo. The crossing is just outside of Shibuya Train Station. Access to many shops and restaurants

When in Tokyo - it's a must!. Shibuya scramble is a must do when you're in Tokyo - as someone from a small village in Dublin I had never seen such a vast volume of people moving in so many different directions all at once - it's probably the ultimate tourist experience when you're in Tokyo. We had great fun taking photos and timelaspes here too - honestly it never gets old! If you;d like to get a view from above go to Starbucks - make sure you go in the smaller door to the left, go through the door and up the escalator - it's quieter than going in the main door. You don't even have to order anything from Starbucks - you just have to be patient to get a good spot at the window looking down at the crossing.

Its just a pedestrian crossing.... Admittedly it is very unique to have about 7 pedestrian crossings intersecting with lots of people crossing every minute or so but for people going there just to see it. Keep in mind, its a pedestrian and dont overhype your expectations.

Go with the flow. It's one of those places you just have to go to while in Tokyo, I normally avoid crowds, but there's no avoiding them here! Go with the flow and cross the crossing, you're swept along with the tide of people, and then watch from above from the window of Starbucks.

Hilarious experience. We had heard of the Shibuya crossing chaos before our visit to Japan and decided to admit to our itinerary. We went to first floor of the Starbucks cafe as most people recommend and found it packed. However there is a fairly quick turnaround if watchers and we soon found a spot by the window. The experience can only be described as hilarious. Although we were there in the late morning, a quiet time, as soon as the lights went to red the pedestrians from 5-6 crossing charge across the roads in mass chaotic hoards.A real sight to see if in Tokyo.

Best moments & videos . In Shibuya scramble, you will be amazed by the huge number of people passing. It is so much fun taking videos when you are walking there among pedestrians. There are many cafes with scramble view, like Laccotine and starbucks ..etc. One interesting thing that you might notice there: many people utilies their time waiting for the green sign by catching pokémons!! Cool

What a Busy Intersection. I had heard about the pedestrian scramble at Shibuya. But seeing is believing. Yes I now agree that this must be the busiest single pedestrian crossing in the world, as thousands of people can cross in every direction at the same time on one green light. I was there on a drizzly afternoon, so the crowd was not as large as I had expected, but it was still amazing.

Impressive experience. I wasn't prepared to be so overwhelmed when I did the crossing, I had seen it from above earlier that day and didn't think much of it. By chance I landed there after dark and the wall of people awaiting on the other side to hit the wall of people on my side of the street was really something. So I crossed over, twice (it was just too much fun). Would recommend you to do this, but make sure to do this in the evening when people are out and about (I did this on a Friday eve)!

Trip to the crosswalk great times time recommend highly.). Great times highly recommend !!! Gotta go to Starbucks and see the crowd from up high. Pretty amazing that so many people cross there as much as they do.

Yes, a must do. You will find lots of people most everywhere in Tokyo but this is a fun part of town to visit plus they have many volunteers eager to help you navigate the city and they speak English. Most everywhere else we went almost no one spoke English, Spanish, or French. I wonder how they will manage visitors during the Olympics... Nice options for shops and a wide range of restaurants in the area. We tried a few holes in the walls that were pretty good.

People watching at it's best. Crossing the scramble you'll see a range of Tokyo fashions and stereotypes from harajuku girls to sallary men and fashionistas.Go later in the day for a better experience

Poetry in motion. This is something you must witness and experience as its a feast for the eyes and senses. Remarkably everyone seems to know where they are going and its like poetry in motion! This is the Tokyo i've dreamed about.
Choose the right time. The most famous crossing in the world. Come here at dusk to see the colors of the giants screens in the night and the waves of people ready to cross.
Congestioned. Visited Shibuya's crossing on a rainy day, so didn't have the chance to get a full congestioned crossing, but got an idea of it.
A sight to see. We were there on a Sunday, can only imagine how crazy it would be on a weekday. Worth checking out, organized chaos.

A must do. An interesting sight to watch and partake in. A must do when your in the Shibuya area. There are a lot of places to shop and eat in the area. Best time to view is in the evening when the sun is setting, the lights are turning on, and the area is busier. The busier the better.There are several vantage points to watch the crossing from the surrounding buildings. The Starbuck's seating area is an easy sight to access and is literally overlooking the intersection. Staff is friendly there and they know people are there to observe the crossing.

So crazy! . It was amazing to see that many people in one crossing! For me, I didn't have any trouble getting through the crossing, but I did see some foreigners get confused and stop in the middle of it. As cool as pictures are in such a busy spot, keep the culture in mind people! If it was in your home country it would annoy you too if random foreigners were standing in your way! Please be mindful of the culture!
Interesting to see. Super busy crossing in all direction, quite cool to see from the Starbucks on the 2nd floor. Good for a timelapse

Fun crossing. Definitely worth crossing the Shibuya crossing at least once, maybe twice. It is busiest after 11am. The Starbucks overlooking the crossing seems like a good idea but its windows are very dirty, the aircon doesn't work adequately and it can be exceedingly difficult to get a seat with a view anyway.It is fun to cross the crossing diagonally and if you want to be a touristy tourist like me you can take a video while you cross. It's kind of fun.

CRAZY BUSY! We watched for hours!. We crossed the pedestrian scramble a few different times throughout the evening we were in Shibuya. If you want a great view visit the Starbucks or L'occitane Cafe nearby. It's a really cool area and I'm glad we spend the evening in Shibuya!

let's cross all together!. It's incredible the quantity of people who cross at Shibuya. At first, wonder how a street crossing could be interesting to visit, but hey! It's Tokyo, and that crossing represents the city itself: hundreds of people, in a hurry, silent and ordinate. Don't miss this experience at 18:00 from Starbucks cafè and get involved in this amazing city ! <3 Tokyo
Busy!. Super busy. Not as crazy as I had expected, but still worth checking out whilst in Japan. Would still recommend.
Unreal. Just a crazy crossing. A must-see. The amount of people is just wacked. Grab a coffee at Starbucks, try to get a seat from the window and just watch.

Fun to watch. Although I wouldn't recommend going here if it is out of your way, it is a fun activity if you happen to be in the vicinity. It's nice to cross along with the huge crowds and not bump into anyone amidst all the hustle bustle. There is a Starbucks near the crossing which offers great views from its 1st floor location just above the crossing.

Great Tokyo Experience. The Shibuya Crossing is something that you should not miss if you come to Tokyo. It is a gigantic intersection in the Shibuya district of the city. It is organized chaos at Tokyo's busiest part of the city. It is not very hard to get to because it is right by the subway station in Shibuya. The place is known by everyone is called "The Scramble". You can just walk across the street with thousands of people and with giant video screens, it is a Tokyo experience.
You must experience this. You can't believe how many people and how many crossings there are, but it all works perfectly, as you would expect in Japan.
Wild As!. Just go. Walk. Cross. Cross again. Then go wherever you are going. Organised Chaos at its best. Find yourself engulfed by humanity and not feel threatened at all.
Great Madness. Went here today for the first time and it is great madness with everyone crossing the street at the same time. I could walk this street back and forth all day.

Makes your heart skip a beat. This place is so loud, so filled with people that when I first came I had to get out for a second just to relax and only then could I come back again. I then stayed there for around 1 or 2 hours people watching. Do go to the indoor market located in the nearby buildings

You will just be mesmerised. Best spot to watch it is from the Starbucks.
It keeps changing through the day. We watched it from our hotel room when it was raining and all you could see where the umbrellas crossing the street. Don't forget to see the statue of the dog.

An interesting experience!. The area looks like a condensed Times Square. Hustle and bustle from the nearby Yamanote line station spills out into the scramble crossing, with huge crowds forming in seconds!
Must experience for yourself!. We crossed several times just for the experience. At night it's even better due to the color and action of the jumbotrons.
Huge shopping plaza. It's one of the busies intersections in Tokyo. If you sit by the window in the starbucks, you'll be able to take a photo of the entire intersection :)

The art of supercrowded. This area is a famous place that travelers should visit. It is actually a crossing at a junction. The crowd because Shibuya was a fashion, bussiness and food district, so a lot of people are using this junction

Be a part of this!. It's a real buzz seeing so much humanity moving all around and generally oblivious of those around them. Right at the Shibuya station. A great spot to watch from is a cafe L'Occitane with views on two levels over the crossing.

Must do in Tokyo. You must see view this crazy scene, masses and masses of people at several crosswalks at once. Get yourself to a cafe and people watch. There are all sorts! Expect the unexpected. New fashions galore. Heart of Tokyo nightlife here too. Plus, visit the Hachiko dog statue, gorgeous story.

A must when visiting Tokyo. A crosswalk that cannot be missed for any complete visit to Tokyo.
It's very pretty and exciting in the early evening with the lights and sounds. Take some time to observe the beautiful polite nature and style of Tokyo people.
Brilliant at night!. We visited Shibuya at night and it was incredible! The lights from all shops and the hundreds of people crossing makes for a memorable Tokyo experience!

See it to believe it!. It's a wild, but organized chaos when crossing the Shibuya scramble, the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. And it's always busy, especially in the evening!
People (tourists) line up to sit on the 2nd floor of Starbucks to witness people scurry around like busy ants. It's a fun experience just being there.

Well, I was kinda in it before I realised how famous it was!!. Call me naive if you like but I just thought it was a crossing. Then I realised how big it is and how many people cross all at the same time. So it was really cool to be there in the thick of it all when it dawned on me what a fab place it is. We had just checked in to our hotel before going out to explore. We could see the crossing from our hotel room window which made it even more fun. Later on Friday evening all the local soup-up classics came out to play and it was huge fun! We crossed over the Scramble several times to get a better view of the cars! The area itself reminds me of Piccadilly Circus and it gets better as the sun goes down (and a lot cooler!)
Get that selfie. All the madness we were looking for. Head to Shibuya 109 for Tokyo teen fashion. Then Yoyogi park and shrine.

Amazing and a must do in Tokyo. Never saw so many people cross the street at once. Really funny. Tip: visit Starbucks at the opposite of the Shibuya crossing and go upstears to have a great view on the crossing and to make a photo there.

Loved it! Well worth a visit at night! . Amazing! Loved the atmosphere and the buzz of the city. Great experience to have in such a wonderful city. Great site to see with family. My sister is obsessed with the Fast and Furious films which was one of the reasons we came but I'm so glad we did!

Shibuya is Tokyo's Times Square. I am a native Nw Yorker and was stunned by the number of people. It was my first day venturing out and had to stay close to my cousin (who lives in Japan) so I wouldn't get swept away. There's also "decora girls" and other people in costume. Good cheap eats, including crepes nearby. My heart was filled with joy! If you're not Japanese expect the locals to be fascinated by you

What a fun thing to watch!. This is just one of those fun things you must do if you are in Tokyo! Set, ready, go! And the pedestrian lights turn green and masses of people are crossing the intersection in at least five different ways. Additionally, there are lots of restaurants and shopping near here.

Must Go in Tokyo. Going to the Shibuya Crossing is almost impossible to avoid if you are in the shopping district of Tokyo. Once you exit Shibuya station, first visit the bronze statue of Hachiko the dog. It is a touching story. Then the massive cross walks in front collectively is the Shibuya crossing. Have your camera ready. Don't feel silly. A ton of people are doing selfies and videos too. You can also experience the view from above by visiting cafes or restaurants overlooking the crossing. The first time I walked through- it was quite exhilarating. Next couple of times were still fun and amazing. Sea of people but orderly and swift. Keep up!
Fun area to explore. Grab a coffee at the Starbucks to get a full view of the crossing. The entire area is fun to explore.

Easy & Fun People-Watching Activity. Fun to go see - with masses of people crossing in each direction every couple of minutes! Even if it's raining, its still worth going to see, as all the umbrellas add to the mix (not to mention the photographic opportunity!). We went at somewhat off hours several times and were able to get seats in the upstairs Starbucks window. Just be forewarned that if you go in the very early a.m. (which we did when awake due to jet lag), its fun to also see the intersection impressively empty (but be aware the Starbucks doesn't open particularly early)

You have to experience the crossing for yourself at night!. Great place to take in the hustle and bustle of Shibuya. Gets pretty busy from 7 PM and peaks at about 9 PM. This is where everyone takes selfies at the famous crossing - stop in the middle of the pedestrian crossing, but be careful of traffic! There's also plenty of good shopping and eating to do once you're done! Lovely place. From there, you can visit the statue of Hachiko.
Chaos road crossing. This is another attraction to see. It is a mad scramble to cross the road.So many people but good fun to watch.

Hard to miss - a thrill to experience. Made famous this immense crossing is an absolute study in urban living! Just a few steps away from the station it is easy to find and a must do! Curious about Hachiko? His statue is near hear and has a beautiful story behind it.
Not hard to miss, a blast to experience!. Exiting the station it is not far and quite amazing to watch and try! At the south edge is a very famous statue of Hachiko, and a wonderful story too!

Rrrrrrrrruuuuuuuuuunnnnnnnnn!. You have to do this! Looks like chaos but is safe. Would be a bloodbath in Italy or Greece. There's a great food Hall under the crossing that is very cheap and massive, we got proper wasabi root here.
A Must See . Great fun when you have time for a quick coffee. Exit the subway, cross the famous Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble and grab a coffee at Starbucks on 2/F or one of the neighbouring cafes.
Good place to start your day. We started our day with the experience, crazy place to witness. Then there are loads of great shops and restaurants around.

Good busy crossing. Good spot of selfies. Every tourists are doing it.. Lots of people doing selfies, so we joined it. Managed to get a good picture. Good fun setting it all up. Noisy with good musics. More for young people. Good view from the two major brands coffee shops.

Must see for Tokyo madness!. It's hard to picture just how crazy this place is until you are there. Must do when visiting Tokyo just to see the commuters cross in their thousands! You don't need long here, once you've seen it a couple of times then your done but there are a lot of shops and restaurants in the surrounding area of Shibuya. Good views from the station crossing just above (up the escalators). Good to visit at dusk when the city lights give it a great backdrop and it's packed with commuters.
Overrated. Lot's of people, thats all there is. So don't go to Shibuya just to see this. There are many other reasons to go to Shibuya though :)

Crowded.. . We made the experience.. Crossing the famous pedestrian scramble.. We incredible thing is that everybody is going left and right, every direction is taken but nobody touching or bumping anybody else.. ;-)

Nothing like it anywhere else. This street crossing is insane!!! You must must see it!! Walk it several times. It's fun!
Plenty of shopping to do in the area after witnessing the street crossing mania.

Many people and Stores. Yes, you have to see it once. It's really impressive and not frightening ;-) Different angles to watch this pedestrian show, from the streets, from above in one of the buildings.
Iconic scene. Visit the cruising that still of your friends will ask if you saw it. Surpriaingly less crazy than one would expect for 7 crosswalks.

Crazy Fun!. We went on a rainy night with lights reflecting in rain drops and on the wet pavement. The pedestrians were very orderly and the crowds crossing were massive, but we were able to capture a lovely photo of our daughter on her birthday as a memory keepsake. It's definitely worth the quick trip; it's right near the subway station. And, we enjoyed the night view with all the lights!

You gotta!. So much fun...and we saw a collision between a nice lady and man during a routine crossing event...quite the scandal. We spent the time it takes to enjoy a coffee watching from Starbucks observatory (obviously we bought a SB!)

the Times Square of Tokyoo. ...well not quite, just like Times Square it has the bright advertisements and neon , a multitude of people. Unlike times square, when the lights go red and the cars stop...the whole multitude, easily a couple of thousands flood the intersection getting across it to their destination. If you have not seen the videos on the Internet, which you should, I bet it sounds chaotic - it is not! The flood scramble of humanity only lasts a minute and just as sudden as it begins...it ends. The moment the lights turn green coincides with the last stragglers finishing safely their journey across the intersection and cars begin to move. No this it's no Times Square, this on another level .....this is INTENSE!!!

So much to do and see! . Loved the atmosphere. Day and night. There's Always something to do. Shops everywhere and plenty of tax free shops too. So many choices of food places, to cater for your budget and taste buds! Definitely get a map! Pick out what you're there to do. We mostly wanted to try authentic Jap food. And buy presents for relatives back home.

Fantastic. A really amazing place with so many people at a time!!Everyone will be there crossing the road when the light turns green and the best part is that you can still take photo at the centre of the crossing!!!Never seen so many people crossing the road except here at Shibuya crossing

Amazing sight not to miss out by everyone visiting tokyo. One should really be there to experience this wonderful place which is full of people crossing roads in all directions in such a busy junction outside shibuya station. Wow!
Great experience. You can experience this wonderful walking around thing and roam around the area conveniently. Recommended.

Nothing like it anywhere! . Only in Japan (I think)... So you must try to get into the scramble and see/experience it for yourself.
Was awesome to watch as well from the 2F of Starbucks across Shibuya Stn.

Scramble. Well its a big crossing!
We went to the starbucks to get a good view overlooking it. Didn't buy a drink, just got a cheeky window seat, took a few photos and videos and disappeared!
Traffic stops, it is fascinating to watch.

It's cool to say you've walked it!. Get your Go Pros ready! Nothing more than a tourist novelty but regardless it is a really awesome experience. You cannot miss the scramble exiting Shibuya station as it is right in front of you. To get the most out of the scramble go during the day, at sunset and at night, the illuminating advertisements make for a futuristic setting !

A must-see. An essential sight in Tokyo - both to experience and to watch. We came out of Shibuya station and walked across the crossing first, then went to get a coffee and watch it all happening from above and take some photos!

You have to... but don't go too early. We exited the Shibuya (labyrinth of trains) station and found ourselves standing here. You need to do this... we crossed many times, took photos, time lapse photos, walked through this area but if you want an interesting perspective go up to the second floor Starbucks and take pictures... Don't go too early, it gets better the later in the day... more people and the LED screens start illuminating the whole place.

One and Only!. Busy town, busy shibuya, the pedestrain scramble was very crowded and loads of people walking.But it's great to take photos of it due to it is one and only in the world.Even HK is a busy place but doesn't have these kinds of pedestrians...

The Rush!. I couldn't leave Japan without experiencing The Shibuya Scramble! I went during peak hours and it was exactly that!!! B.U.S.Y.. You think New York is busy.... think again! SO...MANY...PEOPLE! You have :60 secs to cross the street. It seems like a long while.. Well it isn't! it goes by very fast when there are so many people rushing to cross. It is easy to get lost!! I lost my brother..Or...he lost me! I'm not quite sure! My phone was turned off while I was traveling so I couldn't call him. So, I waited under the Starbucks while listening to a local group sing a few songs hoping he would find me there. He knows me well.. I love music.. He found me grooving along. After he donated to one of the local "non profits" requesting money, we sat and enjoyed the rush from above the streets while sipping on a nice warm drink at the Starbucks as he is a loyal customer. AGAIN...It is easy to get separated as everybody is speed walking and maneuvering their way towards the other side. I suggest holding hands. It was a live area. Many shops to visit. An array of dining choices just a few blocks from the subway/train. It's very easy to get around. The metro system is fantastic! Really simple and to the point. It is hard to get lost as the stops are colour coded, numbered and named in Japanese and English. My first observation was that Japan was very quite and clean. I landed in Narita and made my way down to Yokosuka on the Metro.. Not one person was talking on their phone, listening to music very loudly or playing games for all to hear.. It was quite nice! Also, I found the locals to be very pleasant. Although, I only know a few Japanese words and phrases, I was able to shop, order food and get directions from every person I asked. Japan is one of my favorite places to visit..so far! I can't wait to go back and explore more cities. Arigato!

So many people!. In some ways, this is just like every other pedestrian crossing. But at the same time, there are so many people that it makes it very interesting!! Keep close to the people you're travelling with, or you will definitely lose them!! Good luck!

Scrambled but Smooth. A neat crossing at one of the busiest intersection in Shibuya. A lot happening on every corner so you will want to cross it several times. Try doing in a direction other than what is painted on the pavement and see if it confuses anybody. You get from one side to another fairly smoothly without ever having to shimmy for anybody.

Shibuya crossing - dive in, join the crowd - pedestrian and traffic management with a Japanese mindset. I think the Shibuya pedestrian crossing need be experienced both during the day, and at night. I preferred the night crossing as the electronic billboards /advertising that surround the area, the light, is very atmospheric. I like the way this crossing works - it really does say something about Japan, and Japanese people. You have five roads feeding into the crossing, 22 lanes of traffic, and hundreds of people crossing but it all works, happens with minimal fuss, people cross, traffic moves - it works. I think one of the better views of the Shibuya crossing is via the walkway at Shibuya Station, to the Inokashira Line - its free, not crowded, and gives you lots of photo opportunities.
busy. Very busy area and super busy cross .. Fantastic athmospher full of different colorfull people . lots of interesting shops

Fun place to people watch. Tokyo's Time Square, this is a very busy intersection with many crosswalks.
Its fun to watch the hoards of people scramble and disperse as the traffic lights turn green.
Lots of shops and restaurants around the area, and its right outside Shibuya Station.
Don't miss if your in Tokyo!

Close to Shibuya station. Something to check off the list "worlds busiest pedestrian crossing". Opposite of Shibuya station, close to Hachiko statue. We walked the crossing to Starbucks across the street and went to the second floor and quickly got a seat. Spent about half an hour there people watching. its fascinating to see the number of people crossing this busy intersection.

Watch this Iconic Spot from Starbucks. Buy a cup of coffee and head up stairs and grab a seat by the window.
This is a wonderful spot to sit and watch the pedestrian scramble. A great place to rest, cool off from the heat, get away from the crowd, log onto the free wifi and take in the sights.
Thank you Starbucks!

You have to be there at the right time.. It is an interesting crossing. Sometimes it is extremely crowded. A lot of people many tourists. It is a walking distance from Meiji shrine. It is worth the visit if you are close to the place.

Just a crossing . Just a crossing
If you live in any other city on the world its nothing diffrent from london or new york. But if you like people crossing a road then this is gold dust for you.

not as big as I though. I loved see the people cross by without touching.
the big screen, the music, the people.
your sense could get overwhelme but please don´t miss a thing.
It´s clouse to Hachiko and well, deserve being see.
Worth a visit. Definitely a site you want to see if you get the chance! We brought a coffee at the Starbucks and overlooked the crossing for an hour or so before wandering the nearby shopping strips.
Nothing special. Heard it was one of the place to check out if one goes to japan but it's just a road where people cross. Granted that its unique but nothing wow about it.

Come see why it's been featured in so many commercials. Nothing represents crazy busy in Tokyo like the scenes at this busy 5-road (or 22-lane, if you like) junction. It's busy when the traffic is flowing, and it gets busier when the pedestrians hurl themselves across the junction when the traffic is stopped. But come during the morning and evening rush hours, then see a mass of humanity moving from one side of the junction to another. It's an interesting place to people-watch, in a sense. And you can always tell who the tourists are - they're the ones who cross the junction a number of times in succession, probably have their cameras or videocams out or over their heads.

Crowd not as thick as made out to be, but still awesome!. Went to this place with family, and we loved it. We loved it so much we made multiple crossings! It is truly a wonderful site to see so many people crossing all at once, without any problem. Really a must visit while in Shibuya.
