The Starbucks overlooking the crossing is rumoured to have wonderful views, but to get into it you have to order something as you have to join the line going past the counter. In our case, it was a tad bit long.

Underwhelming. I guess it just looked bigger on TV, but even from two different vantage points and two crossings I could still not be impressed. It's fun to watch but not much more and not busier than Sydney's Castleagh, Melbourne's Collin's, Rotterdam's Weena or New York's 42nd street crossings. As longs as you're crossing any way, might as well stop near the statue of Hachiko and give him a pat on the head for luck and appreciation.
Crowed place, but a must visit in Tokyo. You must visit this famous spot. A lot of shopping opportunities and many restaurants. Starbucks nearby if you need free wifi.
Blegh... Nothing special, just full of pedestrians trying to cross to the other side. The starbuck opposite is full of people just trying to take photo of the cross.

Has to be seen to be believed. We went on the off chance and glad we did. My teenage sons kept crossing, the many different routes and my wire and I photographed them in the melee. Quite amazing to see so many people cross a crossroads at once, using the differing routes.
Hassle and bussle. Growing up in Japan, it is still a wonder for me that people can cross this scramble without any problem every time. It is worth a look and walk.

Selfie Central. In the heart of Shibuya, right outside of the station, at its peak 1400 people crossing the street at the same time. People stopping mid crossing taking selfies and video footage. Hachiko statue is located right next to crossing and tourist information. Go to Starbucks and get a window seat and just people watch for 20mins. Plenty of other great stuff around this area and make sure to visit at night also
A Tokyo must do!. There are probably many crossings in Tokyo almost as interesting but this is a must do. Look where you are going when you do that selfie!

interesting to watch from starbucks. it is weird and yet interesting to see SO MANY people busy crossing - starbuck has a commanding view so its better to "relax" sipping a coffee and see how busy the world is down there.

Insane, so, so many people here!. A must experience. Seem to be crowded all the time. We were here close to midnight, and this intersection is just as packed. Great place to do your people watching activity.
I don't know what the big deal is. It's just like NYC or San Fran no big deal to me so much more to see in Tokyo. Like the beautiful gardens.

Fun to do once, better to look at once you're out of the way of the crowds. This crossing is crazy during rush hour, but you'll find that people don't crash into each other. Just look where you're going and it'll be fine. It's one of the icons of Shibuya, so it's good to say that you've crossed this street once, but I'd keep walking after the pedestrian scramble to experience most of this area.
OK . I think it's very good to see.. It's weird how people crossing streets have become a tourist attraction, but it's fun and definitely worth seeing...

Best experience if it is raining! see the umbrellas dance. You can watch the crossing when it is raining and see how umbrellas scramble up and down and avoid collision. Try it your self it will be fun.

A selfie spot you should gi. You cant missid it, of you go to shibuya this is the most place to take a selfie. The thrill take a photo while is a green light to pedestrian then many tourist will took a photo. And bealive me there is a queuee just to take a selfie here.

take crazy pictures. y not if you r in shibuya? i've seen ppl taking lots of pictures.. for those who love photography it may be worth your time.. i took a time lapse video from my iphone in my hotel room and its lovely. u can take pictures of the crossing view from starbucks , at the crossing itself , at tokyu level2 (i think) as there's a connection from tokyu train entrance to another building (mark city?)..

Enjoyable. I've been to the Starbucks which can see the whole view of the scramble. Apparently there are tons of people thinking about this. It's too popular to find a place. But air guess it's worth to wait there for a while to get a seat
Truly a sight to behold. It was surely a sight to behold. The scramble has the best view from the starbucks at the shibuya crossing.
Worth doing if you are in the area. Crowds of people, singing, dancing, street performers and general controlled chaos, what's not to like? just do it!

Great to look at!. I went here almost everyday just to spend one good hour watching the people cross the street going everywhere! Crazy yet it was fun watching everyone! I would recomment going to the Starbucks just at the intersection of Shibuya and stay on the 2nd floor for a really good view!
Hustle and Bustle Crossing. People just come from everywhere to cross the road, but the local are all self-discipline without any choas

Smaller than the movies!. Honestly thought this crossing would be a lot bigger from what I have seen in films, so I was a little dissapointed with the lack of size.The view from Starbucks is the best, but I recommend travellers to come at office times so there is an influx of pedestrians which makes the whole experience a lot better.The good news however is there is a lot to see with little alley-way shops nearby.
Experience the hustle bustle of Mordern Tokyo. It just so different where you get to see so many people at the same time crossing the road.. It has a unique experience and should be visited

Not too busy during the weekdays. If going, I would recommend going on a Friday or Saturday evening. I have been there during the weekday and on the weekend, and the weekend did not disappoint. Be sure to buy a coffee in Starbucks and wait it out to find a seat overlooking the crossing. It will not disappoint, that is if you love to people watch!
Crowded. The pedestrian walk is not thing much. It s only the famous crowded crossway in Shibuya. But it s fun to witness such the crowd crossing the street.

Great views from Starbucks. Pedestrian scramble is a must see!! Especially rush hour times (If you're prepared to face the crowds) It has a Times Square feel to it. The best view is from Starbucks, although it seems busy we weren't queued for long and managed to get a spot with a great view of the sea of people crossing! Would definitely recommend visiting here, there's also good things to see and do nearby like arcades and sushi restaurants!

Fun to watch, good place to hang out.... I had a great time here and came back 2x in my short vacation in Tokyo. So many places to eat and to shop. A good place to hang out with my children. So busy and yet so safe.
Crazy place to walk. Good place to walk, really crewd.A lot to see, places and people. Place to young people, noice.Recommend to visit in night.Good place for dinner.

Must-see for all lonst in translation fans. Just missed Bill Murray there - but it was still facinating to see this amount of people everywhere. Go to the starbucks and get a better view - if you can kick your way through...
Such a funny and crazy thing!. This is a cool thing to see, if you have never been to Japan before. People are crossing the street in all kind of directions, and still it looks organized!

Interesting way of handling traffic.. This is a bit like Times Square with loud billboard advertisements high up on buildings. This is an odd cross section of more than 4 roads so they have timed it so all the cars are stopped so that all the people can cross at once. And you can cross any direction you want including straight through the middle. One of the reasons this seemed a bit different is that the Japanese never step off the curb except at a crosswalk and never until the green walking sign lights up. They are so endlessly patient that I began to think maybe it is a law. I was not always as patient and when the coast was clear I might bolt even with a red light. The neighbor hood of shops here are fun to wander around but I got the impression that this place is busier at night.
Scrabble . One works scrabble and crowd! But you can't not go there. It is the biting hearty of Tokyo: if you go do not forget to say hi to the little dog!

Never seen so much people and vibrancy!. Must see in Tokyo! This is one of the most crowed pedestrian crossing in the world! Great food and shopping nearby too. Don't forget to take a 360 selfie in the middle of the intersection!

Must-see!. This place is definitely one to tick off your bucket list. Having seen it countless of times on TV, I knew I had to see this iconic place at least once in my life, and it was exactly as I had expected! Surrounded by huge billboards with loud, flashing lights and thousands of pedestrians, the Shibuya Crossing is as crazy as you can imagine! For one minute, all vehicles from all directions stop to allow pedestrians to cross the intersection. And during this minute, it is just wonderful to witness how something that should actually be so chaotic, be so calm and orderly! It is probably the epitome of Tokyo and how crazy and insane this city is. I didn't know that the simple act of crossing a street could be so exciting!We came at about 9pm and the peak rush hour crowds had reduced. Apparently the best time was about 7-8pm. We tried to get a seat on the second floor of the Starbucks, to get a good view of the crossing from above, but it's nearly impossible. Everyone else is eye-ing for one of those seats, so if you manage to get it, you're probably one of the luckiest people in Tokyo that day.

A very famous and picturesque spot. If you're in Tokyo, check it out. The best spot to see the action is on the second floor from the Starbucks window (tip: they do not sell coffee on the second floor - so if you want a drink, buy it downstairs, then take it to the second floor). There is no requirement to buy a drink to access the second floor, so you can skip the purchase if you want. To get upstairs, go into the movie shop on the first floor. There is an escalator in there that will take you to the viewing windows of starbucks.
Wow. Even on a Sunday this is impressive. Best seen with a coffee at Starbucks. Food very good neaby as well

The Japan You Imagine. This is full on crowded Tokyo. Worth seeing it once in your life. It was moderately crowded when we crossed according to my Japanese friends (which is a massive crowd compared to the U.S.) to go to an area restaurant. Normally an intersection like this would be a nightmare. Here people seemed to be enjoying it and people, like me, were taking pictures.
It's just people crossing the road.... It is cool to have a traffic scramble like this but there's really nothing fanciful about it. Catch it if you're in the area.
A photo opportunity!. As the Japanese have such impeccable manners it is so easy to cross here, despite how busy it is, as people move orderly and calmly without bumping into each other!
Wow. Everyone going everywhereWas there on the day Pokemon go launched. Everyone was playingMust see if you come to tokyo

Super duper busy street!!. Amazing with how busy this street!
I don't care if it looks too touristic but trust me, capture yourself during red light is a must!!
You can experience all the people walks across the way from different side!!!

Cool to watch . You have to see this. 5 way intersection that is stopped all at once and people scramble to cross in every direction even diagonally. It's free and fun to see. It's in many movies including fast and furious and Lost in translation. While here see the Hachiko statue of the dog from the movie about a professor whose dog loyally waited here for him to return from work every day. Right at Hachiko exit at shibuya station.

Worth walking across the street for. We went during the days just to see the crowds. What a hoot! Go up to the Starbucks on the second floor to watch. Cross to participate. Have someone video you from Starbucks while you cross. Somehow it is a lot of fun just walking across this street.

You have to see this. This is a must for visitors to Tokyo, i walked with the crowd, through the crowd, around cars, it was exciting to experience. There is a starbucks there, go up to the second level and take pics and videos.

Very busy street. It's a very crowded streets. It's really amazing seeing all crossing.from all junction. Especially at night, the view is very cool.There're lots of shopping and restaurant around this area.

Magnificient Atmosphere. Shibuya crossing has the best atmosphere in modern Japan. It was really wonderful when I passed the crossing area with a hundred people in one time! Even I crossed it 4 time and made a video while crossing. Subarashi!!!

"To get to the other side ...". Shibuya station is one of the busiest in Tokyo (Shinjuku is the busiest) and so it shouldn't be a surprise that the so called Shibuya Scramble is full of pedestrians crossing the street to get to Shibuya Center Gai. I believe this is the busiest pedestrian crossing in Japan, but I don't get the attraction as a tourist site. I've made this crossing many times before it became famous. Now the tourists are taking selfies and videos of themselves crossing the street. There is no need to make yourself look foolish by falling to the ground in the middle of the intersection like some people I witnessed in my most recent trip to Shibuya. I don't see tourists doing similar actions in crowded stations during rush hour, probably because it is a much more frantic scence in the stations.I'm probably in the minority, but I wouldn't go out of my way just for this. There are plenty of other attractions and you will probably wind up experiencing this intersection on your way through it.

Popular pedestrian crossing at Shibuya. One of the most popular pedestrian crossing on Tokyo. Near the Hachiko statue and exit of Shibuya station, Most of the shopping spots are near this intersection.
Great area - busy with fun vibe.. You must go here when in Tokyo. Cool shops, bars and restaurants. I loved it. Easy to get to on the subway/metro. Enjoy the shopping and the food!

A must see. Worth going...more so at night, just because of its reputation. Lots of shops in the area that close pretty late so once you've taken in the lights you can have a wonder round. Needless to say, it's extremely busy. Be prepared!

Amazing. This is a must do!!!
Great to be part of the crowd that crosses the street at this infamous crossing.
Best viewing point is from the second floor of the Starbucks, enjoy a coffee and watch the spectical!!!
Must do it . Weekends is more full , it 's Wednesday and not too many people but still interesting.go up sturbacks to take the pic

One of the best experiences.... All I can say is, It's amazing. This indeed is the BUSIEST pedestrian in the world. All day 'round, it is packed with people. It is fun crossing numerous times from one end to another. Definitely satisfying. There are tons of shopping centres too, so make sure to drop by them. The only downfall is that Shibuya is not much for cheap-buyers. In Shibuya 109, one small skirt costs like 25-50k yen (shocking, ain't it?). But other than that, it is a place worth going to. And if you happen to be in Shibuya, drop by UOBEI Sushi, too :)

Fun place to watch the world go by.. We went here in the morning and for this I was grateful as it wasn't so busy. We went to Starbucks and sat in the window which looked over the crossing to watch everyone. The area around the crossing is full of shops including the Disney store and many other different shops. Great place to wonder the streets and look for something different to the normal shops.

A must-go when you are in Tokyo. Shibuya is famous for this venue and if I am not wrong, Fast and Furious team have visited this spot for their movie shooting. You may experience the advance feeling of this city at here, and also, the surrounding buildings are the essence for shopping in Shibuya. Eg. One individual building of MUJI, Forever 21, Shibuya 109, H&M, and more are at here! Most local at here are younger generation, it's interesting!

Run, run, run!. It's not as scary as one might think. The groups of people are quite organized and wait patiently for the crossing light to turn green. Then begins the charge for the other side of the street! It was very exciting to witness and be a part of.

Fun to observe!. Outside the donuts station is a complex intersection where's traffic is stored to allow thousands of pedestrians on a Sunday afternoon to cross. Most go in there there larger crosswalks which form a triangles while others cut across to dwarves time. They comes from Cork directions so you see a dance of people avoiding each other in perfect yet unrehearsed choreography. We watched from an upper floor of these station and very much enjoyed the spectacle.

Great for people watching . As crazy-looking as all the videos I've seen but still worth checking out. Easy to do if your passing through Shibuya train station. Amusing to also notice the people staring at the intersection from the windows of the 2nd floor Starbucks. Photo taking is not allowed from there, FYI. But you can take photos from the street and there are usually a lot of folks setting up their cameras to capture the moment when all four crosswalks gets the green light. With all the people- and traffic-watching, this place is always interesting. Lots of shops and restaurants nearby.

A must-see in Tokyo!. Behind the Shibuya crossing you find the actual Shibuya district with larger European high street brands, small sushi restaurants, Japanese department stores, a huge Uniqlo and gambling houses. Even at night the small streets are brightly illuminated and full of young people.For more night photos of the crossing check out my blogpost :)http://franie-travels.com/2016/01/24/tokyo-japan

Loved the place! Shopping was great!. Shibuya is huge use a map to get around. The loft and the 100 yen store was really good. There is so much to do. Loved the energy of area even though there were so many people.

This is Tokyo!. Every definition about Tokyo is here: extravagant, state of the art technology displays, sophisticated, Fashionable, Trendy, big crowds, energetic. The biggest pedestrian scramble in the world. it's a must!

Unbelieveable!. This is an incredible site. When the green man shows, people literally appear from everywhere. If you are in Tokyo its a must visit. A good tip is to try to get a widow seat in the Starbucks overlooking the crossing. A great view.

The essence of Tokyo can be experienced for 30 seconds.. Of course it is full of tourists, but it is still quite exciting when the crossing light changes to green, the mass of humanity all rushed to and from all directions. It is fun, besides it is where you can see Hochiko's statute and all the stores and neon lights at night. So, yes, it is worth your time to visit the crossing and Shibuya in general.
amazing busy street. This is one of the landmark in Tokyo and I love it. I love the view when people were crossing the street. For me, it is a must visit, a must see and a must experience in tokyo
crowd. thousands people will pass by this crossing every day. This is one of the busiest cross in the world. It's crowd, just enjoy !

Tokyo in a nutshell. Shibuya Crossing is the one place I'd choose as a representative for the rest of the city. Surrounded in every direction by high-rise shopping malls, bright and colourful LED screens and bustling with people at all times, the Crossing fulfils every expectation of Tokyo as a modern metropolis. Having been raised in a significantly smaller city myself, I found it incredibly fascinating to watch the masses of people build up during the red light only to flood the street as soon as the light turns green. I scrambled across several times, and I think that no Tokyo experience is complete without having visited Shibuya Crossing, even if it's just for a few minutes so that you can say you've seen it.
Somehow they don't hit each other. There are loads and loads of people crossing at once and Somehow they don't hit each other. A good place to visit. many shops and restaurant around it as well

Extreme Crossing ! . It was for sure a scramble! And people come from any where. If your not paying attention you can get disoriented. If you have kids. You must hold on to them or carry. Please dont let them on their own.

So Much Fun!. Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble is a fun place to visit. The crossing fills every 2 minutes as people cross the street from 5 directions all at the same time. For a great picture go to the second floor of the Starbucks. Night time puts another spin on the whole experience.

So Many People Crossing All At Once. In Adelaide we have a couple of intersections that allow the pedestrians to walk across in any directions. But this intersection in Shibuya is so huge with so many people (3,000 people) crossing it all at once.

Time Square of Tokyo - Cross this Street and Observe the Surreal of a Modern Japan City . +: How do they control the flows of 10,000 pedestrians and 1,000s of cars effortlessly? It's unreal to stand in the middle and watch the flow.-: A lot of people that could make you feel super dizzy.<3: The discipline of Japanese pedestrians to follow the traffic lights is remarkable. You must see it to believe it. Do this in Vietnam and you would be dead!
Go with the flow!. We had to pass by the scramble going to Donki and we had our best photo here. Just feels fun walking here since I have seen this so many times in Mangas, Anime and Japanese Movies.

Just like the movies!. Hundreds of people all crossing in different directions at the same time! Complete chaos, but was so much fun to make the scramble just like in the movies. The square is right near the subway exit.
day and night people are crossing. go to starbucks and have coffee! Best view for crossing. I love it so much fun. It was like my daily exercise:)

Fun Fun Fun. This is something you have to experience to fully get. This whole area is a great people watch. The busiest starbucks in the world is at the crossing. I tried to meet a friend at the crossing, that took a while! People people everywhere.

When in Tokyo, just do it once. The first time I went to Tokyo, I hated the new year's crowds at Shibuya 109 so much that I practically sulked my way across this crossing. 3 years wiser and more open to a new experience, I went back again this June. It's definitely something many who visit Tokyo want to experience and there's certainly nothing quite like this in any other city I've been to and not even my native Singapore. Just do it for the fun of it and don't forget to snap a selfie in the middle of the street to keep as a memento. I like it better at night when the neon lights are up and the whole area is lit up!

the famous scramble in d heart of Tokyo. The famous scramble in the heart of Tokyo, where lots of people crossed the road from all over was a sight as portrayed in dramas and guide books. Nice night view if you are chilling out at Starbucks situated just above the pedestrian scramble crossroads.

One of the busiest places in the world. I always wanted to experience the mad scramble at the Shibuya crossing, and it didn't disappoint. I went there on a rainy day just so I could see the sea of clear umbrellas hurriedly making their way across the street. I am a guy that likes to enjoy the little things, and views like this are picturesque and worth taking in my eyes. Never have I been so thrilled to cross the street and never has my adrenaline kicked in as soon as the pedestrian light gave way. It's certainly on my list of things to do when I visit Shibuya again.Happy Travels

Unbelievable busy. We were told by a local guide that approximately 3,000 people cross on average each time!! It is a must do attraction when in Tokyo, which is strange because its only a crossing, but the sheer volume and number of people and how busy it is makes it a sight to see.
Illuminating. Even at night the lights are that strong that it looks like day, if you walk from the metro up to the streetlevel. Great to cross the roads here, you feel the crazyness of the city

Great for people watch and vibe of Shibuya !!. 5 Pedestrian crossings turn green at the same time to give a dramatic effect when viewed from above ( Starbucks has the vantage point !!)
Bustle and vibe of the place even at midnite makes it like a Times Square on steriods !!

Probably more impressive at night or rush hour. We got off at Shibuya train station and walked straight out the Hachiko exit onto the crossing. It was mid morning and not overly busy. Plenty of pedestrians around, stopped in at Starbucks for the obligatory coffee and photo opportunity from the second floor. Stayed long enough to people watch whilst enjoying our drinks and then promptly moved on.

Cool!. We went during a busy time of the day and enjoyed watching the giant sea of people. We stood in the middle and did a quick video- but dont do that, its not safe! Disclaimer! Lol. Side note: One of our passports got lost at the crossing and only 2 hours later someone had picked it up and walked to the Shibuya police station!! This is common in Japan! Shibuya police were really nice

Crazy amazing place. Great place to see what is to be in Asia, I've never seen so many people in the same place looks like a swarm totally organized, look for a spot in the next Starbucks or at the plaza both works and you can enjoy the show from prime spot

Phenomenally busy, incredibly organised!. Just has to be experienced! Several thousand people can cross, from a number of directions, at any one light change - but it's completely orderly. This is a vibrant part of Tokyo and well worth the experience.

Starbucks. It was fun to see it early in the morning after my flight. It was quiet and little traffic. Lots of cherry blossoms in the city lights. The starbucks was also quiet. Going to the same location in the early afternoon was chaos. People walk every which way and the Starbucks has a huge lineup to get to any of the observation windows. Still a classic Japanese experience.

The energy of Tokyo right here. Love this crazy busy junction, always a hive of activity all times of the day, symbolic of the vibrancy of Tokyo. I love the story of Hachiko the loyal dog and shops like Itoya (in Tokyu), LOFT and Tokyu Hands. Trying the tiny restaurants where coupons are purchased first and seating is around a counter is always fun.

Crazy fun!. Organized chaos indeed! But I can't imagine visiting Tokyo without seeing this. Make sure you go into Shibuya 109 to see a mall so very different from those in the US. Go on a Saturday evening and be prepared for noise!
Mayhem. If you can catch this sight, it's a must do! Just watching the mayhem unfold every time the lights change is amazing. Take a seat in the Starbucks, has the best view of all
What's not to loce. It's organized chaos at its finest! Just a cool experience seeing everyone come out from each part of the intersection. Starbucks has a great birds eye view.
Fun experience . It's nice to be able to say that you got to experience it. Picture was taken from Starbucks. We were only there during the week but I bet the weekends are better.
Chaotic fun!. Enjoyed watching the organized chaos from the 2nd floor of Starbucks. Loved walking in the chaos even more.

A cross between Piccadilly Circus and Times Square . Wow. This is buzzing with activity. Lots of younger people making their way to the trendy shops. My sons drooled over the shoe shops. Nothing is cheap but the choice is amazing.

Orderly chaos!. Funny how crossing the Shibuya Pedestrian walk is an "activity", however, if you can you should try it.It is amazing how many people are in the area, crossing the street and watching the huge TV's. As usual in Japan (in my experience) the people are very polite and friendly. Amazing considering the number of people in walking around - there is no pushing, jostling or rudeness etc.

BUSY. Busy place. you can see people flooding the street when it is time for them to cross, there were heaps of people going in every direction and you can be lost if no caution is attended. at the location, there are various shopping centres you can visit and enjoy the day.

Crowded shopping street. This area is huge and a lot of shops and crowded with people. Also a lot of building with shopping mall. Restaurant also a lot, just walk around to chill and shopping, shop till you drop.

Humanity. We never sought this crossing out but being based in Harajuku ended up going through it many times. The astounding crush of humanity made impressive by the sheer civility of so many crossing at once. Each time we discovered something new: the famous dog, the famous mural, famous tempura.

Great experience. This is great place to see many (young) people hanging out. It is very busy at cross roads. It's really unbelievable where all people are coming from.It's really fun to watch, many trendy japanese youngsters. Go to crossings near railway station in Shibuya...also nice to shop and many restaurants around.
This is where people scrambled. Just like in TVs, Shibuya crossing awed me on how many people scrambled on the crossing. especially if you see them from above.

Wild and Exciting . Election speakers, shoppers, families, young people hanging out - so much going on. People crossing at the same time - then orderly they move out of the way for car time. A "must" place to see.

Not sure why this is even an activity . Fortunately we did not go to Shibuya just to see. Tokyo is a crazy busy city loaded with pedestrians and this is the best way to cross the street. I guess if you are from a small town it may be noteworthy Shibuya. Worth it to see the neon billboards and lights but seeing people cross the street. Not a big deal

Utter but controlled madness!. In Shibuya, there is no escaping the crosswalk. Even if you think its over-rated... which its not.Just the utter maddness of having so many people walking in different directions in a controlled manner. Where else but in Shibuya.
Busy crosswalk. This was only a 5 minute walk from the train station. Pure organized chaos watching so many people cross the street at the same time.

Overated. To me it was just a crossing and yes with lots of people but didn't do much for me. I did go there during the day so a night visit would probably be better with all the surrounding lights. The area itself is good to visit as has lots of quirky shops and all types of different people.

Stupid fun. You've seen it in movies or you've seen it on TV. It's silly fun, but you must do it. Take your phone or camera out a record a video like every other idiot while you're crossing through the throngs of people. You'll probably cross several times just to get a laugh. Silly fun.
Hub of All Events. Must see spot of the city, do not forgot to take a picture of Hatchico. Visit local restraounds around. Use shibuya station to reach other metro lines..

Cool view from the starbucks . Interesting point of view how organized Japanese people are even when crossing the pedestrian in both side they don't push each one they walk withou pushing you. Is a nice to take a picture.

It's a crosswalk.... Sure there are a lot of people here and you should go just to experience it but seriously, it is not that big of a deal. The Starbucks offers a good view of the scramble but it is SUPER packed so good luck getting a seat! I would mention that there is an old subway rail-car that is used as a tourist information center. It has seating and fans so can make a nice place to take a break in a city that has a remarkable lack of places to sit!

Not quite as expected. The first time I saw this crossing was a clear fall evening weekend and the density of the people created the wonderful visual of the scramble. This time around, I brought two friends who wanted to see what the fuss was all about. Unfortunately, it was a rainy Monday afternoon and the crowds were thin. Our takeaway from this is that the crossing looks best on a busy weekend night when framed by the numerous neon signs,and from a high vantage point like the Starbucks at the 2nd floor on the corner. Unfortunately, it almost impossible to get a seat by the window facing the crossing.

Daylight. The scramble was very interesting to watch however I feel that it would be much better to go at night as this is when it's most busy and along with the lighting from the buildings it would be the most beautiful too. Was still a good thing to sit and watch whilst in the Starbucks.

amazingly crowded. This is little confusing as one side you will find Hachiko exit shibuya 109 Mall separate for men and women actually 2 multi story malls big sign boards loud music young people walking around looks like a very happening place

took pic from train station. we just went after been told about it by other travellers. lots of people! We were using the JR line so stopped at the station and could take pics before getting back on train to continue trip. . went to Starbucks as recommended but better view from station. Starbucks was very crowded. Lots of neon lights and big video screens and music. We didnt get effect of these from the station.
Crazy. . Fun place to see and get across. Busy place for sure!!! The neat thing is that you most likely will not even get bumped into. It's a well organized crossing

Most "Selfied" intersection in the world . This crazy pedestrian intersection is busy pretty much anytime of the day, however, if you want the full shoulder-to-shoulder scramble experience, check Shibuya Scramble out on a weekend. In the end, it's just an intersection, but there is plenty to do in Shibuya once you get through the Scramble (EST is a highly recommended family fun center, btw!) One of the best photo spots of the scramble is from the Starbucks windows, but another awesome view (that's free) is from the Shibuya Station catwalk, heading to Mark City mall. That's also a great spot for making a time-lapse video of the crossing. Oh, and smile as you cross, because you will probably end up on someone's social media page. :) Dozens of people take selfie pics and videos during every crossing, so you'll likely be captured by one of them. Say "Shibuya Crossiiiiiiing!!" :)
Must visit. This is a fascinating place...surrounded by really good restaurants and shops. Easily accessible by bus as well as train

Interesting Insight. It was interesting to see so many people walking all over the place to cross which ever way. It was also always fun to navigate through people fast enough to cross diagonally across the whole intersection. Cool place to see.

A must see experience. If you visit Tokyo you must take a walk across the famous intersection outside Shibuya Station. When the lights turn red at this busy junction, and they all turn red at the same time in every direction. Traffic stops completely and pedestrians surge into the intersection from all sides. You can observe this moment of organized chaos from the second-story window of the Starbucks in the Tsutaya building on the crossing's north side.

Ordered Chaos. Lots of people crossing at the same time. Be careful if it's raining because the umbrellas come out! Also, the crossing time is not that long, but you may still have time to snap a picture or two.

Fun experience to see. A very touristy thing to do in Tokyo. It is definitely worth a look, grab a coffee at Starbucks and sit back and enjoy the view. Outside the Shibuya station so its very accessible.
Impressive. Impressive must-see When in Tokyo. The kids (9 and 7 years old) thought this was very cool... there is a Starbucks that provides a great indoor voverview..

A super touristy must-do. The busiest crossing in the world. Definitely worth a look. Key things to know:
- Busiest around 7-8pm WEEKDAYS, it is a work district
- Starbucks is a great place to watch from, but can get crowded, and photos will reflect from glass once it gets dark.
- Make sure you get amongst one or two crossings also.

great if you like pedestrian crossings. If you like a good pedestrian crossing this is one of the best in the world.
Just looking around you will see you are in the company of others whom also enjoy the rush of crossing the road

Fun to See and Experience!. At one of Tokyo's shopping Meccas, the intersection in front of the Hachiko exit of the Shibuya train station, we had to experience the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble crosswalk!We went on a Saturday night in June and the place was lively with all its neon ads and giant screens.We went to the 2nd floor of the Starbucks and took photos and time lapse videos.Fun to see and experience!
A quite uninteresting "must do". You can feel the pulse of Tokyo and shibuya at the crossing and it's on every to-do list for Tokyo tours but as an experience it's pretty average.

It's a zebra crossing.. It's sort of fun to see 1000s of people crossing the road once. Spoiled somewhat by the loud obnoxious American tourists taking selfies of themselves. Why do they think everyone on the planet wants to listen to their boring drivel? Shut up.

Like scrambled eggs. Walk across the diagonal Shibuya street when green and take a video! Mad scramble of people crossing the street...never seen anything like the volume of people crossing all at once! Best time is anytime between 5-8pm on weekends.

that's Tokyo live - use the crossing in the rushhour. impress intersection. thousands of people cross the intersection. Be a part of the crowd and run with crowd. in the rush hour you see people, people and people. all of them have one goal: to cross the intersection. this intersection Tokyo pur. each Tokyo Tourist must have been here! I would come back!

For me a must see!. This is used on virtually every segment ever shown on TV featuring Tokyo. I'd read the reviews on Trip Advisor and saw that the best view was from Starbucks. We grabbed some drinks and headed upstairs. I got a few good pictures. The best time of day is early or after 5 during rush hour. At these times there are a lot more people so the impact of large crowds crossing at the same time would be even more impressive. This is obviously popular and getting a seat next to the window for optimum viewing takes patience. Well worth a stop off.

The Best place in Tokyo for Shopping. One must visit this place once in Tokyo. Excellent vibrant life. So many restaurant, including a good Indian-Nepali restaurant just opposite to Miami Villa. So many good shops for buying Souvenirs.

Amazing. Two things about this place that absolutely blew my mind. 1) How ORDERLY this scramble is!! How so many millions of people can walk through without crawling on top of each other was unbelievable to me. 2) How CLEAN this place is! I was seriously looking - I couldn't find one piece of trash or rubbish on the ground anywhere. Absolutely spectacular.

Don't miss this!. I'd seen the crossing in various films so it had been on my bucket list for a while. It didn't disappoint. It was like organised chaos! We stayed for a while to film it and take in the atmosphere. Then crossed a few times of course. A must see/do if in Tokyo.

Fun to relax and see the scramble. As suggested by previous posts, we visited Starbucks to get a good view. We waited for tables nearer the window to be vacated, but the wifi was good and we didn't have to wait too long. It was interesting and nice to relax for a while
Must see. It was amazing to see how busy this crossing gets a night time. Definitely a must see if you are in Toyko.

Best in the rain. Shibuya crossing is always exciting to see and be a part of but it is especially so while raining at night. The reflection of the neon lights on the wet pavement with a massive wave of umbrellas crossing when the light turns green is simply spectacular. Try viewing from other locations beside the starbucks. The other tall buildings in the area will offer a less obstructed view.

Great and busy place. Our very favourite place and first place in Tokyo and Japan / except Airport of course /. We were soo amazed and nicely surprised about its spirit, amount of people and atmospere. We lived nearby so we were just walking around almost all the time. Definately must see place.

One for the Bucket List when in Tokyo. Amazing to see how many people transverse this set of crossings at the same time and respect the red/green lights. There are a couple of vantage places to view from but even just street level you get sense of the size of the crossing area. Next to the crossing is a number of shopping areas so is a way to do tourist thing, shopping and eat.

Good to see. Went to the strabucks which was a good view of the crossing but nobody left the window to let you get a good look. Grabbed a few cool pics over peoples shoulders as i'm tall. It wasn't rush hour but still a spectacular maze of people. Nice to say we crossed it too.
Wow. Very nice place where they have alot of Stuff. Hachiko status is there aswell. And alot of pedestrians walking. June 2016

Silly but fun act for tourists. Hundreds of pedestrians cross the cross roads at the same time when the traffic turns red. It is cute to do a quick video, strike a silly pose for a shot, and just follow the herds as they pass. The visit seems silly but it's a 'been there done that' kind of experience which you want to share to show that you have been initiated into the Tokyo lifestyle.

The hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Who would think that a crosswalk could be a tourist attraction. This is really something that every tourist in Tokyo should experience. Crossing the Shibuya pedestrian scramble makes you realize the immensity of this city. It's a little touristy but it will wow you, especially if you are from a small town.
One to see and experience.. This favourite symbol of Tokyo lives up to expectation, and lasts long enough for a pause to photograph mid-crossing. Get a view from above from Shibuya Station.

Fun place to see lots of people and some good shopping. Worth the stop when in Tokyo and fun to watch. Right outside the train station with lots of people and neat stores. Really pretty at night, too. Hachiko statue is also right there.

Insane. You have to be there in the middle of all this or see it with your own eyes to believe it. I used to live in NY and NYC crosswalks even during the rush hour are NOTHING in comparison to this crossing. I shot this photo from the train station. It was quite amazing to be there.

Must do when visiting Tokyo. This is a must do when visiting Tokyo. We've all seen it on tv but to experience it in person is really cool! We probably crossed 10 times (yes I know, we're silly!). Showed up around 6:30 and were able to score a window seat at Starbucks. As the sun dropped it only got busier and busier.
Interesting view. Great to see this iconic scene in person. Very similar to what you would see on TV or in movies. Many places to get a good view.

Has to be seen really. We headed to the scramble to see what you get a glimpse of so often in the movies. The first time we were there was the middle of a week day afternoon and I must admit I was a little disappointed. There just weren't enough people around to make it impressive. We did end up back in Shibuya on a Sunday afternoon a couple of weeks later though and it was much more like I expected - chaos! Get yourself up to the Starbucks (other overpriced mediocre coffee brands are available) for a good view.

Unique!. Shibuya is the party town. It is easy to get here. You just need to take the metro and stop at Shibuya station. There are several interesting sites to visit such as the Dogen-zaka with many art galleries, the Tower records, Bunkamura, etc. The crossing is unique. I have never seen such a crowded and at same time organized crossing. You have to walk and cross through shibuya and you should see the crossing from the second floor of starbucks.

Crazy doesn't begin to describe!. Walking toward the pedestrian crossing there were slowly more and more people walking. All of a sudden, I realized I was there and then the lights change and people were walking everywhere! I didn't wait to go to the second floor of Starbucks or any of the other restaurants nearby but it was an entertaining stop. Truly makes you appreciate how many people live in Tokyo.
As Crazy as You Expected. Whether you want to feel the city's pulse, see the variety of people, or get sensory overload of the sounds and neon lights, its a must see.

Not worth it. My husband was very keen to go to Shibuya to see this crossing as everyone had told him you had to go. We were there at 10.30 so not peak time and honestly folks its just a crossing. I saw busier ones in Shinjuku. Thankfully Shibuya is not that far from Shinjuku because I would not want to travel a long distance just to see this crossing. The streets around it a worth a look around.
The Busiest Pedestrian Crossing In The World. Nice scenery if you can stay on 1st floor of Starbucks (just nearby)...Crossing from Tokyu, JR Station, Shibuya Station and many moee...

Omg hectic!. Loved this crossing and regularly enjoyed ending up here! S much fun! We ran into the middle and rook touristy photos, nothing wrong with doing that. As long as you end up at Shibuya crossing, you will never be lost.
Silly . This is just a busy intersection. Do not go out of your way to see it but if you are nearby it's quite a scene with millions of people crossing every which way at once

Manic 😀. It's fun to enjoy a drink up in Starbucks or one of the other places which overlook the crossing and see the locals dashing across while all the tourists either wave up at you or try and take selfies before the lights change. Entertaining.

The Times Square of Tokyo. It's quite a sight to see so many people crossing the roads when the pedestrian lights turn green. Even more epic when it is raining and people somehow manage to weave in and out without colliding their umbrellas.

Fun!. Try to go on a Friday after work; it really is a sight. Also, if you like to take photos, sneak up to a high floor in the hotel right there (sorry, forgot the name, but I think it starts with an "S") and take a picture through a hallway window.
It's a really big zebra crossing.. Nothing too crazy happening here... rather on par to times square if it were in Japan. Plenty of other things to see in the area.

Perfect Timing. We made a special trip to see this and were not disappointed - especially as a Fire Engine attempted to cross with all sirens going when we were in the middle! This is great fun, we crossed over and then crossed back again just for the fun of it.
This is how i picture Tokyo. Title says it all I think. Lots and lots of people everywhere. This is one of the film locations for the movie "Lost in Translation".
Worth a visit!. Amazing place. Even on a Sunday I had similar experience at this intersection. Crossed this multiple times. I strongly recommend a visit.

A must see location for foreigners. Shibuya crossing connects the JR train and Tokyo metro stations with the shopping and nightlife areas of Shibuya. It’s known as a “scramble” crossing where all of the people cross either directly or diagonally from where they are to where they want to go. It’s very organized but it’s terrific for people watching. You can get an overhead view of the crossing from Starbucks or the department stores.

Iconic Place in Japan. The place you have to visit when in Japan, we visited Japan twice and we always took time to enjoy this intersection. The best place to see it is at Starbucks Cafe Tsutaya, especially in the Saturday afternoon.

a real scramble. We were just walking around Shibuya and the crossing is difficult to miss as there really are a lot of people all around, either crossing or just standing on the sidewalk.We were busy looking at google map and I didn't really get a chance to just take the scene in. Also, I didn't think of taking a picture right there as we already needed to cross the road.

Cross the scramble. So many people scrambling at any given time. Foreigners taking pictures while scrambling. Good to experience. Bere are many mini versions in shibuya..but nothing beats the main one at the station.

Just amazing . Only in Japan can you find an organized crowd. It's amazing how the streets fill up with people, and every time the crossing sign turns green a mass walks across Shibuya. And this happens every single time. You can observe it for hours!Both during the day and night, this place is never without people.Try to find a nice spot in Starbucks, probably the one with one of the best locations in the world, and enjoy your coffee while admiring this never ending flow of people.Definitely a mandatory stop while in Tokyo.

Just more people going more ways-with phones in their faces. It is probably worth is just because you can, but would not go greatly out of my way to see this intersection. If you there, slow down on a quiet corner (if you can find one), and just watch. Be sure to look up when you are in the area!
Worth watching later in the day.. It is worth going to the Starbucks on the corner, grabbing a coffee and doing a little people watching. Even better in the evening.
Obligatory point on the list!!!. Definitely this is one of the reasons to visit Tokyo! Shibuya has a lot to offer! Great restauranst, shops, people, lights and loots of fun!

Must See in tokio. Good view on the Masses from Inside JR Station, the starbucks Opposite Or the Café l occitane Provence. Best in the evening To See Japanese Street musicians and the billboard lights

Watched from Shibuya station second floor!. Makes a great time lapse video! So many people crossing at once, it's crazy. Guidebook said to watch from second floor Starbucks but the subway station second floor worked great and was free - and you can check out the "Myth of Tomorrow" giant mural painting in the station too!

Very cool!. This is something that just screams Tokyo to me!This famous crossing is just steps away from Shibuya station and quite easy to find. Sure enough, when the lights indicate you can walk, a sea of humanity just overtakes the intersection. They come from every direction in droves. Apparently, you don't even need to stay in the crosswalk lines, as people just walk thru the middle of the street to head towards their destination. After a few moments of somewhat organized chaos, the intersection clears out and traffic resumes! It's just as I had imagined it would be! lolThis is pretty much the way I found it to be like walking around various parts of Tokyo. Hordes and hordes of people walking very intently and aggressively to wherever they are heading towards! It just seems to be more "concentrated" at this intersection!Anyways, very cool to see and, anywhere you have a ton of people, the people watching is a lot of fun as well!
Amazing to see. I could see the pedestrians crossing from above and it was a unique sight to see as this was not available in all parts of the world.

A walk through city . At first I didn't even realise we were there until much later when my friend pointed it out. Amazing sight. Although I was told it would be more busy during weekends which I won't be able to witness.
Crazy. we visited at 9am, which was a little late for the true craziness of the crowds, but it was still very lively. Good shopping in the area, and reminded me a lot of times square.

Times Square of Tokyo. This is a very famous location in Tokyo and is a must see when there. Although it is very crowded there is no pushing and shoving, everyone is very mindful of not bumping into anyone else. There are loads of shops and restaurants in this famous location. Crossed it back and forth a few times, loved it.
Shibu-ya, not Shi-boo-yuh. Huge crowd scene like giant square dance do see do. Best at night on weekends. Walking as group street art. Good vantage point from upstairs at Starbucks.
People scramble!. People everywhere! It's is slow in the morning and busy at night. Starbucks close by. Always musicians playing on the street!
Over rated! . Expected a much bigger intersection but it was just like a normal crossing! Smaller and messy but most people cleared off into the train stations pretty quickly. Disappointed!

Shibuya Crossing. Usually you just see this on TV, but when you are there, and see the hundreds of people crossing this intersection at once you will be amaze. But aside from that, there many shops, and restaurants. But be sure to bring your passport with you, this way you will be able to get tax free when you shop 5000 yen and up.
Bustling crossroads. Crowds everywhere. Many large buildings with leading department stores. As in most Tokyo crossroads pedestrians can cross diagonally also.
Very fun and near studio 109. That one area of Shibuya sees way too many people each day! Visit Studio 109 for some amazing shopping.
New York-ish. At last...we were able to check out tokyos famous intersection. Very busy area. Some street performers were present when we visited the place. Nothing spectacular really.

A fun experience . This is a must if you're in Tokyo. Sure there are many other busy streets, but this is the one you've seen in movies and other depictions. Surprisingly it's not too hard to cross and sometimes people do silly things in the middle. At night and nearby there are plenty of things to do and listen to like local artists and pop up raves.
Just a crossing. Famous crossing, loads of people but nihing that spcial. Sill fun to see and take som pictures :) so, go there
Cross the road and then go somewhere else.. Lots of shopping I guess, but really, you see the crowd, cross the road and then are standing near mall or a train station.

Yep, scramble sums it up well!. A fascinating sight of a very busy road intersection which tests Japanese obedience to the limit! Close to Shibaya Station - the world's busiest railway station, there are always throngs of pedestrians who still amazingly manage to obey the red and green men when crossing the road!

You have got to go here. It feels like the epicentre of the civilised world when the Crossing lights turn to green and the whole world (well not quite) crosses the road together at what must be the most populated part of the world at that time. A lot of atmosphere and a little bit of history meet as you cross this road..Make sure you take a picture from the Metro station..WONDERFUL

If this is a scramble , Mumbai is a stampede!!. It's not a tourist attraction but something to experience in shibuya.. We were on a weekend'm but it was crowded.. V are from Mumbai. So crowd seemed v pleasant to ous.. Despite of d no of ppl everthing Moving smoothly like everthing in Tokyo.. Just d most amazing and we'll planned city in d world

People Watching At It's Best. On our recent trip to Tokyo we visited the busy Shibuya crossing. We grabbed a coffee in the Starbucks across the street and sat at the window and watched the hustle and bustle of the people go by. Worth a visit.

It's a crosswalk, not a tourist attraction. As many have mentioned, this is pretty much just a crosswalk. And don't be fooled by what you've seen in the movies or from the description here, it is not a scramble. Everyone is just walking in their own pace as normal plus some annoying tourist stopping in the middle taking picture of . . shock . . gasp! . . other people crossing a street.

There are many people!. Anyway, there are many people.
Will you go to all wherever?
It is hard to take the photograph here.
Amazing!. Amazing place specially for streetphotographer. You could see so many different character crossing the street a once! You could stand there for hours and won't get bored.
Underwhelmed. I thought it was bigger based in all the pictures I've seen online and in movies. Granted, I was in shibuya during weekdays but still! Was a little underwhelmed, sorry!

Shibuya Crossing. A must do when in Tokyo. It is just a crossing and there are many big ones in Tokyo so do not expect too much. However, it is rather fun to view. The Hachiko statue is located right by the crossing so go have a look at it too if you are here.

Spectacular view of Shibuya Crossing Street!!. My bus from Mt Fuji heading back to Shibuya around 6.30 PM and I guess want to check the famous Shibuya Crossing Street and woahhh amazed with what I saw at that night, when the traffic light turn green for pedestrians, so many people like they cross from everywhere..filled the street! Hahaha such a nice experience to see..I managed to be there for couple minutes, back and forth to see those scramble bunch of people..awesome! Taking photos in the middle of Shibuya Crossing also recommended to try :) not far from it you may also find Hachiko statue, something that you won't miss in Shibuya

Not so much a "scramble". Came here with my family expecting it to be super exciting and chaotic but turned out to be average. Yes there are lots of people crossing in every which way, but its no different than walking across any other street. Thinking about it now, what is so exciting about walking across a street? Anyway, we went to the starbucks to get a view of the crosswalks from the top. We had to wait for seating as there isn't much and people camp out in their seats for a long time. Anyways we watched the light turn green a few times and the sea of people cross but again, its just people walking across a street and some walk outside the lines which make it look more like a scramble. I guess its neat to say I've been there but really, all I did was walk across the street with a bunch of people.

A great place to people watch. The pedestrian scramble is a great place to people watch from Starbuck across the street. You'll be amaze are how many people are scrambling across the street before the light changes.

Unique experience..... ....that you cannot miss....is like a "movie"....perfect crossing....everyone walking, traffic lights change and everyone stops....we were lucky enough to find a bar right on the street where we sat down and saw the movement of Shibuya...spent a couple of hours watching everyone go by and sipping wonderful Japanese single malt...Dont miss Shibuya crossing!

Tokyo's Time Square. Not quite Time Square but with much more courtesy. Japanese people are so quiet, courteous and polite. I base this on up to 3000 people converging into the intersection at any one time. Two shares:1. Get a drink at Star Bucks and go up stairs at night time and look down on the coordinated chaos.2. Pay homage to Hachi and Google the story if you do not already know it.
Not as mad as you would expect. Worth seeing, experiencing, photographing and enjoying the orderliness of the crossing. Not really a scramble.

For best views, go to Hikari building. It's pretty difficult to get a good view of this busy intersection as a whole. The Hikari building is a short walk away and accessible free of charge. Take the elevator to the 11th floor and walk to the corner window for views of the intersection and the city.

Not exactly a tourist attraction but worth visiting. We went to the Shibuya Crossing one evening when the area is well lit up - was amazing to watch and be apart of the light change when hundreds of people cross in all directions, something to give you a proper 'Tokyo feeling'. If you think it's a bit of a waste to travel to the area purely for what is essentially a traffic junction, combine it with shopping or eating/drinking in the area - the streets are packed with all kinds of shops, restaurants and bars and is very lively at night.

Organized Chaos. This is everything I imagined. I was being knocked from every which direction. It felt like you just had to zig zag past a sea of people, but it was sort of fun. Even though it looks crazy, it somehow works for this intersection and that's what I love about it. A lot of people also sat at the Starbucks to watch the crowds from the second floor, but since it was so crowded, I went across the street to Loccitane. You can also get coffee there for about 700 yen, but no free wifi unlike Starbucks. But I prefer this over Starbucks since it's much less crowded.

Mesmerizing!. One of my favorite attractions in Tokyo! There are pedestrians coming from different directions and it is truly a visual feast. The area is so lively, a lot of people use the spot as a meeting place. There are street performers too. Try to visit at both night and day but if you only have time to check it at one time, go at night since the lights from the buildings and billboards are beautiful. Starbucks and L'Occitane Cafe would be a good place to see the crossing as a whole.

Busy busy busy. Omg. This place is so busy so it's great for people watching. The hachiko statue is in the square beside shibuyu. Just make sure you hold on to your friends so you don't get split up ;-)
goox experience. Interesting to watch and experience. You see this street scene in a lot of movies . Station nearby and bus station undergoing a lot of building.
So busy. This crossing is so busy. It is filled with people and shops. We crossed the road a few times and it was amazing. Japanese people are so polite.
Must experience . All I can say is WOW . People, people and more people . Came back a few hours later and was still the same . A must view for any Tokyo visitor

Great to see after sunset. We got off the train to have a look at the crossing, known from films/documentaries we have seen before. It is quite an impressive sight, I would recommend going after sunset, at night it looks even more fun, with the talking/singing/moving ads and lights adding to the commotion. Make sure to take your cameras!
Fun for people watchhing. Grab a coffee and sit and people watch. It's a very busy area and you are sure to see all types of people. If you enjoy people watching this is a good place to unwind.

Wonderful experience . Amazing and most complicated crossing I ever come across. My children and I were there during our March holidays.First time experiencing this crossing in front of Shibuya station .When the traffic lights turned 'RED' people rushing in all directions crossing the junction, making us so confused and ended up making another attempt to the right direction to view the statue of Hachiko - the faithful dog. Very touched story about Hachiko. Busiest scramble crossing I had experienced.Surrounded buildings are mounted with huge TV screens advertisement.Viewing from upper level, Chinese saying, "people mountain , people sea".Grab the opportunity if happen to be there in Tokyo, visit Shibuya.

Must see experience. I recommend being there for rush hour around 5-6pm. You can get really good photographs from the Starbucks right there on the 2nd floor. We went during the really afternoon hours and there weren't that many pedestrians in the area.

Pedestian Crossing Extrordinaire. We went out here on a whim after reading about it in Lonely Planet. When we got there, it had to be seen to be believed. At one point all the traffic stops and it is open slather for pedestrians. It is organised chaos. The best time to go is peak hour when all the people are emerging out of Shibuya Station.There are a number of small restaurants around the "square" which are very reasonable. There is even a Starbucks fronting the crossing.
Interesting!. It's quite interesting to see pedestrian walk across the zebra line from different direction! Lots of restaurant and shops here!

Just a busy area but good for shopping!!. Nothing special over there except for it has been used for movies always. It is not big area that you can find. However, very good for shopping. Millions of shops over there. My daughter 7 years old was not interested in it at all; on the other hand, my wife was very excited about shopping.

A must experience in Tokyo!. It is just an ordinary pedestrian crosswalk but the feeling of crossing one of the most busiest and famous crosswalk in the world(?) makes this experience truly worthwhile! It was fun doing this knowing that the some of the people around me has the same reason why I was there. The next time I will see this in movies, there will be a sense of pride as I experience what it likes to be there!

Orderly pedestrianised chaos!. Everyone's heard of this - yes it's just a crossing but it is so iconic a thing to do in Shibuya. Just join the crowds waiting for the lights and then walk across - don't think, just go with the flow and enjoy the organised chaos of the Shibuya scramble.
Fun. Funny to watch, especially when it is evening and extra busy. Interesting to see how during the daytime every pedestrian is waiting for the traffic lights to go green and the mass starts moving.

A Must Visit. It is my favorite spot in Japan. Everywhere I look, there are people around me. When the crossing lights turned green, everyone start to move..like the ants army. We can cross the junction in six different direction. Very fun ti watch.
A must see in Tokyo. It's really impossible to describe until you see it with your own eyes. A must do! Also, if you feel like a pro, try to take a picture of yourself while crossing :)

It's like an anthill. Shibuya crossing is unique in that it has pedestrian crossings that go through the middle of the intersection. That and the sheer number of people crossing during rush hour makes it special. But really it's just a crossing. The best view of this would be from the 2nd floor of the Starbucks. It's in the middle of the street you can miss it. Come at about 4 to 5 pm so you can see Rush hour, and be there for the lighting up of the neon signs in Shibuya.

Blade Runner-like Technicolor Experience. This is amazing to see with your own eyes. GO AT NIGHT. GO IN THE RAIN. Cross the street multiple times, zig zag and look up. I have attached a panorama photo, not sure if it will display in all its glory....a truly Tokyo experience.
Dante's Inferno. Kind of a nuisance.Go see the Hachiko statue at the west entrance to the metro. Hit every corner of the crosswalk and you'll find it.
Busy busy!!. Very crowded on Shibuya crossing. It is fun to see and picture this crossing. Love the shops and restaurants around that area too. A must to go and see by yourself when you go to Tokyo.
Make sure you see it from above. Either from the elevators in the Shibuya Tokyo Excel Hotel, or from Shibuya Hikarie building (11th floor)

Iconic but.... It's an icon of Japan. Everyone knows the pictures of the crossing. But that's all it is - a crossing. There is lots to do in the area though so it's worth stopping and checking it out. Try for peak hour if you want to see it really in action.

One of those things you just have to see. There are many examples of pedestrian scrambles in Tokyo, but this is by far the largest, noisiest, most photographed, and most fashionable of them all! From here you borrowed deep into the labyrinth of Shibuya youth fashion. Take a Valium and dive in!

A must-do because why not!?. It was definitely something to experience! The biggest scramble in the city is this one, located right outside Shibuya Station; you'll see people holding camera and phones as they prepare to partake in the crossing, so you can't miss it!Actually participating in the scramble isn't so bad; it just looks like a mess from a distance, but it's actually well spaced-out when you're crossing the intersection, so it's really not too different from any other street crossing. BUT! You still have to do it if you're in the area because come on, it's the most popular pedestrian scramble in the world!It's definitely more fun to watch than to partake, so I absolutely recommend sitting somewhere near for a few minutes to watch it happen; it's great fun!

Like in the movies . This place is crazy busy with it's hustle and bustle of just how you'd imagine it from the movies. Arrive, take some photos and the scramble across like everyone else. Don't forget to see the Hachiko statue.

It's cool, but just a big intersection..... I think I expected this to be a bit cooler, but it really is just a big intersection. You should still go and see the busiest crossing in the world, but don't get your expectations up too high!

Iconic. Easily one of the more recognizable spots of Tokyo, especially in movies and TV shows. The equivalent of Times Square. Very busy intersection, very vibrant feel. Try getting seats in the upper level of Starbucks for a good view of the scramble.

Amazing. Amazing experience with number of pedestrian moving at the same time. The good experience in Tokyo or perhaps Japan is you'll never get pushed or hit by the crossing pedestrian even thought it's crowded.

A must see. The Shibuya Crossing is a must see/experience. It's like thousands of people crossing at the same time. Enjoy the view from the metro station, Starbucks (cafe on 2nd floor) or L'Occitane (cafe on 2nd and 3rd floor).
The busiest intersection in the world.. Of course in Tokyo you need to experience the famous Shibuya scramble crossing. Pretty amazing experience.

Organize chaos. All races are here, this is like new york . But the difference here is the attitude of the people, they are warm. People who visited japan should visit shibuya and see the organize chaos of the pedestrian. A well disciplined people of japan
Multiple times. We stayed near by and wherever we went we crossed Shibuya crossing. It is always fun. Many people crossing the road, taking pictures. Very nice atmosphere.
Organized chaos!. DO NOT leave japan without seeing this! Go at night of you're able.. there's nothing like it. literally looks like ants!

The Times Square of Japan!. This is the iconic place in Japan often showed in movies and TV shows. The Pedestrian scramble is so busy and cool to watch. The Starbucks overlooking the square gives great views of you can get a window seat. During the day I didn't find it that busy, though we found that trying to go off course from the regular pathways across the scramble was super difficult. The busiest we ever saw it was on a Friday in the evening.

Fun place to see. Go up into the nearby Starbucks to get a great view of folks doing the famous Shibuya scramble. You might have to wait a little bit to get a seat at their windows but the view is worth it.

Simpl, fun, mad.. We came here in the evening and it is jut a mad pedestrian crossing. Something very different to experience. We got a table looking out onto Shibuya crossing in a 1st floor cafe and it was great. Very entertaining to watch.
A must see at Tokyo. Get off at the Shibuya Train Station and you can easily find this intersection. It's not as great as New York's Times Square but worth the experience :-)
Scrambled scram scrap scrambling. Pretty fun to watch. It's like a well ocristrated dance. Good place to watch from is the Starbucks on the north side. We also loved seeing the stachue of Hochiko.
A great experience. A must to do - be a part of crossing over and then find any coffee shops to watch others doing it. Unique and free and really is a spectacle.

Amazing sight. The reason this is unique because the sheer number of the people(few thousands at a time) crossing this Point in a short and fixed amount of time. Most of the pedestrians cross this junction as they have to get to the other side of this busy road but I have also noticed several tourists just crossing this junction for sake of experience. I hardly see anyone running into each other in spite of the enormous crowd crossing this place in a maze of multiple pathways. There are several Restaurants overlooking this crossing and many visitors just spend their time watching the crowd building up and crossing this place until it is empty for the vehicular movement. All this happen with the precision and discipline that people normally see in Japanese public attractions. Since it is so unique, I also notice a lots of people making videos of this amazing sight.

Over hyped. Ok, so there is a lot of people. That's about it. I don't understand why this intersection has become so famous. If you really want to experience it, you will need to sit in the starbucks and watch people cross the road for an hour. I'd rather do something else.

Neat to watch!. If you're in Tokyo and want to experience the rush of people, this is your place! We took the train here, went to a Starbucks in the second floor and watched & videotaped the mass below. The tour guide (from a previous tour) said there can be up to 3000 people that cross at every 30 second interval.

Just a hype, what still very impressive. Watch Fast and Furious Tokyo drift for example. The scene where they drift around that crossing splitting the crowd.Then walk over this cross diagonal and try to be in front. Don't forget to film this experience. It's incredible, how so many people can walk, film and still somehow manage to get through without pushing other people. We didn't manage to get a window seat at the Starbucks, but in the station you can get up to the first floor and what the whole scene from the window. Then you find out, that it looks way more chaotic from the outside than being on the cross yourself.

one hour walk at Shibuya. I remember last visit was Feb 2015, this time at May 2016 i was trying to search for the same bookstore i brought my notebook last year. I could find it as the streets are busy and not in parallel configuration, i eventually enter loft and find the same thing. Kill my time with a Ramen in the afternoon and night time had beers and bbq beef in the same area. Excellent to stay for days. If i bring my wife, she will be excited for shopping.

Ant farm on steroids . Highly recommend a visit when in Tokyo. I found walking the actual crossing a little overrated, but sitting at a nearby coffee shop and watching the crossing below is a great way to experience it. We were at Hoshino Coffee with lovely soufflé like cakes on the second floor. Cooked to order. It wasn't crowded with tourists and has bench seating facing the crossing. Great angle for time lapse videos too.
Heart of Tokyo. Walking across the Shibuya Pedestrian is a must-thing to do in Tokyo. I miss the scene, the people and the atmosphere in the area.

Lots of people crossing a street. It is satisfying to watch for a short time, but to me it isn't a must see.Unlike the other reviewers that suggest watching from starbucks (which i also did, but I could not get a seat let alone a good view), I suggest sitting on the balustrade behind the hatchi statue but close to the crossing. It is more immersive with the signs and ads playing and people rushing past.There is free wifi if you show your foreign passport at the information desk and other locations.
Crazy crossing . This crossing is the typical Tokyo scene that I'd seen in all the guide books. Somehow it doesn't feel as chaotic as you'd expect. Definitely a sight to be seen.

Fun to watch and to cross this intersection!. Learnt from many magazines and blogs that this is one of the fun things to do in Tokyo. It is also quite entertaining to watch people crossing the street at this intersection, especially from the upper floor of Starbucks Coffee. Also, please ensure that you have your VDO camera ready and ask your friend to film you while crossing the street from Starbucks. Good fun!Around this area, there are a lot of good malls, café and restaurants and a walking street for you to explore as well.

Pedestrian Scramble: Fun way to spend 30 mins. The Shibuya Pedestrian scramble is best viewed from 1st floor Starbucks and best also to go at peak hour for maximum effect. If you can get someone to video or photograph you walking across even better. Around here is a good shopping district so this is a nice diversion and probably something you are unlikely to see anywhere else. Worth a look.

Be part of it and check it out from afar. After we checked out the statue of Hachi at the Shibuya subway station, we experienced the nearby Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble. It was busy and crazy at the same time.Then we went to the second floor of nearby Starbucks to check it out from a different angle.

The Busiest Street in Shibuya. This six street intersection is no doubt the busiest intersection in Tokyo Shibuya area. I am amazed on how people whould cross at the same time. Its more amazing during rush hour when people are literally shoulder to shoulder while crossing this busy street. My wife told me about this because she has seen this intersection before so I was kindda curious about it. Again, just like the hatchiko statue, if you are expecting something phenomenal, then dont bother to come and see this. If you hate the crowd, then stay in your hotel.I love crowded areas. I love to bump bodies with people so this was an exhilirating experience for me. I even attempted to cross this intersection myself. Hahaha!Its something different to see especially if you come from a quiet province that has only a few thousand people.

Crossing. Busy crossing streets, all crossing at one time. Very interesting sights. Actually just to see the crossing. After all there is nothing more besides nearby are many shopping places and foods restaurants
Fun n easy. You will spot the tourists - thats us standing in the middle of the crossing with cameras while the locals try to get past! Good easy fun, and in the middle of more shopping.
CRAZY CRAZY. make sure you go at peak hour so you can fully understand how busy it gets! Grab a starbucks coffee and sit and people watch all afternoon!

Heavy traffic but no traffic jam. There are alot of people crossing the roads, but they are so organized. It's oddly satisfying to watch the cross, as you'll find interesting motion patterns of people.

Not as busy as you'd think. If you're going, suggest watching from the Starbucks 2nd floor window. Great view...
Yes, there were lots of people, but ultimately I think a large portion were tourists just there to photo/video. If you want to see some real action, hang out in Tokyo Station midday during Golden Week. Puts Shibuya Crossing to shame.

Craziness!. It is amazing how many people cross at each light. Do yourself a favor and try to snag some seats at the second floor Starbucks (order on the first floor to get your drink) for excellent people watching.
Tokyo attraction. If you're in Shibuya you must swing by this iconic location. Only a short walk from the JR station it'll provide a great photo opportunity any time of the day.

The look of Tokyo. Hop off the train at Shibuya Station, Hachiko exit. Cross the street. Or just watch people do it. Stare at the giant video screens (running ads, I guess) and neon. If you've met someone at night, wow, Hachiko statue is a lovely meeting point. Who is Hachiko? I had no clue.
Amazing. Never seen so many people crossing a street without walking into each other. Great view of the crossing from Starbucks

Busiest crosswalk. There is not much to say about it. If you are in tokyo don't miss the chance to go here and maybe cross a few times. In busy hours the crowd of the crossing people is just amazing. Watching the flow of crossing people is showing the real overcrowded face of Tokyo.
One Word - WOW!!. The Shibuya Scramble is amazing. I went there at night and there were lights and people everywhere. I guess every visitor to Tokyo should not miss this.

Thought it would be crazier. We came here in April during the afternoon and we felt that the crossing would have been more hectic and crazier. Nonetheless, we still had a good time and can check it off our list. We do love the Shibuya area with the various shops and restaurants. It's also a great place to people watch.
