Selfie sticks crossing. Another tourist hot spot in which people cross with a selfie stick in hand. Good to join the crowd but make sure not to lose your friends. I had my gang separated as we were too excited and didn't discuss which direction to go beforehand.
Lively. I love to see the people start to cross all over the direction when the light turn green. We took picture for the crossing and feel very lively and energetic. It make you feel 'excited'.

Always entertaining to watch for new trends. Great place to people watch, from locals to tourist. Get the scoop for the latest trends and then explore the shops to create your own the bring back home. Don't be afraid the explore side streets and explore all the buildings and floors, you may find that unique item to complete your outfit.
Hectic at night. You can enjoy the shibuya crossing conveniently at the starbuck on second floor. but if you want to experience the hectic crossing you have to come at night.

Shibuya Crossing. Crossed it twice! Once in the evening and afternoon but evening is more dramatic with all the neon lights flashing. Crowd is even bigger at nighttime -mostly young crowd. It's nothing fancy but the experience of joining the crowd is fun! Try it at least once just for the heck of it!

Fascinating. Been here several times and always been fascinated by this organised chaos and the amount of people ready to cross. If you have a camera try to get a good pic before and during the crossing. There are a couple of good spots at the first flor of the train station. If you are going to meet someone the best place is outside the Starbucks after the crossing..
Shibuya Crossing. I've always wanted to experience crossing the street "the Shibuya way" ^^Finally got the chance to. No need to worry about pick pockets despite the crowded place

Oh, is this it? . After all the hype we were mightily let down. It was busy, but quite frankly there are busier crossings just up the road. Good view from the Starbucks but nothing to get excited about

Very touristy but entertaining. If you want to get a good view of the crossing, head across the street to the double story Starbucks - for the price of a drink you can get a seat facing the window to see the lights changing. It's very touristy but fascinating to observe.

Japans Oxford Circus. Its just a big crossing. Lots of people. But I've definitely been across more chaotic crossings in New York and London. I think this place is unique but I can't figure out why. Like others say... go for a starbucks and people watch. That's all there is to it.
Tons of people. It lives up to the hype. There are just tons of people walking in all directions. You better keep moving or you'll be run over! Lol

Amazing number of people. So here we are. The famous shibuya crossing. You can see a lot, i mean a lot of people crossing the streets. No direction required hahaha while seeing lots of led screen and ads.

Busy pedestrian crossover. Enjoyed and spend for my lovely afternoon to see such as busy pedestrian crossover to each direction at Starbucks. But, difficult to get the best view seat at Starbucks unless you willing to wait.
Iconic. The Shibuya crossing is iconic- come here on your first trip to Tokyo. Be prepared for the huge swell of crowds!

Ants... And more ants. So cool! People everywhere and then it's cleared. Then once again there's people everywhere.
I sat on Starbucks watching this cool place.
crowded place. Crazy and crowded place. The best way to see it, is go there, cross the streets and run to subway. Thousands of people on a giant zebra crossing. Sights and quick escape.

Chaotic beauty. It's very very crowded but that's what makes this crossing special. We watched a few crossings, participated in some (just crossed the road and see where which corner we ended up in), giggling like mad and took photos right smack in the centre (don't worry, the crowd will make way). Worth a see!

Visit at dusk/evening. Ah, the famous shibuya scramble. It might only be a scramble, but there is always a reason why anything got famous. This scramble is a pedestrian cross connecting shibuya station and the shopping district. Needless to say, it is very crowded on rush hour. That said, unlike most zebra cross in the world, this scramble looks organized and choreographed. With hundreds of people crossing both ways, it is surprising that no one bumped each other. You can come here at noon and get a clear shot of hachiko close to the station and the crossing, but in the evening this place truly comes to life. Get a clear view of the whole scramble from a starbucks store above; just look up and you'll see it.
Super Busy Area. This famous crossing is great to see in person and very easy to access with it being right outside the stayion, though be warned it is always incredibly crowded.

A cheap thrill. Really cheap - just walk across the street. Lots of photo opportunities of tourists taking photos. Kind of fun when a car gets caught int he crowd, or when someone on a bike tries to zoom across before all the pedestrians. But honestly, lots of other more fulfilling ways to kill an hour in Tokyo.

Could not believe my eyes.. This really is worth seeing. My daughter explained about the crossing and that it featured in a film. You really have to see it to believe it. There were people crossing in all directions.

It's a scramble!. Loved going through the crowd morning, noon or night. There are mini scrambles in other parts of Shibuya but this one is the best.Where's the best spot to see this - right smack in the middle of the street or sit at the Starbucks right at the corner.

Do it - but it is just a crossing!. Our guide took us here as we requested. He couldn't understand what the fuss is about. That said it's free, it's fun and a bit daft to visit a pedestrian crossing. Were not as many people as expected, and something that is better done at dusk / night - may add some more atmosphere.There's a statue of a dog close by with a touching tale of faithful devotion to his owner - worth a look and a photo too.

Best spot to view Tokyo crowds. Every day, nearly 3 million people cross this street. Watching the mayhem happen is entertaining. Best viewing spots are at street level near the Hachiko dog statute or in the Starbucks overlooking the intersection.

People everywhere. We actually went two times to Shibuya in our short stay in Tokyo. There are a lot of people and a lot of shops, so we came here for shopping. It is also beautiful to be here in the evening as the street will be lit up with all the lights from the different shop signs.
A Tokyo must see. If you go to Tokyo you must check out this classic spot. You can also take a picture with Hachiko, and do some quality shopping!

Impressive!. Crowded, crowded, crowded and more crowded! So crowded that is beautiful that still work without accident diary.Wait to the light stop and take pictures or record one of the most interesting videos of your life!
Got to do!. Ok so its just a crossing but its world famous and a real must do when you're in Shibuya. Its good to just watch it a couple of times, it looks so beautifully choreographed.

Just walk.. We are quite lost when walking out from the Shibuya station.But we manage to find it. And we walk the Shibuya crossing. Not too crowded. Mayb due to the timing. Yeah, took some picture and tat's all. Just like that. We just randomly walk in some malls inside and spend like 2-3 hours at Shibuya.

don't miss this!. We went there at night and the pedestrian crossing looked mad! Although it was 11pm, there was still a lot of people crossing over from every direction. We followed the crowd like lemmings because we were confused where to look LOL. Shibuya is the place for the professional working class shopping area. Lots of place to go eat as well - spoilt for choice in fact.
Have to be seen !!!!. Have to be seen !!!!You should not miss this spot. It is the world's most busy Pedestrian crossing. One of the most popular areas of Tokyo.

Only in Tokyo. Definitely worth finding a perch and watching the chaos. The Starbucks coffee offers a good vantage point from the second floor, otherwise find a good spot on the street corner and snap some great shots. Plenty of eateries, cafes and shops nearby.
A must-do. Funnily enough, one of the best things to do in Tokyo is cross the street. It's amusing to watch the people do their impressions of ants.

いつの間にか観光名所. When you'd like to take a picture by the viewpoint you are walking, the ground is good.
But when you'd like to take a picture of person's flow, I recommend Ginza Line ticket gate floor .
朝から外国人観光客の方がいますが、夕方以降は撮影のために大勢集まっています。
いつの間にか交差点が観光名所になっていました。
歩いている視点で撮りたければ地上が良いですが、人の流れを大きく撮りたいならば、銀座線改札フロアがオススメです。
真上から撮影できます。

Shibuya Pedestrian crossing is a must see when in Tokyo!!. When you visit Shibuya, you have to watch the pedestrian crossing --quite a spectacle!! The best view is from the pedestrian over-pass walkway!

Fun and vibrant crowded but organized. Shibuya crossing can be daunting for first timers but after a while you get the drift and follow the crowds criss crossing the streets from one end to the other. Can be fun and indeed very organised. Lots of shopping in the area like the shibuya 109 mall

It's worth seeing in real life. This is the street crossing so many people have seen in so many pictures from Tokyo. It is fun to see it in real life. If you don't go there, there is a fair chance you'll regret it after leaving Tokyo.
Organised Chaos . What else would yoy expect from the brilliantly organised Chaos that is Tokyo. We were here with our 7 year old and 9 year old kids and what a spectacle to watch.

Don't follow the hype train. This is a nice place, a great place to start your adventure into Shibuya, but I don't know why it's such a known attraction for tourists. I would recommend it if you're not used to placed with a lot of foot traffic, but if you're used to traveling in a city then it's not too major. Still a cool spot though, no complaints. Just don't understand the 'Hype'.
very crowded. the famous shibuya crossing. its amazing to see it for the first time but its too crowded. but its still nice to take pictures and make some videos
Fabulous at night - pat Hachiko the dog for luck!. I would recommend visiting at night as the neon aspect is magnificient. Don't forget to stroke the statue of Hachiko the dog for luck.

Go with the Flow.... Went on a Saturday. It's a massive wave of humanity, but fun to experience for a moment. As the crowd builds to cross the street, you can't change your mind on your intended direction!
famous crossing. this famous crossing is always full of people, no matter what time you go there, plus many shops and restaurants around

Not as big as I'd thought!!. Another must see/do in Tokyo, although much like times square NY, ALOT smaller than its made out to be. Still, pretty crazy the way everyone legs it across the road from all directions when the lights change, think was the only time we saw anyone move quickly in Tokyo at all!!!

Not much to do. It was so windy on Shibuya that night. So many people walking around fast. And, well actually there were not much thing to do on Shibuta. It is just a famous intersection that you have to check from your tokyo checklist. made some video there, and went home :D

Tokyo in a nutshell. Best time to visit Shibuya is after dark. Then you can enjoy all of the lights and musinc. However, be prepared to leave quite fast. The street is extremely noisy and after a while you have enough of all the sounds. Take a walk from Shibuya metro station to the end of pedestrian walk. Go for a beer or nice dinner in one of plenty bars and restaurants. Just by the entrance to the metro you can look for Hachiko dog statue - Hachiko used to come to the station every day to greet his master. When the master died, Hachiko kept coming to the station for many more years. It's easily found, if you are coming from the station, it's on the left.

Suprisingly serene to watch. Simply marvelous to watch. Getting a decent vantage point was hard, walked into a cafe that gave us a window seat but you are paying a premium for the view. Still worth it. It's a testament to the japanese culture and adherence to the rules of the road. Everything seemed so seemless and peaceful.

Just plain fun!. I've walked across this scramble crossing about ten times over the past few days and it's always mindblowing just how many people are there at any time of day! Definitely worth a look if you're close to Shibuya!

If you must, visit Hachiko as well. If you've semi-decided that you need to see this famous crossing for yourself, then why not pop by to say hello to Hachiko as well. It's less than 50m from the crossing, just outside the Tokyu Dept Store exit of the Shibuya station. The statue is.... A little dog statue..... Not particularly impressive, but the story behind it is touching. Shibuya crossing, to me, is just a big city pedestrian crossing, lots of people, but I wouldn't have known it's that special had it not received so much mention. Shibuya itself is worth a walk-around, so if you're there, may as well have a look at the famous crossing for yourself and decide if it is as noteworthy as rated.

See it to believe it. I have to admit, being from Tokyo this doesn't seem that crazy, but having lived in other countries as well I know you'll likely never experience anything like this anywhere else. There are people everywhere going every direction. It's crazy, and it lasts about ten seconds. If you're in the area, go. I wouldn't make a special trip just to see the crosswalk though.
Exactly what you think . Shibuya is exactly what you think and have heard. It is crazy! Soooooo crowded and chaotic. It doesn't matter the time or day, it's always super busy.

The Million crossing you dont wan to miss. Shibuya crossing is one of the most famous attractions in Tokyo city , crossing the riads ehere thousand of people cross with you, is an amazing experience to have in Tokyo . The wide road with breath taking skyscrapers. Something very unique.
Fun to walk. Getting a decent picture is quite the challenge. But you aint alone (you could see tourists with selfie sticks) Joining in the scramble is fun.
having fun while crossing. This is an interesting area, you will wonder how so many people move together crossing the street and tourists having fun doing it.

Worth a look. We didnt go at rush hour but the crossing is still busy through the day, and you can get decent photos from the train station building. If not theres a couple of eateries that have a good view. Take a time lapse video of people crossing and explore the rest of the area.Hachiko statue is right next to the crossing, but its very popular and difficult to get good photos without other people being in them. Might be better visited very early in the morning, then going for breakfast at one of the places overlooking the crossing and waiting for the rush hour to start. Be aware of the time limits in these places though.

Shibuya crossing. When I went to Shibuya, this is one of the must see. Shibuya crossing was amazing because even though people from different direction cross the area they weren't bumping into each other. Well, that's for me was fun to watch and experience.

Spectacular. It is worth making an extra trip just to see this zebra crossing, (these zebra crossings) The sheer number of pedaestrians is mind boggling. At night with the lights on all around it is even more impressive. We bought a drink at Starbucks so we could look over the crossing from the first floor but it was not worth it as lots of others had the same idea and it was more fun on the pavement anyway. Amazing the lengths some tourists go to to get original videos, definitely worth watching:). The noise level was remarkable also. If here one should get a glimpse of Hachiko outside the station, That was the faithful dog who waited every day at the station for his master until he died 8 years later. Therre is a sweet film with Richard Gere about him. The atmosphere all around Shibuya is not to be missed

Its fun to go there. One of the biggest pedestrian crossings ive ever seen...the place is surrounded by lots of shops and restaurants...but the real fun was watching the people crossing...its amazing how in one minute...all those crowds simply disappear and the pedestrian is empty for cars again...

One and only on this planet!. This is a street crossing with may be 6 streets joining at one intersection. The traffic light will allow pedestrian to cross in whichever direction at the same time with no car traffic at this time. You will see all the people crossing whichever way. One estimate I read, there could be 3000 to 4000 people or more crossing this intersection at the same time. We went during the afternoon rush hour. Wow! Very impressive.

A Citys a City. Not sure why so many of my friends recommended me this particular crossing. Yes it was pretty interesting to see the masses from the starbucks at the top. But really its just another pedestrian crossing. If anything the Hachiko Statue is more meaningful than this pedestrian crossing.

Huge X pedestrian walk. Right after you go out Shibuya station you can see this huge pedestrian walk in X form. It`s impressive to see how Japanese people are organized, the place is crowded but you don`t get bumped by others.Go ahead and cross it, it`s really funny!

Just like new york time street. A very busy street. Full of lights and so many people walking eventhough its already around 11pm. It is near hachiko so might as well visit the area. Its like a small new york times street.
cool but overhyped. It was amazing to see all the people cross safely at the intersection. Not the highlight of our trip, but certainly fun to participate.

Must-do for every 1st time visitor . This famous crossing is bustling! Especially during peak hours and weekends. One must take a photo of and in this crossing. You've not experienced Tokyo and it's high density population until you go on this crossing, at peak hours.
The Hachiko statue is also at this crossing, just in front of the station exit.

Not of Everyone. On a Saturday this place was a zoo. Granted, I don't love big crowds and don't go to Costco on the weekend. It was amazing to see all the people, but after a few minutes, I needed out and we headed to Yoyogi park. Much more my pace!

Organised chaos!. Omg this place is crazy! When the pedestrian lights are red it is like the calm before the storm... Once green it's a ducking and diving dash to the other side! Well worth a visit just for the sights tho definitely not for those hating crowds... Like my husband for example... :)
Done it. . Not my kind of thing. But when in Rome :) Not for people who hate crowds. Rush hour might not of been the best idea also. But a life experience you should try while in Tokyo.
busiest crossing ever. It was unbelievable to see. There were people everywhere.Thousands of people crossthat pedestrian cossing every 6 minutes. Great view from starbucks

This is Tokyo. Shibuya and Shibuya crossing are THE places to be if you want to experience the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. It is really no other place i have visited. Immense crowds and music blasting everywhere you go. You may have seen the crossing on TV or in video games, but to experience it first hand is something else. The closest thing to a human Ant farm you can get. Shibuya itself is a shopping paradise with loads of department stores, boutiques and second hand shops, as well as great places for gifts like Tokyu Hands and LOFt. I had to come here 3 times to explore it all.

Watching Waves of People on the SHIBUYA Shores. Across from the station, you'll see a Starbucks on the second floor. Order coffee at the downstairs station and take the escalator up. With time and patience, maybe you can score a seat at the bar along the window, and watch the repeating waves of humanity at Shibuya Crossing. You might also see & hear one of the huge trucks advertising new releases by pop groups...you'll definitely hear them at street level outside. The Tsutaya store features CD's and soundtracks like the Tower Records of old...but Tower on steroids.

It's a busy intersection.. Meh.... It's a busy intersection. Part of me thinks I should've gone up to the Starbucks and videoed everyone crossing it in time lapse mode, but I'll live.We went, we walked and we can say we did it but I wouldn't worry if you don't make it there.

Only Good for Picture Purposes. Seems like most of the people crossing the street are just tourists. Nothing really interesting about the place but it is good for a great Instagram photo or Facebook profile picture.

Impressive but not as much as in movies!. Shibuya crossing is huge and huge crowds are indeed crossing in all directions, even in diagonals, but it looked smaller than what I expected. It is funny how movies distort our vision of real things! Nevertheless it is worth seeing it.I would advice to first see it from up and then do the experience of crossing with the rest of the crowd. Good experience! Do not miss it, as it is located in an area full of good restaurants (some with no English menus probably...).
Well worth witnessing. Very busy, very active, even late night during the week. Good for photographing locals and long exposure shots, even in the rain.

Craziness personified. We visited in the evening and it was still a mad scramble. When everybody starts walking from every which direction, we almost forgot which direction we were walking. That being said, completely worth it. It is such a fun part of town and it feels unique.

Fun.... Love shibuya, perfect place for photographers. It is so crazy at rush hour but somehow it works. Shibuya district is a fun place to walk around , also has some great lively bars and restaurants.
wow. Amazing place to see such a huge amount of people crossing the street when the light turns green. Very crowded
Busiest crosswalk!. I have never seen a busier crosswalk than this one. It was quite a sight! As soon as the light changed, everyone was crossing from all directions.

Take a video and go with the flow . This is definitely something to do when in Tokyo!This is one of the busiest pedestrian crosswalks in the world! People are going all sorts of directions!Walk fast and don't stand still and get in people's way. It's neat to go through it a couple times and that's all you need. You can get a overhead view from Starbucks or other surrounding stores in the area.
Many People. It is fun to walk in the middle of all these people. Go to Starbucks get a coffee and watch everyone running around. It makes you see how insignificant you are but in a positive way.

Nothing like I have seen before. Also called Shibuya Crossing is nothing like I have seen before. We went on a Sunday night and it seemed like the whole of Tokyo was there- A lot of people (but not an unruly crowd) walking in all directions to cross the intersection. Shibuya Crossing is right outside the Shibuya Station making it very convenient to get there. One other way to enjoy Shibuya crossing/and people watch is to have a Starbucks coffee and look out the window to get a get a decent view.

Funny but not attraction. Sure it's really busy and the first time there it will feel a bit overwhelming. But in the end it's just a crossing with a lot of people. Have a coffee across the road and enjoy the view if you happen to be there but don't go specifically to see this. Also don't be one of those guys who stop in the middle to take a picture.

Crazy but Exciting. I was there at peak hour and watching the masses waiting at each set of lights looked like a horse race ... on your marks get set go. The photo on trip advisor doesn't do this any justice - it's better to be there and experience this. Shibuya is a great place to visit and soak up the culture of busy Tokyo - hundreds of shops, screen displays and food!!

Shibuya pedestrian scramble . Yes this place is quite a scramble of people. It is truly remarkable to see hundreds of people scramble across in every different direction to the other side of the street. If you have little ones, hang on tight to them. If one gets lost, it is virtually impossible to locate them again so plan a spot where you meet anyone should get separated. It was fun to sit on the side and munch on food from family mart and people watch. There's every kind of people there.Totally fun but not a whole day trip. But a must see for sure !

If you like crowds.... ...this is THE place to visit! Reputably the busiest crossing in the world - and when you see it this is not a claim with which you would argue - crowds waiting for the traffic lights to change look for all the world like runners at the start of a marathon! Loads of shops and stores for the serious shopaholics. At night this place turns into a wonderfully bright and glitzy place with a fantastic array of lighted signs. Don't forget your camera!
Scramble For Sure. This place is a madhouse. As an entrance into the Shibuya shopping district and right outside the massive Shibuya station, it's a must see.

People watching!. Best to get pics of the crossing is at the station just before the hachiko exit. It is where you'll see the real action. So nice to witness how fast and alert people are when crossing. Also nice to see a tourist staying at the middle of the crowd not moving but just taking video.

It was fund to sit in Starbucks and overlook the organised mayhem. It was good to see something which is paraded in the media as a 'one off'. The area travels from watching traffic negotiating the junction to lights changing and then throngs of people use different crossings in their thousands. If you are in the area it is an experience but you can see it on u-tube, I believe.

Good to join in and view for free from above. Its free, its fun and you can cross from whatever direction you fancy pretty much!. Its something you need to be involved in and take a look at. Easily located from the metro station and if you take the wrong exit you will soon find it. Avoid the Starbucks and cross over to the shopping centre then go up to the walkway floor and take your overhead pictures for free.

Exciting place!. Really exciting place with lots of energy! Loved staying at Starbucks and people watching from there. This must be one of the greatest and famous crossings on the planet. Many nice shops around and huge variety of people!

Interesting and exciting at the same time. We took the train from Shinjuku to Shibuya since we already bought a 14 days JR East Pass Tohoku which we can use in any 5 days. The station in Shibuya is right at the wellknown Shibuya Pedestrian Crossing where the movie Fast and Furious scene took place. We got there around 5PM right about then all the neonsigns were turned on and bright and lively. The infamous Hachiko dog statue was right at outside of the station.Food outlets so many to choose from made us confused. Prices were very reasonable and cheaper compare to Singapore but Indonesia is much cheaper. Shops were all over the place.

Weird but Very Entertaining / Shibuya Pedestrian Crossing. Very entertaining experience in Shibuya, you just can come and go several times just to enjoy the experience. This is truly a very iconic place in Japan, seen in magazines, movies, comic books (both American and Japanese). Shibuya is big, so get ready to spend at least 4 hours in this area. Recommended for first-time travelers (selfie-video) and pictures.
Interesting to visit. Very crowded but very interesting place to visit with lots of things to see,buy and eat around.Good place to take pictures

The crazy scramble!. What can one say about this world famous crossing? One has to be part of the crowd to witness mad scramble! Its amazing how people do manage to get to the ends they need to get to and life goes on just like normal after the "scramble"! its busy, lively, colourful and so full of energy.

Coffee Scramble. It's difficult to get a seat at the Starbucks facing the scramble but there's a good chance this place would be less crowded later at night. It's a a nice place to watch the people go by but there are less troublesome places to stay at with a decent view.

Get lost in the crowd... I enjoyed the scramble so much!!!! It was amazing to see so many people crossing the crosswalk in five different directions. There are crossing guards on the corners to control the flow. This was the coolest thing to do and see. If you are from New York, you probably will not be impressed.

Worth to see the madness. It's great to just be at that crossing since it's so famous, thousands of people crossing the intersection, knowing exactly where they're going. I'm sure it is nice at night too, but it was great to be there at morning rush hour. The best observation spot is at the Tsutaya Starbucks. Some reviewers mention that they don't let you take pictures, we didn't encounter any and were able to take pics and film while we enjoyed breakfast, but mind you, we were there on a weekday morning when the Starbucks wasn't too crowded.
Oh my.. people. What a place to see..... a mass movement of people in such a small amount of time. Only watched from building which was enough.

Wasn't as busy as we expected.. While it was a sight to see it wasn't as chaotic as we anticipated. It was a very orderly scramble, especially when you compare it to others throughout the wold. We liked the feeling of the night scramble more than the day one with the billboards really lit up and music blaring from everywhere adding to the experience.

Fun to watch!. It's not Time Square but is pretty neat. We got coffee and roll at Star Bucks across the square and watch for awhile. Fun to see everyone going about their business. Must see if your in Shiybua City.

What can one say - unique!?. You have to be there to feel the buzz and the run of all pedestrians walking in different directions! Sure you'll film, you'll take photos and most of all you'll remember it forever! Crazy!!!

Shibuya crossing!. A must to take photos in the middle of the crossing as this is what all tourists will do when they are in Shibuya! :) i even saw a couple taking their wedding photos over at the shibuya crossing. One thing to note is that you must be fast as when the pedestrian are crossing, they might knock onto u

Enjoy and study what Japan just now especially young Japanese are.. I'm sure you can study good Sociology field work/gain good knowledge if you watch peoples crossing the scramble carefully for a while.
Crossing peoples are different from NY/ London /Paris or Jakarta.
Take care for their clothes/ not hit other peoples /quiet,crossing point are clean and peoples rushing /have good relations with police officers. Enjoy watching!
Interesting if you are in Shibuya. Not a standout Tokyo attraction, but if you are nearby it is worth stopping by to watch the crowds, the upstairs Starbucks was a great location to view the swarm.

Free Fun if you are in Shibuya. This is not something I would go to Shibuya just to do but if you are there it is great fun to experience the scramble and to people watch. Make sure to visit the famous status of Hachiko and they have an awesome Tower Records not far away too. Plenty of places to eat and shop. Note: Some people mentioned taking pictures from Starbucks. They do not allow photography at that Starbucks so you should not be taking pictures from it. They will say something if they see you doing it and have some signs up.

Famous scramble in the world. This pedestrian is located at Hachiko Square in Shibuya. Hundreds of people cross for each signal change where all vehicles come to a stop.One need to witness this especially during the office rush hours.

Been there, done that !. Even after seeing it countless times in movies/TVs, it is still an amazing experience to be part of the rushing crowd.Night times are better in my opinion - the digital boards around make for a sublime effect.Don't forget to visit the Hachiko statue while you are there :)

Spectacular. Really fun to walk around the area - endless shops and restaurants. Neon lights everywhere, a lot of people, and watching the crossing from Starbucks is really fun and a must-do activity.

Ton of Fun. I'm 66 and I had a blast watching the crowds and walking the streets of Shibuya. It's colorful and a fun place to spend an early evening. It's busier than times square. It's fun walking around the area with it's narrow streets and neon lights. They have speakers blasting music all over the area. It' worth a few hours hanging out in the area.

People watching and shopping. A lot of shopping to do and a few nice restaurants in the area. Keep in mind that the majority of the shops seems to be directed at teenagers. There is a fairly large Uniqlo nearby which was also fairly good and more suitable for all ages. Not too many designer brands around, if you are interested in that sort of thing try going to Ginza as well. The crossing itself is not that spectacular but still it's something you should experience if you are in Tokyo.

For your insta-worthy photos. Photo tip: Go into to starbucks in Tsutaya CD shop for best photo-taking views (2F) and even from the ground floor where you place your order. Do patronize them for a cuppa coffee too! They have some interesting flavours sometimes. If it rains don't worry, you get a cool shot of all the umbrellas.

Disappointing. I was so excited to see this spot and to be honest I was totally disappointed. It is amazing how many people are there but I really didn't understand why, theres nothing there. No restaurants, no bars and the shops were closed- totally bizarre.

So much fun. Ok so it's just an intersection with stores around, but it is so much much fun to see so many people cross at the same time in total controlled chaos. You have to see it, try to come at night, bigger crowds and the lights take it to the next level.

I like to play swim against the current . Is great to have a smoke next to the dog waiting for no one. Is better to see the young people hanging out do in nothing but is better to see the swarm of people and walk against the current. This place is what outsiders think of Tokio.. at least is what I was thinking.
Just crossing with people. Nothing special. Just people and people on crossing. There is Hatchiko (dog) monument near crossing. There are many shop for shopping around.

Good way to feel the crowd of shibuya. I was feel amazed & excited when i got here..
there is something different about this place..
So crowded!
So lively!
If you only see this street on movies and you think it's amazing.. then wait until you get here!!
Worth seeing! . The best time to see the crossing so far has been on a Friday evening, it's like a moving sea of people! Sums up Tokyo and is an iconic sight.

Busy, Busy and Busy.. It was busy, busy and busy. But it was a great experience to get at the most busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. Just walk at the pedestrian crossing at Shibuya is an experience, of course you thing there is a potential for a bit of human collision, but for some strange reason, it all runs so systematically and ordered and no one hits you.
Wow what a sight!. A must see spot for those who love big cities. I've never seen a diagonal crosswalk before. Watch the scenes at night and then grab food in the Hikarie building.

summed up tokyo. Met an old japanese man on the train who recommended shibuya scramble, so we went. What an experience - people coming at you and past you from every which way. Enjoyable and great for people watching, but in the end it is just people walking across a road crossing - wouldn't go specifically to view this more than once.

Crazy!. Simply something to see once in life. Being there, surrounded by this massive crowd or stepping behind and look all these people crossing each other is something that has a great visual impact!

A real fun experience!. Get there around 6pm, as the sun goes down and the neon lights start to shine brightly, and the crowds start arriving in mass. It's a unique experience, so many people crossing at the same time, organised chaos. You can get a higher view from the cafe in L'Occitane, or from Starbucks, but L'Occitane is technically higher (you can get to the 3rd floor). Careful, prices are really high in the cafe, but then you get the view you wanted! Do not get fooled if you spot a free space at the window there from downstairs, these spots are always reserved. But hopefully you will get a spot not too far from the window.

It is just a busy pedestrian road. Not sure what the fuss is all about. It is just a road with lots of people crossing. Not sure how to take a picture there without causing bodily harm to myself and the people around me.

Unique. When the lights turn red at this busy junction, they all turn red at the same time in every direction. Traffic stops completely and pedestrians surge into the intersection from all sides, like marbles spilling out of a box. You can observe this moment of organized chaos from the second-story window of the Starbucks in the Tsutaya building on the crossing's north side. Its rare to see such a chaotic crossing. I visited this place at 2100 hrs when the rush was much less. I believe at 1800 hrs to 1900 hrs the rush would be much more and fun to watch
Scramble. Great location for people watching, just immense amount of people moving at the same time. Right outside the station so can't be missed. Well worth a stop over if passing Shibuya station.

This was great fun!. Went to scramble square on a recent trip to Japan and it was breathtaking, I have never seen so many people in one place in my life.We took pictures of each other in the middle of the mayhem and really enjoyed ourselves.Lots of things going on around the square, lots of different shops, definitely a place to visit while in Tokyo.
Pedestrian rules here. This is probably the craziest crossing. Its 5 intersection stopping all at once for the pedestrian to cross...
Very Japanese Experience!. Basically the Times Square of Japan, filled with people, lights, and lots of fun activities around. This is a great place to take some pictures and then go out afterwards.
Crazy. This is just an amazing experience, best viewed from the Starbucks cafe that overlooks the crossing - in the evening seats are reasonably easy to get.
crazy crossing. A must little see in Tokyo, and it's probably best described as "orderly disorderly!" Lots of people are going it lots of directions.

The Famous Shibuya Crossing. There is nothing much to see here. Just the view of people crossing the road but you should see it during the night, it is like awesome, especially with the lights. The best way to view the whole scene, is by watching from the Starbucks shop, on the 1st floor. Though, just walking and crossing the road is enough, you basically cannot stop in the middle of the road when people are crossing. You might get stared at.

Crossing road is a tourist attraction here. When you think that road cross or crossing road is something boring and ordinary, but that's not happen in this place. Because its lot of people from any direction, crossing together at the same time, surounded by malls, stations, departement stores, and audio & visual signage. Just try to cross the road and you can feel the real hustle bustle of Tokyo here. Nice place for taking some pictures.

Wow!. Thought I woukd go here just to take a photo of the crossing. When walking out of the station I got the sense of "wow, now I am in Tokyo". After watching the crossing a couple of times I finally decided to join the rat race across and loved it.After that I grabbed a coffee from the Starbucks conveniently located at the crossig and spent over an hour just exploring the area and the streets surrounding. Was a great experience and best of all quite cheap, only the train ticket there and back.
one big mad rush. This is amazing, how thousands of people manage to cross the road without bumping into each other!TOP TIP: grab a starbucks and view this mayhem from the second floor
ants of people. super busy intersection infront of the railway station. People rushing to their destination. Good for people watching, dining and shopping

Just a tourist attraction. Well, been there in the morning around 9.00 a.m. Yes there were lots of people crossing the road. However, would not come back here again. If you have been here once, its enough.

Never thought I would have this much fun crossing a street.. I thought I would just go there, take a picture and leave. I ended up spending an hour around the area. It was incredibly fun to people watch and even more fun to jump in to the river of people.Weather doesn't matter much, the first time we were there on a rainy day and the umbrellas made for great pictures. Weekend does help since there are more people crossing.
Iconic. It was fun to watch the crossing from then train station exit as well as actually crossing it. If you're in Tokyo you must check this out. Convenient from train

Worth a few minutes if you are in the neighborhood. We were on the train and came to Shibuya Station. There was no extra charge to get off for a while and then get on another train so we went to Shibuya Crossing. Crossing both ways and going up to the second floor of the Starbucks for a view from above were worth a few minutes. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to see it or spending money on transportation if you are not going to be close to Shibuya anyway.

Kind of fun to join in. We have heard and seen so much. It's quite an experience to come here and walk with the masses. Somehow there's coordination in so much craze. It's like a symphony coming together when the lights turn green for the pedestrians.
Bucket list fun. This attraction speak for itself. Try to do a crossing both during the day and at night to see the differences. Pick a busy time, 8pm, to really experience the scramble at its best.

The main crosswalk was the only attraction. I'm not really into shopping so I mainly went for the sights of the famous Shibuya Pedestrian Crossing and the street night lights of city life. But I think Shibuya may be a spot for "wealthier" people?? Not sure, I didn't really go inside the stores.

Underwhelmed. There is nothing unique about the Shibuya scramble, in which all traffic is halted so that pedestrians can cross in any direction, including diagonally. This maneuver is sometimes referred to as a “Barnes Dance”, after the traffic commissioner who implemented it in several cities, including New York. I’ve even seen diagonal crosswalk markings in Oakland CA. The Shibuya scramble is a particularly large scale Barnes Dance, as it involves five streets outside a busy station. It may be impressive during heavy traffic times, but I was there around 9:30 on a Monday morning, and my reaction was that it was no big deal. I had other reasons for being in the area, but had I made a special trip, I’d have been disappointed. There is an excellent live cam view of the Shibuya scramble on YouTube; check it out to decide if you want to see it for yourself (and to time your visit).
Fun to join the crossing scramble. Fun to join the crossing scramble. Could have been busier but it was raining so made for a fun walk. Very iconic like times square in New York City.

Busiest Cross Walk in the World. Check this out from Starbuck - it photographs best from up high and starbucks is in centre looking down onto it. Great fun to walk through the sea of people and take some snaps. Lots to do in Shibuya!

If you like lots of people the go here . Shibuya hachiko crossing is famous all over the world for the crazy scramble over the main road junction. It may seem like total chaos but it's now being used as an example of an efficient way to cope with pedestrian crossing at very busy crossroads. (Lo dons Oxford Circus for example)But be prepared to get jostled and to dodge tourists stopping for selfiesIt's a good giggle though
Amazing. Do not miss.. Crazy! Get a drink at Starbucks for the best view. You won't get bored looking at the junction. My pic was taken from Loccitane cafe
Fun experience . Just had to do this when visiting Tokyo!! Glad we did, it was a fun experience and got some great video footage! Also this district is the best for shopping in my opinion.

Rather hilarious! . Its amazing how systematically chaotic this intersection is. Thousands of people somehow making their way through within seconds, then all of a sudden its clear for cars to go. All amidst the chaos people are taking pictures of it. Its truly incredible. Just make sure you hold hands!

Bright lights of Shibuya. I really do not like shopping. But...my wife does. And, as a New York City dweller who steers clear of Times Square, I admit I was curious. So I went and, much to my surprise, enjoyed the atmosphere. Yes, lots of people and lights everywhere, but the shops were clean, the energy was positive, and the selections were great. The boutique malls have really good food courts too! Worth the experience, although I'm sure denizens of Tokyo avoid it like the plague.

Just another busy intersection crossing. As a tourist, you might have to experience the famous shibuya crossing. But in fact, it is just an intersection full of people crossing from different section. Nothing special and you can just spend few minutes just to cross the roads and take some photos and short clips. Do not waste your time if you just come shibuya purposely for this. However, Shibuya is a shopping district that worth a visit, you can do some shopping here and enjoy the night view of this busy district and do the crossing at the same time. The best location to view the shibuya crossing is Starbucks that located atopposite shibuya station. But please do not spend too long there except you are really paying for a starbucks coffee or else, you are just disturbing other customers that do indeed need some coffee moment.

go there , do the crossing , take some vids and pics ... that's all :D. I donno what do you expect but , I've been there and the only moment I've got exited was the moment I saw the crossing moment on the fast and furious movie , anyways , it's a must to do list in Tokyo visiting ... cheers
A must experience.. The iconic Shibuya pedestrian scramble is exactly what you expect it to be, crowded and noisy. Even though it's just a pedestrian crossing it's definitely worth experiencing.

Unbelievable . It's an unbelievable experience watching and taking part. So many people crossing in every direction yet not bumping into one another.a big tourist destination yet it's part of Tokyo's daily life. A must!

Enjoyed a coffee watching the toing and froing. If you've seen the film you just have to. Found a nice little restaurant close by. Yes it's just people crossing the road but the traffic light system is different in Japan and everyone going every which way at the same time is just part of the Tokyo buzz.
Epic, Amazing view. This famous Shibuya crossing is a must-go! You have never been to Tokyo if you never visited the Shibuya crossing!

Pretty amazing site if you have never been here before. The world famous Shibuya crossing. All the streetlights from all locations close at the same time, so once its safe to walk, everyone moves in all directions. Don't stand in the middle of the crossing to take pictures unless you want to get bumped into or run over haha. The cool thing is that there are like 4-5 different roads people can walk to from the intersection....so many different places to check out. I stayed at the Shibuya Excel Hotel, which had elevators with glass windows, so it was pretty neat to see this crossing at night. Most of their rooms had a crossing view too.

It's one of those "I can't believe I am here" moments. Breathtaking. I just stood and watched people cross for 10 minutes soaking up the atmosphere. Visually stunning. I got some great views from the train station (albeit photos were taken from behind glass!)Visited at night- this is when I think it is truly special.

Impressing Place. The Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble is a great vision of what Japan looks like in terms of culture, respect and organization. A place to go and pass along the way, back and forward several times.

Unusual tourist destination but a must see, nontheless!. I was wondering why my husband wanted to visit this busy intersection. After all, who travels to see an intersection. He found a prime spot on the second floor of Starbucks and, true enough, the intersection was a sight to behold. We sat mesmerized just people, and intersection, watching for about half an hour. Did not regret it.

Only if you want to say you did it.. This place was pretty average. We crossed many similar scrambles/crossing in Shinjuku and Akihabara while in Tokyo and and the only thing that differed from them to this one was the people taking photos and stopping in the middle of the road while crossing to take photos. Pass, there are many other places you can take photos that say Tokyo here I am!

A people watching extravaganza. Have been here many times. It's a fun place to sit (if you can get a seat in one of the cafes that overlook it) and just watch the comings and goings. This is apparently the busiest crossing in the world and you know it. If you don't like crowds then you probably shouldn't go, but if you don't like crowds you probably shouldn't be in Tokyo at all.Shibuya is easily reached on JR lines and via the subway. There are lots of shops and restaurants around there too for when you get bored.
Not sure what all the fuss is about. It's big. But it's just a pedestrian crossing. If you live in any big city it's not that different. Don't go out of your way. There's so much else to do in Tokyo.

MY FAVORITE PLACE IN THE WORLD. This is without a doubt one of the most amazing places I have ever visited. The Shibuya Crossing as it is so famously crossed is one of the most busiest crossings in the world. Just outside the Shibuya Station, It is exactly how we have seen it in movies. This is one of the most prominent areas in Tokyo and is lively 24 hours. Hundreds of people cross the street at once and it is really exciting to be a part of them. There is a Starbucks just as you cross the street and is said to be one of the busiest Starbucks in the world.. A must visit for anyone visiting Tokyo city.
Flowing. You will be amazed by how that amount of people can function flawlesly... The bussiest crossroad in the world lives up to its name.

Swarms of People!. This was a pretty darn cool experience and I think it is a must if you like to people watch and are a curious person. I have never, nor will I probably again ever see so many people crossing at a single cross walk at the same time. And the crazy thing is is that it happens every time the pedestrian light turns green so it's not like you just get to see a huge wave of people one time at some particular time of the day... It is happening all the time all day! Pretty cool to see and also cool to be a part of.

True Tokyo Experience. After a week in Tokyo, I've decided Tokyo is a lot like NYC, you can certainly visit museums and see some cool sites, but in the end, it's about the experience of humanity. The masses of people, the rhythm of the city, the cultural norms, etc. Shibuya hits on that squarely. You will see a total freak show here, make sure you head down each of the side streets.

Pedestrian crossing. I'm amazed how Japan labeled the normal places as tourist attractions. This is a pedestrian crossing with lots of people. There is another pedestrian crossing a few meters away. =)

Its a crossing that lets you experience the dynamic of tokyo. Its quite interesting to experience the hassle and bustle of Shibuya. Very dynamic. Shibuya is a very busy place with lots of shopping and restaurants. My husband and i have been to tokyo twice, the most recent trip we travelled with our 2.5yo son and he loves it.
Shibuya scramble. It's more about watching the people walking every which way without a collision, or standing on the corner watching the adverts on the walls of buildings. Good fun.

It's just a crossing. Ok so it gets a lot of attention and yeah in essence it's just a crossing but if your into your Asian films or anime you know this is a very often used location as a reference and see so many people just at a "crossing" is unreal and just out of the station

Pedestrian crossing full of people. It is compared with Times Square but is not. It is amazing how many people can cross an intersection at a given time. It is also amazing how many ads can run on the buildings aurounding the intersection. But in the end is nothing more than a pedestrian crossing.

Very exciting. Quite a cool area, we went through the scramble a few times and watched it from Starbucks, best not to look at the giant tv advertising screens whilst crossing or you might run into someone.

This is insanity. I absolutely loved watching the scramble especially on Sunday when everyone is out. Its basically 5 intersections where all pedestrian lights go green and people go multi directions. What was amazing is how smooth this system operates. People are so respectful that no one bombs against the other (unless tourists) and everyone stops on red for traffic to start. it is a great sight.

You'll probably pass through anyway. Anyone who plans on going to/from Shibuya will probably see the crossing regardless of if it's an attraction in and of itself. IMHO it's really nothing special, and the camera tricks used to make it look enormous on TV are highly amusing.

Fun bustling people. This was a pretty cool intersection. Very hectic. Unfortunately it was raining when we went but I don't think it took too much away from the experience. It was similar to Times Square. I've recommended it to friends traveling to Tokyo.

Most lively pedestrian crossing. Where are they from? Where are they going? Why are there so many people? Japanese people seems to be busy even in the evening after working hours. It's always fun just to watch people crossing from all directions at Shibuya Pedestrian crossing.
Unbelievably busy crossing.. We sat in Starbucks and watched the massive numbers of people moving through this area. It was worth while for the coffee and the viewing.

Overrated . Cool to watch, but it really is just a crossing full of people. If your a movie buff then this place might be your thing, however we felt there were better things to see in this city than this
Fun to see you need yo see it from right spot . Nice to see but not nothing special- you need to see it from Starbucks optional from the train station but not as good but okay
Crowdy and spectaculaire . You must go and see This crossing where thousinds of People cross the Streets. This is Tokyo in a nutshell. Very good opputunities for taking fotos carching Tokyo citylife.

Organized scramble!. One of the most absurd experiences - the scramble in any other country would be complete mayhem..but wait - this is Tokyo/ JAPAN. The scramble is orderly just like every other thing about this country. I thoroughly enjoyed in crossing and recrossing this. You can even sit on the first floor at the Starbucks there and watch it.

"the crossing". I realized that Shibuya crossing is not the only crazy crossing. Most of the crossing in Tokyo are crazy. Here is the central, though. It is true you can actually get lost. One tip: walk fast during the crossing or you'll get bump and lost.

People watching.. Great views from Shibuya Station or from the Starbucks directly opposite the station a few floors up.Mesmerizing to see that at every green pedestrian light, literally hundreds and hundreds of people scramble across this crossing. Very easy to pass time here and the best thing is you can go and be a part of it as you head towards your next destination! One of those things that you 'must see' as part of the Tokyo experience. It won't cost you anything and will only take a few minutes of your time if you are in a hurry.
You scramble, I scramble, we all scramble. You just have to go to Shibuya and do it. The sea of people is fun to watch, workers, tourists, school kids everyone packing across the intersection.
you will be amazed of how pedestrian scramble. just experience to be with the "scramble" of the local pedestrians. still worth a visit and picture perfect.

Crazy!. The Shibuya crossing was chaotic and exciting at the same time. Tons of people in different directions trying to cross the street. Its exciting to see however only lasts a couple of minutes then you move on to other things

Shibuya Crossing. I think Shibuya Crossing is the Guinness Records Book for the busiest crossing in the world. So If you have the chance, if happens to be outside Shibuya Station just go and see the crossing. Its unique in the world!

such a culture shock . it's amazing seeing the people cross and you have a nice view from the shibuya train station, it's even nicer actually walking across the crossing. you can't really go to Tokyo and not do that. surrounding the crossing there are plenty of roads to go down with restaurants and shops and there is a big Starbucks that looks over the crossing so you can have a coffee with a nice view
good to experience, once in a lifetime. it's one time life experience, be there, do the cross, take picture, and that's it. I personally wont do it twice hehe. Enough said.
An experieince of a lifetime. Organized chaos. Over a thousand people headed in different directions merge into the crossing every few minutes and somehow make it to the other side. WOW!

Just many people crossing the road . Nothing so special about this crossing. Just many people crossing the road at the same time. However , if u like shopping, there are many shops around that might suits you.

Fun Experience. This was part of our visit to Shibuya and Harajuku. It was a short but fun experience to cross the street with so many people. We took the train from our hotel in Shinjuku to The Scramble which is just in front of the Shibuya Station where the statue of Hachiko is also. We went up to the station where there is a walkway connecting it to a mall for a view of the Scramble from above.

Loved the energy of this place. Spent three days in Shibuya and loved every minute-stayed just behind the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble and just loved the our entire stay - will definitely stay longer next time. Went to Japan to ski in Hakuba and Tokyo was a bonus.

First place you must go to when visiting Tokyo. This experience is unforgettable and overwhelming with the mass of people crossing all the streets at the same time. My suggestion is that you go to the 2nd floor of Starbucks at Shibuya to have the best views of the worlds busiest crosswalk.

Great representation of Japanese pop culture. Very difficult to explain this unique experience.The Scramble is definitely what represents the modern Tokyo, this is not only due to the massive exposure on the media but also what represents the modern Japanese lifestyle.Even nowadays there is several tourists with cameras and GoPros laying around, the Scramble represents a unique experience on getting involved with the Japanese society. You get the opportunity to see people from every age range, and the consistency of not seeing people getting injured as it is rare to see people collide each other when there is easily 300+ people walking in just a single street crossing.Also, one of the coolest features are the screen panels that you see when you get off from Shibuya Station. This is something no other place can offer you but Tokyo.For fellow travelers who are willing to travel to Tokyo soon, you are not alone. There is a green van right before the Scramble which is a tourist center, so if you have any questions feel free to go there and ask!

Go up to the train station for a view. If Starbucks is full (I saw like a 30 mind line) the best option is going to the train station, there is a bridge between the station and and shipping mall where you can see perfectly the pedestrian cross
Shibuya pedestrian scramble. Must visit place in Shibuya. One should always try getting a seat at the Starbucks to get a great view to take pictures of everyone crossing.

Allegedly the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. I came from a very small town so after that life, this kind of mass is repelling, exciting and peculiar at the same time. Near the scramble you can find the famous statue of Hachiko, the similarly crowded Shibuya station and a variety of restaurants, bars etc.

Somehow it all works. We have been through the Scramble a few times now and found it doable if you just focus straight ahead and walk with a purpose. Eye contact with opposing pedestrians can lead to confusion and collisions so best to avoid. Evenings and commute times are the most crowded.

More entertaining than I'd thought it would be. I wasn't really planning on stopping by here since, well, who would want to see a measly pedestrian crossing, right?Thanks to my fantastic navigation skills, I ended up here on a prime Friday night instead of getting to Akihabara, where I was trying to get to. Since I was already here and didn't have to scout for a spot to view the crossing, why not a bunch of people cross at the same time. You can easily see the crossing fromthe train station (I got off the Tokyo Metro Ginza line). Oddly enough, it was interesting to watch people cross all ways again and again. I still don't know why, but I guess it's just one of those things that you have to experience yourself. Also, getting down there and crossing with a bunch of people (and simultaneously dodging others) is pretty fun for some reason as well.

Not as frenetic in the mornings!. You can't visit Japan without seeing the world famous Shibuya crossing where hundreds of thousands of people cross at the same time when the lights go. It is interesting in that it is a free for all.. you can cross wherever you want and it's been known that tens of thousands can be crossing at the same time. It's most busiest in the evening during the rush hour when people are finishing work and rushing to get home. We went in the morning when it wasn't so busy.. it was still interesting to watch though and I think to get the full experience, you've got to to in the evening. People say that you get a good view from the Starbucks but that was so busy so we were in L'Occitane.. which is a cafe overlooking Shibuya. We got some good views there.Interesting place though.. not as amazing as I thought it would be but that's probably because we should have gone in the evening!

A short but mind blowing experience. It's a famous corner and everybody saw a picture from this street but being there as one of the millons of ants is amazing! An incredible mix of technology in the screens, architecture, people wearing totally different one each other, shops and more shops. So many things to watch simultaneously is so nice to be there and experience the real crowd!

Busy...but not as crazy as some would say. The crossing is busy but not as crazy as some would say...no different to any other big city.Viewing the people from the nearby Starbucks is a must to watch the crossing, but be warned it gets very busy inside and window seats are hard to get.
A must experience. A crazy shopping area! And you will cross use this to start off. Its nice experience, and a must! There are lots of shopping mall, and great food, and supermarket too.

Brilliant . This is a must do if your in Tokyo ! 1000s of people crossing at the same time is not for the faint hearted if your afraid of crowded places. It's a great opportunity to get the camera out because I think know where else in the world has a crossing as large as this . A MUST DO AND SEE

LOTS of people. Kids were amused that there were so many people crossing the roads at the same time, lots of people stopping midway to take selfies and videos. Hachiko statue is nearby. Good to experience at least once!
Starbucks view. You have to go to Shibuya Starbucks on the crossings. Try apricot coffee. I made some time lapse videos and turn out great. Must see place in shibuya.

Unmissable. One of my favourite things about my trip to Japan! I thought it was fascinating and so much fun to watch masses and masses of people accumulating and reaccumulating at this crossing every few minutes, and then scramble very politely and respectfully across the road at the same time, all the while surrounded by the crazy neon lights and noise of Shibuya! I would recommend going here in the late afternoon or evening when it is busy and looks particularly impressive. The Starbucks just opposite the crossing has an amazing view of the crossing from the first floor - well worth the price of a mediocre coffee!
Good fun. Good fun, but let's face it, you're just walking across the road! You have to do this while in Tokyo, it's all part of the experience!
Must see in Tokyo. It's awesome to see it at night, you can go to the Starbucks to have a good view, or even from the metro station.

Just came to see the scramble. Came to see the famous pedestrian scramble but I guess I seen more people on the Subway I found this place is better for shopping though than shinjuku. A lot of big brand shops but price not cheap, pretty much same as in Sydney. A lot of restaurants and cafes if you don't mind lining up so you can have a good view of the famous intersection and take some cool photos.
A must see. It's a place to see when you are in Tokyo from somewhere high like the starbuck. It's not something you can see in France.
Never seen so many people!. Like watching ants! We were there on a rainy day and I've never seen so many umbrellas in my life! Good place to see as there is plenty to do nearby.

Nighttime visit . We have visited this square both in the day and night. I'ld recommend going at night when all the lights are glowing it looks wicked. Can get some good photos walking through the scramble. Also if you go up to the Starbucks which you can't miss it's good to view from there or to get some pictures looking down onto the scramble from there!

Chaotic blur. The reason why this intersection crossing is so spectacular is because of the department stores entrances along with the subway stops intersection at Shibuya station.Just crossing this intersection is a chaotic blur with people going left right up and down.To get a better view of this experience seek higher ground and view it from above.

A nice tourist experience...if you are in the area. It was a bit difficult to locate this. There is actually a crossing that is multi-directional and extremely busy about 3 blocks away. The only reason that I knew I was at the wrong place is because there is a Starbucks at the Shibuya crossing.The Starbucks was suggested by our tour guide as a good place to go and take pictures or video of the crossing. The windows are lined with tourists, so you need to be patient to take pictures. I think it is on the second or third floor (the Starbucks starts on the first floor).I went on a rainy day. I think the effect of the open umbrellas crossing added some magic to my experience. If I went on a non-rainy day, I don't think that I would have felt that spending 30 minutes trying to find it would have been worth it.

Meh....Halloween was interesting though.. I don’t think the crosswalk is as amazing and interesting as it is made out to be. It’s just a busy crosswalk…I don’t even think we realized we were crossing the famous Shibuya Scramble until after we got to the other side. However, when we were here for Halloween it was REALLY packed and that is when it was truly an experience. I remember we were waiting to cross and it was so packed, we were like sardines. Actually crossing the road was fun because there were a lot of people dressed up in funny costumes and you had to try to squeeze past them. The police were blowing their whistles and corralling people back onto the sidewalks. It was exciting. Next time we go to Tokyo, we will try looking at the crosswalk from Starbucks. I wouldn’t say that I don’t recommend the crosswalk…you have to cross it at some point if you are going to Shibuya. It’s just not that interesting. Shibuya itself is very awesome and interesting though.  I am giving this a good rating because Shibuya is amazing and you might have to use the crosswalk anyway if you are in that area. So if you go to Shibuya for the crosswalk, you might be a tiny bit disappointed by the crosswalk, but you will still find a lot of cool things to do in Shibuya and you'll get that busy, city experience. You will probably get some cool video of the crosswalk if you use a GoPro and selfie stick.

If you're in the area, check it out. We decided to head over to Shibuya to see the scramble. Like others say - it's simply a busy intersection but it was still neat to be part of it with all the people. It's hard to really get a glimpse of it though since in the movies, you view it from different angles. If you're in the area though, check it out! It's worth the few minutes of entertainment and to say you were actually there.
Worth a cross.. Not as good as expected, but that's the only place in the world I've seen so much people crossing a street in so many different directions. A cinematographic place :)
Awesome feeling. We didn't know if this was the intersection, but as soon as the crowds started to amass we knew. It is amazing to see how well and without any incidents so many people cross.

Not as fascinating as you would expect. It really is just an intersection where people cross the road. Even in Starbucks you can't really get the same vibe as you see from the films. It is merely a very busy pedestrians crossing.
Hustling bustling Shibuya. Lights and sounds of Tokyo. Bustling downtown area of shopping, dining, sightseeing. Very much the image of modern Tokyo. Interesting and enjoyable

Really wanted to see it. I was really looking forward to seeing the "scramble", but have to say I was a little disappointed. It just wasn't as busy as I'd expected.But there's a lesson in that - we were there on an overcast mid-afternoon. Pick a busier time and a nicer day! I hope to go back to take another look myself in such circumstances.Lots of people take advantage of the view from the Starbucks that overlooks the crossing, but of course, it's hard to get a seat and you have to buy something - it's the luck of the draw. But we found a perfectly adequate, uninterrupted second storey view from the Shibuya JR railway station. the window is a bit dirty, but the camera seemed to "see" through that, and again, the crossing wasn't that busy so the station wasn't that busy. It might be harder to get a spot at the window in busier times.
A fun experience . If you like crowds and a quick jostle then it is great fun but if you like solitude then avoid it.It's a street crossing unlike any other.
Fun to watch!!. Gotta see the scramble from atop Starbucks! 2nd floor view best. Wait for it... Get it your time lapse video and shoot away!

Not Amazing, but one of those things you just have to see. For being possibly the busiest intersection in the world it is surprisingly efficient and organized, as everything in Japan. It's not really something that will blow your mind, as it really is just that, an intersection. Still it is captivating to take a seat in one of the numerous cafes in the surrounding buildings and watch the endless stream of people go on about their day like ants. One of the most iconic locations on earth for a reason.
Take a picture and go. Nothing spectacular here. We didn't even know we were there before our tour guide told us. Probably better from above but you don't see much on the street.

so crazy so cool. my visit to the famous SHIBUYA CROSSING was so magical people are everywhere but polite and there are allot of attraction there and the most important thing if u like to take some cool photos I recommend u to go to the Starbucks second floor drink tasty coffee and snap some photos

An Organized Mess . We just couldn't bear being in Tokyo and not take part and witness the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble. What seemed to be chaos from a birds' eye view, is actually a normal part of people's lives in Shibuya. One needs to cross that street, even tourists, as we exit tha subway station (particularly for the Hachiko Statue located outside one of the exits). It is a perfect example of an organized mess, as it all starts after the pedestrian lights turn green on all sides for everybody to safely cross the street. We went to Starbucks on the 2F of Tsutaya Building which you could easily spot right across the street if you're standing by the Hachiko Statue. A piece of advice though, you may find people there taking up seats without consuming any orders from Starbucks. Unfortunately, we found ourselves with drinks and food on our hands and no place to put it on. To make matters worse, it got really humid inside with all the people crowding the place and staring at the Shibuya crossing. We eventually found our way to some seats with the kind gesture of some tourists who were sensitive enough to finally give their seats up for us. So if you find yourself in Starbucks solely for the view, do yourself a favor and skip ordering anything. It would cause too much of a hassle and unnecessary stress. You're better off having coffee somewhere else, where you're sure that you'll be able to enjoy it. ;)

Time square on steroids . This was the touristy venture that I wanted to make whilst in Tokyo and I loved it! Shibuya in general was a cool place lots to see and plenty of places to eat. The amount of people can make it quite claustrophobic at times but that's what I wanted to check out. Well worth a trip.
Crazy. This is an absolute must if you are visiting Tokyo. You can get a great view from the Starbucks Cafe while having a coffee and snack.
incredible :). very interesting to just look all this mess there. Just sit and look, also must take part Yourself also

A tidal wave of pedestrians. This is quite an experience. Traffic stops in all directions. And then people swarm from all directions. It is fun joining the crowd. After that, you can go to the second floor of Starbucks ans get a great view, although thry have someone there discouraging photo taking. For your aerial picture, go to the pedestrian bridge of the subway right outside the second floor of Starbucks.

Exciting to cross and good for a check off the bucket list but too many tourists!!. Exciting to cross and good for a check off the bucket list but too many tourists!!It was too much dodging all of the tourists taking pics and vids like me!!
Quite a spectacle. Quite amazing to behold how many times you see it. I got to participate in it during the day and at night! Can't miss if you're in Shibuya!
Fun Fun Fun!. This is a must experience! Everyone comes at you in every direction, its amazing! Super fun at night with all the bright lights.

Crazy busy but 1/2 tourists.. It's a crazy busy intersection as we all know, but there is definitely alot of tourists and most being Japanese tourists. I'd almost go as far as saying 50-50 tourists and locals, in saying that, we did go on a Saturday afternoon so maybe during the week it's more locals and even busier!
Underwhelmed. A weekend afternoon and it was surprisingly quiet so there was no scramble. Not sure that it lives up to its reputation.
Crazy and cliche. Much like Time Square in NYC you'll visit it, be a part of it for a minute or so and have boosting rights forever.

Sea of people!!!. I told the tourist guide that I will never want to miss this! When the traffic light turns green , sea of people from different corners cross the street at the same time,never seen this before. I enjoyed this- feeling like a local while crossing the street. the best view for me is at the Starbucks café. Lots of tourists sits there just watching people cross the street. Its an experience!!!!

Do it for the people watching.. It's hectic, and neon, and bustling, and touristy, and full of local flavor. Not sure how it manages that but it's certainly a stop worth making on your Tokyo itinerary. Lots to see, eat, and do in the area.
WOW!!!!!!!. one one minute all streets are closed and then on that unique square is passing a RIVER,i do mean it a, RIVER of people ....Only in Tokyo !!!!

Exploring Shibuya. A pleasant stroll around one of the busier parts of Tokyo... It's still very patient and well organised, even though much busier than the likes of Oxford Circus, it is a calm, stroll across the junction with no pushing and shoving at all!

Feel the busy time in Japan.. This the busiest area I have ever seen. At morning, a huge of pedestrian crossing. At rush hour, this intersection look like a sea of humanity. At night about 9pm, all buildings decorated by neon advertisements and giant video screens. Surround shops shops and shops. It's funny when the lights turn green, the place is as busy as bee hive. Don't missed this place when you visit Tokyo.

Cliché site of Tokyo, but worth it!. it It is actually funny to see this crossing for real. You can go there from 7am to 9pm and the crossing will always be packed. It really shows how busy Tokyo can get.
It is to be experienced. So many people crossing at the same time. Amazing to watch and experience. There are a lot of tourists just taking videos of the crossing at peak hour.

Wow!!!. I'm speechless, I stood on the side streets and just couldn't stop watching the people walk pass, cars drives pass, people walk pass, car drives pass...Coming from London & Hong Kong, this would have never worked in both places! Japanese people stick so much to the rules! There are local cafes that you can sit there for coffee and see the people go pass. Or even the train station you'll get a good view of the action!
Lost in time. Maybe I'm overreacting, but watching people cross it for 5 minutes really brings excitement. They're very organised and law-obeying citizens!

Great experience . Even thought it's just cross a road it is an experience everybody needs when visiting Japan The site of everybody waiting to cross and then walking through it with all the sounds and lights of the buildingsThis is what you see on tv about Tokyo Was a great way to end my visit

Busy busy place. We first went thru the intersection at 9 am. I thought what is the big deal.....well 12 hours later, holy cow. I have never seen so many people waiting the cross the street in every possible direction. Maybe 20 people deep. It is very bright, colorful, and loud at night. A very fun environment, but can be overwhelming.

So much adrenaline . We went through the scramble so many times over our two weeks there by the time we left it was just a standard crossing! The first few times especially as we had young kids it was a really exciting time. Lots of people and lots of running! It's just a fun experience
You must do it.... So Tokyo...and fun! Why is this not in every city? Makes sense for high pedestrian traffic areas. This is Tokyo to me....ordered chaos
Must see. Great vibe and must see attraction when visiting Tokyo. being part of the crossing is fun, but also watching the crossing from Shibuya station is great too.

The moment you know you are in Tokyo, when you see all the people at the popular Shibuya Crossing.
