Shibuya is the trendiest area for young people in Shibuya and there are a ton of restaurants and shopping areas.And to get there, you need to cross the road at the popular Shibuya crossing (or Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble as it's called here).There is nothing magnificent about crossing the street, but its the feeling of seeing so many people crossing, it's a sight to be seen, may it be overhead or just crossing it yourself. We see it in movies, anime, etc., it's one of the most memorable things that tend to stick in your head if you love the concrete jungle of Tokyo. And for many people who vacationed in Tokyo, it's one of the reasons why the Shibuya Crossing livestream channel on YouTube is quite popular, because people love the area so much. But again, it's not about the gratification but for fans of Japanese pop culture, it's more or less the feeling that you have arrived in the pop culture mecha, Shibuya.
Not worth a detour. Somewhat interesting, but not worth a substantial detour. Some interesting department stores nearby.
Fabulous!. A must do when in Tokyo! We captured this photo from the Starbucks cafe above the music studio. The energy is strong, the people are friendly. Fabulous experience!

Cool Place to say you have visited. Despite not being a conventional tourist attraction, it is most definitely a place worth visiting. Assuming unlike us you take the correct exit from the Shibuya Station you are thrusted upon a Times Square like intersection (at night). It is worth visiting in the morning or evening when the most people are using the crossing. An ideal view is from the Starbucks on the second floor. There are plenty of shops around here as well as food outlets, so there is stuff to do and see. It is worth a visit just to say you have been on the busiest intersection in the world.

Head to Starbucks for a great view!. We went up to the Starbucks on I think the third floor of one of the main buildings (above a bookstore) to sit and enjoy the view. It was very crowded, as Starbucks is a popular place to go to get photos of the Shibuya Crossing. But, order and drink and wait a few minutes until you can get a spot by the window.I went at night and was able to balance my camera on the counter to use a slow shutter and get some good photographs. I also crossed the intersection a couple of times to experience the madness.

Busy intersection. Fascinating to watch when the cars stop and throngs of people cross the pedestrian lanes from all direction. But...that's just it...just a crossing. Check it out if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of the way to go there if time is limited or staying at the other side of Tokyo. You can also check out a statue of Hachiko (from the movie about a very faithful dog) on the way to the crossing.

Be there at 3pm (broad day light) and return at night (neon lights). We shopped around the area during broad day light (3pm). And went back hotel at night (after dinner). Views & ambience are very different. Night time, most people gathered and atmosphere are intense, You can understand and feel what is the "typical fast pace of Japanese" here!

People watching to the extreme. Nothing quite like it. As the light is preparing to change, people gather in great numbers, and then... its green! Some how nobody crashes into each other. I spent about 30 minutes people watching here.
Crowd!!. We went in the night time. Is so crowded... However is great to look at the peoples walking around. There's alot of shopping mall and drugstores around there.

Crowd, crowd, crowd. the place to go for pictures of a crowded Japanese pedestrian crossing, crowded Halloween party and costumed people, crowded Japan football/rugby match fans gathering ... You got it: a very crowded place. Avoid it if you like quietness.

Had to do it! . We had to do it! An easy stop on the Metro
And we enjoyed walking around all the shops in the area. Everything LIT up at night with a very NYC Times Square feeling. A younger crowd than at other places in the city- great people watching.
Weird underground comic book stores too

Rush hour people watching. During late afternoon we had a few drinks at Scramble, which has a good street level view of this busy crossing. Afterwards we walked for a few minutes to the Cerulean Tower Hotel for the night view of the city from the 40th floor, which was great!
A big crossing. Don't really get this as a tourist destination. It's a big pedestrian crossing. That's it. If this is a highlight in Tokyo you are not really trying.

Just a road junction with a lot of people. I knew this place from the movie 'Fast and Furious : Tokyo Drift'. Because they made and impressive scene there I wanted to see it in real. And yes it exists, but in real it's not so impressive as in the movie. It's just a big junction with all pedestrians crossing at the same time. Nothing special, just something you must do, at least you can say you were on the best known junction of Tokio and Japan...

Nothing extraordinary, just a matter of 'Been there, done that'. Some people say that best spot to watch Shibuya crossing is from a Starbucks nearby. It's a good spot, but the windows of the Shibuya train station which you will pass by on your way out the station are even better. Unlike Starbucks, it's totally free, and immediate without needing to cross the road. I'm still at a loss why this crossing is popular. However other people think differently. I saw hired photographer taking photos of certain people crossing that road. View of buildings around the crossing is not bad at all, so it might not be a bad idea after all. So just be there for the sake of being there. It's your call.
Must go see. Shibuya and rapongi are 2 places you should hang out while in Tokyo. The crossing is classic a must see, lots of people going in all directions
Tokyo icon. The Shibuya crossing is a must see. We were there around 5 pm. Amazing crowd crossing and walking in/out station. This is the center of tokyo metropol.
so many people!. You can see so many people! I often see foreign country people taking a picture and movie. Sometimes, I visit some countrys but, I have never seen!

JAPANESE discipline and order. Our fisrt objective in Shibuya was this crossing made famous all over the world. It is stunning to see these thousands of people patiently waiting and all move on cue without bumping into each other many still busy with their phone. It portraits the discipline of the Japanese people.

Pretty cool to see . If you're in the area, or not, I would make a visit to the shibuya pedestrian crossings. It's right by Starbucks. Which I recommend going to Starbucks & get the view! It's amazing at night. && it's free!!!

It is a intersection.... Come on. It is just an intersection. But if you have it on your bucket list you can do as a lot of other tourists - get a coffee from Starbucks and watch the people for a couple of minutes.

Precise movement, but not unique. This all-way pedestrian crossing/scramble is considered one of the defining Tokyo highlights, although the concept has spread to various other cities in the world as well. Even inside Tokyo there are other intersections of the same kind. Even still it makes a nice detour, especially if you can get one of the chairs at the Starbucks on the second level.

A sea of people!. The crossing has what literally feels like a sea of people, through much of the day. While walking through isn't a piece of cake, the crossing works. The energy is palpable, and this is a great place to see a slice of Tokyo. Plenty of shopping and eating options around, looking down at the crossing for a little while from say Starbucks is fun

Crazy but it works.. You must visit the Shibuya Pedestrian crossing. I am just amazed that it works so well. Best spots to watch the crossing from above statbucks providing you can get a window seat that looks over the crossing. Or the station walk way also looks over the crossing. Well worth your time.
PEOPLE! Every where!. This was a blast as the energy, day and night is so invigorating. The whole area is full of things to see, watch, eat, and buy. It is a great place to go and kill the whole day.
Shibuya crossing. A wonderful experience to cross a junction in a systematic way. Visitors will definately record, selfies and snap pictures while scrambling the way.
Crossing and happy. Experience it yourself! Happy to cross this road. Got lots of shopping area, railway station and best spot to chill with friends.

Big shopping district; Iconic location. We hopped on the subway to Shibuya so that we could say that we had seen the famous crosswalk, but as a district it wasn't really us. It is certainly an iconic part of Tokyo, and I'm glad we went, but this is truly a district for those who love to shop, and unfortunately that isn't me and my husband. Shibuya 109 is a must-shop destination if you are keen, and I would have loved to see the crosswalk lit up at night, but unfortunately our time in Tokyo ran out before we had the chance.It also didn't help that we couldn't find the subway line we wanted back out of Shibuya; it turns out the one we were looking for leaves the station above ground so you have to climb a flight of steps. After a long, busy day getting lost in the crowds of Shibuya wasn't ideal!

Crowded but the Icon of Tokyo. I visited the amazing Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble with some friends in August 2015. I recognised it immediately from films and TV shows. It's just one of the major icons of Tokyo! And crossing the road with everyone else is so much fun. I recommend you come back and do it again at night! It's fab.
Shocking Sight. You will be shocked when you get to see the amount of people crossing. Kind of lost myself as I was there on a sunday. Worth visiting
just like in the movies. People, people, people, people...great for feeling that Tokyo busyness and good photo opportunity. Walk across and then head up to Starbucks to watch from above.
Scramble Crossing - Crowded. Shibuya Crossing location is in front of garden with Huchiko Statue. Amazing, Extremely crowded with pedestrians

Too full of millennial with selfie sticks!. This once human rite of passage has now turned into avoiding millennials recording the useless minutiae of their lives. It was already an effort to dodge all the locals walking through and it's now become frustrating with the sheer bulk of mostly Chinese tourists joining in the chaps

Must see. One of the images that one often sees of Tokyo is the Shibuya Crossing so I had to see it for myself.
It is not as big as one envisages but nevertheless it is interesting.
coincidentally, there was a big video ad running nearby so when the pedestrians launched themselves into the crossing the music was the William Tell Overture.

A unique experience and odd attraction. People attracting more people.. There's not much to say... A ginormous crowd floods the street every couple of minutes and it's sort of overwhelming and cool to see from inside the crowd, as well as looking down from a nearby building. You will be many people taking photos of the crowds. Might as well too! Hachiko statue is right by the JR Shibuya station as well.
Iconic . It was cool to cross the famous area but its just another street. It was just something to do in between other activities. Go to say you went otherwise don't waste too much time there.
Interesting. Just a lot of people crossing at the same time...not much to see, but it is iconic and slightly interesting. Lots of shopping in Shibuya. Right in front of the Shibuya JR station.
Good to see. This is good for a quick visit while exploring Shibuya. There's a Starbucks looking over the crossing that offers a good vantage point for pictures and videos.

Orderly disorder. How people manage to cross the street all at the same time without any confusion is a sofht to behold. Situated just outside the Shibuya station, the pedestrian crossing draws a crowd of amused tourists taking photos and videos of how people cross the street. The surrounding buildings look like Times Square in NYC. The smaller walkways lead to shop after shop after shop of almost every kind of goods you can imagine. So pack up and do the pedestrian crossing! It will lead you to great finds in tokyo!

Crazy pedestrian crossing in Shibuya. This is a series of pedestrian crossings just outside the train station at Shibuya linking up lots of different shopping areas. As its a main area it was busy each time we visited. The area at night is reminiscent of Times Square with the big electric billboards and electronic adverts. Traffic whizzes up and down the street but when the lights change hundreds of people cross zig zag and straight. There's some good vantage points to take overhead photos by standing on the side of some raised flower beads once you don't step in the flower bed. Its a bustling fun place to visit with great photo opportunities

Tokyo is a scramble itself. So because I had seen this scramble on so many shows, I made it a point to go even though I only had 4 nights in Tokyo. It was definitely cool to see and I got a couple great pictures, but the whole city is a scramble in my opinion. I would say go here, but make sure you plan something else in the area (I would consider Makeashita Lane to browse) so this is not your only reason to go to this area
Loved the experience!. What an iconic place. Incredibly busy but awesome to see once in a lifetime! Somewhat of a Tokyo icon.

Site to see . So this insane crosswalk is a must see. It only occupied for 15 minutes but it's in Shibuya which is very lively neighborhood so no reason to not see the crossing. A few restaurants and cafes offer an upstairs view of crossing. Check out Shibuya while in Tokyo and watch this crazy mass of humanity cross the street.

Cross walk which not surprisingly is crowded!. I think this crosswalk came to me so hyped up that I expected more. My boyfriend and I got off the JR line at Shibuya to watch the crossing at the crosswalk. We went to a near by hotel (25th floor) to get a view and it was crowded but not as fun and chaotic as we thought it would be. If you have the time, do it. If not, it's definitely something you can skip.
Lively shopping district in Tokyo. This area has a good night view, with lots of bright signs in many colours. Good shopping in this area too (clothes, chain & department stores).
So so busy! Great to watch!. An amazing sight! We watched all the people crossing for about 10 minutes before crossing ourselves. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area.
Heaps of fun . It's a great experience for first timers. The vibe and atmosphere is so much fun and the amount of people is crazy! Great time

Don't go on a public holiday as it's almost empty of people. We had great expectations of going up to the 2nd floor of the Starbucks building and watching 5,000 people cross this intersection at the same time but it was not to be. We went on the 1st January, which we thought would make this place extra busy but it was almost deserted. I doubt there were more than a hundred people using the crossing at any time during the hour or so we were there. Also, the part of the Starbucks building that normally allows visitors to go to the 2nd floor to take photo's was closed and we had no option but to buy drinks in Starbucks and go to their 2nd floor area. The most interesting thing we saw was a man with a dog wearing sunglasses who posed his dog on the dog statue outside the station so tourists could take photo's. Disappointing experience but we'll know better next time not to go on a public holiday.

Busy!!!!. Funny place to go. Lots of people crossing the crossing ;-)
A should-see while in Tokyo.
Close to the statue of the famous dog who after his owner died went to the station every day and waited for the owner to come back.

If you're in Shibuya chech this out. I've been in Tokyo a couple of times and I always come here and watch this place especially at night time with all the lights all around. And when you're there don't forget to check out the statue of the famous dog that waited for his master for a long time. A famous Japanese true story.

Tokyo Controlled Chaos. I had to come see Shibuya after seeing it in so many movies and shows on japan. When i got out of the station i was disappointed as the area was more open than i expected and there were a lot less people than i expected. The crossing was similar to any busy junction in any major city. However later in the evening the crossing was ridiculous, people moving in every direction and then nobody as the cars started moving. Definitely recommend going for a look but for sure do it in the evening. (For good photos head up to the Starbucks across from the station its window looks down on the Scramble.)
Shibuya cross. One hell of a cross .. Won't believe it unless you see it yourself ... Center of the great shibuya district

It's Tokyo . So! This is the real Tokyo. Welcome to the city the size of Australia. It's not surprising that this pedestrian crossing is so crowded and busy. Still... It's fascinating to watch people 'scramble' to cross the other side of the road. Go at night and watch the city light up! It's a billboard haven, advertising everything imaginable to man.
Crossing back and forward. It's an experience to cross it in the first row and see the mass of pedestrians flowing in all directions.

Fun to watch. This is not an attraction or a sight per se, but nevertheless it is a fun place to spend a few minutes. Watching the massive scramble at the crossing is quite the spectacle and at night, it becomes even more spectacular with all the lights blazing. Chaos at its best :)

Always shown in movies. This intersection is usually shown in movies and dramas, so I had to come see it in person when I got the chance to visit Tokyo! In this big scramble, people will manage to avoid bumping into each other, but make sure you look in front of you. My boyfriend was distracted with filming while crossing, he didn't notice a cyclist coming by, but luckily I held him back. Definitely a fun experience crossing this busy intersection!

Not much. So I had heard lots of about this, hearing it was crazy and huge and all this stuff basically exclaiming how exciting crossing this street was, but I have to say I was a bit disappointed. Maybe I'm just a jaded New Yorker but this crossing had nothing on time square which has a million people going in a million directions with absolutely no regard to traffic lights.The craziest thing I witness was someone trying to run me down with their bike, but apart from that, it was not very impressive.

Crazy!. The first night we went to Shibuya was a Monday and it was so crowded, we then went on a Saturday night and it was unbelievable. The atmosphere is great and the crossing and lighting is fantastic. Lots of restaurants and shops and easy to get there by train.

Winter visit. Its widely know area of Japan. We have to go to Starbucks to have an elevated platform for better view. Its busier probably 5 pm -9 pm .the led lights of billboards will add to the color of the scene.
Eye opener. Oh wow. Stand at a corner and enjoy the view of hundreds of people crossing at the same time. Star bucks on level 1 also offers a good viewing if you can get a spot.

Worth a look. We stayed in a hotel right on the scramble so we used it plenty. Although I would definitely recommend seeing it if you were in the area, I would worry too much if you didn't ;) The view is better from a height rather than actually being on the crossing. Its fine but once you've done it it's not that interesting anymore.

A five minute attraction. walk across, and then walk back again. That's it. Avoid all the other people and their selfie sticks and video cameras. Sure it is busy, and the "Lost in Translation" helped make it more famous, but it is one of many busy intersections in Tokyo

Must See. Just because it's totally hectic!!! So, so many people you get washed away in them. It's in every sense "a scramble" but def a sight to be seen. If you want to watch it from afar there's plenty of cafes overlooking it like the multi story L'Occitane

Wow !!! A sea of people moving like a tide to and fro !!!. We stood here for an hour taking pictures.. It was 4;30pm when we arrived and couldnt see what the fuss was all about.. bY 5:15 we were in a virtual tidal rush of humanity... amazing... TIP ! there is a 2nd storey coffee shop in the shibuya station which has a great overhead view....

Supper cool to watch . I watched the people crossing a few times and did it myself once. It is very busy. If you have a fear of crowds it would not be a good place to go. There's also lots of electronic tvs--it's like a Japanese time square. There were lots of high end cars driving around and some nice stores in the area.
Great shopping area. Located at the east exit of the Shibuya train station. A must see for everyone. Considering the amount of pedestrian and vehicle traffic in this area it is spotless

One of the highlight of Shibuya!. Fashion, Trendy and modern shops, different brands, busy people, tasty food, youngsters, and crowded with people... these are the words to describe shibuya. One of the most famous street here. And the pesdestrian street is well-known around the world too where all pedestrian can cross at different angles. This is a great experience and livelihood of japanese livelihood.Simply enjoy the moment I stand right in the middle of the road where many people walking diagonally the road and capture some beautiful moments.

Times Square of Tokyo. This is Tokyo's version of New York's Times Square. Better be ready to cross the street. Very busy and when the pedestrians cross, you better watch where you are going. A must visit.

A great experience. Be sure to bring your selfie stick or your Go Pro to capture a video of you crossing and blending in the big crowd of people there. Also, be quick when taking photos! You wouldn't want to be hit by a car 😂 plenty of shopping places in the area which reminds me of Times Square in New York
One of the busiest crossing I have seen. If you like to watch people and wonder about their story, this is probably the perfect place to do it.

Amazing Place. This intersection is absolutely amazing. The amount of people that cross is awesome to see. There is a Starbucks across from the station, that has an upstairs section so you can see the whole area. The shopping in Shibuya is phenomenal!

Great to see/experience. I actually happened to come across the area by accident. It is the area that you will see in movies that show Tokyo and its mass of people. If you have seen the movie Lost in Translation you will recognize the crossing. In fact they shot a lot of the scenes from the Starbucks on the second floor that overlooks the crossing. I recently read it is the busiest Starbucks in the world. Go up to the second floor and watch the amazing spectacle as the lights change.
A must see. Crossed a few times at different times of the day and night! So much fun, crazy amounts of people. Such a sensory overload, Fantastic experience.

Not just another crossing. So we have been attracted to come to see the crossing based on review and rave from friends and review site. On tip: if you want to take picture of the crossing and yet don't want the crowd on level two of the Starbucks, go to the bridge that join the Shibuya station and a shopping mall. It's free.

The infamous scramble. Pretty cool site to see tons of people at night and even during the day.My boyfriend and I sat in the Starbucks it was a perfect birds eye view of the scramble we even took cool pics and video.

I will never cross a road and have as much fun!. I went across different parts of this crossing about 8 times. First time to take it in, second time to take pictures, the third to make a video, the fourth because I became stuck and had to ... the fifth, sixth, seventh and eigth were for the heck of it!It's odd to describe how crossing a road can be 'fun' but there seems to be glee in everyones face as they pass you. Living in London where crossing the road is boring, usually wet and full of sour faces, I really appreciated the experience.there is a Starbucks on one corner of the crossing in a bookstore, you can go up a level and view the crossing from above.

Shibuya Crossing - You just have to cross it. Wanted to see it and it was great although not as crowded at 10am on Saturday which was when we were there, but we enjoyed the area and there were lots of shops around to look through.

The Night life is Whats good here. I went to Shibuya 109 during the day and then to the city at night. This place is similar to NYC Times Square with many arcades where you can win prizes and take pictures in tiny booths.Still this area is dazzlingThe area is very congested. I had a hard time orienting myself just due to the rush of people walking around.Another poi here is the Hachiko Dog Statue. He is quie popular. I had a harder time getting a picture with Hachiko than With Lady Gaga hahah.***A general tip: Rent a pupuru pocket wifi for your trip as free wifi is hard to come by in Tokyo. This little device kept me connected to google maps and I basically used the walking directions to get around

Interesting. Located just outside shibuya station, it can get busier at night. Tried the crossing from any direction while recording it. It's cool experience. Once u r tired u can go to Hachiko statue lol, just around the corner.

Shibuya crossing!. It's located just outside the JR shibuya station, if you get there at night its really busy. Although i give it 5 stars it does not warrant a special trip to see it, go there only if you want to do some shopping too!
People everywhere!. This is crazy. You can literally cross in any direction you want! Shops littered everywhere... Many drug stores selling cheap make up!
WOW. just one word to describe this amazing attraction...WOW. Get carried away by the crowd..feel people and sound around you..reach the center of the crossing and stop a while...fantastic !

Busy..all the time. Mayhem all the time..and I dont know whyThe first time I have been to Shibuya was in the morning, when most employees were already at work. It was busy then.When I cam back a year later, it was a Saturday at lunch time. And I thought it was so funny already. But lo and behold when it was sundown! It was mayhem! :o And everyone's in a hurry. Though not really an attraction, its interesting that even its mayhem everywhere, people were still organized.

Interesting but thought it would be better. It is worthwhile going here at night to see the lights and the hoardes of people. However, once you have travelled through Shinjuku station or travelled the metro at peak hour the crowds are not that overwhelming. Still interesting so go if in the area.

Madness. The Shibuya crossing is one of those "attractions" whose appeals lies in a pretty plain fact: there are lots of people in Japan. Coming from a country with a lower population density, you quickly get used to this fact, and crossing the street there is a bit of fun, ducking and weaving through the madness. Once through, it's good to view the crossing from a higher point, such as the Starbucks nearby, though this is where most people go to do it, so it's usually very crowded. There's a lot to do in Shibuya (shopping-wise) so the crossing is a nice start.

Iconic. This pedestrian crossing is pretty iconic. If you enjoy anime, or Japanese films or drama, you'll notice that this crossing is featured frequently. Although it's not much of an "attraction" or activity, it is fun to see it really come to life and be in the center of the action for real. (Although, don't visit this place on Halloween! It gets crazy crowded and you can hardly breathe. But visit any other time.)
LOTS OF PEOPLE SO COOL. There is always sooo many people.Busy busy busy.Just watching is fun.At night is the best for pictures.
Iconic pedestrian crossing. Best to view and take photos from a higher view point at one of the surrounding buildings. Other than that - it's just another busy crossing.

An interesting cultural event. Start by going into the Starbucks (yes...Starbucks) and go to the upper level windows. You don't have to make a purchase to get to this area by the way. It gives you a great view of the crossing from above. Once you have seen it from above...head down and do all of your selfies. I was there before and after sundown after a rain and the reflections were fantastic. Great shopping in the area and plenty of restaurants.

Famous crossing in centre of Shibuya. It's better to look down on this crossing to appreciate what happens to the mass of humanity when all the traffic is stopped at the same time. As a pedestrian it just seems like a relatively busy crossing!

TO HELP VISITORS GET TO THE NARITA EXPRESS TRACK WITH LUGGAGE. I am writing this to help visitors who need to get to the Narita Express track at Shibuya station with heavy luggage, pointing out how to get to the elevators which are NOT easily locatable without help or information.I assume you have already bought your Narita Express ticket. At the point of purchase (in the station.ask), they will tell you it is at level 3 track 4.(Remember this)The easiest way is to then go through the turnstiles there BUT it means walking up stairs or escalators.1. Find the statute of the famous Hachiko Dog. (You can't miss it. Ask).2. Face the statute head to head.3. To your left is Tokyu Department Store.4. There are two entrances.5. Take the entrance on the left, ie, closer to the train station entrance.6. Walk through it.7. You will pass an information counter. You can ask again if you want.8. Emerge on the other side and you will see a huge ugly head/face statute on your right.9. Walk strait on and you will find lockers on your right, and then on your left.10. You will see the JR Line information counter on the left in another entrance to the station. It is the south entrance.11. You can ask again.12. Face the info counter and you will see the entrance turnstiles on your right.13. Go through with your paid for Narita express ticket.14. Turn right immediately. You will find a lift hidden but can be found.15. Take it to level 2.16. At level 2 exit and find the next lift which is close by (My memory went hazy here but you can't get lost. It's Japan! Ask).17. Take the lift to level 3. 18. Look up and always, always follow "Narita Express" with the aeroplane sign next to it.19. You will find2 sets of travelators.20. You will gradually approach track 4. BUT the first time you will see stairs.21. Take the travelator to the end and you can find (hidden but can found again) another lift to take down to track 4.22. Once on the track, look a the displays above head and it should read Narita Express.23. Wait. It comes, get on.It takes about 10 to 15 minutes to get to the track from Hachiko. So plan ample time before your train timing.
It's worth seeing. You could easily see this very busy crosswalk in less than 15 minutes, so I recommend it. We only saw it during the daytime, but I hear it's fun to watch at night as well.
Great fun. Shibuya is a great area to visit with busy streets and a great atmosphere. We spent about 10 minutes going back and forth amongst the thousands of people.

Fun to watch. My kids loved this, all five corners stop and this sea of people crisscross all at once. You see all tourist go to the middle of the intersection to take a selfi of the organized pandemonium. Watch out not to get run over lol. Have fun
Beautiful chaos. It's an awesome site to see when the little man turns green and the masses start crossing the street!

A must for first time visitors. If you've never been to Tokyo, you've got to put this on your list. It's just a great bit of Japanese culture to experience. Yes it's just a crossing, but it's a hive of activity around the station and Centre Gai which makes it great people (culture) watching. If you're into that sort of thing, you have to experience this. Take your camera and just chill here for an hour. You wont regret it.

Busy road crossing. This is pretty interesting as far as road crossings go. Unfortunately, for most people, road crossings just aren't that interesting.Yes, it's interesting how so many people cross in different directions without constantly colliding. Yes, it's pleasing to watch it happen over and over. Yes, it's apparently interesting enough for numerous tourists to be filming and photographing their crossings every time it goes.No, it's not worth going just for the crossing. Fortunately, there's an abundance of shops and other attractions nearby. For most, the crossing is just a way to get between the station and the surrounding area.There is a great vantage point from the Starbucks opposite the station if you want to sit and watch the crossing for a bit longer.

Organised Chaos. This is an interesting attraction for obvious reasons. There's a lot more that Shibuya has to offer but it's certainly worth watching this spectacle. The Starbuck's on level 2 is a great vantage point.

A must go to place!. I recommend all kinds of travelers to visit this place. It is a cool and spoken of place and a must go to if you are in Tokyo. We were there on a Sunday around 5 pm and it was super crowded. I have heard that sitting at Starbucks 2nd floor and watch all the people cross would be so cool.

Sit back, relax, and observe the pinnacle of Shibuya's liveliness.. Definitely worth a few minutes of your time, and very easily accessible. It's a no-brainer. Generally between 6-8PM will get you the best crowd.
Hectic. What a crazy place loved every minute of it so busy which is part of it, if you atay long enough you will see some unusual things.

Not sure why people are so enamoured?. Lots of people crossing a road? Basically I didn't purposefully head here, just ended up here as everyone does via walking the area and enjoying the sites.All this is is a huge number of people going about their everyday business and crossing a road.. people loving this is just bemusing for me and only those living the 'tourist' or 'hipster' theme should bother looking for this really.

Watch Out! Relax! You won't be knocked down!. Very famous and interesting Shibuya pedestrian scramble area. Very interesting sight! OMG! Some tourist even stop and take photographs in the middle of this scramble/crossing but are not bumped by the crossing pedestrian.
Amazing. It's amazing how so many people cross the street and it is done in such an orderly manner. Wonderful experience just to be part of the crowd.

Exciting!. I had to say it was pretty cool to walk across the scrambler. As hectic as it looks it's actually pretty organized here in Japan and going through the scrambler is exciting. Feel free to be that person to stop and take a selfie people won't bump into you :)

New Years fun !! . We were in Tokyo for new year, we had read lots of things saying new year in Tokyo was very quiet, no one did anything, it was family time etc. One person said go here - we were so glad we did! We got in at 7am after meeting some great locals who met us the next day to show us round a temple! Amazing !

Stand back, find a good spot, and watch the crowd. Loads and loads of people, day and night, just nice to watch.Gets very busy, but so does most other areas in Tokyo.Lots of shopping and food around, get ready to eat your way to fatness.You can find some budget restaurant where all the working people go to.Great fun overall for shopping, eating, seeing the lights at night.

Order amidst chaos. It's order because everyone know what and where they are heading. It's chaos because you will feel like a gold fish in the midst of incoming salmons charging at you. Be there and experience the energy of shibuya scramble crossing

Fun to watch and scramble. Great photo op at night and a fun place to walk around and explore. Took lots of pics, did some scrambling, and found a great place not far away for a fresh s'more. Great night out.
A bucket list item!. From Shinjuku station, head towards exit 8 "Hachiko exit". Take a photo w/ Hachi, then head for the Pedestrian Scramble and be a part of the fun!

Go to the midddle... then look around. Crossing diagonally is an interesting concept, and when you see it in reality it's something you just have to do... take your camera with you and take a picture from the middle. At night with all the neon lights it looks even better.

Part of a wondering day. Ants! All of us. It was pretty crazy to see but I wouldn't exactly call this a destination. There are lots of shops and mall type things around but I wouldn't of been there if I didn't eat around the corner after a long stroll through Yoyogi Park.

Take your own piece of the hype!. It's just a crazy scene to see and experience, the first time here we crossed it a few times just to see how awesome it was.Don't worry, you won't be the only foreigner/tourist wanting a piece of the action. The locals are used to it and will just navigate around you if you're in the way. Definitely a fun experience.
Crossed it!. The famed Shibuya Crossing was just how it looks like in pictures. Busy! Hundreds of people cross this and many (visitors) stop in the middle to snap that perfect picture.

Pedestrian madness! It's fun!. I'm glad I had the opportunity to see this, I had seen it on tv and pictures many times but seeing it in the flesh is an experience! The crossing crowds, the lights, the music, the huge Ads, the noise, it's all crazy, coordinated and fun at the same time, It's something you don't see every day; the are some vantage points where you can take nice pictures from.Ensure you have time to go see this spectacle!
Scramble!. Good Fun at the scramble,great spot to watch it all unfold is from the Starbucks on the corner.During the day it's busier, a unique experience.

Worth a look...nothing special. Was ok for a look but really not that exciting. A lot of the people crossing are just people taking photos. Might of just been the day we went. Good shopping and food close by so I was glad we checked it out.

Fun Fun Fun. An insane number of people go across vertically, horizontally, and diagonally when the light turns. There are so many people, locals and tourists, and one would sometimes get pushed around. Come at night for the biggest hit from the shoppers, drunkies, foodies, and looking-around tourists! There are many food and shopping options around, so try to get lost around this area, and one would not be disappointed!

Wow!. My 5th time here and am always amazed by the constant amount of people walking pass the main traffic junction in front of the Shibuya station (across Hachiko's statue)!!! Worth the photo opportunity in the middle of the crossing, if you can!!!

Great experience of the world's most famous street crossing. Walking across Shibuya Crossing was on our to-do list while in Japan and it was quite an experience. It was packed with people as we crossed. We went to the second story of the nearby Starbucks and watched the crossing below a few times before crossing again ourselves.

One to tick off the list. Fun to tick off the list and is very hectic although I must say it is quite short lived. A decent area with a nice selection of shopping and food and some places on an evening out too. The area is still quite lively at night but of course not as lively so it's a very good place to come to.

People Watching at its Best. You have to do this at least once when you are in Tokyo. Best vantage spots are: - step onto the small garden wall (with the statue of kids playing) next to the crossing as you come out of Shibuya Station - this gives you an above-the-crowd view of the Shibuya Crossing- 2nd Floor of Starbucks - but here be prepared to wait your turn for window seats as people tend to plant their behinds on the seats with views of the crossing and don't move for hours ...It's probably more time efficient to take your photos from the sidewalk, of Tokyo pedestrians making their way in different directions at this huge crossing.If you know Hong Kong, this is just like the Sogo Crossing in Causeway Bay.

Go for the "madness", stay for the shops. I went here because it seemed to be one of the "Top 10 things to do" while in Tokyo. I also wanted to make sure I was able to witness one of the crazy pedestrian scramble dashes you see so frequently on tv and in media. It wasn't as massively entertaining as I would have hoped, and seemed somewhat smaller than I pictured, but it was still enjoyable due to passing the Hachi statue on the way down to the crosswalk. It's a good experience and it's easily accessible from the train, so you don't have to stay for long if you don't want to.

Worth about 2 minutes. You can go on the 2nd floor of the Starbucks to get the best view of the scramble. There are rarely any seats available, but worth about a 2 minute visit, on the way to or from another place.
Amazing site. You should definitely do this if in Tokyo, to see that great throng of people all converging at once with no road rage.

Big crossing... . Huge crossing, heaps of people, but definitely not a highlight of my trip. I don't believe it is a necessary to-do list item. The area around is good for exploring and shopping however so it ultimately was a worthwhile visit.

Great experience. The people! Wow, where do they all come from? A must do experience while in Tokyo. We were there on Christmas Day and there were some quirky Christmas decorations, like the bronze statue of Hachiko with a Santa hat and a live cat below it licking it's paws also with a Santa hat on, and fake santa's climbing the trees.. We did try to watch the crossing from Starbucks but could not get a set by the windows-would have been a great vantage point..
Must see. This is a must do when in Tokyo. It is also fun to see it from the second level of Starbucks or the second level of the subway station.

Worth the Trip to Japan. Just being at the famed Shibuya crossing is worth the trip to Japan. Best time to be here to totally experience the mad dash is from 6pm to 8pm where literally thousands of people try to cross the intersection at the same time. Should you want to take a video of the scramble, Shibuya station Hachiko exit on the 2nd floor, as well as Tsutaya Starbucks 2nd floor are recommended locations.
If you go to Tokyo you've got to go here. One of the most amazing sights. People, people, people and all orderly and polite. A snapshot of Japan.

Just incredible... I loved it, but I was extremely disappointed... The New Year's countdown was cancelled. I know that everyone was on high alert, but I think that they should have still had it. It's a great place to see (and you'll have to anyway since the station is right by it) and to explore.

Crazy/Awesome!. It was awesome to experience it firsthand! I thought I will only see this place in pictures! It's really a scramble! We crossed this famous PedXing a few times, just to experience craziness all over again. Must-see/must-try when in Shibuya.
Amazing. Diagonal pedestrian allows you to go straight across where you want to go ! So many people crossing at the same time !

Never ending wave of people . This crossing is probably one of the most photographed streets in the world...and it's just incredibly fascinating to watch how hundred of people cross it in multiple directions but never hit into each other (unlike in London...) head for the Starbucks upstairs on one of the corners and sit by the window and just observe the flow, it's pretty spectacular, particularly during the rush hour.

Busy crossing but fun!. A must do while in Tokyo!Amazing that a massive number of people can cross at the same time and in several directions without hitting each other. OMG, we crossed about five times while in Shibuya and not to mention it is right in the middle of fantastic shopping malls. Our family enjoyed the experience!

Take a Video of Yourself Crossing!. 'What's so special about a pedestrian crossing?' You may ask. But this one is different, take a video of yourself crossing! I had so much fun with my family doing that. However, you may need to keep your direction focused, otherwise, you may end up on the difficult side of the crossing that you wanted to be. Go for it!
Crowded. When I decided to come to Japan, I really want to know this scramble. And I get surprise to see how many people walk there! It was crowded at the same time organized. Really nice experience

let the scramble begin in 5..4..3..2..1. A visit to tokyo will not be complete without an experience and visit to the popular shibuya crossing and its famous pedestrian scramble. We took the yamanote train from shinjuku to shibuya station. from the station we went up the main streets and the famous hachiko statute greets us. then porceeded to the pedestrian and waited to the scramble to happen. It was raining then so we ended up using the famous japanese transparent umbrellas as well. Tips if you want to get a photo or video from a far? There a starbucks right across the ped xing in one of the malls. It is famous for people shooting their friends/family crossing the street . You have a good view of the scramble from there.
Never feel better crossing a street. This pedestrian crossing is one of a kind. A massive number of people crossing at the same time to several different directions. You must experience!

The most busiest crossing in the world!!. If u happened to be in Tokyo, this place is a must in your list. The crossing is so famous it has featured in a number of Hollywood movies like Fast and Furious: Tokyo Drift. It is amazing to see so many people cross at the same time without hitting one another.

An experience!. Even if just for a laugh, you should visit Shibuya crossing during rush hour. Thousands of people cross at each set of green lights, miraculously missing each other. Whether you are watching the mayhem from above (at Starbucks) or getting involved, it really is quite something. I'd recommend it during Halloween - you won;t see anything like it anywhere else!

Meh. We were here about 8pm at night and it seemed just like any other crossing in Tokyo. You certainly did pick up a vibe that this was a place to go and see, it's just something you don't have to plan to spend lots of time doing!
Busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. Go on a weekend evening....6PM. Mind boggling......look at the latest fashions and the beautiful people. This area is the fashion capital of Japan.
Amazing!!!. Had a ball here! Sights and sounds of Tokyo! Awesome experience to get to be one of the 250,000 people that cross this busy intersection everyday.

Amazing experience !. We were here by Nov 2015. I found this attraction through Tripadvisor and decided to experience it. We can see those pedestrian line once we exit from JR station at first floor. We took photo at Starbuck cafe also. It was so amazing when we crossed the pedestrian together with hundred people. It is not a crossroad but more like criss-cross between each other. I had never see so many pedestrian at a busy road like this. Must come if you are shopping at Shibuya because the price of skin products selling here are cheaper than Shinjuku.

Crowded all the times. Shopping and restaurants around this area. Everyone came out from train station has to wait to across this place. I went here many times and surprised that there were always lots of people in this place. Amazing that it is always smooth to walk by not interrupt each other.
Overrated. Yes, if you are used to rotating traffic crossing , it's cool to see all the people cross the street in every direction at the same time, especially at rush hours. But then you are done.

Crazy at New Years. The crossing is very impressive and busy as predicted. We travelled to Shibuya on New Years Eve and did some karaoke to use up some time before the countdown. When we came out of karaoke at around 11:30 the area was absolutely packed and very hard to move anywhere. A very crazy area to be at new years, especially when people started to climb buildings, the police also moved everyone away from the crossing area and into the other streets. It was still easy enough to slowly navigate our way out and back to the subway station and back to our accommodation.

It is certainly an experience. We stayed near this crossing about a five minute walk away and it was certainly an experience to cross that road with a wall of people coming towards you. Everyone was orderly and no one pushed shoved or abused. Just go with the flow. It was very busy when we we're there but I am told its busy all the time.

You have to experience this to understand it. We took a short train ride from Shinjuku to Shibuya which was 3 stops and then made our way to this famous intersection with bright lights and ads being displayed on large billboards on the buildings. The crowds were amazing but orderly as the Japanese are polite are orderly. We found this everywhere we went, that even in crowds it is still easy to get around and they are very systemised in how they get around. A great place to go and see and also great shopping around.
Awesome. Go around rush hour during a work week. It's truly awesome to see. Make sure you stand on something to get a good picture.

Very busy people crossing. This place are famous because of a lot of people walking across the street when the cars stop, very crowded and interesting sight. This location are near exit of Shibuya Station
Love the busy city vibe. love the intersection and Hachico waiting for you patiently around the corner. Cant imagine what TimesSquare NY feels like
Nice sight. It is cool if you want to take great picture in sea of people just be careful not stumble upon others in this super busy crossing street

Come here if you want to look like a tourist. If you like annoying people by stopping in the middle of the road to pose for photographs then this is the place for you. But please don't. It's just a crossing so let people cross and get where there going. If you really must watch this then go to the coffee shop and watch gracefully from above.

You're in Tokyo.. If you want to feel like you're in Tokyo, cross Shibuya Crossing...but not just once! And don't bump into anyone or stop in the middle of the crossing to take photos (very annoying). Especially great at night.

An Awesome Sight! . I would definitely put this on the to-do list in Tokyo. It is located outside the central exit of Shibuya Train station. It is very easy to get to, doesn't take up a lot of time and doesn't cost anything.

Well it is just a pedestrian walk, but fun / busy. It is exactly what it claim to be. The neighborhood makes it a good destination. Start with this. Walk north through the shopping area towards the two parks. The one with the shrine and the one where all the locals go to have fun on sundays. Then continue to the local luxury good street and the teenage trendy street just east of the shrine.

Seen It In The Media... Just As Cool In Person!. Finally I can tick off another experience off my long list of places to visit in the world! Coming from the most isolated city in the world, this is the stuff you see on TV! To finally have seen it in person! Wow. Just wow! A must visit when in Tokyo!

A famous Pedestrian Crossing. How amazing, even a pedestrian crossing could be such a famous land mark. However it is really a sight to behold. Once the lite goes green, it is really a scramble but than it is in Japan, it is still in orderly scramble. One could join the crowd crossing the roads or stays in one of the place nearby (Walkway at Keio Station is one of it) and see people 'scrambling'
walk walk walk. grateful I can walk there, can't stop for feel amaze. thousand people, so crowd. music everywhereI wanna crossing again and again
Crowed place. The most famous crossing in the world. It was an amazing to see so many people crossing the street.There is Starbucks coffee so stayed there to took some photos.

New Years Eve . As always on New Years the police were in full force routing people and keeping things in order.It's full of electricity and a must do spot for New Years Eve. Walk around, pub hop, join folks outside for a loud joyous countdown.

Normal chaos. Not exactly what I expected but still an interesting landmark that makes for a great photo. Best spots are from Shibuya Excel Hotel Tokyu (ideally) but lifts can only be operated by staying guests, L'Occitane Cafe or the walkway between the Keio Station.

The Stressful Grind of Tokyo represented. The dazzle of the city lights, the temptation of designer label shopping and the irresistible aroma of food abound in this place. Check out the nearby tourist assistance train car and the stature of Hachiko

A Race Accross The trafic Junction. I was amazed by the Shibuya Pedestrian crossing. I have never seen such thing before. The people looks like racing from one end to the other. This is the only junction a have seen where people can cross it diagonally. A must go location when Tokyo
Crazy sight in Tokyo. If you visit tokyo this is one of the sights to see! you'll never experience a crazier crossing, with hundreds of people crossing in five different directions. Crazy indeed!

New Years on the Crossing. Caught a taxi to Shibuya crossing tonight which is New Years Eve. It's very much like Times Square in NY with all the electronic billboards towering off the buildings, but it's a lot more organized. NYE in Times Square would be chaos, this was really peaceful and controlled. Make sure you see it at night to really appreciate it.

Best during rush hour. At the end, it is only a street crossing like you have many in Tokyo. But it is simply great to see during rush hour - how quickly the intersection fills up and empties out again.

Shibuya Crossing. busy people and tourist alike are here. with the more than 5 way pedestrian it is a busy intersection which is nice to look at. everybody going there own way. best be seen from the starbucks near it.

Shibuya Crossing. Wow!!! Shibuya Crossing is the biggest intersection in the world, and when you see it, there's no doubt about it! Swarms of people come from all directions, and it's a really cool sight. Definitely worth seeing!

not as obvious as i thought it would be.. i was honestly unsure if it was even the scramble crossing because it seemed like any other crossing. perhaps if you got an elevated view it would seem more impressive (try starbucks or the bridge with the painting called the myth of tomorrow). i was honestly more interested in the hachiko statue.

A vast sea of humanity . Yup. If you are in the area, you gotta experience itOne minute the five plus pedestrian crossings are red and cars are buzzing by. Then the lights turn red, the walk signals turn green and a beautiful symphony of humanity starts an "organized chaos" to cross all the different streets. All in time to be safely across before the lights turn green and the cars start up againPretty cool

Has to be done. Well, its a little cliched but how can you come to Tokyo and not cross here? Go at night, its great. But just don't follow people out unless the lights are green - we saw some crazy salaryme, with briefcases swinging, just plow straight out into the traffic....truly crazy (and drunk!)
Humanity concentrated. An amazing spectacle of humanity moving in different directions all crossing the same intersection. Great shopping in the surrounding area

Frenzy!. It's just something you have to do to experience the buzz of Tokyo. Exit from Shibuya station at the Hachiko exit - there's a famous story around this dog that was made into a movie starring Richard Gere. It is not life changing, but really akin to doing the crossing in the UK for the Beatles. Just good fun if you're near the area!

A must see if you are in the area. This is one giant pedestrian crossing. One minute it is empty of people with them on the curb, and as soon as the pedestrian light goes green, there is a sea of people crossing in a myriad of directions, but somehow, with some order.This is worth seeing and experiencing if you are in Shibuya, but I wouldn't make a special trip to Shibuya just to see this. However, a trip to Shibuya for half a day to people watch and explore the shops is a good thing to do. Start at Shibuya and work your way via all the tiny streets up to Harajuku.
A sight to behold. Basically, this was just a typical four way crossing. It was a very busy shopping area and the crowd crossing in all directions was an interesting experience.

Not up to the Hype. We expected some jaw dropping experience but unfortunately although it was impressive it definitely wasn't all it was made out to be. We took advice of fellow Trip Advisers & headed to the Starbucks cafe for a primo spot to view - the downer was that as wel as lots of other tourists checking it all out - we found the majority of prime spots were taken by school kids sitting & texting of mobile phones while everyone clamored around them trying to get better views. Although they have every right to be there as well - I feel as though Starbucks should police the use of these spots more strictly as we waited for over 30 minutes while watching a group of ignorant school kids text - not once looking out at the spectacle we had all come to see. Hopefully Starbucks can sort this out as it appears the place is a victim of it's own popularity. Suggestion - maybe a deck out the front of the huge steel columns to add some much needed seating would go a long way. We will definitely give this one another go next time we come to Tokyo .
amazing sight to see. we called in here on out trip around Tokyo after seeing it on tv. Quite amazing seeing so many people cross the road. Like walking into a big swarm of bee's!!!

Busy Crossing. We know this intersection as the most photographed one. It was exciting to see all the locals waiting to cross and be a part of it throng. Try being there on a working week day. It would surely be more stunning.
busy but orderly. Typical of the Japanese, such a busy intersection works well. It is good to get up higher in the train station, or cafe's nearby to look down onto the intersection.

Wow. I've been to big cities but this crossing is so fun! The pedestrians have more rights aways than the cars! People are walking in every direction on this corner. My kids enjoyed the hustle of this scramble! It doesn't take more than a couple minutes but worth it!

It's just busy.... The only reason to go here is to photography the area at night time. Apart from that can't really see what the fuss is about regarding the road crossing. It's just very busy, but that's it.

Experience once only. 1st time it's all very exciting and novel. After that 1st or 2nd time trying to cross that intersection you'll dread the sheer amount of people trying to cross at the same time in ALL directions.

Good to visit try for experience. There's nothing else exciting here aside from crossing the street together with other hundreds of pedestrians. What I found more interesting here are the shops, restaurants and the people that visits this place. There are street performers outside Starbucks and they are very entertaining to watch and they are really good! The shops around cater to younger Japanese and the vibe of this place is really lively and young. It was already midnight but there are still lots of people strolling around and they seem to be friendly to tourists too!

Fun experience. One of the images of Tokyo, the Shibuya Scramble is best seen on weekends and when the weather is dry for the most number of people. Been here on a rainy day and there weren't a lot of people. Go to Starbucks as one of many places to people watch.
Good experience. Good experience that you have to do at least once but a different experience and much better at night.

Great photo op. It's huge, it's packed with people, and it's uniquely Shibuya! Filled with neon n led signs, it's really amazing. Head to the Tsutaya building and grab a seat at Starbucks to enjoy the view.

Interesting and very Tokyo. Definitely something you should check out just to say you've seen in Tokyo.. that's about it. You don't have to spend much time checking it out. Walk through it, see it from Starbucks, you're done. There's enough to see and do in Shibuya though, so you won't be wasting time coming to see the crossing

Not very exciting . Maybe it's because I'm from New York City, but I didn't find this intersection to be terribly exciting. Sure, it was pretty big and there were several cross streets. But nothing crazy or spectacular. Might be fun if you enjoy people-watching though.

Fun and Exciting. I went to Shibuya just to experience the pedestrian scramble. It was a very interesting experience for me. I was so amazed by the chaos and the number of people who cross at the same time. =)

Fun to soak in the atmosphere. It's fun just to feel the mad rush. Just be careful that you are not caught taking photos silly when the lights turn red. Makes you feel that you are in Tokyo. If it's a rainy day, make sure you get to look at this scramble from the windows at the train. You will see lots of umbrellas. What a sight. Was there during December, Christmas lights, umbrellas, Ah, what a beautiful sight
It's a big crossing....... That's about it. Go in rush hour times to see it at it's most busy (obviously) and watch the organised chaos ensue from the 2nd floor Starbucks .
So much fun . Across the street at least 10 times running back and forth with my girls! Busy, hectic and we loved it. What a great experience! What a blast!!! We shall return!!!!

Heart stomping!. One of a kind experience! You feel being engulfed by people from all sides... but dont feel any pain. Locals and tourists alike walk with a vibe that's exhilirating! Great way to start your first evening in Tokyo.

First time visitors should probably visit it. The best views can be gotten from Mark City (there is a slope where Mark City is connected to the JR Shibuya station, where people line up for photo ops). Walking in the scramble is kind of a fun experience, but otherwise, there is not much else to be said about it. Interesting nonetheless, and first-time visitors should experience it.

Iconic. There isn't a great deal to say about it i suppose.It's an iconic part of Tokyo with a good photo opportunity and i reason to watch tv and shout "I've been there" when you see it :)Surrounding area is good for shopping and food and it has amazing trnasport links in and out.

A must. Go Friday/ Saturday 6-8pm for best effect. A must do really.
To get the wow effect when you arrive and for your pictures/ videos go late afternoon / early evening, especially on a Friday/ Saturday night: you'd feel as if everyone in the world is congregating there!
Great place to see the life of Tokyo. People watching, coffee and chilling, there is only one best spot in Tokyo which is at any corner of shibuya pedestrian.
Interesting. Its like legal jaywalking.. Interesting... Shopping nearby. Worth dropping by in the evening to experience this....

Great to experience but smaller than expected . Being in the heart and soul of Tokyo must be a great experience at once and Shibuya crossing is a must to visit! I was actually expecting it to be more big than it,was. Highly recommend to look at it from the nearby Sturbucks coffee shop 5th floor. It is nice just to observe never ending river of people crossing it day and night.

Crazily crowded. It was nice to experience the crossing full of people and the hustle and bustle in the city. The people in Tokyo walk in extremely fast paces. I had to watch where I was walking and be careful not to walk into anyone! It is a must go place if you're visiting Tokyo. You have to be there to experience it!

Best to Visit at Evening / Night. The crossing is easily accessible with JR or Metro by stopping at Shibuya station. You may follow "Hachiko Exit" signage as this is one of the exits that will lead you to the crossing. The crossing is less busy in daytime, so, be there as night falls (especially weekends and holidays) to feel the crowd. The traffic will stop at all directions to allow pedestrians to cross. Note: This crossing is featured in The Fast and The Furious: Tokyo Drift movie.

For the young. The great part of travelling with teenagers is that in Tokyo, you can let them go do stuff on their own without worrying too much. My son wanted to visit this place (I have been here several times). It is definitely crowded but not rowdy. plenty of lights, fashion, food but not for the older folks.

Fascinating to watch and to cross. My advice: find higher ground where you can view the crowds cross and weave through each other. The footbridge of the Shibuya train station, the coffee shops, and the shopping centers in the vicinity all make good viewing spots. Better yet, try crossing it yourself. It doesn't feel as crowded on the ground as it looks from above. The Japanese are very courteous people; you won't get pushed around even on this crowded crossing.

Organized chaos!. If you don't mind crowds, then I would definitely recommend viewing and participating in the Shibuya Scramble. I have experienced similar crossings in Las Vegas. But this being Tokyo, people are respectful with minimal pushing, the streets are spotless, and I didn't spot any drunken people wandering around. Best of all, it's completely free and conveniently located outside Shibuya Station. So even if you only have 15 minutes to stop, you can still get a taste of the excitement. Wander up to Starbucks for an excellent view of the crossing from above.

Tokyo Version of NYC Time Square. The evening of my arrival, this was the #1 place I wanted to visit for picture purposes for its fluorescent lights and crowds. I visited the Starbucks on one corner that is part of a book store. I walked blocks and blocks looking for sushi and found one place but it was too crowded. But it is no problem finding ramen and other warm Japanese dishes. Great people watching and so fun to walk around. The energy here is electric.
Like the others, must see. Lucky to have a warm start to winter so the people are out in force as per usual. Good vantage point from the Starbucks on the corner.

Overwhelming!. A view from an 11 year old, hmmmmm let's see....Shibuya intersection also known as the busiest intersection in the world, is something that everyone has to see. The electronic billboards, the music,all of the people, the shops, just make that much more real. It is fabulous going into Starbucks and looking down onto Shibuya intersection.Don't forget to take you camera when you go to Shibuya because I got sensational photos from the intersection and you shouldn't miss out. Be sure to experience the busiest intersection in the world. Be sure to get a train line map so you know when to get on and of the train. And when you get off and on the train at Shibuya make sure you are off or on first or last so you don't get lost in the middle.So exciting, don't miss out!!!!!!!!!!

Controlled chaos. The scramble is an intersection of 5 roads at the east exit of the Shibuya train station. Great energy and symphony when the crossing light turns green and everyone crosses from the five directions. Day time looks busier but night time looks prettier. Good view from Starbucks on the second floor.

People watching. 1 - Not necessary to view from Starbucks 2 - Cross it a few times, watch people at various time of the day, it's fun3 - Only do the above if you stay nearby for a few days, mine was just 5 mins walk so I can do that haha :P

Fun walking across the street here. In front of the Shibuya station on Hachiko exit side, you will see the big Shibuya Junction that allow you to walk across in any direction you'd like to do. Only in Japan that you can do something like this. Go ahead and enjoy it.

Cool but doesn't live up to the hype. It's nice to be able to take a photo of the crossing, but honestly I've seen more crossings busier than this one. I kept wondering if we got the right one, since it wasn't very busy! But perhaps it was the time of day for me. Anyway, get a photo during the scramble - fun, especially if you have props, or take a photo from the 2nd floor of Starbucks, of which I did both. Night time is much nicer because of all the lights!

Orchestrated mayhem. The crossing is something that you need to experience. There's people crossing from all sorts of directions. The thing is though, it was quite organised and not many people ran into each other ! When I went , I went across it a few times so I could take photos . The crossing is close by to the shopping complex Shibuya 109 and from what I hear, you can view the crossing from Starbucks inside Tsutaya building on the 2nd level.

Busiest intersection in the world!. Once I stepped out of the JR Shibuya Station and passed the Hachiko statue, I was greeted by a sea of people! I've seen pictures and videos but it's nothing like experiencing it myself. Once the light signals for you to walk, people are not pushing or rushing you at all. Everyone's got their places to go and people to see and amidst what looks like chaos, it is also very systematic at the same time. Tourist can stop to take pictures and videos right in the middle of the intersection and still somehow get through the crosswalk without getting hit by a car. Tip: There are several places to take videos/pictures of the crossing: (1) the 2nd floor of Starbucks across the street from the station, (2) the 2nd floor of the JR Shibuya station itself, or (3) do what I did and enjoy some warm milk tea and a fluffy pancake on the 2nd floor of the men's Shibuya 109 at Hoshino's Coffee. Whenever you decide, it is quite a fun sight to see. :)

SUPER experience!. I never faced this much of crowd while crossing anywhere. This was simply awesome and a exciting experience. Best if you can use a monopod to get a aerial view of the crossing. Please be aware when taking picture on the road side, bicycles and bikes will pass you, be careful not to get knocked down. There is a Starbucks right opposite of the crossing when you exit Shibuya station, pass by Hachiko statue and cross the road to the Starbucks. Enjoy your best coffee with the best view you can possibly get.
Too crowded. interesting to watch the scramble, but too crowded. Heard that Starbucks is the best place to take pictures, but Starbucks is also very packed.

Good old Starbucks. Starbucks is a good landmark to find your way around here.
So is L'Occitane. Once you come out of the subway, as someone where Starbucks is to get your bearings.
All the great little shopping streets are in behind there.

Great to see. Went to this crossing and I was well impressed with the scale of it. After crossing a few times we made our way up too the second floor in Starbucks to get a better look. The only place we found to view the crossing was here, we tried to go further up to the higher floors in the same building but there is no window to see out. There is however a lovely looking coffee shop on the top floor.

I had my photograph taken in the middle of the crossing. This crossing never cease to amaze me with people crossing from all directions! :) and Hachiko is just nearby! A must try if you are in Tokyo. And to get the best view of the crossing, drop by Starbucks to get a nice photo.

Organised chaos. Shibuya crossing is something that needs to be experienced first hand. There are five streets with crosswalks that intersect at this junction. When the lights change, people flood the crossing from all directions but with the help of count down timer on the crossing, the intersection is clear by the time the traffic starts flowing.As per other ri

Mad but orderly rush. I viewed the mass crossing on the 2nd level of a mall (forgot the name of the place, but there's a food street on that level) bridge leading to the JR Line station. Got to experienced it yourselves ....
Join in!. Instead of just watching you must cross at least once! There is some interesting shopping in the area as well. UnderArmour, Bic Camera and several ladies stores are here.

The most organized messiness . That crossing never fails to amaze me, people going in all directions and yet not one bumping into another. A Japanese friend of mine tells me it's an art to master. There's a Starbucks across the Tokyu building from which you can observe the crossing ritual.

A must-see for Tokyo. This was fun and definitely should be on any Tokyo itinerary! Night time is very pretty which all the shop lights and advertising signs lit up. Very bustling and vibrant part of the city.

Amazing sea of people. if you come to japan you just got to see this. I recommend you to go up at the Starbucks cafe so you can watch the phenomenon from above. Best time is during evening time around 5. I was there on a Saturday night. Extremely lots of people but nobody would bump into you.Train station is exactly across the street.

Playing in middle of the road. Visited the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden, on way back, decided to experience the madness. Wow! It was fun and my kids were screaming for more. For the first time, they're playing in the middle of busy road without their Mom nagging at them.Pedestrians were going in all directions but orderly and calm, though it might look crazy and chaotic from far.

Bit Disappointed. A cool thing to see but a tad disappointed. Even though Starbucks has the best view of the crossing it is extremely difficult to get a seat. You are better off viewing the scramble from the shopping centre connecting Shibuya train station.

A must for first-timers in Tokyo. Just observing millions of people walking across this multiple intersection is spectacular if you have the time and patience... Maybe having a drink at the second floor of Starbucks is a good idea. This is the classical spot for your photo in Tokyo (like the one in Times Square in NYC)...

If you think crowds are cool.... You will love this crowded intersection with people milling about. On the other hand, if crowds aren't your thing... avoid this area like the plague. I am not exactly sure of the attraction to this attraction, perhaps it is everyone wanting to visit Hachi and being drawn into crossing the street. But a busy intersection, is a busy intersection.

Check it out!. It was as expected, just thrilling to finally see the Scramble in action.We did not check it out during the daytime so the impact was firsthand at night time.This famous crossing outside Shibuya station has been much talked about, filmed, reviewed and written about, And it became a scene of organised chaos when all traffic lights turned red at the same time, all traffic in every direction stopped and pedestrians flooded into the intersection -crossing to the other side.When the traffic lights turned green, the tide of humanity has cleared the junction, and the sidewalks have been replenished with the next wave.Enjoy a birds eye view from Starbucks and then get into the thick of it and join the pedestrians for a personal experience.Worth taking a look best times Friday and Saturday evenings.
If you pass by. Ok its impressive but what:its only people walking (but it is really a very big number.)Much better at night with the combination of lights and huge screens and sounds

People watching . This area is probably one of the most recognizable sites in all of Tokyo. Watch millions of people walk across the crossing daily from the Starbucks. Getting seating sucks but it's a fun time if you're in the mood for quiet thought while watching people. Watching while it's raining outside is great as you see a sea of umbrellas passing each other

Experience the madness. Worth a visit!, you can combine it with a visit to Hachiko!Wonder at the busiest crossing in the world, where everyone crosses the road at once, try to avoid bumping into people- mental but fun

A Must for a Tokyo Trip. The huge crossing is amazing. Don't just cross, do remember to stand by the sides and watch other people crossing. Take photos and videos. After that, stop by in one of the cafes or food outlets nearby. There are also many retail outlets in the area, including those in the large station.
See it to believe it. This has become an iconic place in Tokyo, especially after the movie Tokyo drift. You can spend 5 minutes here and see the madness surround you.

Wow!. We never such a busy pedestrian crossing before! Just amazing! Plus, there are a lot of things to do in the area such as arcade centers, shops, restaurants, and lots of light! It was an amazing atmosphere and would definitely recommend a visit if you happen to be in Tokyo! For movie fans, this is were parts of Fast and the Furious 3 movie were shot.

Must see & enjoy à coffee at Starbucks. Ofcourse à 'must see' while visiting Tokyo. Go for a cup of coffee at Starbucks And make a movie/ Some photo's. I expected iT more busy, I was there around 11 Pm.

Crowds, chaos, noise, havoc, mayhem... downright insane! But strangely beautiful and sensational...!. Complete mayhem... what more would you want??? We are people big-city born and bred, yet we found ourselves drawn to this spectacle. And that is precisely what it is - a truly incredible spectacle! Naturally we had seen videos of the Shibuya Scramble - including its adaptation in many movies – but experiencing it firsthand, on-location is terrific (to say the least) and a “must-do” for any tourist to Tokyo.On our recent visit, we had allocated a day and night for Shibuya; as the area is in itself an attraction without the pedestrian scramble. That said, we kept being drawn back to the scramble throughout the day and night. From various locations surrounding the traffic intersection, we observed and recorded the masses of people scrambling across in all directions. It was absolutely phenomenal...!Even mid-morning on a weekday, where you would expect the least amount of people, it was mind-boggling. Come evening and night, however, the crowds scrambling across the intersection was... well, words fail me... For us, it was not daunting or negative, quite the reverse... it was downright fascinating!Upstairs in Starbucks (north) or the L’occitane cafe (south-west) are good vantage points to observe the scramble; not to mention being out of the mayhem. Once we had experienced the scramble at various points at street level, we were ready for some sanity. So the cafes were nice, quiet havens to enjoy the spectacle without the noise and chaos. At L’occitane particularly, request a window table upstairs.Lastly, please don’t forget to pay a visit Hachiko. If you are unfamiliar with Hachiko, read the touching story on the internet. What a loyal dog!!Enjoy Shibuya!Thanks for reading this review and my gratitude if you choose to rate it as helpful. No pressure though. Cheers!
Vacation . This is really a nice place to walk and go shopping. Although it was really hot during our visit. But spent almost half day and it only take us 20 minutes to reach this place.

Would not make a special visit. Perhaps my title is unfair as I generally stay in a Shibuya Hotel and cross the crossing to access the railway station. In my opinion, best viewed from Starbucks coffee shop.

Do it! Its fun. Everyone has seen it on tv before. Its free to go and do. You can walk across all day long if you feel like it. Tons of shopping and restaurants right there. Really if you are in japan there isnt a reason not to go check out the shuffle
