Once , when you were in Tokyo!. They are always in screens of many movies. So crowded and lots of people from many direction but smooth like in slow-motion pictures. You can sit and watch their moving or be a part of it. Enjoy!!

Tourist Spot. Cool to see at night when everything's lit up (especially Christmas time), and it does get pretty busy. I decent view point is from in the station before you take the Hachiko exit... Loads of people go to the Starbucks across the road to watch Shibuya crossing too. A bit touristy for me, but there's plenty to explore in Shibuya so worth a look if you're in the area.
Crazy. Crazy sight to see! Worth a quick trip for a fun picture. Grab some dinner and watch the people go by from the many restaurants overlooking the crossing.

Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble. the famous Shibuya Scramble, nice to see all the people crossing the rode in chothic order, you can go to the starrbucks and get some coffee while you watching from the observation level. located just outside the Hachiko Exit of Shibuya Station

Controlled chaos. Awesome feeling to cross at the same time as thousands of other people! Even though there are thousands of people crossing at the same time I still felt very safe. Many shops around the area and restaurants.

I could watch it all day. It is a really big crossing and very busy. You might even lose your way during the crossing. Just ride the human current and you'll be fine. I watched it for awhile from Starbucks and i never got bored.

Maddness. We visited in the afternoon when it wasn't as busy and it was still a mad crush of people. A people watchers' dream seeing the scramble of crossers. I had a good laugh and even did the crossing for the obligatory photo/selfie or two.
Walk fast or you will get lost!. This is a man`s nightmare specially at night! Walk fast or people will bump into you! Bring comfortable shoes always in Japan. Taxis are so expensive!

Crossing the famous street!. This is unbelievable. Thousands of people crossing every minute and so orderly. We cross it twice and then we hang out and just people watch. Incredible.
You won't find any trash, with these huge crowd, if it's some place else other than Japan, trash will be a big problem.

Unbelievable sight of the world busiest intersection. Has to be seen to believe. So many people crossing the place in 3 different directions. Somehow, people moved orderly without any incident given what seems to be thousands of people.

You have to see it to believe it. Two main reasons to go here. To see the scramble crossing - a mad 5 way road crossing where all traffic stops then hundreds of people seem to cross from everywhereSecondly to see the Hachi statue. The loyal Akita dog that kept returning to the station where hi master travelled from and to every day before he died whilst at work.It's a very busy place and the statue is a very popular meeting place. Lots of shops and restaurants around to keep you occupied.Starbucks upper floors are the best place to photo/ video the scramble crossing.
worth a watch.... the amount of pedestrians crossing every time the light changes..are just.......breathtaking. Worth a minutes of your time to watch.. ;)
Busy. It's everything you expect it to be, busy lots of lights and somehow everyone manages to cross the road without bumping into each other

Fun. We've read, heard and seen on youtube about this famous Shibuya Scramble . This place was located just outside the Hachiko Exit of Shibuya Station. To be actually there in person was such fun!^^ My family and I enjoyed doing just that, crossing to and fro as we did our shopping in Shibuya, amidst the throng of people. It was such a spectacular sight to see. My family shot some videos on this to share with others at home.
Wasn't very busy when we visited. We visited on a Sunday evening, and while there were definitely a lot of people, there were not nearly as much as I have seen in the pictures.

Just as insane as you imagined. After taking the Shinkansen from Kyushu, we arrived at Shinagawa and got on the Yamanote line for Shibuya at rush hour. Total insanity - how do people do this every day? Getting out at Shibuya Station and facing the scramble crossing was the icing on the cake. Total chaos, lights flashing, loudspeakers blasting, mobs jostling, perfection!

Time of day matters!. We went around noon on a Sunday and were disappointed that more people weren't crossing! Probably better to see during rush hour or at least during the week. Find a spot where you can get a great view; I found it difficult to get a good one from the second floor of Starbucks that some of the guidebooks recommended.

Come at night. Hold hands. Don't get lost. You can watch all the videos you want of this crossing but you won't appreciate the sheer volume of people that cross this intersection every few minutes. It's constant! If you're not careful you will get separated from your party. There's really nothing like it. Unfortunately for us it was also raining but that didn't stop anyone. Clear umbrellas anyone?

Army ants crossing!. Have fascinatingly seen (on video) and read about this very unique Tokyo 'organised mayhem/chaos' pedestrian crossing, it was not disappointing us!We got off at the Shibuya station, the crowd of many hundreds if not thousands of people was building up on every end of pedestrian crossings! When crossing lights turned green, here they/we go, walking across the roads at our own preferences and didn't bother to keep left or right, no one was hit or crashed onto each other. It was like a chaos or mayhem, but in a very nice and self-organised way! It was an army ants crossing, that all I shall describe!Must try it yourself if you are in Tokyo to experience the operation of the organised chaos. The best way to do, is to get off at the Shibuya station, pay a visit to a statue of the most royal dog of Japan named Hachiko, then do the crossing. After that, It is also good idea to have a cuppa at Starbucks in the upper floor, take a window seat for a short break and continue observing interesting collective human's behaviour!

One of those "have to do" things.. There is a certain irony to this attraction, as half of the mass of people are there to witness the mass of people... There is a certain strange pleasure - a silly pleasure - in crossing this insanely busy road though. Worth a look, it is all good fun.
Classic view from Tokyo. Something that you have to do. Around this lively area, you can find thousands of shops and good places to eat

interesting view, watch it from the top!. Quite an astonishing sight, hypnotizing if you watched too long. Best viewed from starbucks or the opposite train station bridge!At times, makes you feel like you are looking at ants running around!

It's crowded and has a lot of tourists. The Shibuya pedestrian scramble is exactly as it says... when the lights turn, you scramble across the road in multiple directions. As I was there during Halloween, there were quite a number of people dressed out and taking there in their Halloween costumes.I guess if you are in Tokyo, you should take a couple of photos if you are passing by.
You know you will go here so just do it. This gives you a good impression of the Tokyo crush. With access to lots of good shopping and sights near by this is a good experience, once.
Cool To See. Cool to see, especially at night. Watch the people cross for a couple of red lights and then take the easy-access JR station to your next activity.
Hustle. Kind of like Times Square and Old Town Pasadena meet in Tokyo. I quite like these type of crosswalks and would like to see more of them please and thank you.

A truly manic experience on Halloween!. I came to the pedestrian crossing on Halloween and it was manic but amazing to see. So many people in costume and so MANY people! You honestly couldn't walk, and basically moved wherever the crowd moved. But it is iconic in Japan so definitely come on a normal day and experience it, even then it's still very busy!

Wasn't busy when we were there. We went to the crossing expecting to see hundreds of people scramble across the crossing but to our surprise it wasn't busy. The crossing were rather empty and not like what we have seen in movies probably cause it was raining that day. We went to Starbucks to catch the view from above. The view was amazing but a little disappointing as it wasn't as crowded as we thought it would be. Definitely a must see/experience.

Havoc.. Iconic as it is, I don't enjoy the idea of colliding with so many people. Scenario worsened with huge entourage that some kept slipping from eye view. Not a great idea with big group or small children. Probability of getting separated is high.

More That a Crosswalk. It costs nothing to make the crossing, but the experience is priceless! All those lights. All those canyon wall like video screens with the endless commercials. All those people. It's OK to be a tourist. Stop in the middle, pay attention to the other pedestrians, and take a selfie. What the hell. It ain't like Vegas. It ain't like Times Square. It is SHIBUYA! So unique -- just go.And then . . . go to the Starbucks Tsutaya -- the building directly across of Hachiko Station and from above, you can watch the pedestrians make the crossing too. So cool.

Not busy when I visited. I went to the crossing expecting to see hundreds of people scramble across the street, but it was not very busy when I visited. However the square is interesting and there is a nice food court in the basement of the department store that is at the crossing. There is also a tourist information office there.

Shibuya swarm. If you really want to experience this at its best you need to check it out from all angles, but the best view is grab yourself a coffee at Starbucks, fight for a window seat and watch. It's like watching a human ant colony as they spread in all directions. I found the experience even more exciting when it's raining. The sea of umbrellas is like watching a cartoon
Not a good idea with young kids. Mad rush of traffic and people rushing to some places. Nice place though. Taking photos either from Starbucks or from bridge linking to Ginza line.

Not as impressive as it might once was. The crossing is depicted over and over again, and such feels strangely familiar. I was expecting it to be more japanese'y so it was a bit of a let down. Not nearly crazy enough.

Non stop 24-7 action!. Definite must see in Shibuya! It's right by the train station, the famous Hachiko and also the 109 malls so it's quite well located!If you want to see the crossing in full action it's best to experience either in the mid morning or the evening when its busiest. During the day it can be quiet, though do note that I mean "quiet" in Tokyo standards, this would still be considered busy in other countries.

It's just people crossing.... Shibuya station and the area around the crossing is quite amazing.. with the lights, the action and the people watching... We stayed in a hotel in Shibuya and so this crossing was basically our everyday and every night.. Whilst impressive and I recommend you try and at least cross over once, in my opinion it is nothing to travel to Shibuya to see .. If you absolutely want to see it from atop, then the Starbucks upper floor window seats are the best spots to see it.. Be warned though, these seats are almost always full..

Interesting. Since its a famous crossings my family and I felt like we should experience crossing at this place once. Its just a normal busy crossings though. But at least when people ask if you've ever tried crossing in shibuya at least you'll know how it felt like

Interesting. Hundreds of people crossing the massive pedestrian cross but not once they collide with each other. There are gigantic screens around the cross so waiting the lamp to turn green is no longer boring.

Fantastic experience!. An absolute must see when in Tokyo. Comparable to (if not more busy than) Times Square, the Shibuya Pedestrian scramble is Tokyo's NY equivalent. Lights, action and endless rows of traditional Japanese food places - this area has it all. Recommend going there after 6pm to really see it all in action. The whole area is clean and you feel safe even among the drives of people. Some fashion shops are also In this area - open late, for the shoppers. The scramble is just outside the train station. Shibuya station is approx 20mins on the green line from Tokyo Station. A definite must see!

Tokyo in action. I was on the 20th floor of the sibuya excel hotel, looking down & as the people were crossing, i could see a sea of black heads that covers the crossing as the people moves across. What a sight!
energetic. This was a really cool area. Lots of shops and pretty much the start to get to a lot of great places and right on the subway station.

One of the Busiest Crossing in the World. This is one of my favorite in Japan. It looks even better at night. Besides the famous Hachiko Statue, the pedestrian scramble is quite a scene. Also, it is a famous meeting point for friends and strangers. Lots of offices, restaurants, shops etc around this places are to be found. Not to mention that Shibuya Station is also a intersection for few Tokyo Subways and trains.

Take a photo here! . When in Tokyo....do the Shibuya Scramble! Chaotic yet mysteriously almost noone bumps into anyone else..try getting a much sought-after window seat at the Starbucks (1st floor) right in front of it for a great photo op. The after-work rush hour has an entire population of a small island-nation crossing at any given time(kidding).

place to be. If you arrive to Shibuya crossing around 6-8 pm, this place bursts with energy and life. It is fascinating to watch hundreds of people crossing on the green light and empty street on the red light. You can grab matcha frappuccino in starbucks on the second floor and overlook the action. Whole area is full of shops, bars and restaurants. Huge neon lights make this area even more vibrant.
It's bustling!. It's a great place, always VERY busy, grab a coffee, pick a spot and watch Tokyo at its most frantic. Theres a LOT of shopping here as well as restaurants and bars.

A must visit in Tokyo. Visit the Shibuya area at least once if it's your first time in Tokyo. The best time to visit is when it's dark, to see all the huge video screens and how the pedestrians "scramble" in the huge crossroad. Best viewed from a bit higher, example places: Starbucks or the Ginza line station.
Awesome to watch. Just something to tick off the list. You'll fell as though you're in a Hollywood movie watching the world pass by. Just enjoy a coffee and people watch in this wonderful city.

Busy anytime - mad at Halloween. Shibuya of an evening is a pretty busy place anyway but being in the area on halloween we decided to take a trip and grab some food but little did we know how massive the crowds would be!
An experience any time but if you are around when there is a big celebration the place is a one off!

Awesome. Great experience just standing at the traffic light and watch the people pass by.
Its such a well organised chaos. Fascinating really.

Interesting but not worth a special trip. Came one evening the night before Haloween. Lots and lots of young people (under 25) and multiple cheap eating places within a 500m radius of the crossing, in many directions. I would not go out of my way to come here if you are pushed for time!

Sometimes over 1000 people per light change. This is according to Lonely Planet anyway. We visited on a rainy Sunday afternoon and it was still busy enough so I would love to see it on a weekday morning during rush hour. It's not like it costs anything anyway so just go and check it out. Starbucks is the best place for viewing. You also get to see the Hachiko statue, giving you another reason to visit Shibuya station. Go out the Hachiko exit for both crossing and statue.
A must do. Awesome! Just amazing to see so many happy people and to feel part of it. Great shopping and of course the statue of Hachiko, the loyal dog from Richard Gere's movie.
It's fun to join the hustle and bustle of Tokyo's Times Square. My wife and I finished a busy day touring Tokyo with dinner and joining the throngs at Shibuya. It was fun to see and experience.

Tokyo's Times Square. You know saw it many times. Perhaps in some movies or animes you watched or mangas you read. You know you've seen it before. It's the famous Times Square of Tokyo--with more population. You've never been in Tokyo if you haven't cross the Shibuya crossing!

Fun!. It's really impressive in the evening. The cacophony of all the commercials, the crowds of pedestrians running in all directions and us, mesmerised by it all. Something not to be missed when visiting Tokyo!
Very crowned.. The crossroad is very full of people, got to be very careful not to be knock into other people crossing the road.
"Eh". I was there during rush hour on a Thursday night. Sure, it was busy, but if you've seen Times Square you'll be underwhelmed.
True Rumor. So crammed and happening. Luckily I went there during Halloween, people are dressed in costumes, many people took photos in the middle of the crossings. :)
Bright lights and more !. Best to go at night when most active and lights are bright ! Access to subway system excellent as well.

Controlled chaos! Have to see at least once!. Japan's propensity for order is put to the test at the famous Shibuya Crossing, as it's once of the few major pedestrian intersections where traffic on all sides is stopped to allow a free-for-all crossing of all pedestrians going in each direction. Recommend first getting an overhead view in one of the buildings overlooking the crossing to see what it's about--the mad scramble of people is truly amazing! One minute, car traffic is flowing quickly, and then suddenly all cars come to a stop from both directions and a pedestrian-only signal allows for everyone to just walk out into the intersection, many crossing the intersection diagonally! After viewing it, take a stroll out into the chaos yourself!
Tokyo's time square. Massive pedestrians, tons of stores, lit up at night from all the signs. Definitely worth a visit if you don't mind crowds.
Amazing crossing. I can strongly recommend to take a cup of coffee at Shibuya Starbucks and sit on the 2nd floor and watch all the people crossing the roads, you feel you are in a big city!

Cahotic :-(). The most impressive organised cahos I have ever seen! I dont even think a trip to Tokyo could be complete whithout a visit to these traffic lights cahos! The busiest city in the world :-) great to watch!!!

After seeing "Lost in Translation" this was a must-see.. It is estimated that about 1,000 people cross this intersection at every light change -- and they don't bump into each other. We walked across for the experience!
You can't escape. Shibuya is one of the two busiest places in Tokyo. And here, the cars stop and the pedestrians walk to 5 different directions.

Crazy. We were there on Halloween night and it was crazy. You could hardly move through the crowd. We went to Starbucks to get a good view of Shibayu crossing. It is on the 3rd floor of the building directly across the street from the metro station and they repeatedly ( but nicely ) told everyone that photos or filming out the window is not allowed. Not sure why.
Impressing crossing. Being in the middle of Shibuya is impressione. You can feel solitude in the middle of thousand people.

Interesting, but not much to see around here. The Shibuya crossing itself is quite interesting and one can easily spend 30 minutes watching it. However, there is not much to see around apart from some shopping malls.

Ready...steady...Scramble!. If you visit Tokyo and not do the Scramble, you cannot call yourself a traveler.You may think "It's just walking across the street" but it aint. It's fun. Almost feels like a ride at a Theme Park LOL!I recommend going once during the day, and doing the scramble at least once during night time (Shibuya is beautiful at night). Also make a point to just sit at the Starbucks there and have a coffee (Chop chip Frappuccino for me thanks) at night and checking the view of the scramble. I sat there for an hour just watching. Amazing!
Love the hustle and bustle of people!. Stayed a while to see the multi-crossing in the area. Love the hustle and liveliness here! People watch here for a while if you like to experience this area!

Crossing the road. This famous intersection is very cool to see in movies or from above. But to actually cross the road is simply that, crossing a road. If you are not fond of crowds or tourists simply taking picutres of a crosswalk then do make a trip out of it. But if you are in Shibuya then definatly do the Pedestrian Scramble! It is right outside of Hachiko Exit in Shibuya Station. There is a starbucks on the (2 or 3rd floor) that gives a good veiw of the scramble, but a good view is also available from the Shibuya station!

Well you have to go if you're in Tokyo.. Unless you have a fear of crowds (in which case I don't suppose you'd be in Tokyo) then this is a fun place to be. We were there for Halloween when the youth of Tokyo go costume crazy. The rest of the time every tourist with a GoPro and a selfie stick is to be found going back and forth for no particular reason but to be part of the scene. Starbucks overlooking it is the place to watch from.

Crazy!!. Imagine, thousands of people crosses the street of Shibuya Station. Make sure to go to a nearby top floor restaurant and be amazed with sea of people crossing. Don't forget to bring your camera.

Halloween extravaganza. Found myself at the Shibuya crossing on Halloween night, it was crazy! It was one big party on the streets where every self respecting Japanese was in costume. Name it, they have it: Disney princesses, ghouls, Mario Bros, minions, cosplayers, trannies, etc, etc. If you don't have the energy to observe the revelry on the streets, just stay in the subway station. They have a veritable fashion show down there as well. The Japanese sure know how to party!
Mad indeed!. Shibuya crossing on Halloween is such a sight! Minions, vampires, counts, superheroes, anime characters, they are everywhere!

Cross the roads with more than two ways directions. You can cross the road at whatever direction you like. Be in the crossing to enjoy it! Don't just watch it from above, like sitting in the Startbucks.
Nice walk. Nice neighborhood for walking, shopping and people watching. I really enjoyed my time there. A lot of restaurants and coffee shops.
Great fun. The area of Shibuya is great and the scramble is quite a laugh. If you use exit 5 from the subway you will get an elevated vantage point to get a pic.

It's a pedestrian crossing! . Have been to Tokyo twice and now Shibuya Crossing twice. It has a good Starbucks to sit and watch the crossing from. The Starbucks is particularly useful when you get in from your flight at 6:30am and need something to eat so early (think it opens at 7am). The bottom line is that it's a pedestrian crossing, but it's fun to watch and worth the trip.
People galore . This place is well worth it just to people watch. So many people cross the roads at the crossing. They all look like little ants. Take some photos and soak in the atmosphere.

You gotta see this!. When you arrive at Shibuya station make sure you take the correct exit, Hachiko. You will exit the train station and be caught by thousands of people waiting patiently for the pedestrian lights to go green. When that happens you'll see all these people from several directions, all at once, crossing the streets. It goes all in an orderly fashion, without yelling and pushing. If you go back into the station and go up one floor to the shopping area, you have great views from above of this "scramble". But the best experience is to follow the crowd and join them in this "big migration".

When in Shibuya. I think you have got to experience crossing this street at least once when in Tokyo. It's crowded, but it's not chaotic. It does not feel like just people rushing to get to the other side of the street. It's right off the Hachiko train exit. And visit Hachiko while you're at it. It's probably common for locals to see foreigners taking photos of themselves while crossing a street, but do it. You're there, when else do you intend to take a photo? There's a good view on the second floor of the train station, too. Found it by accident while looking for the exit.

Bloody Hilarious Really 😀😀. Look it's just a crossing, a convergence of people but you have to see it first then have a crack - everyone is smiling crossing the raid - noise everywhere, great shops and restaurants - you have to go..was great fun..

Cool experience. This crossing is as big and crowded as they say - super chaotic but yet feels super smooth when thousands of people cross at the same time and come from all directions. You can get a good view of the scramble from the 2nd floor of Starbucks, but it's always super crowded up there too!

Crossing but unlike anything you've seen before. You rally have to do this is japan, yes it's just a crossing but it's a crossing on steroids. It is japan in a crossing....controlled madness. Really must see it to believe it. Good view from Starbucks or across the street in the mall (just above the dog)

Astounding . I stayed very local to Shibuya Station so I experienced the scramble a lot and it never lost it's appeal. I'm still amazed at how chaotic it is, yet coordinated enough that no one runs into each other. I would definitely recommend seeing it for yourself. Videos and photos don't do it justice.

Pure Fun!. Walking through these streets is pure fun!!! Be mindful though if bringing kids with you (we brought our two 5yr old twins). It's easy to get distracted with the many establishments, shopping places around, topped with the thousands of people walking and running around. So keep watch on your kids! :)

A classic. This crossing is famous from numerous movies and tv-series. It's rare enough that a pedestrian crossing is a place worth visiting. The best hours would be during the morning rush or something after 6pm.

The busiest intersection in tokyo. This is the busiest pedestrian crossing in the whole of Tokyo city surrounded by numerous retail centres auch as Seibu, Tokyu, Shibuya 109, Shibuya Mark City, Loft, Bic, etc. You can observe the younger set mingling around with all their latest dressing assessories. It a haven for street photography.

Greatest Crossing Ever!. It's just a crossing right? No. Nothing feels more like Japan than being a part of the people crossing this crossing. The hustle and bustle of peak rush hour really gets to you :)

Great for Halloween. Walked through the area 7-8pm on halloween. Crowds were out of this world in creative costumes. The density and flow was not always what I wanted, being carried up the wrong street almost, but it was fun.
Great! . It is so interesting to watch people crossing the shibuya crossing. :)) love it! Must see in tokyo! :)

Ants streets. Love standing at the road junctions watching the people crossing over like ants on the streets
An interest place to watch the local fashions on the street

Crowded... Only for the Young. The place is just crowded basically anytime except super early morning. I dont see how soecial this place is while many (especially foreign people) say this is such a cool place to visit. Maybe because I do not like too crowded spots... However, I agree that the place is unique in the way that they have multiple pedestrian crossings; this palce has got the most crossings at one spot in the world. Please check if you are curious about seeing too many people at one spot and like Times Square-type places.

Pick your times wisely. This is a very "Tokyo" location. But pick your times carefully, I'd recommend around 6:30-7:30 on a weekday evening. You can go to the Starbucks or any other of the surrounding spots to get a bird-eye view.
Not that much of a Scramble. It is described as a scramble but would not interpret it as such - It is what it is - lots of people trying to cross different crosswalks.

Where were all the people?. We made a special trip around 10am on a Sunday to see this grand spectacle but there wasn't the huge crowd we'd expected so we walked up to Harajuku (no Kawaii girls there!), did some shopping, lunched and came back. Still no mad scramble. Not to be deterred, I came back on Tuesday after shopping at the Oriental Bazaar... still a lot of people but not at all what I'd been led to believe. Maybe if you've never visited a big city this might be impressive but as a former Sydneysider, Shibuya crossing was all a bit meh.What is great is the shopping, particularly if you head off into the smaller side streets, and the local restaurants and cafes are really great.

Vacation/ site seeing. I saw this spot on the movie fast and furious Tokyo drift. After that, I knew I had to see if this spot really was as crazy as it was on the movie. Yup, sure enough. It's just as crazy. Such open space, so many people, so many colorful, shiny, tall buildings surrounding the location. Talk about alive, I'd recommend visiting this chaos. Plus shibuya district has the best shopping for fashion. I still didn't get to see everything.

Cool experience!!. I've never seen so many people cross and cycle in different directions - literally a scramble! You can even see some crazies try to make a run for it well after the light turn red - it's hilarious!! Best spot to view this is on the 2nd floor of the Starbucks! Get a drink, grab a prime spot and get your camera ready!
WOW! THIS is Tokyo. This was the place where I felt "Hell, I'm in Tokyo". So many people, so many things to see. Non-stop fun, especially after sunset.
Good place to people watch. You can spend the whole day here people watching and never get bored of it. If you want to have a good view, go up to Starbucks and enjoy the view.

Sit in Starbucks, watch the mayhem. Grab a coffee and sit in the window of starbucks and watch the mayhem unfold. We watched countless people nearly get run over and the sheer volume of people at rush hour has to be seen to be believed.

Mind Boggling. It is definitely something worth seeing. Ideally get a spot at the starbucks located on the 1st floor or a similar place nearby. There are an amazing number of people and yet everything is executed with such ease. We looked from a vantage point and then crossed a few times ourselves just to experience it. The best time to see this is late evening. Plenty of fun bars etc close by so one can get a drink after.

So much to see. . Shibuya was a great place to wander and people watch. So much going in there and lots of shopping is available. We came on the subway line and everything was very close. Great tourist information inside an old subway car by the Hachiko statue.

A bit hyped. It's all about when you visit; a weekday around 10 am, shops closed, rush hour over, nor a lot of people, it's rather unimpressing. Night time, neon signs and lots of people, it's a different game altogether.
Very busy crossing. Great place for people watching, some awesome shops and good vending machine food places around! Make sure you go up to Starbucks and chill out :)

Amazing. Amazing crossing so many people yet it's so Organised...
Everybody walking was so careful and there was no rush.
The crossing is just next to the Hachiko statue, lots of people taking photos.
Must Try !!!
Great crowds. The place was so crowded. Never seen so many people crossing a street like that before. Lots of shops on the area

Cannot Miss. You cannot pasd through Shibuya without seeing the organised chaos that is Shibuya crossing. Personally i think the best view is from the glass view9ng platform in the station (we also went to starbucks but it is sooo crowded and the glare on the windows doesnt make for a great picture)
You have also to cross the crossing!

AMAZING PEOPLE WALK!. SO many People around the cross the street.. near here you can go to disney store, so you no need to queue in the disneyland park.. just ask tourist information Center you'll find out.. there's so many food choice, and many branded mall... Grab it when they SALE ! Find supermarket for food and drinks, go to Bunkamura at the basement floor...

Must do!. We visited on a Monday morning, There was still plenty of people around.We took the JR Yamanote Line and the Hachiko exit which was right near the crossing. There is a planter box just to the left where you can stand and get some elevated photos.

try it, you'll like it. I was amazed at the hordes of people crossing ... such organized chaos - so I crossed three or four times at least. Looking about while you're waiting for the signal, the elevated train crossing in the evening lights and the buildings and signs in neon lights, reminded me of Blade Runner.

Weird and funny! . My whole purpose of coming to Shibuya is for this big scramble scene and the Takeshita street. Definitely something you wont see in North America! Take the train to Shibuya station and take the Hachiko exit. Cross the street and be part of the scrambling crowd! Grab a coffee at Starbucks and best of luck finding a spot near the window. If you do find a spot for a good look of the intersection, make sure you whip out your camera as the scramble happens often enough (every 3-5min). All traffic stops and you will see huge crowd of people trying to cross in all directions. What a scene! When you cross with the crowd and filming at the same time, make sure you don't knock someone over! ;)

Can't miss it. One of the top things you must see when you go to Tokyo. You'll want to keep going back and forth. It's near the Hachiko statue so it's super easy to find. Make sure you check out how it looks from the Tokyu Mall walkway and the Starbucks right over it.

Famous area, best camera shots from Starbucks. An experience to do both during day and evening. Best camera shots are taken from Starbucks on the second floor. This crossing have featured in many movies.

Great place to visit. Shibuya is a great place to visit . It is a bustling hive of activity with the famous road crossing . Exit the station at the Hachiko exit to see the statue of Hachi . It is a lovely story about a dog that that used to wait each evening for his owner a Japanese professor at Tokyo Univerisity to return from work . Sadly the professor died and didn't return home so Hachi returned to the station each day for I think 7 years to wait for him . A film starring Richard Gere has been made about the story ... A real tear jerker . The shops in Shibuya range from high end department stores to individual small shops selling a variety of different things . Check out the fruit shop where a cantaloupe melon will set you back 12,000 yen that's around £70 .
An experience. It is definitely something to enjoy experiencing in the midst of the people as well as to sit down and watch it happen.

Would not want to be here during a zombie apocalypse. So many people walking from four different directions, it is amazing that no one gets hurt. There isn't much to do other walking or taking pictures.
Never get bored. I have never get bored with Shibuya. Each time I visit Tokyo, I always try to catch up with Shibuya. Lovely place.

One of my favourite icons of Tokyo. Love this spot! The Shibuya crossing is incredible to observe, I could sit here for hours! Try running out to the middle as soon as the pedestrian lights go green to grab some shots of the hoards of people walking towards you it's incredible.The highest grossing Starbucks in the world sits on the corner with views of Shibuya crossing. Purchase a coffee downstairs then walk up to seats with a view to observe the Pedestrian Scramble!

Top tourist destination. Naturally, the Shibuya crossing is on the top tourist destination lists as it should be to help you realize how incredibly huge this city is. In fact, many people have no idea Tokyo is the largest city in the world. It's a big shopping area, but there are some good restaurant around, but you have to know where you're going instead of picking a random spot for dinner.

An experience but.... If you are in the area and were always fascinated by this landmark then def go, however as for myself I got over it in 5 min or so. The best vantage point is from Starbucks or one of the many cafes...Would love to capture this when it rains, as I am sure colourful umbrellas would be a good photo op

You need to see it while you are there. A busy evening in Tokyo, a busy evening in Shibuya. All traffic lights turn green for the pedestrians and everybody starts crossing in all directions.Amazing, just like ants.It made me smile and enjoy the moment.
Just a crossing. Really just a crossing but when the lights turn red up to 4000 people rush in every direction the best views can be seen from Starbucks first floor cafe adjacent the crossing

Put on your must experience list!. Honestly it's only a minute experience once the light turns green, but it is completely unbelievable of how houndreds of people flow in all directions with minimal bumping, if so, a mild graze. Even more astonishing is the 90% of people focused on their mobile phones while crossing. How do hey do it? If anything, find a nice spot to record it a few times. Then watch it at home and you will notice so many things. Another plus is that it's located in the heart of everything. Food, shopping, and sights. Go for it! Just DONT stand in the middle of the crossing trying to take a picture because seriously that is DANGEROUS to you and everyone else.

Very safe . The thing is with Tokyo and even Japan in general is the people's ability to stand and wait patiently even if there are no cars about.The scramble crossing is a perfect example of Japanese order.Starts and stops to perfect timing.This crossing has featured in many movies. Just don't skip the lights or you look like a fool and probably could end up with a fine or worse ....injured.Use the green cross code!

Crazy Crossing. After watching it on movies, you definitely have to experience first hand the Shibuya Pedestrian. It was really fun to be here and take snapshots as people cross the streets. The best spot to view this is on Starbucks. But you should try to be swarmed by people under the bright sunlight. Definitely should be one of your bucket lists!

Hate Starbucks, but the view is the best. I'm not a Starbucks fan, however... The location to watch shibuya is great!Hundreds of people crossing from 5 different points all at the same time. You do t see this anywhere else
Nice to see, but its a crossing. Nice enough to see, but wouldn't make a special effort. Starbucks overlooking the crossing is a good place to take it in.

Pretty fun. Participating in the scramble is pretty fun. Went up to the starbucks across the street from Shibuya station to watch afterwards. This is the type of thing you spend maybe 15-20mins on total (if that). Close to the Hachiko statue which makes it easy to cross two sights off the list very quickly.

Must Visit in Tokyo at Night Time. A must see sight in Shibuya as there are si many people crossing the road at the same time. You may have a cup of coffee at Starbucks (corner shop beside the cross) while enjoying this night view.
What a buzz. This is a delight, mass of people in such a calm, and mannered way. A must see, and the area of shibuya too!
A must do in Tokyo!. I recommend ordering a coffee at Starbucks and watching the world go by. A must do a night time as well!
Rush hour is frenetic. You have never seen so many people at the same time at the Shibuya Pedestrian cross. A landmark that one easily can experience!

Interesting, worth doing. It's worth coming here as the crossing is so unique. A scramble indeed as pedestrians go every which way across. The best view we found was from the shopping area atop the metro station. The surrounding shopping area is really interesting. We'd been to Ginza earlier in the day and Shibuya was so much busier and livelier. Not to mention, cheaper. A really interesting area and well worth visiting using the amazingly efficient metro.
Biggest pedestrian crossing in the world. This is an icon of Tokyo, must-see for first-time visitor. The scramble is more crowded toward the evening.

One of the most famous scenes of Japan.. Worth coming just to see what the fuss is about. I mean, you can watch it numerous times and each time there are hundreds maybe thousands of people crossing this area! There are also lots of people who cross half way and take a photo of the oncoming crowds but be careful, it's super easy to get seperated from friends or lost in the crowds here it's so busy! When you visualise Japan you probably think of the Shibuya crossing, it's iconic!

Fun to be among the many!. We came here on a holiday - National Foundation day. SO imagine the number of people in this busy crossing! Just Wow! It's quite exhilarating to join the busy-ness. And of course, there are lots of restaurants and shopping places to go to.
not on a rainy day. If you have time left in Tokyo or when you are in the neighbourhood worth to visit. On a rainy day not a lot of people.
Must see in Tokyo. Crossing this intersection with the masses is when you finally feel like you are in Tokyo...such an iconic landmark...best during weekend nights
Great to see!. This is like a maze! Whatever time of day this crossin is jam packed with people going in all directions. It was great to be part of it!

Favourite place in Tokyo. This was the most exciting place in Tokyo, day or night. It is the best place to experience how populated Tokyo actually is. It is hard to even explain the electricity in the air. Even more interesting than Time Square because of how they cross the street all at the same time.

Bucket list. This was in my bucket list.I always wanted to join this crazy scramble.Although it seems that only foreigner are excited about it.My japanese friend didn't see anything remotely interesting in this.

WHAT A CRUSH. After visiting the Meiji shrine we visited TAKESHITA DORI a long narrow street full of wacky fashion shops with shoppers outfits to match - the to the Tokyo Plaza shopping centre for lunch at Starbucks on the roof garden. Try to see the Audi building just down the road - an amazing glass edificeWorth the trip just for the sights
Crazy!. All I can say is hold hands with your group or you WILL get lost! Its super chaotic but exhilarating at the same time! Must go to when in Tokyo!

Amazing place. This place is jam packed with people day or night. Shibuya have major commuters as it process a large train station running various lines by different companies. The area is also surrounded by shops, department stores, restaurants, pubs and convenience stores so a lot of locals go there to hang out after office hours.

Best spot to experience the density of people in this megapolis. Nice spot to take some pictures, from above or from ground level. Just standing at the traffic lights for half an hour and watching everybody pass(yes, it's a lot of people) was fascinating. Or meet someone at the Hachiko statue. I liked it a lot more then Times Square, because it's much more alive.Must be interesting on a rainy day as well with all the umbrella's.

Amazing crossing in Shibuya. This is an amazing place such a strange experience but really good fun.All the traffic stops and people just cross from every location it's amazing to watch and no one manages to bump into each other, they are so graceful.

Quintessential Tokyo experience. When the traffic light turns green, you completely loose sight of the street. A human ocean covers the pavement. Meantime, giant screens projects colorful images and talk out loud. It is crazy. A quintessential Tokyo experience.
Good place to visit . I was hungry so I found food and a coffee and then walked around for a bit and then it rained on me. People are Japanese here
Crazy. Crazy. A must see especially at 6pm peak hour. Just stand and watch as it is incredible to see so many people at one intersection.

Crazy people watching. The Shibuya crossing is descrived as one of the 10 "to do things" while in Tokyo. I do agree as this is a quiet impressive spectacle. All the pedestrians will start at the same time and cross the streets in all directions for a few minutes. After this, cars are crossing. Of note is that the green and red lights are very well respected and that you will almost never be hit by somebody else while crossing. All is well organised and most of the people are walking in artificial corridors.People watching best happens from the window of the Starbucks in the Tsutaya building on the crossing's north side.

It's not the scramble that's amazing, but instead .... Ok, I know this is going to ruffle some feathers, especially since this is such a popular attraction and a very well known attraction in Japan, but! After seeing this multiple times from multiple angles, walking it, etc - I personally didn't find it as appealing as movies / shows / etc have made it out to be. Maybe if you're from some small town (and I assume you've already got a headache just walking around Tokyo in general then), then it may be amazing. But! what really wowed me is how often the scamble happened and how that means so many people cross this single intersection in just one day, heck, one hour even! That was the marvelous thing. Anyway, I do recommend seeing it for yourself either way - why wouldn't I? It wouldn't hurt, and it surely has been popularized for a reason. I wish you the best in your trip!

Iconic!. Since we took the subway there, we just participated in the crossing couple of times. An unique experience and good to watch. It is free and on the way to visit Shibuya and as iconic as Tokyo Tower!

Very busy and strangely hypnotic to watch. Visited here out with the rush hour but it was still extremely busy. As mentioned in the guide books you get a great view of the crossing from the Starbucks on the second floor. It was quite nice to sit with a coffee and just watch the ebb and flow of people on the crossing.

Fun to visit and people watch.. It was a lot of fun to finally see this crossing in action in person. I'd say it's definitely worth stopping by at night to watch all the craziness at the crossing. There's a Starbucks at the corner that's perfect for watching the ocean of people crossing the square.

Take a photo inside the crowds. Too many people.. Shibuya station is like the busiest station of all and the crossings is just in front of it.. Try to take picture inside all the crowds while crossing the road.. It is just perfect!
Iconic, but not an attraction in itself. The original, now copied in London's oxford street but at the end of the day is still a large and efficient pedestrian crossing. Nice place to people watch
Wow!. Never seen so many people cross the road before, but it was amazing, great experience after seeing it on so many movies and TV shows, to be actually crossing it was great!.
Brilliant watching. If you love people watching this is the place for you. Add the noise created by all the shops outside speakers and bam...its got you. Really good fun

The famous Shibuya crossing. watching the Shibuya crossing in the morning from the near starbucks is ok, but crossing it in the evening at about 9pm will really show you why this busiest crossing at its best
A must to do and see. In the middle of Shibuya is this scramble, just mayhem ! a lot of fun , even people watch around there. so many people with their I phones filming and laughing ...very funny

A must do - visit both day and night . At first it may seem this intersection isn't that busy but as the day goes on the crowds grow. At night time it takes on a different feel. We spotted someone doing push ups as they crossed. It's easy to get caught up in the buzz of it all and the traffic has to be very patient. A great place to look down at the crossing is the Starbucks Cafe but in the morning it gets very hot on a sunny day and many people pull the shades down. Lots of fun and right next to the train station.

Worth a visit if you passing. The scramble is worth seeing and it's the times square of Japan. I wouldn't go out of your way to see this but if your passing through its work a stop. Lots of cafes around on the 1st floor which you can use to get a good view. There is a starbucks which we used (you don't need to buy a coffee to get in) to get a good view of the crossing. Good place to do some people watching

it's not terrible, but the value of this place as an attraction is close to zero. There are many places in Japan to observe many people, simultaneously moving in different directions in organized way. In my view, this place can be interesting to somebody, who grew up in a small and deserted place or to somebody, professionally interested in observing big crowds...

Underwhelming. I was excited to see this famous crossing, but honestly found it underwhelming. Maybe it was because we were staying in Shinjuku, where the crowds at rush hour are pretty comparable, but I just didn't feel like the crossing was as impressive as I had hoped it would be. The shopping nearby however, is something that can't be beat! So, come to Shibuya for the shopping, not the crossing.
Really Cool. Wow! What an interesting sight! And the pedestrians are respectful........not running out and cheating when the light is red.

Always bustling . Interesting to see thousands of people crossing the road from/to five directions at the same time without bumping much into each other. Busier at night than in the day. Best place to view the hive of activity here would be at Starbucks at Tsutaya, the mall beside 100men's

Quite the design. If you have the opportunity to see this in Tokyo, do it! Its a happening place and just plain fun to use this way to crazily cross the street. If you go to Starbucks to view from the second floor, order your beverage on the first floor before you head up to watch the "show" through the big windows. Lots of shopping and restaurants were found down the street with the arches directly across from the scramble.

Not what we had imagined. We were looking forward to seeing this iconic landmark, but were both dissapointed when we arrived. Although it was busy and the scramble hectic the crossing itself was much smaller than expected and we struggled to find a view point to get a good view from higher up. Admittedly we were there during the day, so my tip would be to make this an evening event on your itinerary to get the full experience.
must watch. everyone visits japan must visit this place to watch people crossing .best place to watch is from starbucks caffe exactly opposite the crossing

Human Traffic at it's finest. We've all heard about it and probably seen it on movies. We went there once in the morning and then at night. It was mesmerizing watching hundreds of people crossing at the same time. We watched it from the train station before joining in with the crowd. It was a good experience. I was disappointed though when we came back at night. The neon lights were not as bright as it looks.

Must see it. Beeing there means feeling the pulsating heart of Tokyo.Thousands of people, thousands of different styles and different kind of cultures mixed together in the same moment.You must try it to understand, is impossible to transfer the feeling just with words.Suggestion: go up on the flyover around the pedestrian crossing and take apicture...unbelievable memory...
A good view on the way to other attractions. Not a place you'd spend hours but great to get that sense of people in Tokyo. You cannot help to be amazed at the sheer number of people

sort of anticlimactic. we must have been there during an off-time, or I am just used to NYC- I almost wasn't sure we were looking in the correct spot- but we were. Tons of people running through the intersection when they weren't supposed to sort of took away from the stark contrast of tons of pedestrians vs an absence, which I understand to be a highlight of watching this cross walk.

A 'Lost in Translation ' moment. An amazing visual experience that assaults the senses when you emerge from the train station.The station and Starbucks provide great 'kodak moments' of the pedestrian scramble. Once you merge with the scramble and exit there are an amazing array of consumer choices that include a nine floor shopping centre purely dedicated to female fashion with hundreds of boutiques to be slowly experienced as you start at the top and descend in a spiral fashion til you reach the ground.Nearby is a male version of the same experience. An exciting trip that should begin in daylight and end in the neon saturated Shibuya night.

Don't miss the Shibuya crossing. Certainly one of the coolest things to see in Tokyo. I recommend to go up somewhere (for example the Starbucks across from the Shibuya crossing to take a picture from above.

Order Among Scramble. Definition: A Scramble crossing is one where the entire intersection opens up for pedestrians to cross and the traffic comes to a complete stand still.It was an amazing experience to watch and be among the 1000+ people crossing the scramble at each exchange, orderly at frantic pace. We took the elevated views from the 2nd floor of Starbuck and then on the Hikarie crossway on the opposite side. The big screen billboards were smart and colourful - bonus entertainment. One off the list!

東京を代表する場所 it's a famous place . ハチ公前では、某テレビ局の朝番のインタビューをしていたり、交差点では多くの人が写真を構えていたり、スターバックスの前ではパフォーマーがいたりと、とてもワクワクする場所だけど、真っ直ぐ歩けないのでたまにイラっとしますが、好きな場所の一つ。I like it. There is a lot of photographers and famous program of interviews,Many artists are exciting. If its rain you should go to L'OCCITANE cafe. It was good views.

Good experience.. This crosswalk is chaos but also order in the same time. When the green light of the crosswalk is on the chaos and order begin, the crowd flow in to the crosswalk. Follow the crowd and flow into it to experience chaos and order or you just sit at second floor of Starbuck and watch the crowd.

Once in a lifetime experience. Wonderful to see this in action. Try to get a seat at Starbuck or other surrounding cafes which give you a birds eye view of it all unfolding! Also use the crossing yourself for a more intimate experience!

Fun and frantic. This is a fun, frantic and interesting place to visit. Kind of like a Japanese Times Square with a ton of pedestrians, crazy billboards, big crowds. It is not that there is "something to do" there, but rather it is just a signature place to see and do briefly while you're in town. Its immediately adjacent to a major metro stop, so you can pop out enrollee from one real place to another. It is also right in the middle of a major shopping/restaurant area.

Simply incredible.. I enjoyed walking and people watching here. Be sure to take a picture next to the Hachi statute. Best view are from the second floor Starbucks and second floor of the subway station. How do you cross without bumping into anyone?

Fun to see...but don't go out of your way. Ok this attraction is simply for a bucket-list check off. I didn't find Shibuya all that exciting---it had all the same shopping and food as other areas of Tokyo but we went to see "the biggest crosswalk in the world." It was a scramble but fun to walk across and see all the people to get a feel for how big it actually was.
It is impressive . Close to metro stationIt looks good because it's six different zebra crossings in one Plus the road is too big and busy to jail walk it

Chaos and Order all in one. I won't have any problems if you call this place the center of civilisation. The haphazard crossing of people from all sides decaying into the orderly flow of vehicles and then repeating. Weirdly enough, it has a profound effect on your senses despite being 'just a crossing'. Highly recommend you get to the starbucks right at the intersection and get a corner seat. Sit there for 10-15 minutes and soak this experience in
Famous cross junction. The hustle bustle city centre is a good place for people watching. Do go up to the vantage point at starbucks opposite the road!

Very busy . I went there at night, and it was really crowed. There's a lot of shops, but then the best shops and the cheap ones are inside and hidden in the buildings, and u have to go to like 4th or 5th floor. I would not know that, but luckily my Japanese friend was taking me around. Otherwise it's really fun and u can experience the busy life of Tokyo.

A little bit of fun. If you want to experience real crowds, come here any time of day if you want to zig-zag past others while trying to cross. Bonus points for coming on a rainy day with your umbrella and battling for space past others with their umbrella. Just as fun in the evening too when the drunks try and make their way home - they don't always wait for the lights!
You won't miss it when you are at Shibuya. Tens of thousands of people are there crossing the street and you won't miss it because the crossing is just outside the Shibuya JR Station.

Busy busy busy. Definitely recommended for anyone travelling through Tokyo, this crossing can be pure insanity! We brought a selfie stick last time and got some funny footage, being a foreigner is fun as being a little taller then everyone really gives you a good perspective of all the people!
Crazy experience . I just been there a couple weeks ago, it was really fun to cross the street, great view from the Starbucks. It is for sure a walk to remember.

What did we miss..... Sorry but I just don't get the hype. We visited both day and night and this crosswalk is nothing special at all. The shops and little side streets are where it's at in Shibuya, not this little, and it is little, pedestrian crossing.....

Hilarious!. It was really fun to watch the crossing from upstairs of Mark City near the Starbucks. You don't have to sit inside Starbucks, just watch the actions by the big windows. Hilarious and amazing at the same time.

Tokyo Stopover. Iconic to any visit to Tokyo. Muscle your way through the crowds and across the various pedestrian crossings then head up to Starbucks for a relaxing coffee while you watch others do exactly the same.

Deserves to be seen!. Impressive flow of the people coming and going crossing the street as soon as the lights turn green and sudenly theh just stop and now the turn of the cars....and again the light and the people. You have first to experience the crossing of the street to "feel" it. After you find a good spot to see the flow from a higher level (for me the best: buy a Starbucks just at the corner, go upstairs to take pictures and enjoy both, the view and your coffee

You have to see it to believe it. You really have to see it to believe it. Very organised chaos Japanese style - best viewed from nearby Starbucks with a coffee by the upstairs window. Only in Japan would everyone wait for the green light to show !!

Must see! I've spent couple of hours today.... This place is magic. It can resume the spirit of Tokyo. Caos with kindness. Organized mess. Different types of people from all over the world. Bicycles, people, cars, buses and trucks sharing the same space. Yes, Tokyo is fantastic. And if a place summarize this atmosphere is Shibuya.

People Walking Everywhere. This is a major crossing from the Shibuya Station to the shopping restaurant area and is designed for jay walkers and anyone who wants to walk with thousands of others who stream out of the station particularly in the morning and evening.it is a place where you realise there are millions in Japan and everyone walks without any consideration of anyone else. This is not the only place you can see this aspect of Tokyo but this is probably one of the best.

Watch from inside starbucks. I'm not sure if starbucks offers the best view, but I was happy with it! It's pretty neat to see all these people concentrated in one area walking in unison. The lights and screens around on the buildings gives you a little times square feel too. No trip to Tokyo is complete without experiencing this

Watch from above!. One of the most interesting places in Tokyo. I strongly recommend to enjoy the view of Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble from one of the restaurants, such as Starbucks or L'occitane Cafe :-)
Wow!!!. Crowded,a lot of noise,a lot of lights,you realise that you are in tokyo!especially if you are from central europe this place is so far!
Check!. I must visit to put a check on our list :)Immersed ourselves in the crowd yet organised and synchronised movement of people. Interesting to just watch and be amazed.

Free entertainment in an otherwise expensive city. you just have to do this! try it both during the day and at night. Then go up to starbucks with a view of the crossing and watch the chaos emerge. it's great!

An experience. The Shibuya scramble is an iconic symbol of Tokyo, and it's an incredible experience to be surrounded by so many pedestrians at one time. A great place for some photos and in the middle of thousands of excellent restaurants ans activities, no visit to Tokyo is complete without having seen the scramble at least once.

Scramble crossing like no other. An attraction to see in Tokyo simply to see the large number of people in a fairly large area that cross at the lights each time that they change. It is fun to join in and necessary if you want to go into the shopping area towards the Starbucks cafe. Good photographs can be obtained from the upper levels of the Shibuya rail station before going down to road level

It's just a crossing. But organised chaos.. Definitely worth a visit. Nothing like it in Australia. But it is just a crossing with hundreds of people. Good shopping in the area, and is not out if the way. Do it.

Just Join In!. We're talking many many people whenever the lights turn green. I found myself joining with the crowd walking in multiple directions in the pedestrian walk.This is a perfect place for a quick street dance to liven up the whole walking experience! I can just imagine...

Become a Face in the Crowd. Shibuya's famous "pedestrian scramble" is a sight to see and be literally swept up in. The Starbucks overlooking the crossing is good for photos (I think they frown upon tourists quickly visiting for photos, but we were discreet) and lets you watch the crush of humanity from above.Bonus: the statue of Hachiko, the heroic Akita of Shibuya Station, is nearby!
Mesmerising to watch. A must see if you travel to Tokyo. Go to Starbucks and travel to the second floor for a great view. It was raining the day we were there, so lots of umbrellas to see too.

Tokyo Hotspot. Shibuya crossing is right outside the station and somewhere every visit to Tokyo should include. One of the best places for people watching and photos. All roads leading off this crossing are worth exploring and are full of shops, bars and restaurants. Shibuya 109 - a girls fashion shop - right on the crossing, can be enjoyed by women (and men!)

Hypnotizing!. Shibuya crossing is a must see - of course!!Shibuya area in overall is one of the biggest attraction in Tokyo. You can spend entire evening walking around and hop between shops and restaurants.Best view- secure good seats at Starbucks right on the corner, you will see it when you get there. The view from there - hypnotising!

Always busy. Famous for the film "Lost in Translation" this place is always busy with people both locals actually using the crossing and the ever present selfie tourists, yes I was one of them but its not the same taking a picture-best to head up to the starbucks and wait for the lights to go red then get some pics-you really capture the essence of it more from up top.

what the heck!!!. classic example of a controlled chaos. it was nice to see the people criss crossing the street. also found here is the statue of Hachikō who was an Akita dog born on a farm near the city of Ōdate, Akita Prefecture who is remembered for his remarkable loyalty to his owner which continued for many years after his owner's death
an okay experience. For first timers like me, visiting this intersection was a big deal. I've crossed the street a few times (because I needed to) and lost interest afterwards.

Keep on crossing the street, and you'll get a feel of Shibuya. The pedestrian scramble is quite an experience --- rain or shine. I was in Shibuya area during the latest Japan typhoon, and even the harsh rains didn't affect the number of people crossing.

A scramble indeed!. We went on the Shibuya scramble on a Friday night to experience the business and craziness. It was indeed crazy! So many people use this crossing, it was an interesting experience. Park yourself at the nearest Starbucks and enjoy the 'busy' view of pedestrians crossing if you have the time.
A Tokyo must!. This place is a must on the to do list when you are in Tokyo, there is a Starbucks. Grab a coffee and enjoy the view over the pedestrian walkovers.

Overwhelming. If you are nearby, go for the experience, it won't be a wasted trip. You can also go to an overlook by the train station, 2nd floor for some great shots. At this overlook is a mural by a famous Japanese artist about the effects of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.
Very interesting mass road cross in Shibuya!. You can see this many times and still won't get old! See it from Shibuya excel hotel lobby at JR station. But best view is from top!
Worth seeing it. one from the most popular places in Tokyo,visit it at night there are many options of bars,restaurants,cafes.Sit in a place in one corner and watch the swarm crossing
Raining. It was raining during our stay and watching the umbrella dodging from the 10 th floor of our hotel overlooking the crossings was fun, organised kaos

Look left, look right..just look everywhere!. What can you say apart from Crazy! If you like watching people crossing a road then this will fill that void. If you want to get the best view, go up to the Starbucks.

Hustle and bustle . Daily hundreds of people do the crossing here to get to the train/metro stations/shops. I reckon the best view of the crossing is at the Starbucks inside Tsutaya. On my last visit I stayed at the nearby Shibuya Excel Hotel which had an amazing bird's eye view of the crossing.

Crossed the street more than once just for the experience. Upon reaching the area, we were quite amused to see a lot of people crossing the street simultaneously without bumping into each other. My family then tried to cross more than once just for the experience.

Wow! So many people! . I found it best to see the crossing from the train station. It's amazing how everyone crosses by you without running into you. Must be on top alert while crossing, do not multitask!
Lots of people. Lots of people. If you want to take a nice picture of the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble then walk up to Starbucks on the 2nd floor.

Cross and cross again!. Join the crowd of tourists taking selfies right in the center of this very busy intersection. First time for me to see diagonal pedestrian lanes. Cant imagine how many times we had to cross. In spite of the traffic of people everything is very organized.

This is Tokyo in all its garish brilliance. This is the perfect place to watch the Japanese at play and marvel at their ability to be jammed together and still be polite and friendly. It's a great people watching place and staring point for so many places to see and experience. There is a new planetarium just up behind it on top of the Shibuya government office building, the food shops are varied and excellent, the sopping simply fabulous and its full of characters too. Make sure you visit Tokyu Hands as its just bizarre what you can buy there! DO NOT TAKE THE NEW SOUTHERN EXIT from the Yamanote line as you'll end up miles from the crossing region. It is mainly for the younger folk but well worth the trip and experience as the crowds converge for the long green light crossing. Do not jaywalk as the police will stop you!

Shibuya Crossing. Was fun being on the real thing definitely what doing at least once. One word "CRAZY" (crossing left, right, center absolute Madness) & I never went peak time...it's a different world once u get on and trust me u don't want to be on the road when the green light turns red lol
Quite interesting. It's a spectacle to see this and not half as intimidating as you might think walking through it, but seeing it once or twice is probably enough.
Scramble but don't stay long. I mean, it's a crosswalk. A big one but not as big as I thought. A must do, I guess, but don't plan your day around it.

Shibuya - Unbelievably crowded crossroads in Tokyo. It was definitely worth a visit to this unbelievably crowded crossroads - great for photographers - so much movement and so many people people crossing the streets at once!! Worth going to the Coffee shop at corner for a photo from a higher place :)

Frenetic. This is the synonim of civilization! Huge and well organized, crowded and vibrant! Take a few moments to watch it or try going to the starbucks coffee that provides the best view from top! Its hypnotising

Gotta go. Yes it is a cliche. But wow. It is incredible! So many people, so much noise; so much to look at. Multi level shopping overlooking the street, enormous video screens selling products, hyping movies. People moving in every direction all at the same time. If you can get up high it's worth the view. My family and I loved it and went back two more times. Shopping is fantastic too. And lots of great cheap or expensive restaurants. Saturday night is CRAZY! But if you can handle crowds it is truly awesome, and a truly Japanese experience.
Interesting . Good to look at and experience. Just catch the metro train and join in the fun. Plenty of shopping and you can have a coffee at Starbucks over looking the crossing

Cliche, but must see. It's a cliche but definitely worth seeing this.
Crazy but fun dynamic. Head up to 109 Men for their cafe on second floor for a good view if Starbucks is too busy!

Interesting sight.. It was amazing to see the stream of people coming from all directions. This proves that Tokyo is a city that doesn't only exist on the map, it is a city full vibes, sounds, colours and million and one tune that brings the music from within.

Iconic. This is a must do in Tokyo. It's right by the station so easy to find. It's fun to cross and also to watch. There's plenty of shopping and places to eat around the crossing. It's one of those surreal experiences you must do.

Must see!. A true can't miss experience. A must see in person and fun at night as well. 100's of people all crossing the street at once. Close to our hotel so we got to see this a few times and each time was so much fun.
The Times Square of Japan. Plenty of people, plenty of restaurants, plenty of shops, plenty of things to do. The atmosphere is great and fun.
Go for the shopping, not the intersection. It's a busy intersection, but the local stores are much more interesting. If you want a zoo, go at rush hour.
Just like in the animes. Awesome pedestrian scramble! Just like in the animes! Very busy and it's a nice feeling too see so many people from afar!

times square in the land of the rising sun. plenty of people, plenty of traffic, and just off the side there is this shop where there are young teenage looking girls dressed as dolls. totally bizarre.

Must See. A must see/do while in Tokyo.
It is without a doubt a crazy scramble across the street but great atmosphere and great fun.
Easy to locate when you walk out of the station.

Apartment at Shibuya. This area in Tokyo was amazing. Lots of people, stores, and a great modern Japanese cultural experience! I'm happy I stayed from to here and there's lots of great restaurant and sushi places to eat at.

Seen it, done it....moving right on. It's one of those places you just have to see to believe...
People everywhere, but in reality...it's a goddamn intersection.
Seen it...ticked it off...next!!!

Gotta see it to believe it!. It's one of those places that you've just got to experience.
It feels like the whole world, his wife and their dog are there and when the green man comes on it's like nothing you'll see anywhere else on the planet.
Try to grab a seat in Starbucks (which overlooks the crossing) to see all the madness going down!

Unavoidable, displaying Tokyos title of most densely populated city. Must take a picture here, I would strongly advise not doing the standard tourist thing of filming people crossing but rather get a friend to locate themselves on the bridge which is part of the station and overlooks the crossing to get a decent picture of you on the crossing.

One of the 'must see' sights of Tokyo. Funnily enough there are a number of 'scrambles' in Tokyo but this is the famous one. There are a number of cafes and restaurants overlooking the junction and it is mesmerising to watch from above. We went into Starbucks to get a better view. I can imagine a visitor from a sparsely populated home area visiting here freaking out at the sheer volume of pedestrians! Amongst all that chaos is order!

Busy street!. Tough getting a good photo here at night and wow, the hustle and bustle of the street is hard to compare to photos! I tried to get a good photo from the must-visit Starbucks but the crowd... Good to know the Hachiko statue is just nearby.

Spend time longer than I expected . This is a very weird experience. Unlike other photo-trap places, that usually I only spend less than an 30 min, this pedestrian scramble actually took 1+ hours. Tried to take a good picture of myself in the middle of the crowd from the stations bridge (helped by my wife), and didn't disappointed. Just hope there's more crowd like the pictures in the internet.

A total mess!. This is definitely a must see. This is Tokyo's most busiest intersection. There were so many people crossing the roads at once from left, right, front, back and diagonals that it was easy to get split up from your group of travels. The the best thing in this pedestrian is when you go to it at night, you get to see the buildings light up with their displays.

Organised chaos!. Really worth watching if you have time. Depending on the time of day will determine how many people you see mash across but as is the way in Japan it was super ordered and polite. Plenty of shopping here too.
Funny to watch. It's an experience that does make you smile, there are various viewpoints to film the scramble from, in the station, in the coffee shop. Unbelievably busy!

Pretty Great to Watch . Amazing to watch especially if you can find a place close and high up to see it from. Definitely worth experiencing for yourself. It's not that crazy after lunch just make sure you're paying attention while crossing to avoid others.

It was ok. It really is cool to see but I lost intrest fast. Crossed the street just to say i did then walked back and to a bar. Shibuya is really the Shopping district so kept that in mind when going.

You just got to see this to believe.... I have seen this scene many times on BBC but nothing prepared me for what actually happens when the lights turn red and the pedestrians all cross the traffic junction, at the same time, going in different directions. It's like a scampering of ants when you see this from height. A truly amazing sight to behold. If you haven't already seen this, go and spend a little time being astonished.

A walk like any other. Maybe it was the time (no crowd), maybe I was expecting too much. I didn’t see any scrambling activities or resemblance of a scramble. I missed the junction during my last year’s visit so this time around had my camera ready to capture that “famous” scramble. Up from the shopping mall and across I did walk – like any other junction to me. It was quite a distance across and it possibly can become a scramble if you are short for time AND there is a crowd. Not exactly an attraction but curiosity kills the cat...
The biggest pedestrian crossing in the world. You must come here to experience the biggest pedestrian crossing in the world! Welcome to Tokyo guys! This is gonna be fun!
fun place & great experience. Busy street. Shops, store & building are pretty. Great place for shopping. On the street is just like human ocean all over the crossing yet nice to see. amazing place!
Go see. Best views can be had from the coffee shops around the venue. We visited during rush hour and stayed for about 15 minutes and moved on.

Watch out for selfie sticks in your face!. Everyone wants to film themselves walking across the Shibuya crossing...ok, that's cool....whats not cool is nearly decapitating others whilst trying to film yourself. Seriously..selfie stick in the face...it will happen. Anyway, it's great fun and in my own experience, the best view of the crossing is from the second floor of the Starbucks..and you don't have to buy coffee..I think they are used to tourists coming in for the view by now :) Its pretty impressive night and day!

Can't miss. This is a wild scene to take in and you have to make it a stop on your tour of Tokyo. It's very accessible as it is right on the corner of the metro station and it is wild. Head up to the Starbucks on the corner and grab a drink and head up to their second floor. There are great seats overlooking the intersection and huge bay windows where you can snap photos or shoot a cool time lapse video like I did!
As seen in movies. Impressive area. There are a few big crossings in Shibuya so there's lots of opportunity to watch. Organised chaos.
Shibuya. Fun experience, and if youre in Tokyo you'l have to visit if you are in shibuya. and visit the starbuck's across the street from the subway :)
beautiful store and street. The shibuya is a great place for shopping! The street and store buildings are pretty and some are even amazing!
Best part of Tokyo!. Must go here! There are so many fantastic shops and restaurants in this area. It would be silly to come to Tokyo and miss out on this fantastic cultural experience.

Try and do this en-route to somewhere else. Fun for a short period and if you go to one of the vantage points in the hotel, railway station, or Starbucks to get an elevated position. We were there during the day, mid-week so wasn't too busy. Better to go at the weekend and/or in the evening
many, many pedestrians.... Went here after seeing the Hachiko statue. It is an amazing view to see so many people crossing the road all at the same time. Nightview is more spectacular however.

you cant miss it.. you feel like you are swimming in a human ocean . Perfect feeling . I can ust go back to Tokyo to live the scramble .
It was raining when i was crossing one of the time . Thousands of umbrellas .. Magical moment .

You have to see it to believe it!!. We loved the experience and also loved watching from the starbucks opposite!
Its amazing how nobody bumps into anybody and how quick so many people cross... The volume of bodies is amazing!!!

Big intersection . The statue of "Hachi" the dog is out the Hachiko exit of Shibuya Station, and then this monstrosity of an intersection is right there as well. It's impressive for no other reason than to see so many people and cars exist successfully on what should be a deadly dance on any other country. Surrounded by malls, restaurants and nightclubs...it's well worth a visit.

Increwdible. will definitely be returning. the most amazing atmosphere, a truly incredible place! Best place to watch is from upstairs in the starbucks, although places are limited so you ay have to wait bit!
