Ideal for people-watching. This is one of the largest crossings in the world and is always crowded with people. However, if you like people-watching - get a can of beer at night time, and do the crossing. When we were there there was a street band close to the crossing and we thoroughly enjoyed stopping there for a few minutes, crossing again, sipping beer and looking at all the different, eclectic people

Busy, but a must-see!. Obviously the Scramble Crossing is going to be highly populated every time you are able to cross the road. I went here every day on my stay in Japan as I love the Starbucks that overlooks the crossing.It is very hard finding seats at the window here as everyone is looking to view the infamous crossing. I did wait on some occasions for around 15 minutes to sit down and read emails, but it was just amazing! All the people with different destinations in mind. It was a fantastic people-watching experience.OH, on my last day in Japan as I was sitting minding my business and on FaceTime with my partner, real life Mario Karts were racing on the streets!!! People with actual karts and dressed up as the characters. I couldn't believe my eyes! People of Japan are my favourite.
A must in Tokyo. My favourite place in Tokyo. Always lively, full of happening and interesting personages. A great place for pictures, shopping, night life.

Lots of fun. Visited this area in May. Had an overnight layover and chose to travel from haneda to this location on the subway. Easy to get to from the airport, but there is a subway change over. No one speaks English so right down subway station names, people can recognize them and help you. The area is very trendy. Spent a couple hours. Most of the stores there are your typical trendy stores. Lots of people, net seeing all the lights. Reminded me of time square in New York. Crossing the street all at once was fun and very crowded but easy to do, it was a fun place to go for a couple of hours on my layover.

An experience in people watching!. If you want to see something akin to human fireworks and you're in the neighborhood for shopping or dining, exit through the Hachiko gate and you're right on top of something pretty wild. You may have seen it in movies, but here's your chance to experience it for yourself. It's simply the way you cross the street from the station into the Senta-gai shopping area, but that doesn't do the Shibuya Scramble justice. Very crowded as people mass on the sidewalks, the light changes, and then it's a human explosion that spreads across the street. Some other reviewers suggest trying the Starbucks where you can watch the action. That sounds like a good idea to me, although I've never done it. Otherwise, if you're going that way, there's hardly any avoiding it so just enjoy the humanity. Warning, though-- if you're at all crowd-adverse it's not for you.

Fun and enjoy. I really couldnt imagine this place is great that much. It is very nice to go there specially during the weekend afternoon and have coffee in starbucks while you are taking photos of the unforgettable view. I believe you need at least 4 hours there
Must See. A must see when in Tokyo. Highly recommend visiting the Starbucks overlooking the road and people watching with a coffee.
Great . Iconic site but I thought going in the evening it would be packed but it did not seem particularly busy but I think the neon boards are just amazing.

Not sure what the fuss is about.... Maybe I'm not appreciating the touristic value of this crossing as I live in London and experience this on a daily basis. It was nonetheless cool sitting down in a nearby cafe and watch this crossing from the comfort of my chair with cake and tea :)

Bladerunner Shopping District. Shibuya is a must-see part of Tokyo, an over-the-top overwhelming shopping district overloaded with videoscreens, department stores, elevated trains...and pedestrians. Shibuya Crossing is very much the highlight of this science fiction shopping streets. Thousands of people hurdle across the street from six interections. Scene from the windows at Starbucks, it looks like a riot is breaking out. But the instant the light changes, order is restored. Shibuya blends chaos and calm in such a way that it is very much the quintessential neighborhood in Tokyo.

The must do in Tokyo, get lost in translation. A must visit and a must experience in Tokyo, you can recreate the feel of Lost In Translation in this famous Shibuya crossing. The Starbucks is a great spot to sip your coffee while watching the shibuya crossing. You can't miss the infamous Hachiko statue nearby.
Fun. Had fun trying to get across the street. I even recorded my attempt. It is chaotic, but oddly entertaining. I also suggest going to the shopping area and watching it from above

Best seen from above. This is a fun site to see during the rush hour with the masses crossing the street. If you aren't staying in a local hotel, then go to Starbucks on the corner for a good view. It's one of the busiest intersections in Tokyo and the crossing is filled with people going in all directions at the same time, but it still moves swiftly with true Japanese precision.

Amazing experience where no-one collides with anyone else. Living in Japan for a couple of years taught me to go at the same pace as everyone else! Same is true of crossing the road outside the train station. Everyone moves elegantly and without bumping! Visit Uematsu for the most special art materials of the city and Tokyu Hands store was there before IKEA was invented and does it better.

Tokyo central. This is my Tokyo. Chaotic yet supremely organized, eccentric yet running with military precision. Watching the action from Starbucks was a daily activity and never got old. With a sea of transparent umbrellas in the rain, with light bright at night, with UV umbrellas in hot summertime - Shibuya scramble. And Shibuya 109 calling loudly (love that store).

A must see. This is one of those places, along with Shinjuku station, which really help form a lasting impression of Tokyo. The crossing at Shibuya is never empty and it's a good place to just take a step back and take in the human sea.
attraversiamo. everytime I end up at the famous Shibuya crossing I can't stop myself and have to stand in the mere center dfor a few minutes to watche the people all around!
You have to see it. Its a crossing which is never empty. You csn not imagine how many people can cross at the same time. The best view you have from the Excel hotel.

Thousands of people are there!!. It looks just like an ordinary intersection located just at the exit of the Shibuya station, but if you come here you will understand what makes this place so special: when the streetlights turn green, a huge crowd of people starts crossing the street, as if there’s some holiday celebration, and suddenly the street looks totally different… this place is very popular among foreign tourists; it even appeared in the movies “Lost in Translation” and “Resident Evil: Afterlife”.

Massive intersections that you must see when you're in Tokyo. visit this place in the afternoon before headed to the airport. You can ticked at least 2 from your bucket list, since in the one corner of this intersections is Hachiko statue. I crossed this scramble couple times from different corners, and one time i made myself stand in the center scramble for couple seconds and took several pictures. I was amazed by how many peoples that crossed this scrambles in just 60 seconds, Tokyo indeed is a high populated city. Although it was raining but I'm very excited since everybody using umbrellas and it feels exactly like resident evil scene (luckily i'm not the one who stand in the scramble center and turn into zombie hahahhahaha) I found the best spot to see this scramble is from Starbucks on the 2nd fl (i tried to see it from Skywalk Malls but it's too far back to enjoy it and too many distraction). The window table is all occupied but the turnaround is pretty quick, plus the other visitors is willing to share their spots when their done taking pictures. I didn't notice NO PHOTO signs in starbucks window that mentioned by other reviewers. When you paid your coffee don't forget to ask their wifi password and instruction card.
Fun!. Everything I imagined it to be from seeing photos and videos before! Really need to experience in real-life!

Must see !. We have been a few times to the Shibuya Scramble and it just never gets old! To experience so many people all crossing the road among all the bright lights and massive tv screens is fantastic, and nobody bumps into each other! I would love to grab a seat at the strabucks and just watch it all next time I go to Japan.
Human rush hour. To me this is busiest traffic crossing I have ever seen .. Best spots to take photos is the Starbucks building (higher floors) or the opposite bridge building.0

Fun, but not the busiest . It's fun to see the crowds passing from almost all directions. Difficult to get a view from the top as the windows in most of the surrounding buildings are blocked. Got a glimpse from Starbucks on 2nd floor though. The crossing near Shinjuku east station is maybe even more crazy than this.
Nice view. Impressive by the number of people (Japanese and a lot of tourists). Nice view, with buildings and bright. Worth it.
Great experience. In the afternoon we took at seat at the second floor of Starbucks. Enjoying our drinks we had a fantastic view on the incredible crowds passing by and crossing the streets.
Exactly like what you seen on TV. its crowded and at the same time a perfect spot to grab shots of shibuya. From the hundreds of people crossing at the same time to the neon lights
Probably the most known crossroad of the world.. One of the places of Tokyo you´ll probably find in many movies. You can get a good view from all the action from Starbucks.

Fun Place.... Honestly, I was expecting more people crossing the streets and expected to be more crowded. Still, it was a fun experience crossing Shibuya, We did it at least a couple of times and we took dozens of pictures waiting for the perfect crowded picture but it wasn't never enough people (in my wife's opinion). Still, a great place to see, specially at night.

Crowded Crowded. Very crowded and we stood by having a look at the people go by. It has a lot of stores close by and we stored our stuff at the station in the lockers and went down to join the crowd :)

A Must Experience in Tokyo. They said that it would be a shame to come to Tokyo and not take a walk across the famous intersection and thus we did. It is pretty cool to see how people scramble when the traffic light turns into red and all vehicles will stop in all directions. After crossing it I watched them from a coffee shop nearby many times.

Arguably the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world?. Simply one of the coolest sights in Tokyo, which perfectly illustrates modern Japan!The red lights for pedestrians gather the people for about 2 minutes in all four corners of the crossing, and then the lights turn green for everybody... so you see loads of people going at the same time. Pretty irresistible not to quickly snap a picture when you're going through the middle of it!

Organized Chaos. Visiting this area of Tokyo is quite amazing. I recommend standing in the nearby pedestrian bridge at the metro station to get a good view of the crossing. It is best to watch while people gather at all the crosswalks. When the lights change and the mass organized chaos of the crossing begins, it is quite a sight to see.

This is REAL CITY. I used to live in Taipei, which is a busy city.. but I still got culture shock to see how much people could be in one space.. If you have been complaining about your city is too busy.. If you come to here and look at the amount of people crossing street.. then you will know your city is not that busy at all.. The time square is not even near this place.. you can feel a special energy or pressure here if you are not used to BUSY life style. It's fun to see and feel the energy there. I took a video of it and show a lot people. All of them were socked to watch it. so, if you are in Tokyo, must go there in the night and see the real life there!!
Very cool. Very cool at night. It is lit up like times square and has many giant videoscreens on the building. Good restaraunts around

Essential experience in Tokyo.. This is quintessential Tokyo. Come watch the orchestrated chaos. There is a ton of shopping here, from high end to bric-a-brac. There are restaurants, bars, cafes, bakeries galore. Walk and indulge almost anywhere and everywhere in the area. You haven't been to Tokyo unless you come here.
Definitely worth visiting. crossing the Shibuya intersection is a MUST! Also, watching it from the Starbucks/Tsutaya is VERY COOL. I've been countless of times & it never gets old.

Fun Experience. I didn't even know what's happening when I crossed this crossing until lots of people came in from all directions! The experience was so much fun and superb and I guess lots of people came here just to experience the famous Shibuya Crossing, it was nice and fun and there are some people on the other side of each crossing offering "free hugs", indeed very Japanese!

Exhilarating at night - a must see for Tokyo nightlife. Went here with my 19 year old daughter and we both enjoyed it - the sheer pace of the area, the bright lights, the buzz, the dizzying array of fashion on pedestrians is amazing to experience. A must see in Tokyo.

Steping out into organised chaos. After stepping out of the train station I was met by mounds of people. It appeared to be a meet up spot for locals and tourists alike. The crossing itself I found strangely exciting. I was in awe of the huge waves of people and how despite the volume everything seemed organised. It was great fun to cross and I did so deliberately as many times as possible whilst on my trip. Fascinating to watch from the ground and above.

Fast and the Furious Tokyo Drift. A must do in Tokyo as most city scrambles around the world copied this original. Best time at night for the effect of all the neon lights from city and the bustle of people heading out for the night and home from work.Many people were using selfie sticks to get a good overhead shot but just head up for a beverage at the Starbucks or over to the overhead crossing at the subway to get a good shot of the action.Stick around and walk the small streets for something to eat or buy.
You must do this!. So many people and no-one bumps into each other! Great shopping and eateries in the area. Very easy access to the train station.
Fun to watch. This place is fun to watch when the lights go green on a busy day. It's like an antfarm. People everywhere. A must see.
Scramble@Shibuya. True enough we really enjoy the shibuya crossing, my estimate about 4k pedestrians crossing at 1time. We had to scramble all the way and moreover it raining that particular time.
Cool!. Fun thing to do in the area. Even better at night. I suggest watching it from the nearby Starbucks for a bird's eye view and then walking in the middle if it. The rush is incredible!

A bit of fun.... Not as chaotic as you'd think, but fun all the same. People don't neccessarily stick to the crossings and basically just go where they want. It's difficult (or was for us) to find a good place to view it, although the Starbucks on one corner was reasonable. As it was summer there were a lot of people about and so it seemed a lot busier than usual. In any case, if you're in Shibuya anyway, it's right next to the station so you might as well check it out - or if needs be, just use it to cross the road...

Shibuya Crossing. This place is so beautiful with lots of stores, restaurants and coffee shops around the area. The cross walk is wonderful and a lot of people shop here as the prices are less expensive compared to big malls in Shinjuku.

Disappointed . I'm afraid to say I was disappointed. I really went there to be amazed yet only to be let down with the 'scramble'. More like a crawl. Did it on several days and at different times to try and get the effect. No luck.

View from above. We went there around 4 o'clock in Autumn and was getting dark. Although there were so many people it was orderly chaos. My daughter who studied there as an exchange student led me to Loccitane cafe which was on the first floor of the shop. We chose a window table and from which we could have a wonderful view of the crossing. Unfortunately my camera wasn't good enough to take pictures in low lighting otherwise it would capture the mood. Well we did have a lovely afternoon treat at the cafe. I had their organic honey tea and the seasonal special, chestnut creme brûlée which was divine. But it was one of most expensive afternoon tea I had!

Aerial view is best. It's a crazy place to be when the green man appears, hundreds of people crossing in different directions all at once. We joined in and got swept along. To see it at its best go to the first floor coffee shop and peer out of the window.

Better than Times Square. This intersection is great fun. Walk it. Photograph/video it. The big video screens, throngs of pedestrians and plenty of vantage points make this an epic, human urban experience. The people watching is wonderful, and it can enjoyed in a few cycles of the traffic lights, or even up to an hour.
Epic experience. epic awesome movie like experience. Cool for pictures and time lapse videos. This is also close to a cool area so it is def a must

Feel the Tokyo city!. Shibuya is a place where a lot of movies film. it's central of the city and once you are there you feel the city mood. I have been to Osaka, Tokyo, and Okinawa, and this part of city is the most dirtiest out of all the part of Japan. Soooo many people, and sooo many shops. sooooo city of the city. we went to this place to feel the city mood, eat kentai sushi and disney shop. I don't suggest you stay long if you have kids, but without kids, of course soooo much things to do!
A very happening street in Tokyo. A very lively area in Tokyo. A must visit area to take a selfie with friends or families. Good sight seeing of the metropolitan life

See from above!. Go into the Starbucks or we went into another building where you are just above the scramble. Watching it from above was far more interesting than being in the thick of it, although both are worthwhile. Great people watching scene. When there don't miss the statue of Hachiko, the dog!

A bit of mad Japan. Japan is usually so ordered that it is good to find places like the Tokyo subway or Shibuya crossing where it mildly breaks down. The scramble has been made famous in various Hollywood films. The thing to realize is that it is just the entrance to a shopping district.If you really want to see the scramble, then take your place at ground zero, or rise above it all by going for a coffee at the Starbucks or the L'Occitane cafe across the road from the Shibuya subway station. But it is not more crowded than many places in India, China, Korea or Japan.It is really much nicer to walk around, look at the tiny statue of Japan's most famous dog, Hachiko, or visit one of the many stores around the crossing, stand and gawk at the huge video screens showing advertisements, or listen to the buskers.
Well, its just a pedestrain crossing. It wasn't that of a wow for me but just a unique way of crossing the road. So I wouldn't recommend going just for this.

Iconic Tokyo. I've been to Tokyo over twenty times and the site of a quarter million people crossing this intersection still leaves me in awe. The Tokyo Metro drops you off right in front of the chaos but the Starbucks across the street serves as the perfect meeting spot. The rest of Shibuya really fits into the madness of this crosswalk...join the scramble then enjoy the sites!

Wonderful Pedestrian Scene. We have an overnight stay at Narita courtesy of our delayed flight. In order to while away our time, we decided to take an adventure by getting into a train going to Tokyo. But first, we need to decide which part of Tokyo we would want to venture. We asked a fellow traveller and recommended to us a visit to Shibuya. This is about an hour and a half train travel with just a single train transfer at Nappori. We decided to the the Keisei Skyliner train to Naporri and then buy another ticket for the Yamanote Line to Shibuya.When we got into our destination, we just walked into the exit, not knowing where to go, although we know that all we need to do is remember the area where we alighted. We remember landmarks so that we will not get lost since a lot of people in the area speak just a little English.As we walk, we came into the street where the cross walks are all all intersecting and what an experience!! The pedestrians are all so disciplined, once the traffic lights turns red, there they go..people criss-crossing and walking past each other. We just walk amongst the crowd and enjoyed the marvelous scene of people crossing.There are lots of ramen/noodle houses in the area as well. We enjoyed the short visit to the area and would definitely go back there again and maybe stay for a couple of days to explore the area even more.

Tokyo must do. Shibuya should not be missed if you go to Tokyo, as it is the busy place in Tokyo .This is the place for night life and is great.All the other shopping delights are there too and it is centralized.Good place for American and Europeans city wonderers.

Busy with lots of other options to occupy surrounding. We went on a weekday evening and although still very busy, was not as much of a mad scramble as expected. The area around the intersection has a good selection of eateries and shopping.

250,000 people per day cross here. If you want to go someplace where the Japanese are not as mindful of the rules, then you should head over to the SHIBUYA scramble. When the light changes and hundreds of people cross all at the same time.from many different directions, this can be fun to watch. There are very few collisions, but if you are not out of the crossing by the time that the light changes, that's when the fun begins.You will not hear horns honking, but you will definitely pick up your pace. So far haven't heard about anyone being hit by a car. a great spot to take pics

Craziest crossing I've ever seen! . The Shibuya Scramble is famous for being the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world, with thousands of people crossing the street in all directions at every light change. Located right outside of Shibuya Subway station, the crossing leads directly to the main shopping district in Shibuya. After you've crossed several times yourself for fun, make sure you go up to the Starbucks located right across the street from the station for an even better view of the scramble! Best time to visit is during morning or afternoon peak hour when there are more people rushing to and from the busy station.

12 ways to cross a road. Fun to say tht you been on the Famous crossing. This is the langer of the two for the second you have to walk further up the road and iT is About half the size of the one near Shibuya station

Best place to view scrambling...... ......would have to be Starbucks. That's the best vantage point. Another noteworth vantage point would be at Shibuya station overhead bridge. The scrambling is a mess if you're walking amongst the sea of humans dashing across the street from but is pretty amusing to watch : )

Pulsating. Okay ! Not sure if Shibuya scramble is even a real name. This would not have been my list of places to visit. However; after being there this evening, I can see why this place can be hypnotizing. In the evenings the place is pulsating with activity. The Starbucks is a great viewing spot and so are the numerous pedestrian bridges.
Shibuya Crossing. Very cool site to behold and walk amongst. Definitely worth a visit, especially if you're staying in Shibuya or nearby.

You cou;d watch it for hours. Shibuya crossing is huge. Massive amounts of people moving in all directions. The best place to view the crossing is at the startbucks as the windows face out across the crossing.

Lively place. It was what I have expected: busy, lively, and full of excitement. We visited at night and the whole area lit up with colorful neon lights. We sat on second floor at Starbucks and it was as fun just to watch the crowd and movement at the crossing. There is Tokyu Hand with its amazing food shows at one of the corner of the crossing.

Don't miss the crazy Shibuya crossing!. Crazy!! a sea of humanity! Cross a few times to fully experience the fun that is Tokyo! It is right on the Subway line so you can make a stop and do some of the best shopping in Tokyo. Lots of good restaurants around there too with foods that are well-known only in Shibuya.
Best seen at night. Crazy and hectic, but fun to watch from the second floor of the Starbucks building. Worth a visit at night too.

a little overrated,but still fun.. the hype around the chaos of this crossing has meant that it's a little underwhelming once you get there. But still worth seeing, especially from the Starbucks window.
Shibuya crossing - like the movies. We had to use the crossing several times to get to Shibuya station. It really is just like the movies and is the most fun at night when the neon lights come out.

Organized Chaos. Who knew crossing a street could be so much fun? It's pretty cool to see hundreds of people speed walk across the street all at the same time. Even better on a rainy day when hundreds of colorful umbrellas fill the street. It's definitely a must-see/must-do when visiting Tokyo. You can go up to the second floor Starbuck's at the corner and watch the madness from above. Once you've had your fill of street crossing, you can explore the surrounding area and do some shopping or grab a bite.
Shibuya Crossing . Tons of people crossing at the same time in an orderly disorder manner. Fun to watch, but be careful you don't get separated from your party.
Mental. Totally crazy as hundreds of people on a mad rush. Best part is all the tourists trying to get crazy photos as they walk across the crossing.

Very Amusing and Surprisingly Interesting. It's quite interesting to see everyone cross the street from four corners at the same time, and I can see how it might be especially fascinating from a viewpoint above ground (such as the Starbuck's). Keep in mind that this is literally just watching people cross the street at the same time from four large intersections/directions (or crossing with some of them).But this is lots of fun from any vantage point, and there are always tons of people crossing from every direction--no matter the time of day.

A Mad Rush. We went here in the early evening when it was raining - which made our photos look amazing with all the umbrellas everywhere. Definitely worth taking part, everyone manages to dodge everyone else. The sights around the crossing are also fab, with big screens and tall buildings all around.
Amazing to watch and be on!. Loved it - amazing to watch and better to be on. Our hotel room overlooked the crossing. With our without an umbrella it was fascinating. A busy place but great.

Night time experience. Just as you would expect.- Go at night for the full experience.- For perfect photos get your partner/Buddy to sit in Star bucks and take a panorama for -that perfect Holiday snap.

Looks larger in the movies. Gets very busy and have to find a high vantage point to view it properly. It also feels a bit surreal when you are crossing yourself, as you have to navigate quickly between hordes of people.

Tokyo like you imagine. This was really cool as it really does exactly look like in the movies! At shibuya station there is a big window where you can look down on to the crossing or you can go into the starbucks opposite the station in the second floor to have a look. It is really cool and i thought it was definetly fun watching this crowd go by a few times. Did not get tired of it. This in my opinion really is one of the major features of tokyo :)

Human Tide. Everyone going to Shibuya, seems to cross, and suppose it is famous as one of those only in Japan experiences. Like several armies attacking from six? sides, it lloks like it will end in chaos. But being Japan everyone flows through each other like schools of fish, and never any pushing or shoving. Tourists filming are the ones most likely to bump into you.So what's so amazing about a pedestrian crossing? You will just have to be there to see.

Crazy stuff. What a place to visit. Whether it's 1am or 1pm there's a horde of people crossing at this point. We took a few moments to just watch the back and forth of people at various points in the day. It gives you a great sense of the flow of Toyko in this one place - it's orderly chaos! Whether it was just the people, the moving billboard trucks or emergency services, they all become a spectacle in this one place. A must see in Tokyo.

Best view from Starbucks.. when walking through the crossing it doesn't feel as real. However, go grab yourself lunch at the Starbucks above the crossing, set your phone to time lapse mode and watch the scramble. After you've had lunch review your footage and you will be amazed at the scramble!! without failure there are people scampering through the crossing every minute

"Scramble Crossing". This crossing in Shibuya is the busiest in the world. Is so many people crossing all day and night . I choose a hotel very close to the junction so we could go there and see all the people .Shibuya Station where Hachiko statue is. And I went to see and took a picture next to his statue.Most of the people are beautiful and very young Japanese girls.The stores are full,a lot of foreigns,the Tokyu department store,Shibuya 109,is right there,pleny of restaurants and bars.Nice hotels near there.

Big crowd that never ran out. Great amazing big number of people crossed this intersection at any given time day & night. If you like to be in it join them, if don't like crowd don't go here. You'll be lost in this intersection. Must hold each other's hands or disappear in the large crowd.

Good, but not worth a trip. I should start by saying that I find Tokyo highly overrated in general. Shibuya is kind of fun and if you decide you want to do Tokyo definitely go as it is one of the more fun areas to see. If you are thinking about whether you want to visit Tokyo or not there are about 10 other places in Asia I would go first. And another 30-40 globally. People in Tokyo seriously would prefer you not visit. They make every effort to ensure that the only way to get around, read signs, and even eat food is to speak, read, and understand Japanese. Aka...we don't want you here. Hard to believe in a world where English is the universal language. Anyway, we met some nice people on our trip here, but they were for sure the minority, though much appreciated meeting them.

Just like in the movies. At this chaotic multi-zebra junction in Japan, probably the busiest in the world, you find a confluence of human traffic from all directions. Even tourists couldn't help but snap pictures in the middle of the junction while crossing over.

Busy corner. It is phenomenal there are literary hundreds of people crossing the road at the same time it is well worth a visit Shibuya is a really lively place with lots of shops restaurants and bars. It's also home to tower records and that place seems to have just about any record or disc you are looking for spaced over 4 floors there is so much to see and buy

people watching at it's best. The intersection itself can seem dull at first but the hustle and bustle of the city soon sends waves of new and strange people (locals and tourists alike) past your gaze. The is one of the best places to people watch, find a wall or a bench (outside the station) or sit in having a coffee above the street and watch the world rush by. If you get bored of seeing the humans scurry about there is a shopping district up two streets, a food district to the left of that and some great bars and nightclubs should you stay late enough.

You've seen it on TV, You just have to go and experience it. This really is one of those things you have to do in Tokyo. Grab a coffee in starbucks, go up to the first floor, shuffle your way to the window and watch the spectacle of the ebb and flow as the lights change and the area below either fills with people or cars. Even 23.00 at night and this place is mad. The area is good to wander around at night and you will feel quite safe and comfortable.

Interesting when looked at from above. It was somewhat difficult to find a way out of Shibuya station. There were several spots where you could see the scramble from inside the station and since Starbucks next to it is under renovation it was a convenient way to see it. L'Occitaine cafe next to it was also a nice place to watch the scramble (with air-conditioning!!!!), but the que to the cafe was rather long.

Visit The Busiest Intersection in Tokyo!!!. I visited this intersection on a Saturday night in the rain and it was still busy, so be prepared to dodge through a ton of people with umbrellas. If you go to the Starbucks on the corner, you can get some great pictures. Be careful if you use the subway at the crossing on a busy night; I saw a lot of intoxicated young people trying to make their way done the stairs. Go to visitacity.com to help you plan your itinerary. Tip: have your video option on your phone ready for the memories.

Pedestrian > Vehicles. It's a balance between pedestrian and vehicles. You'll see waves of pedestrians in the crossing as soon as the traffic light goes red.The best place to appreciate this is on the 2/F of Starbucks, inside a record store.
Interesting!. Yes, it is interesting to see so hundreds of people crossing from all directions. But that is true to most crowded areas of Japanese cities because of their dense population.
one of a kind. stay at the starbucks coffee shop. just infront of the main road. you can observe the beauty of it. nice to take pictures while they are crossing and you just stay in the middle of it.

interesting to see. This is a well known intersection of a number of streets (five maybe?). In essence, each street gets the right of way via stop lights and then when they've all had a shot, traffic stops so all of the pedestrians get to cross whichever street they prefer in the intersection. Like most things we've found in Tokyo, there seems to be order amongst the hustle of the city. We were told to view the scramble from the second floor of the Starbucks, which was probably a good suggestion, but it is hardly a secret and space is limited.

Just like the movies!. Traffic comes to a complete halt as crosswalks in all directions turn green and people begin to swarm the intersection. It's a wonderful spectacle. I personally walked back and forth a couple of times to just really bask in it. I think it's better to go at night so that you can see the bright lights from the large signs around you light up the night. Decent restaurants are all around the area, too!

Don't trip!. If you are in Shibuya chances are you are 100% invested in doing this and why shouldn't you?! It's fun to be touristy so don't be ashamed! There isn't much to say about this other than if you want to see a visual of the experience check out my clip from my web series here: Starts at 1:30 - https://youtu.be/LdDCscCVs80?t=1m30sThe video also suggest things to do in Shibuya, Shinjuku and Harajuku so feel free to check that out or any of my other videos that suggest places to visit in and around Tokyo. Hope you have a great trip!

Something everyone should do. I've seen this intersection in movies, but they don't do it justice. We saw it two different times. Once on a weekday evening and once on a Sunday afternoon. Both times it was INSANE!! I've never seen that many people at once! We sat there for about 5 minutes just watching people cross the street.

Great Shopping!. The first thing we did when we got out of the Shibuya train station was head over to the Hatchiko monument to have our pix taken at that famous sculpture of the legendary loyal dog, Hatchi.Afterwards, we stood among hundreds of people as we waited at the intersection for the crosswalk light to change. It was warm and muggy, with light sprinkles, but that didn't deter us from making the best of the situation. There are many shops all over that square area, so you can shop to your heart's desire, depending on what pleases you: Disney store, Forever 21, etc. We found Seria, a discount store, on the 7th floor of the upscale 0101 (?) shopping bldg. We spent lots of time and money there--such bargains!!We didn't eat at any of the restaurants--although there were many--because we ate a hefty breakfast buffet at our hotel.

What a sight. This is something to see but now earth shattering. If you are going that way anyway check it out. From the shibuya train walkway you can see it from one story above the street and can appreciate how flipping many people there are. Then you can participate. It's kind of a herd mentality thing. The whole area is worth a stroll. Kind of a permanent street carnival to the max. It makes times square look so lame. Great people watching.

Smaller than expected. Planned a day especially to go to Shibuya and see the crossing. A lot smaller than what I expected. But still busy and a lot of people. Got the best view from a shopping centre. Lots of shopping too.

People watching fun. This is a great area to people watch and pick up some souvenirs. Lots of high end shopping and cute shops for young and old. We love the area and all the restaurants. Must get a crepe.
Messy crossing. It was initially interesting and funny to see everyone just randomly crossing all over the place. Afterwards, it just grew boring. Nothing much in my opinion.
It's a crossing!. And a fun one at that - in any other city it would be utter madness, but it works here somehow. Try and find a way to go into one of the buildings and see it from higher up

Go to Starbucks for the best view of the crossing. We went here in the middle of the day and even though we saw a lot of people, it was probably nowhere near the 1000+ making the crossing on a single green light at peak times. Still, it was fun to have been there, taking a time-lapse photograph from the ringside position at Starbucks.

Not as busy as expected. Maybe it's because I have been to China and Vietnam, where you fight for space on crosswalks not just with pedestrians but with motorbikes and bicycles, but this wasn't as busy as i'd expected. It's certainly busier at peak times (in the evening) but during the day it's just a big cross walk. However, do it just to say you have!

Not as impressive as expected. I was expecting shoulder to shoulder crowds. It was not what I expected. I have encountered busier and more crowded intersection in Hong Kong Causeway bay but I guess this is impressive in the sense that it is a huge intersection. It was still a lot of fun walking around in that area.

Beautiful Madness. It's just fun to cross and few times and people watch. Not dangerous at all, but very "Lost in Translation". Lots of professional photographers set up on Tripods taking long exposures on fisheye lenses etc .. Beautiful on a balmy night with all the lights and buzz.
Wow!. So many people and so much neon everywhere! Awesome to watch! Never seen anything like it anywhere else in the world.

Definitely Pay A Visit and do a Crossing. A must visit when touring Tokyo. A city of multi-millions of people all seem to be here at this crossing. Find a vantage point and watch the chaos as everyone crosses. Have a go yourself and grab your camera for a selfie. Plenty of shops and restaurants around and easily accessed by train. For those who love watching the world go by, you will be in heaven.

Pretty Cool. We viewed the pedestrian scramble during the day and then later at night. Actually seemed busier during the day but the night time provides a really cool backdrop for your pictures. Reminds us a lot of Times Square, meaning bright lights, huge crowds and lots of tourists taking pictures :)

Bucketlist. A must do if you are in Tokyo! Exactly just like in the movies! Make sure you know which way you are heading to. For best view, head to the Starbucks right in front of the crossing. Soak in the atmosphere while you are there. There are some karaoke places you can go to around the area and also lots of dining options to choose from if you get hungry.

Overrated but still worth seeing. I had high hopes for the Shibuya crossing however it was nowhere near as busy as we thought. We actually walked past it a couple of times because we expected it to be much busier. Glad we saw it and experienced it though. Everyone said to go to the Starbucks near the street and watch the traffic however we could only see a take away Starbucks so that was annoying. Im sure during peak times it would be much better but very similar to most other pedestrian crossings around the Tokyo area. Still I'm glad we experienced it.
People everywhere!. The famous shibuya crossing. check it out from the train station or walk up to starbucks and you can get a cool picture

Synchronised chaos!. Went there on Sunday evening, not that packed. Went again Tuesday evening. That's when we experienced the 'scrambling'. Hundreds of people crossing from all corners towards all direction, at same time while all traffic from every direction stopped. Amazing. And it's normal! For the fun of it, we crossed few times from one junction to another. At night, it was livelier with lights and more people. There were many shops to spend your money on, which were still opened beyond their business hours!

Must see go at night. Thousands of shops and restaurants crawded with millions of pederastian build very impressive spot. Go at night after dark and enyoj spectacle of light and movement.Many restaurants around for food and drink after walk.Very recommended
Sea of Humanity. It is fun to see the people crossing at the same time and most especially from the second floor of Starbucks which is just across the street from the Hachiko Station.

Fascinating. Well renowned Shibuya crossing... Fascinating! Must see in Tokyo too. The place is busy with tourists.. tip... Go to Starbucks and sit above to have a better view... Don't forget to look for the statue! At night it is so wonderful to look at.. With the lights and people crossing... But not chaotic.. One thing about Japan I respect is how disciplined they are... Amidst the busy streets and bustling streets... It is very organized.... No jay walking! Specific sections for smokers... Awesome shopping district as well. It is fascinating to see Tokyo fashion!

Just f....amazing !!!!. As seen on movies !! When lights go green get your selfi-stick camera ready and cross along with another couple thousands people. Do it in all directions again and again. For better view go second floor of train station, Starbucks was close on renovations (june 2015) which has a nice view as well.
Go to Hachiko dog for a picture.

Walk fast and discipline by the traffic rules. This is quite an interesting place, to know how people in Japan who walk fast, and disciplined by the traffic rules. If you come here evenings, you can feel interesting, so many people who wanted to photograph him, that they can take a moment between the density of pedestrians crossing the road here. Besides the splendor shades famous shopping stores in Japan.

Lots of people. While this crossing isn't the hugest seen in Tokyo, the amount of people surpasses the others. There are soooo many people! It's interesting to see when it turns green for pedestrians how they just flood the place. Definately worth seeing and takes just a few minutes. Shibuya is a nice place in itself.
Not so much.... It is huge, it has lots of people. But... not so impressive for me. I went to Starbucks to see it from above, still nothing that impressive. Watch if you happen to pass by.

Really fun. Theres not much to say, its a huge crossover in Shibuya. If you go there and intent on crossing it with loads of people, go in the evening. We went there around 10 pm, there was lots of music, funny people and lots and lots of lights. It feels amazing to walk across with all those people, so just go there and do it, way more fun than sitting close by and watching people. And beware: there are people stopping right in front of you, right in the middle of the street to take a selfie, so don't run into them.
Amazing sight. It is just as you think and is an amazing sight there are so any people crossing it is just unbelievable a must in Tokyo
Must try. Its just one of those things that you have to try. Its fun specially if you do it with friends. I also recommend doing this at night.

This is the coolest thing to see.. I recommend watching first from one of the upper windows of the Shibuya Station. You get a different perspective. Then come to the street level, in front of the station and watch, it's so wild to see, when the light turns green, people crossing in all directions, including diagonally. It's all so organized and nobody jay walks! We watched this for five crossings taking lots of pictures and video.

One ogf Tokyo's highlights. I couldn't believe my eyes the first time I saw it, and whatched this strange phenomena about 8 times! Didn't get bored by it. Also saw it from Starbucks without doing the queue for a coffee...

Fun view from Starbucks. If you like people-watching, then grab a spot at the 2nd floor of Starbucks! When we were there, we saw a wedding photography happening (bride and groom crossed several times until the photographer finally gave a thumbs up!) And you'd see tourists try to make their shot at this landmark as creative as possible (jumpshots, stolen shots, etc). Very entertaining haha :)

As seen on TV. I know the pedestrian crossing from some box office movies like Resident Evil and Tokyo Drift. Honestly I would imagine that the crossing is very wide until I saw it by myself.
However, to experience the crowd by muself is very exciting. To see how the Japanese walk very fast and focused so they wouldn't bumped each other.

Crazy. This intersection is crazy. The light changes and herds of people are crossing in many directions. The first time I crossed several years ago it was a bit frightening, since I really didn't know where I was going. This year I crossed twice and it was amazing. People love to video as they cross, showing the crowds.

The amount of people passing through here, even on a weekend.... Just to say I've been here. Honestly, I saw several busy crossings on my way from Harajuku to Shibuya, but you definitely know when you are here. My one recommendation, if you're walking towards Shibuya Station, crossing the street--wave. Someone in the crowd will take a picture of you doing it. If you are heading in the same direction towards Shibuya Station, Hachiko is south, maybe 30-feet, pass the groups of people gathered to photograph the crossing, and you'll find a small 'waiting' area with a line of visitors taking photos with the statue.Be mindful, there are several entrances to the station to different train lines, so choose wisely. A lot of people were getting lost and confused, and trying to get out, and the train gates will close--so you'll have to see an attendant to have your card cleared. You definitely don't want to get trapped here during a rush-hour. If it's this busy on a Sunday, I can't imagine how bad it would be during working hours.For me, alone, it was not overwhelming. Yet, the rush of the crowd and be stressful, especially if you get lost or lose a friend. So make sure you really need to, and really want to come here. It is a huge contrast to the slower pace you find in other places, especially the parks and shrines.
Super fun. Lots of people crossing at the same time. It was great to take photos and videos. Super fun to watch people crossing too.

Nothing interesting. Humid in June. . Go during the night when the neon signboard lights are switched on. I am sure that it would be much more spectacular. I went during the day and it wasn't anything special except for people walking on zebra crossings, and it did not feel much of a "scramble" at all. However if you want a nice picture, you can go to the Starbucks coffee place nearby.

Visited Hatchiko Statue and Shibuya Scramble Crossing. Yes, it is very touristy and there is nothing wrong with that. We went mainly for Hatchiko Statue and since the scramble crossing is nearby we also went up at Starbucks to observe the massive crowds. Bonus for us since it was raining and we saw a bunch of pretty little umbrellas! We did both in less than half an hour and went to Mawashi Sushi Katsu (conveyor belt sushi) which was our main purpose going to Shibuya. I would highly recommend this place, it is located on the top floor of the mall.
fun fun fun. endless fun with the selfie stick and photos on the crossing , day or night, tip if you want a great view head up to the starbucks 2nd floor which overlooks the crossing

It is just thousands people crossing. too crowded...too touristy...after all, it is just a road crossing...the only different is it has multiple path and thousands people are crossing it at any given time...nonetheless, this place is great for shopping, eating and etc

Must see it.. You can take Hanzomon Line or Ginza Line to get there. The scramble crossing is near to the Shibuya station. The best pictures you do from Starbucks coffee. It is very nice at the night when looks like Times Square in New York.

A must see tourist thing. It is a classic tourist ting to do in Tokyo but still just do it and enjoy the virw and vibe this wonderfull city has..sit in Starbucks a just be amazed of the crowds and the disiplin they have...many places to eat and a lot to see..a must do
A must see tourist attraction. Everyone is every angle in the scramble crossing. But as soon as the lights turn green everyone steers clear. Amazing view at night!

Madness Scramble!. It is just like in the movies this crossing! When the light turns green thousands of people cross the run, never seen so many people! For the best view, go to Starbucks upstairs and enjoy the scramble
Shibuya madness. Shibuya 5 way crossing is a must do for a first time Tokyo visitor. People, people, noise, huge screen TVs, sublime madness.
Do the touristy thing, it's ok. Go to Shibuya for many reasons (food, love hotel, you name it) but do not leave until you get the touristy experience and photo of crossing at the scramble.

I loved it. You can take the Ginza line and get off at Shibuya station in the exit 5, when you arrive you will see a big crossing. It's super exciting to see a lot of people in the street.
Around the station you can also see the hachiko statue and a lot of nice stores.

many tourist love the spot. I pass by the junction for commutation often. The tourists from all of the world are coming with the selfie shooting cameras. It is like a Times Square in NY. I think the smoking section should be moved somewhere or buried in underground for the better landmark!

Otherwise known as the scramble crossing. So many people going in different directions. Its definitely a sight to see, and if you're down here for a bit of shopping, head to Starbucks on the first floor to get a great shot of this crossing as well as quick and well deserved coffee break.
Break the rules. Try crossing it without following the white lines its like counter flowing on the side waving left and right carefull not hitting anybody..
Be prepared for the onslaught. there looks like literally one million people all around crossing the street at the same time. They appear to intersect with ease in rhythmic fashion.

Get in there!. Step One: Go there on a Saturday night around dinnertimeStep Two: Take a look at the crossing from the train station. You'll see exactly what you're in forStep Three: Get on down there and experience all those people, all those lights, all that Tokyo ambience This was one of my favourite places in Tokyo. I ate, I shopped, I crossed many many times.

Busy busy pedestrain crossing. Shibuya pedestrain crossing is the busiest pedestrain crossing with thousands of people crossing at this junction.
Better to hold on tight to one another as everybody swamp across like bees.

remember where you are going. SEA of people!! crossing the street is really fun but make sure where you are heading or else you will lost your way. what an experience although it is just a crowded zebra crossing.

If you happen to be in the area..... If you happen to be in the Shibuya area, stop by to see it. A good spot to view this is the Starbucks in the Tsutsaya building, or the shopping area in the floors above the Shibuya train station. The crazy mass of people never ends. It is a good demonstration of big this city really is. However, if you are short on time, I wouldn't go out of my way to watch this.
An iconic gem . What a crazy place, we had a blast just walking across this truly global landmark. A must visit whilst in Tokyo. It's crazy how busy it is.

Take a selfie while you're in the middle of the intersection. This is probably the only intersection with 7 different pedestrian lanes crisscrossing each other. When the light turn greens for pedestrians, walk to the middle of the network of pedestrian lanes and just see the busy world of people go by.Another good spot to see the scramble is from the 2nd floor of nearby Starbucks.It makes you wonder where these people are going, the intersection never gets sleepy.

Very Busy Intersection, Fun to Watch. This is a great way to see what Tokyo is like. Go to the Starbucks and go to level 2. There you will have a great vantage point of the intersection. It's really fun to watch and you should do it if in Tokyo. At night it is very bright with all the neon signs on the buildings.
Just like in the movies. One word: awesome! Give you guys a handy tip. In one of the exits from Shibuya station, there are lockers to be rented for the day for 600 yen. Really handy.

Must do in Tokyo. A prominent landmark of Shibuya is the large intersection in front of the station's Hachiko Exit. The intersection is heavily decorated by neon advertisements and giant video screens and gets flooded by pedestrians each time the crossing light turns green, making it a popular photo and movie filming spot.

It's a happening place!. It's worthwhile to pay this place a visit. The pedestrians seem endless and it is interesting to just stand at a corner and watch things happening around you. Hachiko statue is just outside the Hachiko exit. There are lots of food stalls at the basement too. Across the street, the departmental stores are everywhere.

Sure it is an experience but.... Tou want to see Shibuya. Do some shopping and eating there. Have some fun. So you got off at Shopibuya station. You walk past Hachioji statue. Then you cross to the other side of the street with a thousand other people. Good! You made it across! Any busy and crowded city offers similar experience. Not sure if I would call it anything special.

Try to be part of this scramble at least once. Having read about this, we decided to go and visit/experience the scramble. Went there in the afternoon but maybe my expectation was too high but it wasnt what I had expected. Maybe because the people were disciplined and walked in a very coordinated and streamlined fashion, there was no bumps and shuffling. But still, it was a experience which I might do again if I am there.

Amazing!. we arrived on a friday night and as in every big city it was spectacular! Big city, bright neons and a huge number of people! And dressed to the nines! All the images you see of Japan multiplied by a thousand!! Look around, look up! Look sideways! See with all your senses! The side streets around the scramble had small eateries tempting you with smells that would make your tummy grumble! And ads in lights to make you thirst for drinks, shopwindows glowing bright with wares for sale! Visit this area and be AWED!

Crazy. It's crazy to watch hundreds, if not thousands of people crossing all at once, yet no one bumps into each other and it's somehow calm and orderly. Definitely worth a look and it's very close to the Hatchi statue.
like in the movies. just like you see in the movies, sit is starbucks and watch the crowd. also - ladies - shibuya 109 makes for awesome shopping

A Fun Experience!. The Shibuya Scramble (aka Shibuya Crossing) is a must-do when in Shibuya. It is really not as bad as it looks on TV or in YouTube videos. No matter how crowded and seemingly chaotic, you never bump into anyone! Amazing! Try filming a video of your walk across it...pretty cool experience! We've done it in 2014 and more recently, May 2015 :)

Like an Ant nest. As part of a group our guide took us to the busiest street crossing in Japan.Once the traffic lights change people go in every direction like a swarm of ants.It is very interesting to see so many people all going in different directions and all so polite.Our guide said about 2000 every time the lights change.

Interesting crossing - signifies Tokyo. Somehow this pedestrian crossing signifies Tokyo and hence it is not to miss if you are in Tokyo. It is a great cite from the first floor of Starbucks cafe nearby.It would be more fun on a busy day when the lights turn green and ppl from all the sides cross the street.
Fun. I had low expectations, but really enjoyed people watching from the starbucks second floor. We went on a Sunday afternoon and I was surprised how busy it was!

Fun to watch. To be honest, I wasnt as fascinated by the Shibuya crossing as others, this is because I live in Mumbai (the second largest city by population in world after Tokyo) and such crowds are common but it is an essential Tokyo experience.I have never seen people scramble in such an orderly fashion! The vibe has to be seen to be believed. Watching people cross from 3 different corners and ruch to get to their destinations is fun.Please try to get a seat on the first floor at Starbucks to get an awesome view. Cap off your visit by shopping at the 109 departmental store or many other options nearby.
A must see!. The hustle and bustle. A must see fun spot to take pics and video.Grab a coffee at Starbucks it is know for the best view advantage spot.
Crazy many people. Go here at night! There is almost 200 people walking over the crosswalk each green light. Must see in Tokyo!

Check it out! . I checked this out on a Sunday evening around nine and it was still quite busy. It is a super cool site to see, especially at night with all the mega screens lit up! If you're brave, walk the crosswalk and try to capture a picture using the time lapse setting. It makes for a pretty cool pic. I would highly recommend if in the area.
Oranized madness. I'd never seen a few thousand people cross the street at one time. Amazing! ...and, impossible to photograph.

Interesting. Hoardes of people mingling to cross roads as many as six as i remember.Looks like a stampede,swarm of heads but clears so smoothly and road is devoid of people in a few moments to be taken by vehicles again and so goes the cycle again. Best watched and photographed from height. Try and grab a balcony place in Starbucks overlooking the crossing and enjoy!

Not for the faint of heart!. Before trying this out,ask yourself a few questionsAre you claustrophobic?Do you love crowds?Do you want to shop in stores that charge too much for what you can find anywhere?Do you want to eat bad food?
Hustle but fun. One of the major point in Tokyo. Extremely busy with thousand of people walking around the street. You can find everything there. Good food and brand names you would like to buy.

Not sure what the fuss is about. Went here a few times but never dreamed it was a tourist mecca. I see lots of VG reviews, but to me it was pretty average. I've seen lots more interesting junctions, though this one does have good vibes.

Make the scramble . For those who have watched thus iconic scramble on screens, there's a draw to see it happen in real . Fast and furious fans, it's here. You could see it as a mere crossing or as a Time magazines must do. Large screens playing ads, pulsating and electric atmosphere. Find yourself a place at Starbucks one floor above, just like everybody else. It's apparently one of the world's busiest Starbucks. Watch the lights change and the sea of humanity cross. A nice quote which says,: it's what Tokyo does best when it's not trying. Make the scramble. Next time you see it on screen you can break into a smile.

Could be one of the busiest intersections ...... Could rate as one of the busiest pedestrian intersections in the world. Just outside the Shibuya railway station, when the traffic lights stops all vehicular traffic at this intersection of five (or more) roads converging there is just a "sea" of people crossing here. A good birds eye view is from the first or second floors of Starbucks in a building overlooking this intersection.

A sight to see!. First of all, secure a spot in the starbucks on the second floor above the crossing. So far, that is the best place to view the crossing...GO EARLY.around 5pm is the busiest scramble of people. It happens quick so be sure to be ready.Its a sight to see indeed.

Very inyetesting. These crossroads are very interesting once you get out of metro station of Shibuya. One must be alert as soon as the stop light turns green. On weekends there hundreds crossing the pedestrian so be fast enough to go to the other end of the road.

Get a seat at the starbucks to watch the show. Coming out of the train station you are amazed with the thousands of people rushing to cross the street simultaneously from all directions and then, just as suddenly as the intersection is full, it suddenly empties and the cars drive through. Quite an orchestrated event. I recommend day time but anytime is good.

Recommended Weekends & Evenings. Stayed at an apartment not too far from here for around a week and had to cross this junction almost daily to the JR station.It's the weekend human traffic that makes this an experience and worthwhile watching - or having a video keepsake.It's not so crowded during weekdays - but if weekdays are all you have I found more human traffic during the evenings.You can also have meals around this area. Lots of nice reasonably priced eateries around the area.An interesting sight! People watching can be a laugh!
Just as heard!. the scramble pedestrian is so famous in the world and it was just as imagined. Thousands of people crossing the street to & fro at any hour of the day.

Best way to cross a street. At the exit of the Shibuya Metro Station at an intersection of 5 large streets, you are able to cross all of the streets in any direction as all walk lights go on at all corners at the same time.
All the people!. Not for the faint of heart. Metro stop close by allows you to watch first before descending into the chaos. And so many small shops and eats close by.
Chaos. Controlled chaos, brilliant. We stood by the side of the road for at least 3 turns of the traffic lights, just watching!

Nothing Special. Ok, maybe it was just me. But this really is nothing special. Most cities across the world have a place like this. This one was far less organized, upscale, or special than others (think Piccadilly in London or, of course, Times Square). Heck China had better "iconic" spots than this in their major cities. Fine if you are here for other reasons, but I would not make a special trip.

An iconic spot. This is a tough one -- how do you rate an intersection? But if you are visiting Japan and in the Tokyo area, then a visit to this iconic place will not be too difficult, as you will probably be in the neighborhood anyway. Lots of shopping. Lots of people. Lots of English. We visited the Apple store here because our cell phone contract is almost up. Dentistry, surgery, telecom contracts -- top 3 important times to speak your own language! You have probably seen this spot in the movies, so you can put a check in the "familiar Japan" column. But if you are the type of person who can easily visit New York City and not go to Times Square, then you could give this a miss too. And if you don't like severe crowds, then definitely avoid.

Great place to people watch. The scramble was smaller than we had thought the crowds spectacular nonetheless. We enjoyed the morning rush from the Starbucks cafe at the intersection. Had the fun of watching what looked like some amateur film makers filming some guy doing random things like dancing during the scramble and continuous takes walking back and fourth looking around like a stunned tourist to the unaware of those walking past lol.
No wow factor, but still go. This wasn't exactly awe-inducing but I guess this is a crossing that you must witness when in Tokyo. You can't miss it if you go to Shibuya anyway so you may aswell

Go on a busy time to enjoy the experience. If you are visiting Tokyo and wants to enjoy the atmosphere of this busy crossing, go during rush hour or weekends when people go out and try to cross in a straight direction. The challenge will be to cross it in a straight line.
Pretty cool.. When you're at Shibuya, you're bound to see this pedestrian crossing. Join in the fun and cross. You'll see many other tourists taking pictures and videos haha.

Famous junction for high traffic human. Always watch it in the movie. We never expect to see it in real life!! So surprised that many people walk together at the same time. At night time, it is getting increase. Too many people!

LOTS of people.. I went around 10ish, and it was still going on.I live in New Orleans, so when the lights turn green it is like Mardi Gras every 10 minutes.Way to many people.And not only at the crossing.Wherever you go are lots of people in this area. When I was there most shops where closed, I cant imagine how it will be at peak hour.Its not really what I expected shopping wise.All high end stores for teens, so I didn't stay long.But lots of lights and a fun experiences.

turist. 1000 persons can cross the pedestrian place at the same time! it was raining the day we were there. Lovely to see all the umbrellas crossing. Nearby is shoppingcenter 109 in a skyskraber only for women. Many teenagers in funny clothes. Most for Young women. Nearby is also a shoppingcenter 109 for men , but much smaller!
Got to be seen. Amazing to see so many people cross at the same time - and no one bumps into each other. What with all the video screens and neon advertisements around too.

Very little sport with just people. We went late morning outside the peak rush hour. Not quite as busy but in general it's civilized and has just people. We have traveled and lived in SE Asia and there are far more challenging places to watch with all manner of humanity, animals, vehicles and road hazards. More than a few people "crossing" were tourists getting selfies. If you are in the area drop in and check the box but don't plan anything special to do this.

The famous inter section. I didnt notice that I was sitting on a seat with a view which was used in the movie : lost in translation. Hatchiko statue is nearby this place. Some fashion outlets are also available.

People people everywhere. Every 2 minutes thousands of people cross this famous intersection. My advice is to pick a direction and keep walking! Reward yourself with a caffeine injection at the Starbucks above the crossing and watch the scramble from above.

Loved it. Great city!
Loved walking across this iconic scene and visiting the malls, 109 etc.
The buildings, the noise, the shops, the smells, sights and sounds... the amazing people of Japan... what a fantastic city!
DO IT!
Sea of human!. Amazing,endless humans crowda the place in no time.alo lot activity done there too i.e. mini concert, street performance etc.must visit!

As cool as it looks on tv!. Yep it's official, we loved it! The crossing on first sight isn't as big as I thought it would be but depending on the time you visit it you will get a different experience.During the daytime it wasn't too busy but on Friday night i really understood how crazy it can be. There were people EVERYWHERE crossing from every direction. It's so fun just to watch and see. No one ever runs into each other which seems surprising.As everyone has mentioned, head into the Starbucks and go upstairs to see the view from above. Definitely worth it.

spectacular. i've seen this in many travel magazines before and i was mesmerized while taking our souvenir photo there! we went there daytime and i hope on my next visit to have a nightime photo and experience the spectacular nightlife of Shibuya! this deserves another visit! hopefully sooner!

Must visit. Love the scramble. Right outside of Shibuya Station, can't miss it. Fun to walk across back and forth a couple times to get a good photo. People absolutely everywhere in every direction. Great shopping around this area as well, and lots of cool things to see!

The critical mass. It must to see someone from city like Budapest. I have never saw that many people crossing in 2 minutes. It is amazing, it is good to take a time-lapse video here. Probably the best place is the Starbucks.
Madness. We crossed during Golden Week so a lot quieter than normal. But amazing how so many people can cross without incident. Go to the second story of Starbucks to get a good view.

Never had so much fun crossing a road. This was great - never have I had so much fun crossing a road. People were everywhere and seemed on point at the same time. I think I crossed seven times just because I could.

Great experience. When you come from a small country like I do, I am from the Netherlands. You can at this crossing feel how it is like to live in a city of more than 38 million of people! Of course the busy neighborhood, the loud wall screens with music and the surrounding stores make the experience complete:-)I made a little movie to share with friends at home. The nice thing about Tokyo is that people respect the traffic light rules, which makes it possible that the traffic stays in a nice flow. There is no chaos in Tokyo anywhere, also the metro is busy but also very well organized and people are respectful and structured.

Fun , Fun , Fun !. It was a fun-filled moment ,crazy like fun when you join the crowd crossing the streets like busy ants parading in a scrambling fashion!watching the whole pedestrian crossing/ scrambling from the Second floor of the train station is more fascinating !

People people. The main attraction is the people. They are very fashionable. They seem to be very conscious of their surroundings.
The crossing is also nice to look at at night.

People everywhere. There's just so many people!
It's amazing to watch the crowds cross the street in this popular and busy area. Worth to experience it and be part of the crowd as well.

Shibuya mad crossing .. . If you traveling to tokyo , you just can't miss this sight. Stand here anytime of the day or night, at every green signal , you would see hundreds of pedestrians crossing from all directions. The place is very lively and around this place there are plenty of restaurants & cafés serving different cuisines and great coffees. I would generally sit down in one of the cafe around, order my coffee and see this spectacular sight for sometime.
Go visit at night time. My kids wanted to see this scramble because of Fast and Furious franchise. Interesting pedestrian and fun to cross with all the different directions. Uniquely Japanese.

A must seen place in Tokyo. As a tourist, you must see the place, at least once. It was amazing to see so many people walked at the zebra cross at the same time. We took some picture from Shibuya 109 to got a better angle.

The most fun you'll ever have just crossing the street. We visited the crossing at night, which I would definitely recommend. It's a pretty cool experience to get swept up in the sea of people moving in every direction through the intersection. And being immersed in the lights, sounds, and energetic atmosphere of Shibuya after dark makes the experience that much more awesome.

Great to watch this crazy crossing. Just do it. Shibuya isn't accessible by JR and several subway lines. Besides the people watching, there are also many good restaurants and some good shopping for every budget and taste.

Visit at night!. Go there at night and just enjoy the vibe! Cross a few times and see all the crazy things people do on the crossing! The neon lights are also awesome and the whole area has loads of shops and good restaurants for all tastes. Your best vantage point is Starbucks, but you'd have to withstand long queues. Your other option is the tunnel on the third and fourth floors of Shibuya JR station.

Must see if you're a tourist. If you're visiting Tokyo, you have to come here just to see it one time. Its right outside Shibuya station. There are a ton of people crossing this intersection. Head up to 2nd level Starbucks to get a nice view. I recorded a time lapse video and I noticed alot of ppl try to cross when the light already turns red, and then they almost get hit by the cars.
Got to see it. Go at night...much more spectacular. Fun times. Lots of shops and food in area too. Just explore ...so many different things to see

Crazy crazy crossing - best views @ Starbucks. This place is truly buzzing. Quieter (yet still plenty of people crossing) in the mornings, but by lunch time and onwards, you can't believe how many people make this crossing when the pedestrian lights turn green. The best views are by far the Starbucks which you will notice when you leave the Station area. Highly recommend heading to the second level of Starbucks for the best views.

Fun to experience. I feel like this is one of those quintessential tourist things you have to do when you visit Tokyo for the first time. Its not overwhelming but its just so Tokyo that you have to be a part of it at least once.Besides, its so close to great shopping and small eateries around hidden walkways, and of course Hachiko the loyal dog. I stayed at a hotel above the scramble so I saw it day and night in sun and rain and I found it very beautiful.

Didn't live up to the hype. Glad it was just outside the train station and not an effort to get to. Sure there are lots of people crossing but no more than many busy intersections I've experienced. Try to get an aerial photo from one of the surrounding buildings. At least in Vietnam you cross dodging the vehicles.

Fun crosswalk . It's an easy and interesting walk when you visit Shibuya. Many people climbed to the second floor of Starbuck nearby to take picture and see the move. I went to the bookstore nearby and went upstairs. The view was the same and it's free!

Great for people watching!. I came here at night and was amazed at the sheer amount of people crossing the road from all directions. With the backlight of the neon signs, it really is something you need to see and experience yourself. For a birds eye view and a great people watching session, go grab a drink from Starbucks and fight for a window seat. Sure, it might be Starbucks, but they have the best view of the crossing!

You don't want to miss this. You want to be in the scramble, and then you want to go the the Starbucks second floor area so you can watch it. Just seeing how the people and cars and bikes interact is worth the price of the latte

Christmas in Japan!. My wife and I went to Shibuya to shop and let me tell you that it was an eye opener. The amount of people around these streets is incredible and a must visit. The lights, the crowds and the atmosphere makes these intersections memorable. When visiting Tokyo this is a must visit,

Great place to people watch!. A not to be missed for when in Tokyo! It is crazy to see everyone crossing at once. Even more fun when you cross with everyone! Better pics too! But if you are taking pics take them from by the bicycles that are parked right by the crossing out of the way right next to the street! Or go into starbucks and get a good window seat to watch!
The number of people takes your breath away. Impressive at night or day, it is a must see in Tokyo. The big screens and bright lights makes it really beautiful at night.

Don't miss if visiting Tokyo. Great shopping area, much more than just absorbing the view at night or crossing the busy intersection. I have two teens, our daughter loved the store Shibuya 109, it has floors and floors of trendy and exciting clothing.

Organized chaos. Seeing this crossing many times on TV, it was my wish to feel it and be part of it. Just got outside the Shibuya metro (Hatchiko exit), and I was in a sea of people. I stood on the sidewalk by the crossing watching several traffic light changes, it's incredible.Huge crowds stay still on all sides of the crossing when it's red. The moment the pedestrian green turns, a people flood starts in all directions.Be there at night when every neon is lit up , specially weekend nights (I was on Saturday) to catch up the best.
Awesome!. Did it during the day and it was good and then went back at night on a Saturday night....AWESOME! Soooo many people! It was like Times Sq on steroids lol

Exciting. This was a fun stop for us. We came to Tokyo to see the hustle and bustle so this was a must! We hopped on the train one stop away from Shibuya at Ebisu and were packed in tight. We crossed at the busy intersection twice and our 2 year old was speechless just looking at all the people and lights. There was a lot going on here comparable to Times Square in NYC. We ended up having dinner nearby. It was easy to get to and safe to handle with a toddler.

A sight to see!. Busy Tokyo! At this crossroads, people come from all directions and go off into all directions as well, but all in cadence, men mostly wearing black suits or coats and women in beige coats, without much noise and no one getting caught up in some mad scramble, as if it's all rehearsed and orchestrated, yet it's not! The best view is from the 2nd floor of Starbucks in one building directly across the train station exit. Good luck in getting a seat though.

A Japanese thing. So crowded yet so organized... That's the impression that I have from this intersection. You can see how the Japanese is a very organized society. Take picture from Starbucks and you'll have a great view for this beautiful mess..

Hectic crossing. Wait and wait a little longer on the first floor of Starbucks to have a good view of the busiest crossing in the world. With a cup of coffee it is enjoyable but after 5 times you have seen it all. Be sure to cross a few times yourself. A good combination is Meiji Shrine in the morning, have a look at Takeshita Dori, probably one of the busiest streets in the world and Shibuya Crossing in the afternoon and evening. On a Saturday!

Lots of lights!. Does it say something about a City if a Road crossing is a main Tourist attraction?My friend spent 3 hours taking photos.I just enjoyed the atmosphere of young Japanese being young & the Shimmering lights- like nowhere else I've been.Peaceful & clean, even on a Sat night!

A Must Do. Go after dark. The lights and billboards add to the experience. There are masses people everywhere, crossing in all directions. Lots of cameras, phones, videos and selfie sticks. We had to cross four times. It just makes a person smile☺️.
