TOKYO DRIFT. Shibuya is the best and you're obviously going to come across the scramble if you're there! When you walk out of Shibuya station to cross over to the 109 or just the main part of Shibuya you gotta cross. If you find a window at the station you can watch it all unfold as well. The Starbucks above the crossing is a good place to look as well. Also if you're a fan of Fast and the Furious - Tokyo Drift it's where they shot one of the races and you'll no doubt see or hear a tuner car.

Exactly what you expect!. The scramble is definitely an experience but not something to seek out without a plan for the rest of Shibuya! It's exactly as you think it will be - masses of people crossing the street at the same time with too many looking at their phones and not paying enough attention. My husband and I definitely were happy to have done it, but enjoyed strolling the rest of Shibuya before a nice walk over to Harajuku even better.

Exciting!. Gets very busy at night after 8pm. Tourists busy capturing video.
Try taking video on the opposite side of Seibu shopping complex where there are more people.
It is very very near to Yamanote exit Shibuya station. Or if you are exiting at Hachiko Exit, take exit which is opposite of Tokyu Plaza (easily seen after exiting Hachiko exit)

Lots of people, noisy, lights, billboards. Unfortunately it was raining and very cold on the day we finally made it here, so we in a great frame of mind for "people watching".Yep, there's a lot of people crossing the road - whoopty-do - sorry I know that's sarcastic, but so what.We walked across the road a couple of times and left. It just wasn't that interesting.
Crazy!. The Shibuya Scramble was definitely exciting. There were so many people coming from every direction! This scramble is known all over the world!
Interesting . Very investing to see soo many people. Great place to walk. Lots of stores and things to do. Great food places to visit. A must see are of Tokyo.

EPIC. You can certainly see Tokyo at its largest and most hectic crossing - the view from inside the station as well as the starbucks is pretty good. But it is best experienced in person on the road. The area has loads to offer and lots of shops. Don't miss the worlds most loyal dog statue.

a real scramble!. It was nice to watch people cross the street when we were up at the Shibuya Station before going down to the street level. My kids felt the energy of the people walking fast and going their on way. It was a nice experience espcailly as it is known as the busiest street in the world.

Organized chaos perfected. Pedestrian scrambles originated in North America in the 40's and are most commonly used in Japan. During my visit I came to realize that it is us (tourists) who interrupt the natural flow of traffic as locals naturally flow around each other to reach their destination. We are the one's who walk to the middle and stop for pictures or video's, I preferred the high ground or a selfie stick giving you a better vantage to the shear volume of people.

Watch from a high place. It's basically a place with a lot of people. I had some free time at night and just stood by the road and watch people crossing (and even decided to join them crossing the road just for fun). If you have very limited time in Tokyo, maybe you can just skip this. But if you love people-watching, you have to do this. I've read that it's more fun to watch this from the Starbucks near the crossing.

Love the energy and buzz!. Love the energy and buzz of this place!Go to Starbucks for vantage point view of the crossing. Else stay at the ground level to feel the buzz and absorb the energy of this place!Kind of like being in a futuristic movie!

You will never be bored at Shibuya. There are two, ok three things Shibuya is famous for. First is the pedestrian scramble, where seven pedestrian crossings interchange on one street. Imagine hundreds of people crossing the street from all directions at the same time - a very interesting sight to see. Second, is the hachiko monument. A statue dedicated to Hachiko, a loyal dog who waited for his Master because he did not know that his Master has already died. His Master worked at the train station and that is why his monument is just the opposite outside of the train station. He died a few years after while waiting for his Master to come home. He refused to serve anyone. This place now serves as a waiting area for friends who have set appointments or to meet.Third, is of course, a giant shopping arena where all the brands are located. You will never be bored at Shibuya.

Its the same as the lau pa sat crossing in Singapore :). We visited anyway to find out what the fuss is all about as 8 thought its the same as the lau pa sat - cross street crossing in Singapore :). But yeah, I was with my wheelchair bound mom and we crossed without any fuss :)

A Must Check-in Place When Visiting Tokyo. Come in the evening so you'd get to see the chaos in two different settings. Try crossing it and you'll be amazed, how no body is bumping into everyone. And it'll be even more amazing when you're standing right in the middle of the crossing, having hundreds of people brisk walk through you as if you had a time machine and you clicked fast forward. But don't stay for too long, you'll still have to make it to the other side. :)

A sight not to be mizz. Sight of people at d crossing seems like ants walking in all direction. When u r in it, u scramble to get to d actual direction and rush when u start to see d light going red. Fun and interesting sight to be in.

Fun at night . It's like the time square in NYC but a bit smaller. It's fun to see all the people walking at the same time with different directions. TipThere a Starbucks and on the second floor you can get a pretty good view of the action.

don't get lost. HUGE HUGE crowd all crossing the roads from all direction. LOLand if you want to do some people watching, there's a starbucks on the 2nd floor of 1 of the building that overlooks this crossing. you can't miss this

Hit and miss. I've been here twice, the first time it was just like all the pictures and videos. Hundreds if not thousands of people crossing. I cant remember what time of day but not rush hour. The second time, on a weekday at morning rush hour it was almost totally empty. We sat in Starbucks for ages looking down on the crossing, but...
A must see. A must see...best to have a guide show you where to stand to get the best view from a higher floor on the intersection. Unbelievable.

One of the "Must See" in Tokyo. Have you seen "Tokyo Drift" the movie one of the series "Wild Speed Max"?This was the place where The cars were chasing and drifting around. Very cool.It's a sleepless area in Tokyo. Shibuya is currently under renovation toward Tokyo Olympics 2020. So you must see it before it's finished. Don't miss it.

Must walk on the World's busiest pedestrian crossing. Everything about this pedestrian crossing gives one an electrifying exp. When you view it from the Shibuya Metro station, one gets a full view of the crossing and the surrounding neon lit up buildings. You will be amazed to see the sheer number of people crowding at the signal and waiting for the green light. And when it goes green, its a fantastic sight to watch people crossing each other, racing, heading diagonal etc....  The energy and excitement to cross across this pedestrian crossing is to be experienced first hand. Don't miss Hachiko at the corner of Shibuya station.
Fun to be amongst the chaos. Expected it to be bigger but it was fun to cross a road in any direction and push through the sea of people

Worth being part of the crowd crossing the street!. Amazying the amount of people that can cross the street in all directions whenever the traffic lights go green! Also, surprising how noisy it is the zone for all the TV screens of the different buildings, which projecting different adds/concerts..
Amazing to watch the crossing. It was so fun to watch the crossing! Sooo many people!!! Definitely a must-do when you're near Tokyo :) (and then go nuts at shopping in nearby malls and shops!)

Fun!!!!. I love watching people in every movement both in big city and countryside, well it's one of the way to learn and understand different culture, and this is one of my favorite place to watch. All I did was just sitting at the second floor at Starbucks and looking down on the scramble cross. It took me an hour for just watching people crossing the street at this venue!! It's really entertain when the junction fulled of hundreds people. I love it, it's really fun and relax. You guys should go too!!! Tips : Don't go there too early as there are not many people on the street and it won't look so scramble.

do it!. Shibuya is a great area of Tokyo and is where its at! the crossing moves heaps of people at once from all different directions its cool to see! once the lights change try running into the middle and get a photo before the people close in on you!

Yes, you should go. . I admit, I only went because so many people said it was a must-see. I agree. After experiencing it from street level, we went up into a nearby building to see it from a third floor. Makes for great videos. It's just fun. The area is nice for the stores and good, too.

Total chaos! Worth a visit!. At the blink of signal crowd go crazy and roads are filled up with hundreds of people coming and going in every direction. And as soon the signal turns red, there's no single person on the road. Everything happens very efficiently, over and over again!
Mad scramble to cross road!. Just crazy to see so many people cross this busy junction from all directions, it's a photo/video opportunity.

Must go for taking standard photo.. My girlfriend and I went there and took some photo for pedestrians crossing this amazing the roads.It is very very crowded with many peoples to cross the roads in muti directions. At the time of our visit in 200X, the techonlogy is not good that we cant have good camera. We just had simple digital camera to take some memorial photos. Now, we can take nice photos with special effect if we go there again in future.
Better than Disneyland. Ha. No visit to Tokyo is complete without doing the Shibuya pedestrian scramble. Hilarious fun the first time, the second time and the third time!!!!! Just do it
Must see! Nothing like it!. This was so much fun to watch from the second floor of the Starbucks. Take a time lapse video and share with your friends and they will be in awe.

Shibuya!. It is definitely worth venturing to Shibuya if you are in Tokyo. It's action-packed with shopping, food, and fun. Get a picture with the Hachiko statue and learn his story. Be sure to check out the shops, always remembering to take a detour to the basement food markets. A daytime visit is incredible. A night visit is surreal!
Very entertaining!. First visit was around 9-10 am and it wasn't crowded. A lot livelier and crazy, entertaining in the afternoon and at night.
Mad Mad Mad. Well it does like it says on the tin. Best vantage point is Starbucks Coffee House, good shopping around there.

Out of control!. Pedestrian scramble, scrambled eggs, whatever you want to call it, this intersection is out of control! Go thru back and forth on a Friday or Saturday night and see if you can count how many interesting things take place in the street before the pedestrian crosswalk expires. Kisses, engagements, full blown wedding party photos, we saw it all. Times Square of Tokyo lies in this massive intersection of cultural activity!

Interesting to see and fun!. You can see the crossing from the window of the subway system and that is honestly where we took our best pictures from. After observing for several minutes, we decided it was time to give the crossing a go ourselves. It was a little chaotic, but certainly fun! We crossed to the Starbucks to see if we could get better pictures, as we heard this is the place to go. Honestly, I was more impressed with our pictures from the subway station. Overall, a very fun experience.

Lost In Translation. If you watch Lost in Translation, you should not miss this place at all. This is the place where at the end of the movie the couple met for the last time in this famous scene. When the lights turn green for the pedestrians, 500 hundred people cross the street to all destinations. Find a high spot nearby and take the picture.

Sheer Madness - Fun to Watch. It's just like in the pictures - the signals blink, the crowds go crazy, and there is almost an electric buzz here. I was here mid afternoon on a weekday and it was still insane - hundreds of people crossing in all sorts of directions. It's definitely fun to watch, and hopefully cross too just for the heck of it!
As crazy as you see on videos. There wasnt a time where this crossing was not busy. Night time after work peak the crossing fills up quickly and you do follow the crowd to cross to the other side

Crazy crossing. We went on a Friday night & followed throngs of pedestrians crossing the road - some walking with purpose, others having their own historical pedestrian scramble moment, others making attempts to try and stand out from the crowd. Do it- it's fun. Tick it off the list. Lots of shopping to be done in this area too. Shibuya is buzzing with energy.

SHIBUYA SHUFFLE AT RUSH HOUR. Ya gotta do the Shibuya shuffle at least once in your life. Somehow, you all line up facing each other, coming from every direction, and when the light turns green, you (and everyone else) dashes into the street, somehow missing each other (front, rear, left, right, out of nowhere) . . . yeah, been there, done that.

Madness, sheer, unadulterated madness.. So many people on five crossings simultaneously, but it works. You have to experience it. No pushing, no shoving, everyone just crosses the road. Mind your eyes if it raining, as all Tokyo residents carry an umbrella!

Shows just how many folks are in Tokyo.. Our guide managed to time it just right and we were the first car stopped at the light. It looked fairly ordinary until the lights changed and the human masses came on! For unknown reasons this is a really interesting spot for people watching -- just people but the patterns, colors, movement and STOPPING exactly on time was a wonderful show.

Must be Seen. We went on a sunday night and it was pretty busy although I think it probably wasn't the busiest time. We kept wondering where do all these people come from. We had dinner at L'Occitaine, overlooking the intersection (opposite side to starbucks) it's above a body store of the same name. Very cool to witness.

Overrated. We didn't recognise it as the much talked about Pedestrian Scramble, and instead went pass it a couple of times trying to look for the "real" Pedestrian Scramble. The next night we met up with our friend who had relocated to Japan for the past decade and he laughed, told us that "this" was the overrated pedestrian scramble. Nothing fascinating. During the day and evening, there wasn't much people. But wait till the final train, the roads will be crowded. The last few trains are more entertaining to watch (and experience being sardines in a train/ fun getting push and pushing back people) than the scramble.
Human Bee Hive. Experience it on the street in front of Shibuya train station or on the second level at Starbucks. Not to be missed!

The Tokyo that we see in Movies!. Shibuya Crossing is a well known landmark in central Tokyo which has been featured in numerous movies and documentaries about Tokyo. It is a junction where many major roads meet at a traffic intersection that is surrounded by buildings with neon billboards and signs, just off Shibuya train station. This area is known for its shopping with many department stores and large well known clothing and electronic franchises. It is very popular with Japanese youth and a good place to people watch. Because of the young demographic it attracts, you will often see large trucks with bearing billboards for buy and girl bands with music blaring driving by. there are several ways and perspectives in which to experience the crossing. The first is to actually cross and experience what it is like being part of the throng of people trying to get from one side of the intersection to the other- and be astounded by just how orderly it is! Another way is to grab a coffee at Starbucks which overlooks the crossing and sit there and watch from above. A third way is to go to the above ground crossway that takes you from the main entrance of Shibuya station to the main department stores across the road and take pictures from above.When at the crossing, take the time to check out nearby Shibuya 109 fashion house for young women which showcases various Japanese fashion subcultures and can be quite an experience. It is also right next to the famous statue of Hachiko- the loyal dog who waited for his master each day at the station even after his Master's death.

Nice Experience. I practically crossed this intersection every day to get to the station. I still can't believe how many people cross this street every day - like where do all these people come from? lol. A nice view would probably to go on a higher vantage point. There's a starbucks near the crossroad so you can go there and view the crossing from the top.

Go once. You've seen it on television and in print. A massive flow of people crossing in different directions right in front of Shibuya Station. Go once and get it over with. Say you've done it and let it be. In the end, it's just a seriously crowded intersection with shops and billboards all around.

Crazy. If you want to experience the crazy side of Japan, what better place to start than here. Insane. A whole bunch of people (up to 1000) descend on the crossing from nowhere and becomes a mad scramble to the finish.

Craziest Crossing Ever!. Wow. Coming from the airport and arriving at Shibuya, this was one of the first impressions we got of Japan. And i gotta say, I can't think of many more impressing first impressions ;) Sometimes there are a few thousand people crossing the street at one single green phase. It's just crazy!

Order in chaos. When in Tokyo this crossing is a must see...preferably in the evening it is coming alive.It is just a crossing and nothing more to it than that. But is is a structured chaos, so many people crossing at once with a background as if on Times Square.Once pedestrian lights turn red, it suddanly becomes completely empty for the cars to cross.

Worth A Look See. A must see on our recent trip to Tokyo. Caught the Metro to Tokyo Station. Enjoyed the view of this fascinating intersection from Star Bucks opposite the Station. You can sit comfortably for ages people watching and marveling at the "Pedestrian Scramble". The ultimate example of respect for the rules!

Iconic, Must-See!. Easy to access. Simply travel to Shibuya on the JR or Metro line and take the Hachiko exit. You can't miss it! Best to visit at night so you can enjoy the crossing and see all the neon lights. Also great to see when it's raining, as when everyone uses umbrellas it makes for a pretty cool photo op. You can take some great pictures from Starbucks, however be prepared to wait for a long time for a good seat by the window as many people spend a long time taking pictures.

So much fun to cross on a Saturday night. Crossing the street on a Saturday night is fun to do and fun to videotape. It's a tsunami of people crossing from 5 different starting points, and it's fun to be part of the chaos.

Busiest crossroad in the world. Fun program for free. Just take the subway to Shibuya station, follow the huge colorful adds and you'll find this impossibly huge but organized crossroad. There is like 6 streets that cross at the same point, and all signals close at the same point, so hundreds or thousands of people cross in all directions simultaneously. Hint: there is a Starbucks right in front of it, so you can grab some coffee, get a seat at the second floor and make a video of the craziness.

Best iconic place for Tokyo urban life. Nowhere can be used to compare with Shibuya as the best place for Tokyo urban life as this. The scramble is famous for its, well, crowdedness, neon light, noises from Jpop songs, Hachiko...
Amazing. Go out to Shibuya to see this amazing mass of humanity....go up to the second floor of Starbucks to get a nice view of the whole event....every traffic light change.

Organised chaos. You have to be here to experience this pedestrian phenomenon . Best place to view apart from the crossing itself is at Starbucks on the first floor.As crazy as it is , it all flows well and a great experience.
InterestIng. not sure. This worth going out your way to see, lots of people crossing a road? But if you do then go upstairs in Starbucks to see it from above!
Mad, mad, mad but great fun. This is the best place to people watch. Such crowd, such madness, but so much fun. Cool. Watch the Shibuya crossing from the walkway.
Felt the rush. Crossed a few times to finally satisfied with last photo taken. Felt the rush from people passing by you. You can always get different photo/feel from different section . Amazing.

Very cool. We stayed right here in the area Shibuya and saw this at all times of the day try to come early between 7:30-8 am (rush hour) or 5pm-6:30 pm or on a Saturday to get the full effect of seeing people scramble across in different directions . Shows just how busy and populated Tokyo is

Good place for people watching!. Shibuya is full of energy and life. A fab place for people watching all day if you can grab yourself one of those window seats at a cafe over looking the famous crossing. These seats are hard to come by so be prepared to wait!Makes a good photo opportunity as well both on sunny and rainy days, morning or night. Sometimes there would be baskers in the street and I even saw someone dressed up as super Mario running round the crossing to get a photo in that signature jumpsuit and jumping pose.

Crazy fun place!. Definitely a must in Tokyo as this is featured in movies etc. Just observe the atmosphere and then shop or dine and you can't go wrong! Walking across and taking an "inside view" of the crossing is a must. Look for a good vantage point from one of the many restaurants surrounding the crossing to observe the comings and goings.

A very unique Tokyo experience in Shibuya. I never thought crossing the street would be so exhilarating. Even on a Monday night, this place is lively. You'll have more than enough time to walk, enjoy the surroundings, enjoy the lights and take pictures in the middle of the intersection. It's like Times Square but in Japan. It's best to experience at night. Go for it!
Epic place at night. Make sure you go at night so you can see all the lights, just like off the movies!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Hectic but accessible. We went to the crossing to pass an hour and take a few photos & it's definitely worth doing for that!As another reviewer mentioned, it's quintessentially Tokyo and one of the things we think of when we think back to our time there. The metro is right next to it too, although plenty of other people have the same idea!

Yeayy I finally crossed it!. Since I was little, in manga, anime, dorama, documenter, I always see this crossing with 500-1000 people crossing together. Finally, I crossed it! Wow it just like what I imagined. I make photos and video with 101 background and people crossing. If you have time, go shopping around!

Shibuya Scramble - Yet Another MUST-SEE in Tokyo. The “Shibuya Scramble” is yet another MUST-SEE in Tokyo. It's as quintessentially Tokyo as it gets! Find a window-side seat at the very prominent Starbucks up on the 2nd level. While you sip your latte, you'll have a ringside seat overlooking all of the action.Every 4 mins, when the walk light turns green, READY, SET, GO, … up to ONE THOUSAND people simultaneously, smoothly, politely, effortlessly surge out onto 7 interlocking crosswalks, miraculously never coming close to running into anyone else (Tokyo-ites have built-in GPS + radar which keeps them from ever colliding with anyone else) … the human melange is a 1-minute intricate ballet of 1,000 dancers and POOF! … the crosswalks clear and the cars start streaking through the intersection of 5 different streets once again … 4 mins later, hit the replay button and another 1,000 folks have materialized to re-enact the ballet once more.All of this is surrounded by a New York Times Square-esque galaxy of neon, the dozens of mega-jumbo-trons all talking to you in very polite but loud, insistent Japanese to BUY SOMETHING! A cityscape like “Blade Runner”, without the buzz-kill dystopian part. Please see my video clips at the very end of the photos section for this attraction. ENJOY!Absolute breeze to get to ... just pop out of the Hachiko exit at Shibuya Station on the JR Yamanote line. You'll get to "scramble" yourself as you cross diagonally away from the JR Station to get to the Starbucks ... just keep walking in a straight-line without making eye contact and you'll miraculously not run into anyone ;-)

Nothing to write home about. I went to this crossing twice during my time in Tokyo and I honestly didn't find it that impressive. It's just a large all-direction crosswalk. Big groups gather, the light changes, and it's all over in under 2 minutes. It can be dangerous though if you don't know where you're going. If you're going to see it, I suggest using the crossing bridge near the JR station or the Tokyu shopping centre to get a view from higher up. The street view isn't very good.

Get a good view! . This is definitely something cool to see, but if you really want a good view, try to get a seat at the Starbucks window (although it will be hard) after you are done watching it 10 times and still amazed you can wander around the Shibuya area!

Big and that's it. The Shibuya crossing is known for their large pedestrian intersection, and truth be told, that describes it perfectly. There are many shops around the crossing, however, with the crossing itself, other than it being packed full of people crossing, that's it. And it takes less than 1 minute to cross. However, that being said, if you are in Tokyo, I would still recommend going to the crossing because it is very renown and there are a lot of nice shops and restaurants around the area.

On your marks, get set, go...in Shibuya.... Any video/picture of Tokyo includes this Pedestrian crosswalk which is more like a Lemmings scene where thousands of pedestrians cross the street. Make sure you follow the lights as this conformist nation places a high value on NOT jay-walking. But don't stop as the crowds will push you along as you scramble to get to the other side. Why did the pedestrian cross the Shibuya crosswalk, because the light was green. Good luck and Enjoy!

Slightly impressive.. When we eventually found it we had to find the best place to view the crossing from. I soon found that there isn't a best place to view it from you just need to keep walking around until you get a clear view. Id may attend early evening as I went late lunch and it wasn't that impressive.

Biggest Pedestrian Intersection in the World- But there's more!. How to get there- Take the JR train (green line) to Shibuya and get off. Once you step out of the train station, you are at the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble.Best view- none, varies throughout the day and night.Pictures- Take a few pictures from the JR train station. If you really want, go to every intersection to get a different angle (BUT that is total over-kill)Total time involved- 5-10 minAFTER that, you can either get back to the train station and go to your destination OR better yet, check out all the department stores. Lots of high end stores and famous brand stores. My cousin wanted to check out Shibuya Crossing, but the excitement waned quite quickly and he enjoyed the shopping much much more. We went in Jan/Feb which is like Black Friday in the United States, super big discounts.

Impressive street crossing. Termed to be one of the (if not the) largest crossings in the world. Whether or not this statement is true I cannot verify but it is an impressive to see so many people at one time to cross several streets at once. Obviously no entrance fee and it is close to shibuya shopping locations and the subway.

Don't bother with Starbucks side!!!. We read reviews saying the best view was from Starbucks in one tiny window on the second floor. Firstly, its pretty much an angry/awkward stand off between tourists to get to the "magic" spot that is roughly 5 metres wide and only seats 4 people at best. All of the stools surrounding the area is cramped and overfilled with tourists waiting their turn to get a photo......right beside a "no photos allowed" sign. Secondly, whilst a panoramic photo opportunity IS provided, I found the view to be of the boring side of the intersection that had very little to offer aesthetically as far as good photography goes. Take the opportunity to go at night time and cross the intersection several times yourself. If you do feel the need to stop in the middle of the intersection to get that perfect shot, be realistic and prepared to be shoved and pushed by locals trying to get where they are going. PS The coffee at Starbucks is pretty terrible too....

Great Fun to Watch. We knew we had to experience the famous scramble whilst in Tokyo and we weren't disappointed. We used the crossing to get over to Starbucks to try to get a table overlooking the crossing. Starbucks was, as expected, very busy (we were told the busiest in Japan which is easy to understand given its prime location) but we managed to time it just right to grab a window space as someone else was leaving, to enjoy our coffees and the view. Unfortunately we visited outside the rush hours but the scene was still fun to witness. Even with smaller crowds it's amazing how people don't bump into each other, it must be even more impressive during rush hours!

If you have young children, hold them tight.. We did the Shibuya strolls with a 10-year old daughter. Although it was quite exciting to be in that famous crossroads, it is a parent's worst nightmare. I don't think my daughter enjoyed it and more than any other busy street in the world.
Easier than it looks. We used this crossing many times while in Shibuya, it looks a bit chaotic from above but we found it very efficient and easy like most things in Japan.

Just like in Movie. Just as you imagined. It never sleeps. The best spot to take photo is starbucks in tsutaya. Pack of tourists already took all spot so I decided to not take any photo from there.
When I was there, few film shoots have been sighted. Tourists taking pictures here are quite common, even in the middle of crossing.

Great Short Movies/Clips. Hachiko is right there, and so is Shibuya 109, so what's the reason not to stop by? Shibuya has a great nightlife, so make sure to pop in then to see the lights. Tokyu Food Show is also amazing (with Pariya; the best gelato in Tokyo) and Seibu has the best + cheapest bento (they go for 300 yen after 7pm).

We came, crossed it, watched it and done it!. Yes, we done it and we also went up to the Starbucks to take a few shoots at the Shibuya scramble. Prior to this, I did not realize Shibuya is such a massive shopping and food heaven that is spread across the 2-3KM radius around the pedestrian scramble. It has something to offer to almost every age group, every fashion and shopping preference. Quite an eye opener! For serious shoppers, may be better to research before shopping here as it is so large that not every shopping mall or shopping zone is relevant to one. It will be better to plan ahead which mails or zones to shop in and have a route plan. Simply roaming around can end up to be quite unproductive.

An experience . Worth a look if you are in the area.Cross the road a few times from different directions and experience true Japanese ordered chaos!Then grab a coffee from the second floor of the Starbucks overlooking the crossing and grab a few photos or just watch the magic.

That is a lot of people. Its impressive! You gotta see it with your eyes and walk through it with the people wave.Please experience all the zone, if you want to have a technologic time, there are several places with a lot of videogames, simulators, pinballs.

Just what I expected. It was busy but apparently it gets busier than that. Just being in that atmosphere and being there was incredible. Everyone is off rushing off to either go home or meet friends and family and there's me amazed and shocked taking pics and videos of the whole thing.

Worth a stop. I went on a Sunday morning around 10am. - most shops don't open until 11 so it was relatively "sane". The best view I found was on the overpass from the train station, although there was nowhere to sit.
Organised kaos. One of the must visit attractions in Tokyo! Plenty of photo opportunities as well. Take the Hachiko exit from Shibuya station.

Wow!. You've never seen so many people! Get a view over the crossing and see for yourself, don't miss, it's a real experience! We sat in loccitaine and watched the crossing with some cake and coffee and it's so organised and safe. I loved watching the hustle and bustle here. Tokyo is busy, but nothing like shibuya!

Real Tokyo experience! First cross, and then watch people crossing.... Near the Hachiko statue this massive pedestrian multicross will change your concept of “overcrowded”. The busiest pedestrian traffic in the world is a Tokyo experience you have to try. Waiting among the crowds for the traffic lights to turn green and then cross looking around in amazement at the flock of people, and yet you don't bump in to anyone since Japanses are so polite, well mannered and respectful. Apart from crossing the scramble you can have great views from several places:- TokYu department store's 2nd floor. - Starbucks 2nd floor, with a perfect window counter to sip a coffee while watching the crossing- L'Occitane Cafe 3rd floor.If you want to see lots of people go on a workday at peak hour, though at night with the neon lights views are just amazing.Quite esay to get there since Shibuya Station is one of Tokyo's busiest stations with plenty of connections with Tokyo and the rest of Japan. You can get there by the JR Yamanote Line, JR Saikyo Line, JR Shonan Shinjuku Line, Hanzomon Subway Line, Ginza Subway Line, Fukutoshin Subway Line, Tokyu Toyoko Line, Tokyu Den-Entoshi Line, Keio Inokashira Line and the Narita Express.

It's a bunch of cross walks..... It's not an attraction... If you get off the train at Shibuya Station (and pet Hachiko on your out) you have to cross the street here. Unless you're there in the middle of the day on a weekend it just seems like a normal street crossing with multiple walk ways. It's like a very small scale Times Square (NY) but with more people. If you're coming to Shibuya to shop or eat out you'll have to use the cross ways, but it's nothing special....

Has to be seen to be believed!. We checked out the Scramble from ground level and then from Starbucks (on the second floor) and it's an amazing event. We were there on a public holiday and even then there were masses of people. Try checking it out at peak hour on a working day and it would be an eye opener! You definitely have to get down there and be apart of the scramble as its one of Tokyo's must do events. Shibuya station is one of Tokyo's busiest so peak hour here would not be a great place to let go off your child's hand as they might get swept away!
The mad scramble!. From TokYu department store's 2nd floor the view is fantastic. Try capturing it on time lapse for a unique modern twist.

Controlled chaos. . The first time we crossed here was when we first arrived off the train with snowboard bags, suitcases and carry on bags. We used it many times after. Crossing is quite daunting and familiar to those scenes in movies where two opposing sides(in this case about 4), all charge at each other. However, it works. We didn't bump into anyone and nobody bumped in to us. Everybody shuffles along and left or right when necessary and it all repeats over and over and over all day. A good viewing spot is from the upper level o Starbucks. Thanks Lonely Planet! :)

The real Japan. I don't know why I love this place. I just think to my self when I see many people crossing, hey I'm in Japan! Haha. You can found Hachiko monument here and also unique TIC in old train.

Cool spot. Lots of people but little disruption. Thousands of people and quiet! This is the equivalent of times square in NYC. Except the people of Tokyo are so well mannered and respectful. On trains and all other public places its almost like nobody talks! Well not loud. There's not 100's of cars beeping loudly. In fact the cars are even quieter. I've been to some big Asian cities like Manilla, Bangkok, Shanghai, Beijing, Bangkok but nothing is like this. Its completely different - quiet, CLEAN, and efficient. I loved it. The famous Shibuya crossing was something I wanted to see since a kid, and it was great fun and a great experience just to see how much different Tokyo is to the rest of the world.

Well worth a visit. Have seen this on T.V. before but well worth the visit. We bought a coffee and sat is the upstairs Starbucks Café to watch the scramble. Take a video and show it to your friends.Everybody seems to do the right thing with this crossing.

It's a crossing.... but not just any crossing!. So it's the crossing that you always see in every movie about Japan. It's very well organised and the Japanese are almost better than us at queuing.... The best view is actually from the starbucks restaurant, but there is always a queue to get in there. There are also lots of fun shops around - so a great place to lose yourself for an hour or two.

Organised. It's amazing that everyone waits, then just goes. Even when a few stragglers run across after the traffic lights have changed the cars just wait. Interesting for half an hour,mother have a stroll around Shibuya.

It's a really big crosswalk.... It's fun to head to the Starbucks directly across from the crossing and watch the madness for 15 minutes. Anything more than that, you're wasting your time in Tokyo - it's a really busy crosswalk.
Well it's a crossing!. Nothing much but it's nice to see waves of people crossing over. Roam around Shibuya for shopping and food.

Crazy pedestrian crossing. Well worth the expedition to find this spot. Grabbing a coffee at Starbucks and heading upstairs to look out over the crossing is worth the price of the coffee. Starbucks can get busy, might need to bide your time till a window seat becomes available. Lots of patrons lob in to use the free wifi but hang around long after their coffees are well drained.
Everybody Dance Now. Great views from Starbucks second floor - all traffic stops and everyone walks at once. It's a giant mass of humanity
A fun experience. It was fun people watching when we were here. You'll really see throngs of people crossing. If you're brave, you will go to the center of it all to take a picture.
Crowds. Yes its true every time the lights change a huge crowd of people cross the intersections sometimes thousands cross. Right next to the railway station.

Iconic place.. I wanted to see the pedestrian scramble and for this reason i booked my hotel at this area. Everynight before i returned to my hotel, i take a Coffee at starbucks and watch the people on the pedestrian and take hundreds of photos.
Love this pedestrian!. I just love the experience! Biggest crowd crossing altogether! It was fun! Fun! Fun! Just looking people cross is already fun!

Crazy. Love crowd watching here at any time. Just wish I could remember to take my tripod and a collapsible seat. Want photos and movies from all angles and time of day. An amazing scene if you can above it for while.

Orderly Chaos. It's the biggest and busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. After crossing it ourselves from the Hachiko exit in Shibuya station,we went to Starbucks to see it with a view while having a coffee. We got some good shots from our vantage point.
Just cool to see and experience. It's not earth shattering as an experience however if your around it's pretty crazy to people watch and then of course walk the intersection
Watch the Scramble!. Always busy and great for people watching. Grab a coffee at Starbucks and sit at the window for a while. You will see some amazing fashion.
Great experience . Grab a seat at the Starbucks and enjoy the view!! Good people watching and seeing all the organised chaos. A must do when in the area.
People watching.. Fun and a must-do in tokyo. Tonnes of cafes nearby and the train station of course. Visit Tokyu food hall for amazing freshly cooked food and pastries.

Kids will love. This is one busy intersection, and if you have kids you may spend a lot of time here. My 11 year old crossed back and forth several times and we spent a good hour in the Starbucks above just watching the ebb and flow. Kids will also love the Hachiko statue, as many seem to have read this book.

Ordered scramble. I love this intersection. It is the epitome of Japanese efficient traffic management. It's great to watch the flanks of pedestrians similatrously crossing this multi faceted intersection in formation. A fabulous site.

Fun at any time of day. You will know the famous pedestrian crossing when you find it. There are no signs from either the Metro station or the JR station, which is a little closer. There are also a lot of over-road walkways which add to the confusion of the area if you don't know where you are going. You can get a good view of the intersection from the JR station walkway and the whole area is especially fantastic at night.
Fascinating!. An interesting cultural phenomena that's worth getting caught up in. Try crossing multiple times for the best experience ;D

What people?. Walked from Shinjuku, kept thinking in wrong spot at wrong time as no crowds as expected,Took advice of Starbucks but no tables ,and some locals sitting at windows with blinds down!Did have good food experience but best part was walking through yo yogi park to get there which was much better experience.
must do. experience the great Shibuya crossing. it's fun, it's interesting and don't forget to take photos. you can also stay at Starbucks and watch people crossing.

Proof of Tokyo visit. One of the must-see places in Tokyo. This certifies that you have visited Tokyo. It would be a worthwhile experience passing along the 5 pedestrian lanes during rush hours before you leave for other places.

"Life in the fast lane!!". If you happen to be in Shibuya, you will definitely cross tor see this intersection. The highlight is that all the traffic lights become red for pedestrians to cross at one time. There are diagonal zebra-crossings too. So, its worthwhile watching it once from a distance just to feel the endless footfalls of the crossing. Aptly depicted in movies as "life in a fast frenetic pace"!!!

Organized chaos. You can't miss this when you're in Shibuya. See how hundreds of people, from all walks of life, cross the intersection at the same time. The starbucks at the 2nd floor has a good view!

world's crowdest pedestrian crossing. thousands of human being cross together at the same time from eight directions but no one stuck and no one crash!! It's located about 100 metres from hachiko station, when you arrive at shibuya station, find hachiko square (it's printed on yellow board)

Over hyped pedestrian crossing. Catch the train to Shibuya station and take a walk around the area . There are some quite interesting bars and resturant's in the back streets and lots of upmarket shops on the main roads . The actual crossing at Shibuya is very busy , full of people but you cannot compare it to a place like Times Square . Try Starbucks for a view over the crossing and visit at night when the lights are on .

A sight to see. . Ok, yes it's just a crossing. It's a really big crossing. But I liked it. I don't know why, maybe because it's a tourist staple and it's been in a lot of movies but it was exciting to come and see it in person.I did as many travellers have suggested and went up to the second floor of Starbucks. It was very busy and I had to stand around and wait for a window seat but eventually I snagged one. I didn't buy anything from the Starbucks by the way because it looked pretty unsanitary downstairs, just thought I'd throw that in there. Anyway it was a great spot to sit and view the scramble and also take pictures and videos. It was pretty humorous to see the signs up in the store saying don't take photos or videos when that was what everyone was there to do. After watching the scramble from above go down there and join it, it truly is an experience. I don't know how they all avoid each other but I couldn't manage it, I was constantly bumping into people. The surrounding area was also good for shopping so I can say I would put this on my 'must go' list.

Enjoy the view of people. This is the famous scrambling crossing which always appear in movie. Go to the nearby Starbuck first floor for a better view. Basically you will see hundreds of people crossing the scrambling crossroad at one time. The crossroad is located just next to Shinjuku Station.

Best viewed at night. I had to see for myself firsthand how it's like, and I was amazed at how it turned out. It looks like utter chaos, but it's actually organized. One minute the crossing is empty of people except the occasional vehicles, and when the lights change, everyone seems to just converge in the middle.Read more here: http://jeffer.wordpress.com/2014/12/12/tokyo-japan-2014-booyah-shibuya/
Shibuya experience. It's such an experience to have while traveling in Japan! Crazy busy and super fun, memorable for sure!
Busiest place on Earth. It still amazes me every time I go. Unbelievable how many people gather to cross at the same time. Must be experienced

Great experience to cross. You've seen the pictures and your in tokyo at night you should cross this intersection with hundreds of people doing the same every few minutes. Accessible from exits 3 - 6 from shibuya metro station will bring you right to the crossing. Great lights and a number of cafés on second floors if adjacent buildings to get a different view.

Buzzy Tokyo. Shibuya Ekimae with its famous crossing is t h e place to see and be when going to Tokyo. It's the ultimate experience one can get from the Japanese kimochi, how Japan ticks.
Have a drink at Starbucks and sit down at the window counter on the 2nd floor (witin Tsutaya bookstore) and then wonder and enjoy.

Possibly the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world. I had been forewarned of this experience but nothing can beat the actual. You exit the train station, approach the junction and wait for the green light, then wow! what a scramble for a couple of minutes. Its got to be seen to be believed.

Bz & Happening & coolest pedestrian in the world. This is most popular scene if any movie took in city. Every second and minutes all people gather here to cross the junction. And you could not understand why and where the ppl come from. First time come to Shinbuya must check in here.

Visit in the evening...a big hit!. Its the famous pedestrian scramble, known from movies and Tokyo commercials and...(according to my 14 yrs old son)...its so Fast and Furious in Tokyo! Be in the crowd when they cross the street if the light turns green...thrilled. Especially at night when all the neon lights of advertising are on, its like you' re in the movie. You walk right into the shopping area and street of restaurants. I get crazy here, love this area of Tokyo. Nearby is the Hachi-ko wall, right after you exit the Shibuya station. For people who like crowd, shops and food...you need to visit this area!

Quite enjoyable. Once, twice, many three times is enough. Its a pretty crazy place to sit and just watch people walk across the street. If you sit here long enough you will see every type of person imaginable.
Once if never enough!!. Its just a really unique place to be!!. One of the best places if not the best place to people watch!!! Thousands of people crossing every hour, really cool experience!
Interesting. After some shopping, it's pretty cool to sit down at L'ocitane cafe 3rd floor, and look down at this scramble. this is something i won't be able to see in Singapore.

So cool. Wait for the traffic light to be green and then... just go! If you go there during peek hours, it will look like being in the center of a crowded square during an important event. A must-do in Tokyo.

The World's Biggest Pedestrian Crossing!. You just gonna check out this famous crossing when you are in Shibuya! All traffic will stop for pedestrian to cross from all directions! Find a good spot to enjoy this amazing crossing! The best spot is probably the starbucks (lvl 2) across the JR station where it provides the closest view of the crossing! We could sit there for hours to watch the crossing without getting bored! However, it is hard to get the window seats even during weekdays, can't imagine weekend.Don't miss this famous crossing in Shibuya!
Crossing Fun. This is so iconic you just have to do it. Set yourself up in Starbucks to get a view from above.In my opinion this is better done at night

left, right, straight.... Yes, weekend is just packed like sardine, but during the weekday and non-holiday... not too bad. It is pretty much art of crossing street. I personally enjoy this cross walk as I do not have to wait for signal to cross 2-3 times to get to where I want to go... Just a short cut across, etc. Yes, it is fun to watch people at Hachiko and cross to another area... behind buildings - food, food and food...yes, all kinds of restaurants between streets and shops, shops, shops... Fantastic place really to watch pedestrians, locals, visitors, tourists and much more... A police box... majority of inquiries - how to get where... what a peaceful city...Free and enjoyable attraction - just watching from Tokyu Department store train level (2-3 floor?)
Crowded like ants. Worth to see this crowded pedestrian crossing.It reflects Japanese sense of respect and civilization.Go to Starbucks to get a better view

Scramblee~. One of a kind pedestrian you don't encounter everyday. Hundreds of people crossing in all directions, yet you can still manage to get from point A to point B without getting bummed into the shoulder.

Where do all the people come from. Wow, this was organized chaos. Everyone moved across the intersection with ease, everyone was gone, and like a closed dam wall, the sidewalks just filled up quickly and it all happened with precision all over again. Fantastic to watch. Walked across in three different directions.
Must see. This crossing is a must see like nothing we have experienced before. People come from everywhere. Go to Starbucks and watch out of there windows for the best view
Fun to experience and see. We really enjoyed Shibuya with lots of shops and restaurants and the crossing was something else, great to see.
Have to see it!. We sat up in the Starbucks looking out over the crossing, watching the 'scramble' of the crossing. And of course, we crossed it a few times too! Must visit this area while in Tokyo.

Worth a wander. Just seeing the sheer number of people crossing here makes it worth a visit but (rather obviously) there is nothing other than watching the public going about their business. Would not recommend if massively out of your way, it is right outside the main entrance to Shibuya station.

You just have to. This as crazy as it sounds. We caught a train, travelled for 30 minutes all to see a pedestrian crossing. With all the fine architecture, culture and heritage in Japan, the purists will hate me for saying this but this is fun (and what's wrong with fun). I found it fascinating and it's the iconic Tokyo landmark. Spend some time here, watch the spectacle, video it from Starbucks and then really admit it -watching those crazy pedestrian crossings was one of the highlights of our entire Japanese holiday!!

A bit overrated. It's ok for the first timers. The area is an upmarket shopping centre, alright to just hang out. Go to the adjacent Starbucks, second floor for an elevated view. Go in the evening when lights are turned on. Hang around hiuse might bump into a celebrity, I,e if you cared.

Worth seeing when you're there. Here's the deal, you're probably going to Shibuya anyway. If you're already going to be there, cross here. Yes, it's a crush of humanity and you might want to have a meeting place predetermined in case you get separated from your traveling companions, but it's worth experiencing. Also, across from the train station is a Starbucks on the second floor. Go up there and watch at least one crossing. Yes, you've seen it in videos and pictures, but it's worth the 10 minutes to see it first-hand.

What a scramble!. We were really looking forward to this place. We took prime spot at Starbucks across the road (had to wait) and got several pics and videos. Really, one of the unique things to visit in Tokyo. After this, roam around Shibuya area for some shopping - nice, crowded, expensive -- but that's what Tokyo is

Fun!. disorderly it may seem. however, it is not as craziness as you walk into the scramble.8 ways of traffic stopping for the pedestrians. everyone walks at the same time in every possible direction you can think of go.it is chaos in the most possible orderly fashion.

A unique experience!. We went to Shibuya first and foremost to take a picture with Hachiko, the faithful dog who waited for his master) then we watched the throng of pedestrians crossing the famous Shibuya intersection. It was a a fun experience, seeing the many people crossing the streets all at the same time. Best time to visit is after sunset, with the many colorful billboards all lighted up, many people coming out of the Office. But dont forget to take a photo op at the famous crossing, try it, it was fun! Shibuya is also a great place to shop!

What You See is What You Get. It's a huge intersection where people cross the street. It wasn't busy when I went there, but I could tell how crowded it could get. I was able to get a decent picture with myself in it--pretty much all there is to it.

Experience the mass of human movements. You simply have to see the intersection in front of Shibuya station's Hachiko exit.Seeing large mass of people crossing the road when the cars weight,against the illumination of the buildings is a majestic sight.The place has magic.And do not forget to take photograph in front of Hachiko(the faithfully dog for the uninitiated).Shibyua 109 with a number of boutiques is best visited to see beautiful Japanese girls dressed in latest fashion.
fun, once. It's exhilarating to bump elbows with everyone if you are not used to the big crowds, but honestly I live nearby and it's a heck of a lot more fun to cross the street when NO ONE is there!

Interesting spectacle. Outside the Shibuya JR station (H? exit) 7 roads come into 1 and when the lights change pedestrians from all angles walk - there are masses of people going in every direction. Many people viewing/photographing from Starbucks across street

A classic landmark. The light turns, and masses of humanity move across, mixing in self-organizating patterns. Best viewed from above. There's a hotel in the Mark City towers I stayed in once, and some of the rooms have views of this from above. A testimony to the teeming efficiency of humanity.
I crossed the street!. Like everyone else says - if you come here you have to do it.. No, literally, you have to cross the street if you want to explore the city.Pretty awesome! Do it!
It is just chaotic. Well only in Japan could a chaotic intersection be seen as cool. And anyone and everyone can participate in this chaos. What fun, not! it is worth a look, and night time is best.

Street Crossing for the Fun of It. How many places list a street crossing as an attraction. Once you see this intersection, you will understand why this is a must see and do in Tokyo. I tried it 5 times from different sides just to experience the crowds and the views.

Must See @ Night. Frankly I'm shocked that this pedestrian crossing ranks so highly on this list of places to see in Tokyo.Yes, it's an experience: watching thousands on commuters make their way to their destination of choice in a swift slew of people walking in several directions. But it's also just life in a densely populated city. If you want to see the real Tokyo - that is the gritty, fascinating shadow that falls when Tokyoites take their ties off and let their hair down - go here at 3 in the morning after a night partying at one of Shibuya's numerous bars, nightclubs or karaoke joints. Venture outside in the crisp night air, encountering many fellow revellers in your wake, and take a seat outside the station right beside the crossing. Not only will you make friends with chatty, inebriated Japanese revellers but you'll also bear witness to the piles of trash that accumulate during all that ridiculous people traffic. You also might encounter the various animals that call Shibuya crossing their night time home. It's an experience that rivals Shibuya crossing at it's busiest and, in my opinion, excels it.

Organised chaos. You have to cross it a few times.1st time - walk across, experience the world's most exciting crossing.2nd time - repeat 1, you'll want to do it again.3rd time - run across after a few biru on a Saturday night.Go up to the above ground tunnel connecting Shibuya station to the hotel for a better view than Starbucks. Plus, you'll get to see all the lights in the background instead of Shibuya station (what you get if you go up Starbucks).

synchronised pedestrian crossing. 5 roads converging at an intersection. All lights turn red simultaneously for all road traffic. All u see is a sudden convergence of a huge mass of human beings across all roads crossing horizontally , vertically and diagonally.

A must see and do!. Went to Shibuya in the late afternoon just as the sun was setting. Get out of Shibuya station from Gate 8 (Hachiko exit) to be right in the thick of things. Cross the scramble there and head to the Starbucks and go to the 2nd level to get a good view of what you just experienced.
Organized Chaos in the Intersection. It was amazing to see that many people cross an intersection at one time. Like a mad scramble but in an orderly fashion.
Best Photos . Nothing beats the photos you can get here whilst in Tokyo. It can be a bit less impressive during the middle of the day but come late afternoon you won't be disappointed!

Interesting. The pedestrian scramble is pretty interesting. 5 roads all lead to one intersection and everybody goes everywhere. Go to the 2nd level Starbucks, grab a drink, and relaxing to watch for a bit.

Pure craziness!. Many cities have diagonal pedestrian crossings at major intersections, but this one beats them all! The lights turn green and the scramble becomes a sea of people. It was even more fun in the rain, dodging hundreds of umbrellas!

Most famous crossing!. You can't miss this cross when visiting Tokyo city. When lights turn green an organized crowd walks in five ways making you feel like a little ant, specially if you see it from the JR train station walkway or the 2nd floor of the Starbucks.

Organised chaos!!. If visiting Shibuya the pedestrian scramble is a must. It is a metaphor for Japan, chaos and craziness but all in an organised way.Trying to get to the crossing can be quite difficult as Shibuya Metro station is extremely large.There are a huge number of exits in the station and the maps aren't always straight forward to point out where the crossing is.The exit can you need to look for is the Hachiko exit (Hachi = eight) so exit eight which will bring you right to the crossing. This will also be shown by the famous bronze dog statue right outside the exit.One of the best times to head to the crossing would be around 5pm due to how busy it is and toward the evening the lights on and around the buildings start to come on.Its also best to try and find the suitable place higher up in a building to get a good shot of the crossing. I would recommend the Starbucks, get the Matcha green tea Frappuccino and sit on the second floor near the window.The surrounding area has your usual restaurants, cafes and normal fashion stores, so nothing too exciting but it is a great place to relax in for an hour or two. Also a little note, near the exit there is also a green bus sort of monument out there, where they sometimes have people performing, or when I went there were girls handing out free hugs ;)Always a bonus!A must visit when in Tokyo!!!

Interesting. The whole place is very interesting. I have never seen such a pedestrian crossing before. There are a lot of people going everywhere but there is no chaos. Anyway I loved Japan as a country and this could be just an interesting detail.

It can only happen in Japan. The Shibuya scramble outside Shibuya station has to be experienced to be believed. Just stand there and watch the lights go red, and pedestrian lights go green and you'll see this mass movement of people that's a thrill to watch. But don't just watch it. Get in there and experience the scramble for yourself!

Don't miss this unique spot. Everyone is talking about; yes, but there is a reason. It is only in Tokyo that an ordinary pedestrian crossing becomes a unique spot to see and experience (especially if you have a chance to go to a higher floor in one of the nearby buildings and watch the traffic cycle from above)We crossed it a few times, day and night (as our hotel was in Shibuya). It is definitely one of the more memorable places in Japan.Recommended (especially, even if you don't enjoy it, there are many other things to do in Shibuya anyway, so what do you have to loose?)

This is Tokyo Japan!. A visit to Tokyo and not crossing Shibuya is totally an incomplete Japanese experience. This is a must thing to do in the city. A good place to shop and buy clothes, also a perfect stop to dine and just enjoy Japanese shopping malls.

Fast And Furious. This is a must see as its the most crowded crossing in the world, Go around 5pm and its at the busiest I would say, saying that its busy all the time generally. If you a film buff also this is the famous scene in Tokyo Drift when han drifts his RX7 threw the crowds. Best place to view the crossing is upstairs in starbuck as they have window seating

so crowded. Well, This is the most crowded crossway in the world, when you cross, don't stop ! just keep going until you finish crossing the street. you must visit this crossway to experience something different and also experiencing to be Japanese once :p

Controlled chaos. Shibuya Crossing is a large multi-corner intersection in front of Shibuya Station, one of the largest and busiest commuter railway stations in Tokyo. When the light changes, everyone crosses at once, straight across, on a diagonal, or whatever way they need to go to get to their destination. Some are going to work, some are headed home, some are just going about their day, but everyone moves across in a sort of controlled chaos. Even though it is just a bunch of people crossing an intersection, it is a LOT of people crossing all at once. To get the best view, go to one of the coffee shops or restaurants that are on the second or third floor of the buildings on the corner (Starbucks is a good option) and watch the unchoreographed but graceful ballet taking place below; then go to one of the corners and make a crazy crossing of your own. It doesn't matter where you go; just get in the crowd and feel the energy carry you along. It's fun!

Must see. Skip this and you're really missing the essence of Tokyo. As Tokyo is not really a tourist town the reason for visiting is to see the people, how they live, and how they go about their days. This is surely one of the places for it.We checked it out on a weekday afternoon. With aching feet we grabbed seats on a wall surrounding a planter and just watched for an hour or so. Conclusions? Japanese teen girls and young women love to dress up. Japanese salary men all wear the same black suit. Sensible/comfortable shoes are non-existent. Japanese people don't generally eat in public or on the run. Japanese drivers don't use their horns. And jaywalking is just not done (even when possible).

Expression of the unrestrained Japan. While the Japanese people are usually very restrained, when they relieve the burden they are fun, and sometimes crazy. The Shibuya junction expressed this very nicely, when all of the sudden you get into this huge mass of lights, billboards and striding masses. Fun to see!
A big crossway, nothing more. There are plenty of huge crossways in Tokyo. Nothing special about this one, even though it is the biggest one. It's still just a crossway.
Crazy intersection. Worth going to see. So many people crossing all at the same time and we weren't even there at the busy time so can just imagine what it would be like at its busiest.

Eh, it was ok. Maybe it was the time of day we went - it was a weekday and we went a bit before 10am and then again at 2:30 or so. It was mildly interesting but not as crazy as I was expecting. Maybe rush hour would be more impressive. Worth a look, but I was expecting more

Best show in town. OK sure, go see Hachiko, the little dog statue, and walk the 7-way crosswalk with the crowd a time or two. But then go upstairs in one of the buildings opposite the train station, find a bar with a view looking down onto that mass of humanity. It's like watching those computer simulations of airplanes crossing the Pacific, or ocean currents, or a swimming school of fish. Humans are really sort of amazing animals when in a herd..... Fun.

A must see. The craziest, busiest and biggest crossing in the whole world. Thousand of people crossing at the same time. It looks like a giant wave of people but it seems impossible but it's very organized. Shibuya crossing consists of two big avenues and five crosswalks. It is a must see.

Awesome. Yes, its just a crosswalk... but it's THE crosswalk. Located in Tokyo's shopping district this crosswalk has tbousands of people crossing it at any given time which leads to the big rule one of The shibuya pedestrian scramble: DO NOT STOP WALKING, under any circimstance. You will be trampled to death of you stop.

Don't miss it. Have your camera ready, this is amazing, a video is even more fun. People cross straight and diagonal in big streams.... Impressive. You can have a coffee at Occitane or Starbucks and observe this phenomenon from above....
Mega Crossing. Amazing sight. No crossing in the world can beat this . All red lights come on at the same time . Crazy sight . Every few minutes . The crazy scene happen all over again and again

Fun experience. The first time I crossed the Shibuya Pedestrian was in 2007, I was with 4 other people and it was very difficult to be next to each other while crossing. And recently in 2014, I crossed this pedestrian again by myself and it was much easier. I try to avoid it as much as I can but I like going to Shibuya 109. However, seeing the crossing from above is also a cool sight to see.

Interesting place to see. I wouldn't make the trip here just to see the scramble, but if you are getting off at the Shibuya station, you should plot your route out of the station to see the grand crossing.

Looking is better than experiencing. Walking across was a quite underwhelming experience. From that angle it's just a busy crossing. However looking upon it from Shibuya station or one of the buildings around give a great sight. Especially when it rains with all the umbrellas out.

Brilliant!. I had seen photos and videos of this but never thought that I'd get to see it in real life. Great touristy thing to do, and many locals enjoy it too. For the best view before/after participating go to Starbucks 2nd floor, they have signs up to say "No photography" but no one seemed to mind that me and many others were taking photos. Try it late on a Saturday when fellow crossers are feeling very "mellow" - good craic!

Fun. Who knew crossing the road would be so fun! I drag my husband and daughter looking for this crossing and it was worth it! For great photo op go to Starbucks and go on to the second floor and take photos!

Amazing sight!. Crossing here is a squashed rabble, but even more interesting is to view it from above, Grab a coffee and (you will probably have to wait a while) a seat at the second floor window of the Starbucks on the corner opposite the station. The crowd looks like they will surely crash into each other, but every few minutes they weave neatly into the opposing rush - it's a very cool sight.
Mind Dazzle. Everybody in Japan is here! Everybody in Japan is crossing the street now. If you are in Japan now, you may also cross the street with EVERYBODY in Japan.
Crazy Crossing. It's unbelievable around this crossing. We decided to crossing several times just for fun and it was. This crossing is worth the trip to Shibuya.

The busiest in the world!. Just do it! The starbucks in the corner offers a great view of this but you'll have to buy a drink or they will kick you out. People watching at this crossing is very entertaining.

That Famous Intersection. This intersection has been in several movies - video - photo shoot. Its just crowded, crazy. People comes from 4 different direction. quiet hard to snap a pic while lots of people crossing this section. Go to Starbucks to enjoy the "view" and relax while drinking a coffee - get a table near the window so you can see clearly.
Waves of people.... I love this place... Go to Starbucks in Tsutaya to people watch during rush hour. Cross a few times to experience it yourself. Don't miss Hachiko statue in front of the station.

Astonishing!!!!. We absolutely love this part of Shibuya! I lived in NYC for a while and this put to shame some of the Times Square area crossings. This place is crawling with people coming from every each way and that you either just sit there and people watch or take part of it, this is going to be one of the most unusual and craziest experience you'll ever have in your life. This is an absolute must do/must see while in Tokyo!

Love this intersection!. One of my fave things to do is get a table at the L'Occitane Cafe (on 2nd and 3rd floor of L'Occitane Store) and watch the people cross. One of my most memorable moments is when this happens in rain, the sea of umbrellas moving across is special to me.

Millions of people but everyone crosses safely.. The Shibuya crossing is crazy with what seems like thousands of people crossing in every direction at the one time when the light turns green. There s no chaos, no one bumps in to each other. Just plain order and courtesy to others that typifies the Japanese people. Grab a cup of coffee from that coffee shop ( you know the one when you see the place) and watch from a high vantage point this ordered chaos of humanity. Brilliant.

Not as many people as in the movies. Went to starbucks and sat watching the people crossing. They will be coming from all directions and it is really nice to watch. The number of people crossing is probably 300-400 not really like movie fast and furious. It is was Sunday night and I am satisified by the number of people crossing especially when both side intersect. if you are looking for the maximum number of people, you may try other weekday.

Great fun, completely mad!. Join the world famous scramble. Be careful of all the other tourists trying to take videos!A great experience to see the craziness of the Shibuya area, but a little overwhelming if you're not able to take crowds. Some of the back streets around the crossing have lots of interesting, quaint shops and restaurants so get away from the masses and explore.

Just like movies. If you can reach the top of a building you can see the famous crossing at shibuya like in the movies. Be sure to visit it at night, afternoon use to be crowed too but the view is better at night.

Shibuya cross junction - world busiest intersection?. was here in the afternoon and found it so so, a bit disappointed with the comment as no wow affect, maybe night time with the lighting on might be better... but if you wish to have a nice angle of this cross, can try the starbucks at the junction... the cross is so so, but we bump into the Mikoshi parade at Shibuya, very happening and at least something special for us to see, but Tsukiji market is close because of so I guess, ishhh....

Something to experience!. Crossing at Shibuya is quite the experience. It is really interesting to witness so many people with different destinations systematically crossing the same place on the planet. There are cross walks going in all directions and when the walk light turns green the race is on. It is definitely organized chaos in that there is a lot of potential for collision. The large number of fashion minded people, the billboards, the lights and interesting buildings make for a nice backdrop for this spectacle. Would recommend a stop in Shibuya!

Xing. One of the more"alive" places in Tokyo. They say that this intersection is the busiest in the world. It may even be, I have no idea if this is true but this intersection is a tangle of streets and people walking coordinately, obeying traffic lights. Go at dusk, grab a coffee at Starbucks, which is at a 2nd floor and has a panoramic view of the intersection, and then, when the neon lights are on, you can see the contrast between the colors of the day and night. When the traffic light allow pedestrians to cross, cross it and feel like another anonymous human in the crowd ...

Crowded Cross Junction ~. The famous cross junction in the world is here in Japan. Day time looks busy and crowded, perhaps night time looks is amazing. Everyone here just cross and walk. Best view is probably the SB overseeing the whole cross junction but well, the SB is always full of people seated at there.
Amazing. Just grab a window seat and starbucks and watch the crossings. Never failed to impress. Simply amazing! Must see.

Love it!. I love how this crossing is like... Everyone just walk. Saves a lot of time. For tourist, it is such a sight and so interesting to see so many people crossing in all directions all at the same time. The best view is probably from the Starbucks overseeing the Crossing.

Cross the road, again and again.... Exactly in correspondence with the Shibuya train station and the famous statue from the movie Hakiko, this special attraction I personally consider it among the top attractions of the city, this recall seeing it on TV and in various documentaries hundreds of times and the curiosity that prompted me to visit it was high. It was just like on TV !! Hundreds of people all still waiting for the signal from 4 opposite sides of the road, when the crossing signal is triggered you see literally a flood of people crossing the road and avoid themselves almost by a miracle, it was a weird experience the feeling to cross the road, again and again! I've done it many times and it was really fun. At night with all those lights ... This is one of the most iconic places in Tokyo and throughout Japan as well.

"Lost in Translation" Shows It Best. In all honesty I went here on accident. I had plans to meet with some friends and since I didn't know Tokyo well at all I had no idea where I was at that time. I walked through this intersection a few times before even realizing that it was the "famous intersection in Japan". I would recommend this area for anyone who really wants to do some shopping / clubbing / or go to expensive restaurants. But...frankly speaking I felt that I was in more awe and amazement of the intersection after seeing it in the movie "Lost in Translation".

Another beautiful place of this amazing city.. In my humble opinion I think it's worth it to go to Tokyo just to visit this amazing place, both day and night is an extraordinary sight all those lights and all those people, all kinds of shops, cafes and restaurants everywhere, many people people . In short, you can not come to visit Tokyo and Shibuya.

People watching. sit somewhere around the Hachiko statue next to the crossing and just watch the enormous flow of people, waiting to cross, or find a coffeeshop or restaurant overlooking the crossing, in some of the department stores, now you can really see how crowded Tokyo is.

Crazy junction . I'm surprised where the people go and where they come . The green light for people to cross over the road is just around 11 second . The people are never stop so the place are so so crowned . If u want to take the picture or video of this view u can go to the Starbucks or l'occitance to have cup or drinks and enjoy it . But there are always full .

Rush Rush. it's a place where you can see everybody! its so crowded, so busy, the place that never sleeps! But everything is there, you don't need to worry to get hungry or feel lonely....its alive 24/7

Fascinating!. Enjoyed my time so much here, just people watching is a nice engagement.The area is so vibrant with the younger generation & the merchandise & stores reflect this.Was great to visit the Hachiko statue for some respectful & nostalgic experience.Great place in Tokyo!

Definitely worth doing. It only takes 5 minutes to say you've crossed the street at the same time as 1000 other people, so make sure to put it on your list. Also check out the busiest starbucks in the world right next to this crossing, it's a lot of fun to sit in there and watch the crowd.

What an experience!. I have encountered pedestrian crossings in many cities in the world. The one at Shibuya must be the busiest so far. From my analysis, many among the pedestrians were there just for the experience and there were some who were there to take good shots. While we were there we did the crossing several times. The experience was great!

I could've sat watching for hours!. Find yourself a window seat in Starbucks and take in the view! That's what we did. I know there are better sights to see in Tokyo but hey, this was just fun! When we were there, we watched a group of people dressed in the Japan football strip posing for photos and they crossed over and over again. This was just before the World Cup so I guess it was some sort of promotional thing. An iconic sight - do not miss!

You Have To.... What can I say about a crosswalk - it is one of the most iconic pedestrian crossings in the world with millions of people rushing across it at all hours of the day.It is a must, simply to be able to say that you have done it.Lots of good shopping and great transport links in the area make it a practical as well.
Rare way of pedestrian crossing. It is amazing to see one BIG crowd crossing the roads from all directions where all vehicles have to stop to give ways to the pedestrian.

Great view of people crossi g and city view. Yeah, maybe it just a intersection and ordinary place to cross. But, it will be fantastic if you cross this intersection, took place in such movies this spot become so famous nowadays. And I was one of people who has accross there.The interesting part when you queue with hundreds of people, waiting the traffic light turn to green then *Alakazammm......
