All vehicles stop then all the people crossing the intersection. If you want to take picture, You have to be fast before the traffic light turn into red again

Worth Visiting. I went here at night and it was amazing how many people continuously cross this street. The area reminded me of Times Square, with all of the lights and the crowds of people. It's certainly something you should see when visiting Tokyo.
Fun it see if you are in the area. I am not sure I would go to a lot of trouble to see this, but if you are in the area it is worth a look.

Fun!. It is easy to scramble and see the dog statue at the same time. We stopped off in Starbucks to get a 2nd story view. It is a nice place to sit and watch people cross over and over again. We went at about 10:30 AM and it wasn't very crowded, but was fun because it is such a famous location. Great time.

A must see!!. We first came to Shibuya crossing first thing in the morning around 8 am. There was no one here!! We decided we should come back later on during the day and saw the crowds at that time. Impressed at how calm and quiet the crossings are. A must see for all visitors to Tokyo.

Where do all the people come from?!. This crossing is soooo iconic of Tokyo! You can't miss it! The Starbucks nearby is a nice place to get a view of the crossing - just be sure to buy a drink. The whole area is pretty cool to explore, shop and eat. Make a night outta it!

Five directions flowing . This iconic location is worth the time. Walk the intersection (all 5 crossings) just to say you did! Then head up the the second floor Starbucks (gotta buy a refreshment!) and sit in the window to watch the cross walk ballet from above! Classic Tokyo event. Don't miss it!

Truly a crazy site!. You cannot travel this city without crossing the main intersection and it's crazy fun. There are diagonal crossings. Emergency vehicles warn you with a loud speaker that they are coming and thank you when they leave!

Amazing!. For a tourist in Tokyo this is a definitive must! It is just as wild and amazing as you imagine, but at the same time you experience that you are not lost and it is perfectly possible to cross the street.... The surrounding area is also very interesting so take your time and enjoy.

Unlike any other crossing.. This is the famous crossing that you see in all the movies and on TV. Thousands of people walking in different directions, it's crazy! If you want to see it from above, go to the second floor of the Starbucks or upstairs in the train station.
What a humongous intersection.. Love that Hetchiko's statue is right next to Shibuya crossing. It is amazing how all these people can just cross such huge intersection with ease and harmoniously.
People watching. People watching at it's best. This place is a great spot for that. One of the largest cross walks in Japan, I have never seen so many people crossing the street at once.

fanatstic Toyko area.... This area of Tokyo is famous and deservedly so. It is a great place to visit and wonder and look at the area and people. The style of the area is a fabulous contrast to England. I would recommend a visit to any one and would go back if I find myself in Tokyo in the future. All the people are very nice and the cafes in the area are nice.

Mini migrations. This was great to watch and I stood mesmerized for about 10 minutes just taking photos before joining in the mad scramble to cross the road. There is a Starbucks with a view over the road which is good to get a higher perspective. Worth a visit if you have the time.
"busiest crossing in the world". you have to experience the sea of people crossing the streets at a same moment.obviously Shibuya is more than that to offer besides this.

Tokyo's Times Square. You really don't get a handle of how busy the streets fronting Shibuya Station are until you look down from one of the nearby buildings. We crossed the street from the Station to Starbucks and went to 2nd floor to take panoramic photos. It blew me away to see how many people cross the street in front of the Station. Where did all these people come from? Shibuya is a "happening" place to be!

A sea of humanity crossing at once.. This was an interesting visit. The only place we saw some of the homeless near the station. The crossing was interesting to watch as tourists and locals crossed the road when the lights changed. The electronic bill boards were huge. A very tourist orientated area. Suprisingly, English not well spoken in many restaraunts. Most food venues seem to be on the upper floors of the nearby buildings.

True Tokyo. A must if you go to Tokyo. Lots of bright lights and fun in the area. You can get a coffee, do a bit of shopping or sample the local flavour. I suggest you find a first floor seat near the window at the Starbucks and take it all in!

Organized Chaos. Well worth a visit. Interesting to watch. Plus, the neon. A;sp, interesting and nice areas around the crossing. Recommend to rest and watch on second floor of Starbucks. Good view of crossing while you drink caffeine.

True Tokyo!. I didn't feel I had been to Tokyo properly until I visited this stop! Very hard to negotiate with a buggy (people don't tend to give way), but fun to try if you're in the area. There are some nice department stores nearby- we went to Tokyou and were pleased with the prices and the gift/ stationery department.

Iconic crossing.. Of course you have to go the scramble crossing when visiting Tokyo. Before you go to the crossing you should go for a birds eye view of the crossing which you can get from the second floor of the train station or Starbucks. It's not as crazy as it looks and is very ordered,

Unbelievable. The scramble crossing is always crowded. You can wait for it at night and take a photo. It is really nice and like NYC.It could be very difficult to navigate if you don't have a map with you. My suggestion is to look at the map at the crossing and with a compass, you should be safe.

Quite amazing !. If in Shibuya it is worth spending 15-20 minutes watching the 5 way pedestrian crossing when all cars are stopped and pedestrians cross in any direction.I can only imagine how crowded this would be at peak hour. It was busy enough around lunch when I was there.I wouldn't travel out to Shibuya just to see this crossing but if you are visiting Shibuya it is worth having a look (right outside Shibuya Station).For the best view go to Starbucks on the second floor in the Tsutaya building on the crossing's north side. Grab a drink and a window seat to watch the chaos!

Orderly Chaos. Having seen the Shibuya pedestrian crossing in movies, it is exciting to be in ground zero. If you're not used to seeing so many people, you may find the crossing overwhelming. In fact I have friends who are actually afraid to cross the scramble. But just go with the flow, and you'll be just fine.Tokyo is crowded, and Shibuya being one of the "hip" place to be, is even more so. But Japan is a very disciplined nation, so even if the flood of people coming from all directions seems chaotic, I have always felt safe.
Times Square in Tokyo. If you're in Tokyo and don't mind lots of bodies scrambling to cross an intersection, this is a must experience. Nothing exciting, just something to experience.
you have to see it but.... ...I didn't find anything else worth visiting in downtown Shibuya. Go to Harajuku! Or sit in Starbucks and watch

Reality not as exciting as the image. I'm sure you've built up an image of this crossing too, Busiest intersection in Tokyo, must be incredible right? Meh, lots of people walking across when pedestrian lights go green. For a nice view go for the 2nd floor on Starbucks, otherwise just do the walk or hang around to shoot a picture or a movie. We've been here ten days and must have crossed here 30-40 times, also in peak hour. And well yeah, that's all there is to it. I would have awarded it an average, but it feels too little, it's still something and for smaller kids I'm sure its great.

So Unique to Tokyo. Yes, it's just a mob of people crossing in eight directions but that's not the point. The point is it's really fun to watch and take part in because it's so unique. Shibuya is probably the most exciting part of Tokyo and the crossing here only emphasizes that. A must see attraction!

Best part of Tokyo!. I think I walked the scramble a minimum of once a day on my two-week trip. It was my favorite part of Tokyo. It made me feel like I was in a high-speed frogger game. Always wondering if a pedestrian might run me over. It is an incredible organized, polite chaos. I especially loved it at night. The best part is it is free. Amazingly I did not lose my children. It really was fascinating to me. It almost felt choreographed but really the most elaborate improvisation I have ever scene. It takes great cooperation for that many people to scramble without bumping into one another. I could participate and watch it every day. At night you cross to the square by Hachiko and see all kinds of artists, politicians and nuts. I guess it reminded me a bit of downtown Chicago or Manhattan yet so much more artistic. I was mesmerized and look forward to a return trip so I can once again watch and participate.

So true to the movie scene from "Lost in Translation".. Much more exciting than I expected; my fellow travelers talked about it a lot and I thought "big deal". But when you get there and cross the path few times it makes all worth it. Go to the Starbucks across the street (dont forget to buy a Starbucks card as gifts) and get a window seat upstairs, sip your drink and watch people crossing. Much more fun if one of you gets into the crowd and waves at you to take a memorable picture. Dont forget to walk around and eat at some of the small restuarant for perfectly cooked Ramen noodles (if you are barve enough to read and believe the Japanese menu, pictures and sign-language).

Visit often and see changes / constants. Pretty much every movie set in Tokyo will show this crazy intersection with people crossing the street diagonally. Rain of shine, day or night, it is a hustle and bustle. So far I only witnessed one quiet morning: new years morning at 6 AM, even the screens are getting some rest. Perfect place for people watching.

It's just many people crossing the road... in an organised chaos (oxymoron intended). I couldn't fully appreciate it because I come from a country which is already congested almost everywhere. To me, large crowds are a pain, because i try to avoid them all the time. If you come from a country with a lower population density, the Shibuya Crossing will be an eye-opener. Different strokes for different folks, i guess. If you observe close enough, occasionally, there will be tourists dashing into the center of the crossing as the green man comes on, to take selfies etc. Funny to some, annoying to others.

From Above and Below. There are many references to go to Starbucks to view the crossing, but we found perfect views on the opposite side from the rail building - without crowds or having to interrupt someone trying to enjoy their frappe! Afterwards, went down to street level to try the crossing ourselves. We stopped to take pictures of Hachiko, the statue of the loyal dog before heading back to the rail for our next stop on our fast paced journey.

Just a busy road, but in a prime location. This is basically just crossing the street, or watching others cross the street, and therefore isn't really that exciting. However Shibuya is a busy location with plenty of shops and restaurants, and therefore is a great area to visit.

Busy intersection in the world!. A trip to Shibuya Crossing was fascinating. Head to the star bucks on the corner or any one of the several cafes and grab a coffee and watch the people scramble across the intersection before the light goes red.

Organized Chaos !. Just don't know how to or what to say about this attraction, but go sit in the Starbucks on the corner, order a coffee ; And enjoy the people view. I thought of ants, Very unique attraction.

A lot of people walking in all directions. It looks almost like a choreographed walk of the masses. People walk along the perimeter, straight in the road... Wasn't impressed with this. It's really a whole mass of people moving at the same time because all the traffic lights at the junction have turned red. This concept happens everywhere. I think this particular crossing is famous only because it's in Japan, has a pretty impressive backdrop, and spots to view the masses moving.

Just a fun thing to do and see!. After reading all the reviews we decided we had to see this place and it was worth the trip. It is just fun crossing the street with all the people, and it is fun to watch from the street and from the raised walkway. We found most of the shops around too pricey for our budget so the crossing was the highlight.

TSUNAMI. It has to be experienced, It is a sea of bodies coming from every direction, anywhere else it may be frightening , but the Japanese people are very polite and courteous and therefore make it a must do/see .

Living installation art. I never understood the point of watching a bunch of people crossing a road. However it did have a sort of hypnotic effect that some modern video installation art on a loop. What was really interesting was watching a large number of tourists taking videos of the people crossing.

Madness in peak hour!. If you want the best photo, go up to the Starbucks in the multi levelled Record store on the opposite side of the crossing. I went on a rainy day and the photos with the mass of people with umbrellas was brilliant :)

Worth seeing in the rain. Shibuya crossing is amazing so many people all patiently waiting for the little green man to turn green and then a very civilised walk across in all directions. The first time we saw it every single person on Saturday afternoon had an umbrella, absolutely amazing!!
You need to see this at rush hour to really appreciate it.. Wow what an insane amount of people crossing the street all at the same time. We saw it at the low point and the high point....crazy.

The world's crossroads: Shibuya !. I've been writing about Tokyo and I find that dividing it up into sectors or districts is, probably, the only way! Well, after reviewing Asakusa, Shinjuku and Roppongi, here's the megalopolis's crossroads and where you feel the density of the capital. The amount of people in the streets (all organized, mind you) during rush hour, is an attraction in itself. It can me a a dazing experience to try walking on those sidewalks during any time of day (or night) but - a nice alternative - is to go to a second floor ice cream parlor and view the maze from above.I'm beginning to understand that Tokyo (unlike so many other cities) need lengthy reviews and of each individual quarter. Shibuya is one of the most fun.EnjoyLOVEGerald Thomas

Never seen so many people!. Like a little race crossing with the Japanese residents! If you go upto one of the buildings in Shibuya, be sure to watch the people crossing from the window. It's literally like watching ants!

It's like watching hundreds of little ants. Grab a drink at the Starbucks and watch hundreds (if not thousands) of people converge, making their way across the street.We were there on a weekday afternoon and it was quite crowded. I imagine that if you went on a weekend or in the evening, it would probably be even more spectacular.
Definitely worth witnessing. It doesn't look like there are many people around and then the pedestrian lights turn green and the street floods with people. It's definitely a sight to see.
Must visit at Shibuya. It's look like an ants moving, look from overpass Shibuya Mark city. Shibuya's main pedestrian crossing ranks as one of the busiest on Earth. Then joint crossing with them.

Funny, it looked bigger on TV:). Of course, I just HAD to join the crowds in the Shibuya Scramble Crossing. Feeling: It's a Mad Dash!!! These people had somewhere to go Fast and knew exactly where they were going. I didn't, but I didn't care:) It was just so much fun being in the middle of all that madness!

Don't leave Tokyo without going to Shibuya!. I was kind of skeptical of this because how cool can an intersection really be? It was pretty neat though! Plus, Shibuya is a must-see area. Definitely what you would expect Tokyo to be like. Tons of shopping, restaurants, and lights and music everywhere.

Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble - The World On Its Feet!. Iconic buildings and structures have always been a great attraction to travelers around the world due to their uniqueness and most often they are associated with extravagant cost to build. Some may involved untold sacrifices and miseries over a long period of time and even deatht. It is from this perspective that the Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble, in Tokyo Japan is unique and probably so in the world as this iconic attraction is built by just using a couple of liters of white paint and a few meters of tarmac. Yet it has attracted millions of visitors around the world to Shibuya to witness and at the same to experience and be part of Shibuya scramble history.This iconic venue was not built to attract tourists, neither was their intention, as it was the desire to provide a smooth sailing pedestrian walk from all points and directions. What makes it more interesting is that all the scramble zebra crossings traffic light will turn green all at the same time giving a remarkable impression of movements of human beings which is sheer amazing to look at, giving a circular movements of people in opposite and in all directions. It is a great feeling standing near the Hatchinko Monument [a well known story about a loyal dog and its master professor who died, turned into a Hollywood movie acted by Richard Gere] and just spending time looking at those people crossing.The best time to watch will be during the rush hour in the morning where people are scrambling to cross to go to work and vice-versa in the evening when they return home. At night, it is more stunning as it is illuminated by neon lights all round just like Piccadally Circus in London or the Time Square in New York. The irony is that you may be taking pictures of people crossing but at the same time you yourself may be in the picture taken by someone else. For bird's eye view get to overhead bridge connected to Tokyu departmental store which will give a vintage point to observe. The Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble is surrounded by shopping, restaurants, cafes and everything else you could think of and easily accessible by public transportation.If you are in Tokyo and you have not experience the Shibuya pedestrian scramble, then your visit to Japan is not considered complete. So why not try it out yourself when you are are in Tokyo the next time around - after all it is free and you can repeat the crossings as many time as you wish and be part of that scramble history. Arigato.Saharudin Muhamad TohaElderly CoupleVisiting May 2014Report: 30/05/2014

The most famous, the most frenetic, the most chaotic and energetic. One of the most famous areas in the world. From TV and Film. A sprawling ensemble of people meet traffic meet lights show. The dizzying spectacle never fails to amaze and impress me every time in visit. Mostly this is due to the ballet of the traffic and pedestrians, millions of which who use this crossing every day of the year. The Times Square of the east. A genuine focal point to every visit to Tokyo. The pulsing energy of this area feels like being at the epicentre of the world. From the multitude of crossings, the glare of the digital TV commercials played out day and night and provide the soundtrack to this magical part of the world. Sky high billboards and music, which add to the living movie set which has featured in too many films to mention. This coupled with the nearby tourist office, Hachiko statue, department and boutique stores and restaurants contribute to make this a wonderful eye show.Any visit to Tokyo is incomplete without swinging by the heart and soul of Shibuya.
Must do it once. You have to go. First just look at it from above from the metro station. Then you HAVE TO GO DO IT!!! You will never see such a thing in your life!

Cross the road and have some fun. It's hard to sit down and classify a pedestrian crossing as a "must see" attraction, but this really is. Please check out Hachikō statue near the station while you are there. I have read various reviews, with some stating that the crossing is not that impressive on ground level and the view is better from above (e.g. Starbucks window side), but do yourself a favour and check out both as they are special in their own way. Cross the road and have some fun.

Amazing!. This is something that was recommended to us by a friend who spent time in Japan as a "Don't Miss". We agree! It's just fascinating to arrive at this square and watch the masses of humanity thrusting in all directions to get where they need to go.....I've never seen anything like it! It's completely entertaining......Happened to be a rainy day for us, so all the umbrellas were "accents" to the number of persons swimming in a sea of commuters. My recommendation is to work it into your itinerary if you can. It's such a unique experience! I believe it's one of the biggest train stations, has one of the highest volume of foot traffic in the world (though you might correct me on this one!). We loved it!

Has to be done. You cant leave Tokyo without crossing one of the world's most photographed junctions. Night time is the best when all the TV screens and neon shine in their full 21st century futuristic glory. You will see quite a few people with tripods and cameras set up around the place to capture the mayhem. It is brilliant to watch. There is a brilliant viewing area close to Shibuya station in a shopping mall, it has a bit of mesh over the window though. Don't miss Hachiko statue while you are down in the square. He's held very dearly in Japanese culture as the dog who kept waiting for his owner at the station even after he'd passed away.
Very Confusing. This intersection has many crosswalks and one really needs to know where you are going in order to get to the right place. Better to watch it from higher floor of nearby hotels.

Loving it! :D. You know what they said, you have not been in Tokyo if you did not try their infamous Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble.And I must say they aint kidding!! Around noon its still fine..but wait till the sun goes down and all of Tokyo seem to come out of each corner of the roads. And once the light goes green, its GO time.. Everyone just crossing the road without even looking left or right as if they know are all pre programmed where to walk to. Amazing experience nonetheless.Simple tip, please do not turn your back when everyone else is walking, you might obstruct those that are in a rush :)
"Shibuya crossing view". This is the one of the best photo spots in Shibuya. Enjoy the panorama of huge scramble crossing in front of Shibuya Station.

Excellent feel!!!. Its the busiest crossing in the world! And WHY? Coz all roads leading to the crossing have the red traffic light on at the same time! The feeling is wonderful! Crossing from the Shibuya station towards Starbucks, you can observe loads of people coming to the window to click the crowd...and well, you're in the picture too! :) :)A must-do!!
Absolute mayhem! Amazing. Everyone walks in whatever direction they want, diagonally, straight, left or right. Lots of massive tv screens to look at too while crossing, do not miss.

Crosswalk with many people.... I have seen videos online that look really cool of this, but unless you are high up it looks like any ordinary crosswalk with a lot of people. Maybe it's just that I have been in Asia for so long, but this really was not interesting from the street or from Starbucks.

This is Tokyo at it's most crowded and something you should do. We found our visit to Shibuya a little overwhelming at first but it really was am amazing experience to see so many people on the move. We visited firstly during the day and then again at night with a friend for dinner. At night it really is spectacular with all the giant billboards lit up it reminded me of my visit to Times Square in New York. It is also great for people watching as young people in Japan really love fashion and it's on full display here during the day.

Where do the people come from??. Great to watch, the endless stream of people that builds up in between crossings is fascinating. Being in the middle of the people crossing is actually quite fun, there is heaps of time to cross and everyone gets to where they want to be with a minimum amount of fuss.

OVERWHELMING ENERGY!. Shibuya's heart is absolutely breathtaking! This is exactly the "cliché" of Tokyo and I love it! A HUMONGOUS amount of gigantic skyscrapers, dozens and dozens of people walking and running around!This place is overwhelming, bubbly and amazing! So much life, energy, excitement! If you love huge megalopolis and such kind of madness, this place is a must see!
Its a zebra crossing!. Well, if you go there expecting a super-douper-busy zebra crossing, you won't be disappointed!We did, and it was excellent! So, that's 60 seconds of your day, what next?

Huge all sides go at once crossing. Its an amazing view to see those people crossing all at same & those screen huge buildings makes it look even more huge.
Great experience.

An amazing sight to behold. As seen in so many movies and television shows, Shibuya crossing which can be located near Shibuya JR station and Hachiko Statue, has about five different crossings merged into one crossing, and great to see how so many humans manuver they’re way around to get across the other side. The best advantage spot to film this is the Starbucks restaurant up one floor which gives a good panoramic shot

Any direction crossing. Its just so fun to people watch in this place. So many hip and fashionable people crossing with indefinite age range. I crossed about twice or thrice and its so fun to take pictures while crossing. Its very impressive too that with this volume of people and cars crossing. Theres no accident. Japan is really disciplined
crazy. crazy zone , a lot of people , is very rare like a lot of people move and walk togheter ....very huge zone
So many people crossing the road!. What a spectacular view. So many people crossing the roads and they moved so efficiently without hitting others.

Like little ants... It's worth just watching the mechanics of the Crossing. No one bumps into each other, cars rarely use their homes and like little ants going to and fro it just all seems to work. Grab a window seat at Starbucks and people watch on whats going on below.
Exactly like in the movies.. You will be surprised the amount of people there. Crossing the zebra lines. Quite amazing. Haha. Worth to go have a look

crossing with lots of people. i'm so excited to finally be in the shibuya crossing. because i saw it on the movie or tv before. but afterall it's just a crossing with lotsssss of people. it's a new experience though.

Large Intersection. A prominent landmark of Shibuya is the large intersection (Shibuya Crossing) or Japanese only called it Crossing. It is one of the busiest pedestrian crossings in the world and surrounded with department stores and fashion boutiques.TIME magazine had infact listed Shibuya Crossing the '10 Things to Do in Tokyo'.Look for a peaceful and relaxing place to view the crossing, The surrounding hotels and department stores make a good view point but some prohibit photography. I went up to Shibuya Tsutaya Building (Starbucks), order a drink and get a seat by the window. It was a fun experince to cross the busy intersections but please dont stop halfway for a snap like some tourists, it really disturbence and no respect to the padestrian user. Besides, the famous cross, it is a good place for shopping too.
So many people. You have to see this at least once. I've never seen so many people crossing. I did try to find and empty seat at Starbucks to see it from above. But no luck.
Disappointing. Not really as impressive as we expected. Perhaps we expected too much but there are equally as busy multi crossings in other places.

The craziest and busiest crosswalks. It is situated in one of Tokyos most famous areas at all, both among the Japanese themselves and among tourists, namely Shibuya, located in the middle of the city, and the station is one of Tokyo's traffic junctions. In Shibuya crossing one will find tipping neon lights and big screens with commercials and music videos from the Towers as well as hundreds of busy Japanese, from business men to students in their school uniforms and trendy youth with wild hairstyle, urgent in the crosswalk when the light turns green. Watching people crossing a multi-way junction in thousands, in complete order - amazing. Just like seen in the movies. In front of the station is a small statue of a dog (Hachiko statue) which is the city's most famous venue. The story of the loyal dog Hachi, a dog day after day faithfully waiting for his master in front of the station even after his death.. This story was filmed in Japan in the 80s, and in 2009 it came in a Hollywood version with Richard Gere in the lead role as a dog owner.

Classic Japanese on the Move. I never thought of this as something to witness or to experience. It's always about getting out from Shibuya station and to get to where you are going. It is not as overwhelming as people say I guess unless you didn't know where you were going.There is now a HUGE looking Starbucks across the street in which you can sit upstairs and watch through the glass window this crossing.~although awkward to enter into. AND it's just a sliver of a space.I like that its so civilized to shut all the lights and let the people on feet, the masses all get going after having used the other form of public transportation, the train.

Don't worry, its not that overwhelming!. I love watching when the pedestrian light turns green and everyone rushes across this intersection on a Saturday night. Watch from the Starbucks across from the train station for good people watching.
A sight to see!. Organized, but so full of people it's mind-boggling, this is a must-see when in Japan. Go up to the Starbucks (2nd Floor) to get a great great view.

Not too bad. I been here on weekends, weekdays and its not as bad as I remember it. Its gotten to be less and less people or something. Then again, I was walking through one night before the last train and it was hillarious watching everyone run down the hill at full sprint trying to make the trains. its like a comedy show. I've found wallets walking through this intersection, nailed people who werent paying attention and seen some interesting things. One of those things to do if you are in the area.

Go during the night. Went here twice, during the day and night. I must say, it was at night that I really felt the Tokyo-ness of it. It was such a crazy pedestrian scramble. Afterwards, I did some people watching /sketching at Starbucks (near the scramble). It was a bit difficult to get a seat facing the scramble, so good luck for that. Otherwise, it was definitely worth a visit.
A must. It's in like every Tokyo movie. You have to check it out. Once at day time, once at night. Photo ops are hard to get, any hotel with a view is very costly.

Crossing the Famous. When people say "it's never like it is in the movie" about anything from now on I will refuse to believe them until I see it for myself. It amazed me that whilst the little man was red people slowly started to build up but it never seemed like that many and than BOOM the man turns green and out of nowhere well over a hundred people appear.It's more busier at night but during the day people watching is more exciting. The Japanese are quiet talented as they are able to walk across the intersection without running in to anyone all the while looking down at their phone.A must see if you are in Tokyo if you are on a budget trip (or not).

Depends on the time of day. At night this crossing is crazy busy and such a cool place to be. Earlier in the day the crossing is only a little busy. So strange that crossing a road makes you feel as if you're apart of something bigger but this place somehow manages that. Can be a little intimidating the first time. Especially when playing dodge with the bicycles. Try to get a window on the second floor of Starbucks to really watch it all go down.

Amazingly chaotic. When we were in Toyko there was no way i was leaving without seeing the famous crossing. All i can say is it lived up to expectations! We sat up in Starbucks for a while (got in trouble for taking photos) but I could honestly have sat there for hours watching it. We also crossed it a few times just to experience it! The amount of people crossing when the light goes green is just amazing! This is definitely a must see!

Symbol of shibuya. The pedestrian crossing is easy to find when you come out of SHibuya station -you can't really miss it. The best vantage points are from above like from the railway station or the starbucks. You can also take photos with the statue of Hachiko.
Worth it. A must see check in the block..take the time. There is a wealth of things to do and see around it as.well. grab a starbucks and observe the madness!!

Worth a trip. We stopped at Shibuya for dinner, specifically to experience the Shibuya Crossing. When we were there, it was a Saturday night. It was really crowded everywhere. We had to see it, of course. It was amazing how orderly the Japanese were in the midst of the chaos. At the crossing, I really felt the pulse of Tokyo. I did not really enjoy the experience, I felt kind of stressed with all the people around me but hey, we were there for the experience! By the way, it was so crowded, we could not find a suitable dining place - in the end, we took a train to another vicinity for dinner, lol!

A classic of Tokyo. The Shibuya pedestrian crossing, so famous, is really worth your time if you can spare some, but do not see it as a must to grab the taste of Tokyo and Japan. The crossing is chaotic, yes, but do not expect thousands of persons fighting to get across. It is crowded but not at all times. The most typical place to spend time looking at it is from the second floor of the Starbucks, though normally seating is not easily available there. There are other attractions in the surroundings, mainly restaurants and shops. My recommendation is to start walking from Harajuku down to Shibuya to enjoy all the area of these two well known modern neighbourhoods of Tokyo. And do not forget to pay your visit to the statue of the dog Hachiko close to the metro exits.
Mad.. Worth the flight to Japan. You have to see this. All-way pedestrian crossings, people crossing a multi-way junction in their thousands, in complete order… amazing.

View from our room makes them look like ants. We stayed at Shibuya Excel Tokyo hotel on the 23rd floor (24th being the highest room floor and 25th being the dining floor). We were at the corner room so we could see the crossing clearly.We viewed this during the morning, day, evening and night, during the week day and the weekend. It is interesting to see how empty it is and then how busy it gets. We observed it during the daylight as well as with the night lights. We saw how the crowd thickens and thins. The people looked like tiny ants literally scrambling especially making the dash before the lights change to red.

Crazy cool. I'm assuming this is referring to the crossing/intersection. Crazy. It's like a concert or professional sports event just got out and there's 20,000 people crossing the street.....except it's like this at every light change.

Tokyo fun. Having seen it in plenty of movies, we had to stop by the scramble crossing. We went at the end of the day so saw it in daylight and at night (great photo ops). We got some photos from up in the Starbucks (be quick) but there was nowhere to sit so continued upstairs to Tsutaya, where there was plenty of books and music to check out.Definitely couldn't mistake we were in Japan :)

Fun Experience. Yep, it's one of the craziest and busiest crosswalks in the world. You've probably seen it a million times in movies and on TV. But there's nothing like actually DOING it and being in the middle of the madness. Try it once or twice, and then escape to the Starbucks across the street, buy a coffee, and scoop up a second-story window seat to watch the goodness from above.

A real scramble!. This is an experience and quite amazing to cross on one of the main crossings with a throng of people coming towards you.The best place to see the crossing is from the Starbucks, although they will try to stop you from taking photographs (apparently the police prohibit this, although you are allowed to take photographs from other surrounding buildings).The crossing is fun to watch day or night; however, it does look transformed at night with all the bright lights.Worth a visit.

Beats TIMES Square anytime. My all time favorite spot in Tokyo. I love to sit at Star Bucks, & get lost in the wave of (mostly Japanese) humanity, & then everything comes to a stand stillEverytime - I'm there - it dawns "this is Japan"Its madness & silence both.Fantastic spot, I like it better than Times Square anytimeNo hype - only fun!!

You have to see it and live it. Everyone talks about the Shibuya crossing but you have to go there and experience it for yourself. Go at night when the Shibuya lights are on full display. It's a chaotic but fun experience...

How fun!!!. Watching the crossing is fun but being in the crossing and going with the flow is even more fun! One night we watched a stilt walker as he went back and forth, he maneuvered the crossing with such ease...WOW is all I could say!! There's a Starbucks right at the crossing with a second floor, kind of cool to grab a coffee and watch the crossing from above.

Mesmerizing. New York pedestrian traffic has nothing on this intersection. Watch from the ground and then go to the second floor of the Starbucks, grab a coffee and watch from above. Good cheap fun in a rather expensive city!And if you need a proper loo (not a squat toilet!) you can find one on the 3rd floor of above Starbucks.

Mayhem. On the weekend there are thousands crossing at a time all going in different directions and whilst it is quite a sight none of the Japanese show any sort of courtesy so you have to dodge & weave your way across.

Worth stopping by for a photo!. Ok, so it's just a crossing at the end of the day but it's still well worth stopping by for a photo. I've personally never seen so many people crossing at one time. You'll see it at some point if you're visiting Shibuya so tick it off the list!!
A busy intersection.... Wouldn't recommend going out of your way to view, really just a busy intersection....unless you consider that fascinating

A real picture of the overcrowded and busy Tokyo. It is said that is probably the most crowded crossing in the world. Maybe it's truth, because it is quite crowded. Everybody will advise visiting that crossing.My daughter has a Japanese friend who advised us trying to crossing with our eyes closed. Actually is it possible and it has some thrills in doing so.However, it's not that much than that...a real picture of the overcrowded and busy Tokyo.
Over rated. Except for the chaos and neon lights, nothing much. Too many peddlers and overall, you do not feel safe in the streets of Shibuya.

Must see!. go around 5ish when everyone is on their way home from work, sit in the 2nd floor windows at the Starbucks across from the station and just watch! went twice, once during the rain. loved seeing all the colorful umbrellas! fun to walk across a few times, in a few different directions!

Pick your visiting time wisely. Shibuya crossing is a MUST when visiting Tokyo, just make sure to chose the right time to view the best action here. Noon on weekdays results in average crossings. The evening rush-hour crowds are a little more thrilling to see, but the best, and most crowded, time to view Shibuya is Saturday evening, when not only is half the city is crossing the street, the other half is waiting at Shibuya station to meet people. It's fantastic. Also, a little-known viewing spot, other than the infamous second-storey Starbucks, is in the 2nd floor pedestrian hallway, crossing from Tokyu Plaza(behind Hachiko) towards Mark City. And you don't have to buy an over-priced latte to watch, either.

Stop, Look, Listen!. Arriving at Shibuya station (a place to rival Shinjuku) head over to the Hachikō Exit, here you will see the statue of the dog Hachikō (look up his story) and spanning out in front of him, the famous scramble crossing. With the traffic flowing and the throng of people on the street it looks like any other busy Tokyo thoroughfare, but as the green man shows, so the magic begins. Up to 3000 people cross in multiple directions at any time, repeated every couple of minutes. And as is the Japanese way, it's so ordered. I'd recommend going just after sun set to catch the splendour of the neon jungle surrounding the crossing, the Starbucks coffee shop has a great view and is worth wandering through to experience, however, it is very busy and space is limited. I found a nice street level corner to deposit myself (out of the way of the locals and tourists) to sit and watch the ebb and flow of this tide of people.

This is the new face of Tokyo. A trip to Tokyo without seeing this crossing, and, well, crossing it, is like missing out on seeing the Eiffel Tower in Paris. It captures a snapshot of Tokyo everytime the lights turn green green and a huge swathe of humanity walks by.

Go at night. This is definitely worth dropping by if you're in Tokyo. It's very much like Piccadilly Circus in London but feels even bigger and more crowded. Going at night was particularly good as the surrounding shops and arcades were all lit up and it was busy with Japanese people on their way back from work or meeting friends. The traffic lights all stop so that all the pedestrians can cross at once and it's very manic but a lot of fun.It's also featured in a number of films so it's very cool to look out for it.
Only in Tokyo!. It is so amusing to watch the famous Shibuya scramble. Such organized chaos. Starbucks by the intersection has a great view.

MY FAVORITE PLACE IN THE WORLD. I love this place. I can stand out here for hours and enjoy all of the lights, the sounds, the crowds. People watching is a great activity here. It's always fun to take pictures in the middle of the scramble! Make sure you come at night to see all of the beautiful lights. If you can come on a Friday or Saturday night you will see it at its peak.A must see if you are in Tokyo!!!! You can try and take pictures from Starbucks' 2nd floor but a lot of times the staff tells you not to take pictures. (I normally buy a coffee and sneak in a few pictures!)Caution:Avoid this area on New Year's Countdown, it is the only time I have felt unsafe in Japan. There were drunk people pushing and it was too crowded. (I have never seen behavior like this in Japan until that night!)

Times Square Tripled. This place reminds me so much of Times Square...only multiplied by maybe 2 or 3. I love walking around and looking at all of the store signs and chaos! Everything is jammed packed! You have to keep up with the pace and don't get offended if someone bumps into you and don't worry if you bump into someone...........it is crowded!!
Just a very busy intersection. You may want to go there around 5-7 pm. You will see the difference with the neon lights off and on. Go to starbucks for a birds eye view.

just another crowded place. like in all huge metropolis in Asia like Shanghai, Beijing, Hong Kong...you will find similar views but this one is somewhat special because despite the many people, yo'll never bump against other people thanks to the good behaviour of the Japanese. China can learn a lot from them

Scramble, yes, but orderly. I was crossing one of the signals, so obviously I couldn't see the scramble - it all looked very orderly to me, initially I didn't even realise the significance. But just mid-way, I and my hubby looked at each other and almost screamed - it was THE Shibuya scramble! Iconic, ha ha. Like another reviewer has said below, try to view it from an upper level.
Madness. Not as big as shinuya crossing but madness none the less. Fun to watch and take a few pics. Great shopping around too.

Right outside our hotel, called Excel. You can watch from the lobby restaurant or any of the elevator lobbies if you're staying at the Excel hotel. It is like a million ants crossing the street in Times Square, NY. Too funny.
Mad!. This crossing is insane. Orderly and functionable but definitely insane. Make sure you video it from Starbucks first floor. Fun!

They have shut down the iconic Q-front video screen!. The crossing experience used to be one of the more memorable on my visits to Tokyo, especially at night. The blazing neon signs, the giant video screens and of course the sea of people swarming in all directions once the traffic comes to a halt. But the true centerpiece of the experience has always been the fantastic imagery displayed across the entire facade of the Q-front (Tsutaya) building, made famous by the 'walking dinosaur' scene in the movie Lost in Translation. Unfortunately it appears that this screen has been shut down, if not removed entirely. They are now displaying simple static billboard advertising in its place. This is a shame and it takes away so much from the experience, it was truly an assault to the senses.

Not amazing but surely interesting.... There are many reasons to visit Shibuya center town. The famous crossing, the hachiko statue, the shopping experience and many more. Definitely worth the visit but personally didn't spend more than an afternoon to combine all the above.The crossing is interesting as there are so many people crossing the streets simultaneously but still it's just a crossing ;-). The hachiko statue is a highlight for someone who knows the story and the shopping experience left a bitter taste as everything were awfully expensive and shops were incredibly crowded. The obvious place to make a timelapse video or capture the crossing is Starbucks on the 1st floor just across the exit of the station. The secret place though is the 19th floor of the Shibuya Excel Hotel.
